File: /Users/rkrsn/vcs/se4sci/data-collection/scratchpad/sources/abinit/abimkdocs/variables_abinit.py

1     # coding: utf-8
2     from __future__ import print_function, division, unicode_literals, absolute_import
3     
4     executable = "abinit"
5     
6     from abimkdocs.variables import ValueWithUnit, MultipleValue, Range, ValueWithConditions
7     
8     Variable=dict
9     variables = [
10     Variable(
11         abivarname="accuracy",
12         varset="basic",
13         vartype="integer",
14         topics=['Planewaves_basic', 'SCFControl_basic'],
15         dimensions="scalar",
16         defaultval=0,
17         mnemonics="ACCURACY",
18         text="""
19     Allows to tune the accuracy of a calculation by setting automatically the
20     variables according to the following table:
21     
22     accuracy         | 1         | 2          | 3            | 4            | 5         | 6
23     ---              |---        |---         |---           |---           |---        |---
24     [[ecut]]         | E_min     | E_med      | E_med        | E_max        | E_max     | E_max
25     [[pawecutdg]]    | ecut      | ecut       | 1.2 * ecut   | 1.5 * ecut   | 2 * ecut  | 2 * ecut
26     [[fband]]        | 0.5       | 0.5        | 0.5          | 0.5          | 0.75      | 0.75
27     [[boxcutmin]]    | 1.5       | 1.8        | 1.8          | 2.0          | 2.0       | 2.0
28     [[bxctmindg]]    | 1.5       | 1.8        | 1.8          | 2.0          | 2.0       | 2.0
29     [[pawxcdev]]     | 1         | 1          | 1            | 1            | 2         | 2
30     [[pawmixdg]]     | 0         | 0          | 0            | 0            | 1         | 1
31     [[pawovlp]]      | 10        | 7          | 7            | 5            | 5         | 5
32     [[pawnhatxc]]    | 0         | 1          | 1            | 1            | 1         | 1
33     [[tolvrs]]       | 1.0d-3    | 1.0d-5     | 1.0d-7       | 1.0d-9       | 1.0d-10   | 1.0d-12
34     [[tolmxf]]       | 1.0d-3    | 5.0d-4     | 1.0d-4       | 5.0d-5       | 1.0d-6    | 1.0d-6
35     [[optforces]]    | 1         | 1          | 2            | 2            | 2         | 2
36     [[timopt]]       | 0         | 0          | 1            | 1            | 1         | 1
37     [[npulayit]]     | 4         | 7          | 7            | 7            | 15        | 15
38     [[nstep]]        | 30        | 30         | 30           | 30           | 50        | 50
39     [[prteig]]       | 0         | 0          | 1            | 1            | 1         | 1
40     [[prtden]]       | 0         | 0          | 1            | 1            | 1         | 1
41     
42     
43     [[accuracy]] = 4 corresponds to the default tuning of ABINIT. It is already a very accurate tuning.
44     For a parallel calculation, [[timopt]] is enforced to be 0.
45     E_min, E_med and E_max may be read from the pseudopotential file (available
46     only for XML PAW atomic data files). If E_min, E_med and E_max are not given
47     in the pseudopotential file, [[ecut]] must be given in the input file and E_max=E_med=E_max=ecut.
48     If the user wants to modify one of the input variable automatically tuned by [[accuracy]],
49     they must put it in the input file. The other input variables automatically tuned
50     by [[accuracy]] will not be affected.
51     [[accuracy]] = 0 means that this input variable is deactivated.
52     """,
53     ),
54     
55     Variable(
56         abivarname="acell",
57         varset="basic",
58         vartype="real",
59         topics=['UnitCell_basic'],
60         dimensions=[3],
61         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=3, value=1),
62         mnemonics="CELL lattice vector scaling",
63         characteristics=['[[EVOLVING]]', '[[LENGTH]]'],
64         commentdims="represented internally as acell(3,[[nimage]])",
65         text="""
66     Gives the length scales by which dimensionless primitive translations (in
67     [[rprim]]) are to be multiplied. By default, given in Bohr atomic units (1
68     Bohr=0.5291772108 Angstroms), although Angstrom can be specified, if
69     preferred, since [[acell]] has the '[[LENGTH]]' characteristics. See further
70     description of [[acell]] related to the [[rprim]] input variable, the
71     [[scalecart]] input variable, and the associated internal [[rprimd]] input
72     variable.
73     
74     Note that [[acell]] is NOT the length of the conventional orthogonal basis
75     vectors, but the scaling factors of the primitive vectors. Use [[scalecart]]
76     to scale the cartesian coordinates.
77     """,
78     ),
79     
80     Variable(
81         abivarname="adpimd",
82         varset="rlx",
83         vartype="integer",
84         topics=['PIMD_expert'],
85         dimensions="scalar",
86         defaultval=0,
87         mnemonics="ADiabatic Path-Integral Molecular Dynamics",
88         requires="[[imgmov]] == 9 or [[imgmov]] == 13",
89         text="""
90     Controls whether adiabatic Path-Integral Molecular Dynamics is performed or not.
91     The corresponding adiabaticity parameter is given by [[adpimd_gamma]].
92     
93     If equal to 0, no adiabatic Path-Integral Molecular Dynamics (standard PIMD) is performed.
94     If equal to 1, adiabatic Path-Integral Molecular Dynamics is activated.
95     Only relevant with [[pitransform]] = 1 (normal mode transformation). In that case,
96     - the mass associated with the zero-frequency mode is the true mass [[amu]],
97     - the mass associated to the other higher frequency modes of the polymer
98     chains is equal to the normal mode mass divided by [[adpimd_gamma]] (adiabaticity parameter),
99     - the equation of motion on the zero-frequency mode is not thermostated.
100     NOT YET USABLE
101     """,
102     ),
103     
104     Variable(
105         abivarname="adpimd_gamma",
106         varset="rlx",
107         vartype="real",
108         topics=['PIMD_expert'],
109         dimensions="scalar",
110         defaultval=1,
111         mnemonics="ADiabatic Path-Integral Molecular Dynamics: GAMMA factor",
112         requires="[[adpimd]] == 1 and [[imgmov]] in [9,13]",
113         text="""
114     Adiabaticity parameter to be used in adiabatic Path-Integral Molecular Dynamics.
115     NOT YET USABLE
116     """,
117     ),
118     
119     Variable(
120         abivarname="algalch",
121         varset="gstate",
122         vartype="integer",
123         topics=['AtomTypes_expert'],
124         dimensions=['[[ntypalch]]'],
125         defaultval=MultipleValue(number='[[ntypalch]]', value=1),
126         mnemonics="ALGorithm for generating ALCHemical pseudopotentials",
127         text="""
128     Used for the generation of alchemical pseudopotentials, that is, when
129     [[ntypalch]] is non-zero.
130     
131     Give the algorithm to be used to generate the [[ntypalch]] alchemical
132     potentials from the different [[npspalch]] pseudopotentials dedicated to this use.
133     
134     Presently, [[algalch]] can only have the value 1, that is:
135     
136       * the local potentials are mixed, thanks to the [[mixalch]] mixing coefficients
137       * the form factors of the non-local projectors are all preserved,
138         and all considered to generate the alchemical potential
139       * the scalar coefficients of the non-local projectors are multiplied by the
140         proportion of the corresponding type of atom that is present in [[mixalch]]
141       * the characteristic radius for the core charge is a linear combination of the characteristic radii
142         of the core charges, build with the [[mixalch]] mixing coefficients
143       * the core charge function $f(r/r_c)$ is a linear combination of the core charge functions,
144         build with the [[mixalch]] mixing coefficients
145     
146     Later, other algorithms for the mixing might be included.
147     
148     !!! important
149     
150         Note that alchemical mixing cannot be used with PAW.
151     """,
152     ),
153     
154     Variable(
155         abivarname="amu",
156         varset="rlx",
157         vartype="real",
158         topics=['PIMD_useful', 'Phonons_useful', 'AtomTypes_basic', 'Artificial_basic'],
159         dimensions=['[[ntypat]]'],
160         mnemonics="Atomic Mass Units",
161         characteristics=['[[EVOLVING]]'],
162         commentdefault="provided by a database of atomic masses.",
163         text="""
164     Gives the masses in atomic mass units for each kind of atom in the input cell. These
165     masses are used in performing molecular dynamical atomic motion if
166     [[ionmov]] = 1, 6, 7 or 8. They are also used in phonon calculations during the
167     diagonalization of the dynamical matrix. Note that one may set all masses to 1
168     for certain cases in which merely structural relaxation is desired and not
169     actual molecular dynamics.
170     
171     Using the recommended values of [[cite:Martin1987]], 1 atomic mass unit = 1.6605402e-27 kg. In this
172     unit the mass of Carbon 12 is exactly 12.
173     
174     A database of atomic masses is provided which provides the default values. Note that the
175     default database uses mixed isotope masses (for Carbon the natural occurrence
176     of Carbon 13 is taken into account). The values are those recommended by the
177     commission on Atomic Weights and Isotopic Abundances, Inorganic Chemistry
178     Division, IUPAC [[cite:Martin1987]]. For Tc, Pm, Po to
179     Ac, Pa and beyond U, none of the isotopes have a half-life greater than 3.0d10
180     years, and the values provided in the database do not come from that source.
181     
182     For alchemical pseudoatoms, the masses of the constituents atoms are mixed,
183     according to the alchemical mixing coefficients [[mixalch]]
184     
185     In most cases, the use of [[amu]] will be as a static (non-evolving) variable.
186     However, the possibility to have different values of [[amu]] for different
187     images has been coded. A population of cells with different atomic
188     characteristics can thus be considered, and can be made to evolve, e.g. with a
189     genetic algorithm (not coded in v7.0.0 though).
190     """,
191     ),
192     
193     Variable(
194         abivarname="angdeg",
195         varset="basic",
196         vartype="real",
197         topics=['UnitCell_useful'],
198         dimensions=[3],
199         mnemonics="ANGles in DEGrees",
200         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
201         commentdefault="deduced from '[[rprim]]'",
202         text="""
203     Gives the angles between directions of primitive vectors of the unit cell (in
204     degrees), as an alternative to the input array [[rprim]]. Will be used to set
205     up [[rprim]], that, together with the array [[acell]], will be used to define
206     the primitive vectors.
207     
208       * [[angdeg]](1) is the angle between the 2nd and 3rd vectors,
209       * [[angdeg]](2) is the angle between the 1st and 3rd vectors,
210       * [[angdeg]](3) is the angle between the 1st and 2nd vectors,
211     
212     If the three angles are equal within 1.0d-12 (except if they are exactly 90
213     degrees), the three primitive vectors are chosen so that the trigonal symmetry
214     that exchange them is along the z cartesian axis:
215     
216         R1=( a, 0,c)
217         R2=(-a/2, sqrt(3)/2*a,c)
218         R3=(-a/2,-sqrt(3)/2*a,c)
219     
220     where a  2  +c  2  =1.0d0
221     If the angles are not all equal (or if they are all 90 degrees), one will have
222     the following generic form:
223     
224       * R1=(1,0,0)
225       * R2=(a,b,0)
226       * R3=(c,d,e)
227     
228     where each of the vectors is normalized, and form the desired angles with the others.
229     """,
230     ),
231     
232     Variable(
233         abivarname="asr",
234         varset="eph",
235         vartype="integer",
236         topics=['DFPT_useful'],
237         dimensions="scalar",
238         defaultval=1,
239         mnemonics="Acoustic Sum Rule",
240         text="""
241     Govern the imposition of the Acoustic Sum Rule (ASR) in phonon calculations.
242     Same meaning as the corresponding anaddb variable.
243     """,
244     ),
245     
246     Variable(
247         abivarname="atvshift",
248         varset="ffield",
249         vartype="real",
250         topics=['DFT+U_expert'],
251         dimensions=['[[natvshift]]', '[[nsppol]]', '[[natom]]'],
252         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=None, value=0.0),
253         mnemonics="ATomic potential (V) energy SHIFTs",
254         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
255         requires="[[usepawu]] /= 0 and [[natvshift]] in [5,7]",
256         text="""
257     Defines for each atom and each spin channel (at present, can only be used with
258     [[nsppol]] = 1 or 2, like the +U scheme), a possible potential shift, for the d
259     (with [[lpawu]] = 2, [[natvshift]] = 5), or f states (with [[lpawu]] = 3,
260     [[natvshift]] = 7). In the case of d states, and 2 spin channels, a set of 10
261     numbers for each atom must be defined. The first set of 5 numbers corresponds
262     to real spherical harmonics m=-2 to m=+2 for the spin-up channel, the second
263     set of 5 numbers corresponds to real spherical harmonics m=-2 to m=+2 for the
264     spin-down channel. In the case of f states, the same ordering applies, for
265     sets of 7 numbers, corresponding to m=-3 to m=+3.
266     
267     !!! important
268     
269         [[usepawu]] should be non-zero, [[lpawu]] should be 2 or 3.
270     """,
271     ),
272     
273     Variable(
274         abivarname="autoparal",
275         varset="paral",
276         vartype="integer",
277         topics=['parallelism_basic'],
278         dimensions="scalar",
279         defaultval=0,
280         mnemonics="AUTOmatisation of the PARALlelism",
281         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
282         text="""
283     This input variable is used only when running ABINIT in parallel and for Ground-State calculations.
284     It controls the automatic determination of parameters related to parallel work
285     distribution (if not imposed in input file). Given a total number of
286     processors, ABINIT can find a suitable distribution that fill (when possible)
287     all the different levels of parallelization. ABINIT can also determine optimal
288     parameters for the use of parallel Linear Algebra routines (using Scalapack or Cuda, at present).
289     The different values for [[autoparal]] are:
290     
291       * 0 --> The [[autoparal]] feature is deactivated. For ground-state and response function calculations,
292         ABINIT can only activate automatically the parallelism over spins and k-points.
293     
294       * 1 --> The number of processors per parallelization level is determined by mean of a simple
295         (but relatively efficient) heuristic method. A scaling factor is attributed to each level and an simple
296         speedup factor is computed. The selected parameters are those giving the best speedup factor.
297         Possibly concerned parameters: [[npimage]], [[npkpt]], [[npspinor]], [[npfft]], [[npband]], [[bandpp]].
298     
299       * 2 --> The number of processors per parallelization level is first determined by mean of a simple
300         (but relatively efficient) heuristic method (see 1 above). Then the code performs a series of
301         small benchmarks using the scheme applied for the LOBPCG algorithm (see [[wfoptalg]] = 4 or 14).
302         The parallel distribution is then changed according to the benchmarks.
303         Possibly concerned parameters: [[npimage]], [[npkpt]], [[npspinor]], [[npfft]], [[npband]], [[bandpp]].
304     
305       * 3 --> Same as [[autoparal]] = 1, plus automatic determination of Linear Algebra routines parameters.
306         In addition, the code performs a series of small benchmarks using the Linear
307         Algebra routines (ScaLapack or Cuda-GPU). The parameters used to optimize
308         Linear Algebra work distribution are then changed according to the benchmarks.
309         Possibly concerned parameters (in addition to those modified for
310         [[autoparal]] = 1): [[use_slk]], [[np_slk]], [[gpu_linalg_limit]]
311     
312       * 4 --> combination of [[autoparal]] = 2 and [[autoparal]] = 3.
313     
314     Note that [[autoparal]] = 1 can be used on every set of processors;
315     [[autoparal]] > 1 should be used on a sufficiently large number of MPI process.
316     Also note that [[autoparal]] can be used simultaneously with [[max_ncpus]]; in
317     this case, ABINIT performs an optimization of process distribution for each
318     total number of processors from 2 to [[max_ncpus]]. A weight is associated to
319     each distribution and the higher this weight is the better the distribution
320     is. After having printed out the weights, the code stops.
321     """,
322     ),
323     
324     Variable(
325         abivarname="auxc_ixc",
326         varset="gstate",
327         vartype="integer",
328         topics=['Hybrids_useful'],
329         dimensions="scalar",
330         defaultval=1,
331         mnemonics="AUxiliary XC functional for hybrid functional, IXC number",
332         text="""
333     Specification of an auxiliary exchange-correlation functional, thanks to its
334     [[ixc]] value, to possibly replace the heavy evaluation of an hybrid
335     functional at specific occasions, e.g. when the Fock operator is frozen during
336     the self-consistent cycle, thanks to [[fockoptmix]] == 11, or when evaluating
337     the correction to forces due to the density residual. This auxiliary exchange-
338     correlation functional might be rescaled, thanks to [[auxc_scal]] when
339     [[fockoptmix]] == 11. If [[gwcalctyp]] == 5, 15 or 25, [[auxc_ixc]] refers to
340     [[ixc_sigma]] instead of [[ixc]].
341     """,
342     ),
343     
344     Variable(
345         abivarname="auxc_scal",
346         varset="gstate",
347         vartype="real",
348         topics=['Hybrids_useful'],
349         dimensions="scalar",
350         defaultval=1.0,
351         mnemonics="AUxiliary XC functional for hybrid functional- SCALing factor",
352         text="""
353     Possible scaling factor for the auxiliary exchange-correlation functional
354     defined by [[auxc_ixc]] that has the goal to replace the Fock operator or
355     hybrid functional when [[fockoptmix]] == 11.
356     
357     The default value 1.0 corresponds to the unmodified xc functional. When the
358     auxiliary functional is used to replace the hybrid functional in SCF loops, a
359     value of 1.5 has been observed to speed up somehow the convergence.
360     """,
361     ),
362     
363     Variable(
364         abivarname="awtr",
365         varset="gw",
366         vartype="integer",
367         topics=['Susceptibility_useful'],
368         dimensions="scalar",
369         defaultval=1,
370         mnemonics=r"evaluate the Adler-Wiser expression of $\chi^{0}_{KS}$ assuming Time-Reversal",
371         requires="[[optdriver]] == 3",
372         text=r"""
373     This input variable defines whether the irreducible polarizability
374     $\chi^{0}_{KS}$ is evaluated taking advantage of time-reversal symmetry or not.
375     
376     * 0 --> Use the "standard" Adler-Wiser expression without assuming time-reversal symmetry.
377       In this case, the irreducible polarizability is calculated summing over all possible
378       electronic transitions (both resonant and anti-resonant).
379     * 1 --> Take advantage of time-reversal symmetry to halve the number of transitions to be explicitly considered.
380       This method leads to a decrease in the CPU time by a factor two with respect to the [[awtr]] = 0 case.
381     
382     !!! important
383     
384         Note that the parallel algorithm [[gwpara]] = 2 is not compatible with the choice [[awtr]] = 0.
385     """,
386     ),
387     
388     Variable(
389         abivarname="bandpp",
390         varset="paral",
391         vartype="integer",
392         topics=['parallelism_useful'],
393         dimensions="scalar",
394         defaultval=1,
395         mnemonics="BAND Per Processor",
396         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
397         requires="[[paral_kgb]] == 1",
398         text="""
399     Control the size of the block in the LOBPCG algorithm. This keyword works only
400     with [[paral_kgb]] = 1 and has to be either 1 or a multiple of 2.
401     
402     With [[npband]] = 1:
403     
404     * 1 --> band-per-band algorithm
405     * n --> The minimization is performed using [[nband]]/n blocks of n bands.
406     
407     !!! warning
408     
409         [[nband]]/n has to be an integer.
410     
411     With [[npband]] $\\ne$ 1:
412     
413     * 1 --> The minimization is performed using [[nband]]/[[npband]] blocks of [[npband]] bands.
414     * n --> The minimization is performed using [[nband]]/([[npband]] $\\times$ n) blocks of [[npband]]  $\\times$ n bands.
415     
416     !!! warning
417     
418         [[nband]] / ([[npband]]  $\\times$ n) has to be an integer.
419     
420     By minimizing a larger number of bands together in LOBPCG, we increase the
421     convergence of the residual. The better minimization procedure (as concerns
422     the convergence, but not as concerns the speed) is generally performed by
423     using [[bandpp]]  $\\times$ [[npband]] = [[nband]]. Put [[bandpp]] = 2 when [[istwfk]] = 2
424     (the time spent in FFTs is divided by two).
425     """,
426     ),
427     
428     Variable(
429         abivarname="bdberry",
430         varset="ffield",
431         vartype="integer",
432         topics=['Berry_basic'],
433         dimensions=[4],
434         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=4, value=0),
435         mnemonics="BanD limits for BERRY phase",
436         requires="[[berryopt]] in [1, 2, 3] and [[nberry]] > 0",
437         text="""
438     Give the lower band and the upper band of the set of bands for which the Berry
439     phase must be computed. Irrelevant if [[nberry]] is not positive. When
440     [[nsppol]] is 1 (no spin-polarisation), only the two first numbers, giving the
441     lower and highest bands, are significant. Their occupation number is assumed
442     to be 2. When [[nsppol]] is 2 (spin-polarized calculation), the two first
443     numbers give the lowest and highest bands for spin up, and the third and
444     fourth numbers give the lowest and highest bands for spin down. Their
445     occupation number is assumed to be 1.
446     
447     !!! important
448     
449         Presently, [[bdberry]] MUST be initialized by the user in case of a Berry
450         phase calculation with [[berryopt]] = 1, 2, or 3: the above-mentioned default
451         will cause an early exit.
452     """,
453     ),
454     
455     Variable(
456         abivarname="bdeigrf",
457         varset="dfpt",
458         vartype="integer",
459         topics=['TDepES_basic'],
460         dimensions="scalar",
461         defaultval=-1,
462         mnemonics="BanD for second-order EIGenvalues from Response-Function",
463         requires="[[ieig2rf]] in [1,2,3,4,5]",
464         text="""
465     
466     The variable [[bdeigrf]] is the maximum number of bands for which the second-
467     order eigenvalues must be calculated: the full number of bands is still used
468     during the computation of these corrections.
469     
470     If [[bdeigrf]] is set to -1, the code will automatically set [[bdeigrf]] equal to [[nband]].
471     """,
472     ),
473     
474     Variable(
475         abivarname="bdgw",
476         varset="gw",
477         vartype="integer",
478         topics=['GW_basic', 'SelfEnergy_basic'],
479         dimensions=[2, '[[nkptgw]]', '[[nsppol]]'],
480         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=None, value=0),
481         mnemonics="BanDs for GW calculation",
482         requires="[[optdriver]] in [4, 7]",
483         text="""
484     For each k-point with number `ikptgw` in the range (1:[[nkptgw]]) and each spin
485     index `isppol`, [[bdgw]](1,`ikptgw`,`isppol`) is the number of the lowest band for
486     which the self-energy computation must be done.
487     [[bdgw]](2,`ikptgw`,`isppol`) gives the index of the highest band for which the self-energy computation must be done.
488     
489     !!! note
490     
491         The initial values given in the input file might be changed inside
492         the code so that all the degenerate states at a given k-point and spin are
493         included. This might happen when [[symsigma]] = 1 is used or in the case of
494         self-consistent GW calculations.
495         When [[symsigma]] == 1, indeed, the diagonal matrix elements of the self-energy are
496         obtained by averaging the unsymmetrized results in the subspace spanned by the degenerate states.
497     
498     When [[gwcalctyp]] >= 20, the quasiparticle wavefunctions are computed and
499     represented as linear combination of Kohn-Sham wavefunctions. In this case
500     [[bdgw]] designates the range of KS wavefunctions used as basis set. For each
501     k-point, indeed, the quasiparticle wavefunctions are expanded considering only
502     the KS states between [[bdgw]](1,`ikptgw`,`isppol`) and [[bdgw]](2,`ikptgw`,`isppol`).
503     
504     For self-consistent calculations, on the other hand, the basis set used to
505     expand the GW wavefunctions should include all the degenerate states belonging
506     to the same irreducible representation. Only in this case, indeed, the initial
507     symmetries and energy degenerations are preserved.
508     """,
509     ),
510     
511     Variable(
512         abivarname="berryopt",
513         varset="ffield",
514         vartype="integer",
515         topics=['Berry_compulsory'],
516         dimensions="scalar",
517         defaultval=0,
518         mnemonics="BERRY phase OPTions",
519         text=r"""
520     Specifies the use of Berry phase for the computation of either the
521     polarization, the derivatives with respect to the wavevector, or finite
522     electric field calculations.
523     
524       * 0 --> no computation of expressions relying on a Berry phase (default)
525       * 1 --> the computation of Berry phases is activated (berryphase routine)
526       * 2 --> the computation of derivatives with respect to the wavevector, thanks to the
527         Berry phase finite-difference formula, is activated (uderiv routine)
528       * 3 --> same as option 1 and 2 together
529     
530     !!! note
531         Note that options 1 to 3 require the use of a serial build of Abinit.**
532     
533       * -1 --> alternative computation of Berry phases (berryphase_new routine)
534       * -2 --> alternative computation of derivatives with respect to the wavevector,
535         thanks to the Berry phase finite-difference formula (berryphase_new routine)
536       * -3 --> same as option -1 and -2 together
537     
538     !!! note
539         Options -1 to -3 permit use of a parallel build and will be preferred by
540         most users.
541     
542       * 4 --> finite electric field calculation (unreduced E-field)
543       * 6 --> finite electric displacement field calculation (unreduced D-field)
544       * 14 --> finite reduced electric field calculation
545       * 16 --> finite electric displacement field calculation
546       * 17 --> mixed electric boundary condition: finite reduced electric field in some directions,
547       finite reduced electric displacement field along other directions. See variable [[jfielddir]] for more details.
548     
549     Other related input variables are:
550     
551       * in case of [[berryopt]] = 1,2, or 3: [[bdberry]] and [[kberry]]; also, [[nberry]] must be larger than 0;
552       * in case of [[berryopt]] = -1,-2, or -3: the variable [[rfdir]] must be used to specify the primitive vector along which the projection of the polarization or the ddk will be computed. For example if [[berryopt]] = -1 and [[rfdir]] = 1 0 0, the projection of the polarization along the reciprocal lattice vector $G_1$ is computed. In case [[rfdir]] = 1 1 1, ABINIT computes the projection of P along $G_1$, $G_2$ and $G_3$ and transforms the results to cartesian coordinates;
553       * in cases where [[berryopt]] is negative, [[berrystep]] allow a computation of multiple-step Berry phase in order to accelerate the convergence.
554       * [[efield]] and [[rfdir]] in case of [[berryopt]] = 4;
555     
556     The cases [[berryopt]] = -1,-2,-3, 4, 6, 7, 14, 16, and 17 have to be used with [[occopt]] = 1.
557     
558     The cases [[berryopt]] = -1 and 4, 6, 7, 14, 16, 17 are compatible with PAW,
559     howevever, if in these cases one uses [[kptopt]] /= 3, one must also use only
560     symmorphic symmetries (either because the space group is symmorphic or the
561     variable [[symmorphi]] is set to zero).
562     
563     For a phonon calculation under a finite electric field, respect the following procedure.
564     
565       * a) Run a scf ground-state calculation at zero electric field to get wavefunctions to initialize the ground-state calculation in finite electric fields.
566       * b) Run a scf ground-state calculation in finite electric field. The electric field is controlled by the input variable [[efield]]. [[berryopt]] should be 4. The input variable [[kptopt]] should be set to be 2.
567       * c) Based on the wave functions obtained in step (2), perform phonon calculation by setting [[berryopt]] = 4, [[kptopt]] = 3 and The same value of [[efield]] than in step 2. [[nsym]] should be set to 1 currently but this restriction may be removed later. The other parameters are the same as phonon calculation at zero electric field.
568     
569     !!! important
570         The choice of k-point sampling N x N x N should be the same in the three runs and N should be an even number.
571     
572     In case of finite electric and displacement field calculations
573     ([[berryopt]] = 4,6,7,14,16,17), see also the input variables [[berrysav]],
574     [[dfield]], [[red_dfield]], [[red_efield]], [[ddamp]]
575     """,
576     ),
577     
578     Variable(
579         abivarname="berrysav",
580         varset="ffield",
581         vartype="integer",
582         topics=['Berry_useful'],
583         dimensions="scalar",
584         defaultval=0,
585         mnemonics="BERRY SAVe",
586         text="""
587       * 0 --> for finite electric field calculation ([[berryopt]] = 4/14),
588         the polarization branch will be chosen on each iteration from (-pi, pi).
589         For finite electric displacement field calculation([[berryopt]] = 6/7/16/17),
590         the polarization will be chosen to minimize the internal energy.
591       * 1 --> the polarization will be kept in the same branch on each iteration.
592         At the end of the run, a file "POLSAVE" will be saved containing the reduced polarization in atomic units.
593     
594         !!! note
595             Make sure that "POLSAVE" is empty or it does not exist before the calculation, or else that
596             it specifies the desired polarization branch.
597     """,
598     ),
599     
600     Variable(
601         abivarname="berrystep",
602         varset="ffield",
603         vartype="integer",
604         topics=['Berry_expert'],
605         dimensions="scalar",
606         defaultval=1,
607         mnemonics="BERRY phase: multiple STEP",
608         requires="0 > [[berryopt]]",
609         text="""
610     If [[berryopt]] is negative, this variable is used to compute berry phases
611     using multiple discrete steps, in order to accelerate convergence. The single-
612     step berry phase is the standard calculation using strings of k-points based
613     on overlap of Bloch function separated by $dk$, while the two-step berry phase
614     use strings use overlaps based on dk and $2*dk$, the three-step use overlaps
615     based on dk, $2*dk$ and $3*dk$...
616     
617     The default value of this variable is 1, meaning that only the single-step
618     berry phase calculation is done. If a larger value is set, ABINIT will compute
619     all the multiple-step berry phase from the single-step to the
620     [[berrystep]]-step, and use the large-step values of berry phase to correct
621     the single-step berry phase. Use with care: while experience is still to be
622     gained with this procedure, the outlook is promising.
623     """,
624     ),
625     
626     Variable(
627         abivarname="bfield",
628         varset="ffield",
629         vartype="real",
630         topics=['MagField_expert'],
631         dimensions=[3],
632         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=3, value=0.0),
633         mnemonics="finite B FIELD calculation",
634         text="""
635     Perform finite magnetic field calculation.
636     
637     !!! important
638         **THIS CODE IS UNDER DEVELOPMENT AND IS NOT READY FOR USE.**
639     """,
640     ),
641     
642     Variable(
643         abivarname="bmass",
644         varset="rlx",
645         vartype="real",
646         topics=['MolecularDynamics_expert'],
647         dimensions="scalar",
648         defaultval=10,
649         mnemonics="Barostat MASS",
650         text="""
651     bmass is the mass of the barostat when [[ionmov]] = 13 (constant pressure molecular dynamics)
652     """,
653     ),
654     
655     Variable(
656         abivarname="boxcenter",
657         varset="gstate",
658         vartype="real",
659         topics=['TDDFT_basic'],
660         dimensions=[3],
661         defaultval=[0.5, 0.5, 0.5],
662         mnemonics="BOX CENTER",
663         text="""
664     Defines the center of the box, in reduced coordinates. At present, this
665     information is only used in the case of Time-Dependent DFT computation of the
666     oscillator strength. One must take [[boxcenter]] such as to be roughly the center
667     of the cluster or molecule. The default is sensible when the vacuum
668     surrounding the cluster or molecule has xred 0 or 1. On the contrary, when the
669     cluster or molecule is close to the origin, it is better to take [[boxcenter]] = [0.0, 0.0, 0.0].
670     """,
671     ),
672     
673     Variable(
674         abivarname="boxcutmin",
675         varset="gstate",
676         vartype="real",
677         topics=['Planewaves_useful', 'TuningSpeed_basic'],
678         dimensions="scalar",
679         defaultval=2.0,
680         mnemonics="BOX CUT-off MINimum",
681         text="""
682     The box cut-off ratio is the ratio between the wavefunction plane wave sphere
683     radius, and the radius of the sphere that can be inserted in the FFT box, in reciprocal space.
684     
685     In order for the density to be exact (in the case of the plane wave part, not the PAW on-site terms),
686     this ratio should be at least two. If one uses a smaller ratio, one will gain speed, at the expense of accuracy.
687     In the case of pure ground state calculation (e.g. for the determination of geometries), this is sensible.
688     
689     Prior to v8.9, the use of boxcutmin for DFPT calculations was forbidden. However, after testing, it was seen that
690     the deterioration in phonon band structures could be alleviated to a large extent by the imposition of the Acoustic Sum Rule [[asr]].
691     """,
692     ),
693     
694     Variable(
695         abivarname="brvltt",
696         varset="geo",
697         vartype="integer",
698         topics=['UnitCell_useful', 'SmartSymm_basic'],
699         dimensions="scalar",
700         defaultval=0,
701         mnemonics="BRaVais LaTTice type",
702         requires="[[spgroup]] != 0",
703         text="""
704     Set the type of Bravais lattice. The cell defined by [[acell]] and [[rprim]]
705     or [[angdeg]] should be the CONVENTIONAL cell.
706     
707     If brvltt=0, the code will assign brvltt from the space group information
708     [[spgroup]], and produce the symmetry operations for the conventional unit
709     cell. If the conventional cell is not primitive, the user should set [[chkprim]] = 0.
710     
711     If brvltt=-1, the code will assign brvltt from the space group information,
712     then reduce the unit cell to a primitive unit cell. The echo of [[acell]] and
713     [[rprim]] might thus differ from those derived directly from the input
714     variables. Also, the input variable [[xred]] will refer to the CONVENTIONAL
715     unit cell, but its echo will refer to the preprocessed PRIMITIVE unit cell.
716     There is of course no problem with [[xangst]] and [[xcart]], as they are
717     independent of the unit cell.
718     
719     The echo of [[brvltt]] in the output file will be one of the following Bravais lattices:
720     
721     * 1 = Primitive with no associated translations
722     * 2 = Inner centered with (a/2 + b/2 + c/2) associated translation
723     * 3 = Face centered with (a/2 + b/2; b/2 + c/2; c/2 + a/2) associated translations
724     * 4 = C - centered with (a/2 + b/2) associated translation
725     * 5 = A - centered with (b/2 + c/2) associated translation
726     * 6 = B - centered with (c/2 + a/2) associated translation
727     * 7 = Rhombohedral lattice.
728     
729     The user might also input directly these values, although they might not be
730     consistent with [[spgroup]].
731     
732     The space groups 146, 148, 155, 160, 161, 166, 167, when used with
733     [[spgaxor]] = 1 (hexagonal axes) will have [[brvltt]] = 7 and two associated
734     translations: (2/3, 1/3, 1/3) and (1/3, 2/3, 2/3).
735     For more details see the [[help:spacegroup]].
736     """,
737     ),
738     
739     Variable(
740         abivarname="bs_algorithm",
741         varset="bse",
742         vartype="integer",
743         topics=['BSE_basic'],
744         dimensions="scalar",
745         defaultval=2,
746         mnemonics="Bethe-Salpeter ALGORITHM",
747         requires="[[optdriver]] == 99",
748         text="""
749     This input variable defines the algorithm employed to calculate the macroscopic dielectric function.
750     Possible values are in [1, 2, 3]:
751     
752     * 1 --> The macroscopic dielectric is obtained by performing a direct diagonalization
753       of the excitonic Hamiltonian. Advantages: It gives direct access to the excitonic eigenvalues
754       as well as to the oscillator strengths. Drawbacks: It is a very CPU- and memory-consuming approach
755       as the size of the Hamiltonian scales as $(n_k * n_c * n_v)^2$ where $n_k$ is the number of k-point
756       in the **full** Brillouin zone, and $n_c$ and $n_v$ are the number of conduction and valence states, respectively.
757       Pros: It can be used both for resonant-only and resonant + coupling calculations (non Tamm-Dancoff approximation).
758     
759     * 2 --> Haydock iterative method. The macroscopic dielectric function is obtained by iterative applications
760       of the Hamiltonian on a set of vectors in the electron-hole space.
761       Advantages: It is less memory demanding and usually faster than the direct diagonalization provided
762       that [[zcut]] is larger than the typical energy spacing of the eigenvalues. Drawbacks:
763       It is an iterative method therefore the convergence with respect to [[bs_haydock_niter]] should be checked.
764       It is not possible to have direct information on the exciton spectrum, oscillator strengths and excitonic wave functions.
765       For the time being [[bs_algorithm]] = 2 cannot be used for calculations in which the coupling
766       term is included (Tamm-Dancoff approximation).
767     
768     * 3 --> Conjugate-gradient method. This method allows one to find the few first excitonic eigenvalues.
769       Only available for resonant calculations (Tamm-Dancoff approximation).
770     """,
771     ),
772     
773     Variable(
774         abivarname="bs_calctype",
775         varset="bse",
776         vartype="integer",
777         topics=['BSE_expert'],
778         dimensions="scalar",
779         defaultval=1,
780         mnemonics="Bethe-Salpeter CALCulation TYPE",
781         requires="[[optdriver]] == 99",
782         text=r"""
783     Possible values are in [1, 2, 3].
784     
785     * 1 --> use the KS eigenvalues and wave functions stored in the WFK file to construct the transition space
786     * 2 --> The transition space is constructed with Kohn-Sham orbitals but the energies are read from an external GW file
787     * 3 --> QP amplitudes and energies will be read from the QPS file and used to construct H_ex.
788       Not coded yet because <\psi|r|\psj>^QP should be calculated taking into account the non-locality
789       of the self-energy in the commutator [H,r].
790     """,
791     ),
792     
793     Variable(
794         abivarname="bs_coulomb_term",
795         varset="bse",
796         vartype="integer",
797         topics=['BSE_expert'],
798         dimensions="scalar",
799         defaultval=11,
800         mnemonics="Bethe-Salpeter COULOMB TERM",
801         requires="[[optdriver]] == 99",
802         text=r"""
803     This variable governs the choice among the different options that are
804     available for the treatment of Coulomb term of the Bethe-Salpeter Hamiltonian.
805     **bs_coulomb_term** is the concatenation of two digits, labelled (A) and (B).
806     
807     The first digit (A) can assume the values 0, 1, 2:
808     
809       * 0 --> The Coulomb term is not computed. This choice is equivalent to computing the RPA spectrum
810         but using the representation in transition space instead of the more efficient approach based on the sum over states.
811     
812       * 1 --> The Coulomb term is computed using the screened interaction read
813         from an external SCR file (standard excitonic calculation).
814     
815       * 2 --> The Coulomb term is computed using a model screening function
816         (useful for convergence studies or for reproducing published results).
817     
818     The second digit (B) can assume the values 0,1:
819     
820       * 0 --> Use a diagonal approximation for $W_{\GG\GG'}$ (mainly used for accelerating convergence studies).
821     
822       * 1 --> The Coulomb term is correctly evaluated using the truly non-local screening $W(\rr,\rr')$.
823     """,
824     ),
825     
826     Variable(
827         abivarname="bs_coupling",
828         varset="bse",
829         vartype="integer",
830         topics=['BSE_useful'],
831         dimensions="scalar",
832         defaultval=0,
833         mnemonics="Bethe-Salpeter COUPLING",
834         requires="[[optdriver]] == 99",
835         text=r"""
836     The **bs_coupling** input variable defines the treatment of the coupling block
837     of the Bethe-Salpeter Hamiltonian. Possible values are 0, 1.
838     
839       * 0 --> The coupling block is neglected (the so-called Tamm-Dancoff approximation).
840         The code runs faster and the Hamiltonian matrix requires less memory (factor 4).
841         It is a good approximation for the absorption spectrum which only requires the knowledge of $\Im(\epsilon)$.
842         The reliability of this approximation should be tested in the case of EELF calculations.
843     
844       * 1 --> The coupling term is included (non Tamm-Dancoff approximation).
845     """,
846     ),
847     
848     Variable(
849         abivarname="bs_eh_cutoff",
850         varset="bse",
851         vartype="integer",
852         topics=['BSE_expert'],
853         dimensions=[2],
854         defaultval=["-inf", "inf"],
855         mnemonics="Bethe-Salpeter Electron-Hole CUTOFF",
856         requires="[[optdriver]] == 99",
857         text="""
858     Used to define a cutoff in the e-h basis set. Only those transitions
859     whose energy is between bs_eh_cutoff(1) and bs_eh_cutoff(2) will be considered
860     in the construction of the e-h Hamiltonian.
861     """,
862     ),
863     
864     Variable(
865         abivarname="bs_exchange_term",
866         varset="bse",
867         vartype="integer",
868         topics=['BSE_expert'],
869         dimensions="scalar",
870         defaultval=1,
871         mnemonics="Bethe-Salpeter EXCHANGE TERM",
872         requires="[[optdriver]] == 99",
873         text="""
874     * 0 --> The exchange term is not calculated. This is equivalent to neglecting
875       local field effects in the macroscopic dielectric function.
876     * 1 --> The exchange term is calculated and added to the excitonic Hamiltonian.
877     """,
878     ),
879     
880     Variable(
881         abivarname="bs_freq_mesh",
882         varset="bse",
883         vartype="real",
884         topics=['BSE_basic'],
885         dimensions=[3],
886         defaultval=[0.0, 0.0, 0.01],
887         mnemonics="Bethe-Salpeter FREQuency MESH",
888         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
889         requires="[[optdriver]] == 99",
890         text="""
891     **bs_freq_mesh(1)** defines the first frequency for the calculation of the macroscopic dielectric function.
892     
893     **bs_freq_mesh(2)** gives the last frequency for the calculation of the
894     macroscopic dielectric function. If zero, **bs_freq_mesh(2)** is set automatically to MAX(resonant_energy) + 10%.
895     
896     **bs_freq_mesh(3)** gives the step of the linear mesh used for evaluating the macroscopic dielectric function.
897     """,
898     ),
899     
900     Variable(
901         abivarname="bs_hayd_term",
902         varset="bse",
903         vartype="integer",
904         topics=['BSE_expert'],
905         dimensions="scalar",
906         defaultval=1,
907         mnemonics="Bethe-Salpeter HAYdock TERMinator",
908         requires="[[optdriver]] == 99 and [[bs_algorithm]] == 2",
909         text=r"""
910     Defines how to terminate the continued fraction expression for the dielectric function.
911     The terminator reduces the number of iterations needed to converge
912     by smoothing the oscillation in the high energy part of the spectrum
913     
914       * 0 --> No terminator. The contribution given by the terms missing in the Lanczos chain are set to zero.
915       * 1 --> Use the terminator function. The particular expression depends on the type of calculation:
916         In the resonant-only case, the $a_i$ and $b_i$ coefficients for $i > \text{niter}$, are replaced
917         by their values at $i = \text{niter}$.
918         If the coupling block is included, the terminator function described in [[cite:Rocca2008]].
919     """,
920     ),
921     
922     Variable(
923         abivarname="bs_haydock_niter",
924         varset="bse",
925         vartype="integer",
926         topics=['BSE_expert'],
927         dimensions="scalar",
928         defaultval=100,
929         mnemonics="Bethe-Salpeter HAYDOCK Number of ITERations",
930         requires="[[optdriver]] == 99 and [[bs_algorithm]] == 2",
931         text="""
932     **bs_haydock_niter** defines the maximum number of iterations used to
933     calculate the macroscopic dielectric function.
934     The iterative algorithm stops when the difference between two consecutive
935     evaluations of the optical spectra is less than [[bs_haydock_tol]].
936     """,
937     ),
938     
939     Variable(
940         abivarname="bs_haydock_tol",
941         varset="bse",
942         vartype="real",
943         topics=['BSE_expert'],
944         dimensions=[2],
945         defaultval=[0.02, 0],
946         mnemonics="Bethe-Salpeter HAYDOCK TOLerance",
947         requires="[[optdriver]] == 99 and [[bs_algorithm]] == 2",
948         text="""
949     Defines the convergence criterion for the Haydock iterative method.
950     The iterative algorithm stops when the difference between two consecutive
951     evaluations of the macroscopic dielectric function is less than **bs_haydock_tol(1)**.
952     The sign of **bs_haydock_tol(1)** defines how to estimate the convergence error.
953     
954     A negative value signals that the converge should be reached for each frequency (strict criterion), while a positive
955     value indicates that the converge error is estimated by averaging over the entire frequency range (mild criterion).
956     
957     **bs_haydock_tol(2)** defines the quantity that will be checked for convergence:
958     
959       * 0 --> both the real and the imaginary part must converge
960       * 1 --> only the real part
961       * 2 --> only the imaginary part
962     """,
963     ),
964     
965     Variable(
966         abivarname="bs_interp_kmult",
967         varset="bse",
968         vartype="integer",
969         topics=['BSE_useful'],
970         dimensions=[3],
971         defaultval=[0, 0, 0],
972         mnemonics="Bethe-Salpeter INTERPolation K-point MULTiplication factors",
973         requires="[[bs_interp_mode]] > 0 and [[bs_algorithm]] == 2 and [[bs_coupling]] == 0",
974         text="""
975     **bs_interp_kmult** defines the number of divisions used to generate the dense mesh in the interpolation.
976     [[ngkpt]] of the dense mesh = **bs_interp_kmult(:)** * [[ngkpt]] of the coarse mesh.
977     """,
978     ),
979     
980     Variable(
981         abivarname="bs_interp_m3_width",
982         varset="bse",
983         vartype="real",
984         topics=['BSE_useful'],
985         dimensions="scalar",
986         defaultval=1.0,
987         mnemonics="Bethe-Salpeter INTERPolation Method3 WIDTH",
988         requires="[[bs_interp_mode]] == 3 and [[bs_algorithm]] == 2 and [[bs_coupling]] == 0",
989         text="""
990     Defines the width of the region where divergence treatment is applied for BSE interpolation
991     """,
992     ),
993     
994     Variable(
995         abivarname="bs_interp_method",
996         varset="bse",
997         vartype="integer",
998         topics=['BSE_useful'],
999         dimensions="scalar",
1000         defaultval=1,
1001         mnemonics="Bethe-Salpeter INTERPolation METHOD",
1002         requires="[[bs_interp_mode]] > 0 and [[bs_algorithm]] == 2 and [[bs_coupling]] == 0",
1003         text="""
1004     *bs_interp_method* selects the interpolation method::
1005     
1006       * 0 --> Interpolate using Y. Gillet technique with 8 neighbours (see [[cite:Gillet2016]]).
1007       * 1 --> Interpolation using Rohlfing & Louie technique (see above-mentioned article and [[cite:Rohlfing2000]])
1008     """,
1009     ),
1010     
1011     Variable(
1012         abivarname="bs_interp_mode",
1013         varset="bse",
1014         vartype="integer",
1015         topics=['BSE_basic'],
1016         dimensions="scalar",
1017         defaultval=0,
1018         mnemonics="Bethe-Salpeter INTERPolation MODE",
1019         requires="[[bs_interp_mode]] > 0 and [[bs_algorithm]] == 2 and [[bs_coupling]] == 0",
1020         text="""
1021     *bs_interp_mode* selects the mode of interpolation:
1022     
1023       * 0 --> No interpolation. Standard Bethe-Salpeter computation is performed
1024       * 1 --> Simple interpolation
1025       * 2 --> Treatment of the divergence on the whole set of dense k-points
1026       * 3 --> Treatment of the divergence along the diagonal in k-space and simple interpolation elsewhere.
1027     """,
1028     ),
1029     
1030     Variable(
1031         abivarname="bs_interp_prep",
1032         varset="bse",
1033         vartype="integer",
1034         topics=['BSE_useful'],
1035         dimensions="scalar",
1036         defaultval=0,
1037         mnemonics="Bethe-Salpeter INTERPolation PREParation",
1038         requires="[[bs_interp_mode]] > 0 and [[bs_algorithm]] == 2 and [[bs_coupling]] == 0",
1039         text="""
1040     *bs_interp_prep* allows one to trigger the preparation of the interpolation with method 2 or method 3.
1041     It generates the decomposition of BSR in a, b, c coefficients used for the interpolation.
1042     """,
1043     ),
1044     
1045     Variable(
1046         abivarname="bs_interp_rl_nb",

1050         dimensions="scalar",

1058     
1059     Variable(
1060         abivarname="bs_loband",

1062         vartype="integer",

1064         dimensions=['[[nsppol]]'],
1065         defaultval=0,
1066         mnemonics="Bethe-Salpeter Lowest Occupied BAND",
1067         requires="[[optdriver]] == 99",
1068         text="""

1070     construction of the electron-hole basis set. For spin polarized calculations,
1071     one must provide two separated indices for spin up and spin down.

1074     ),
