1076     Variable(
1077         abivarname="bs_nstates",
1078         varset="bse",
1079         vartype="integer",
1080         topics=['BSE_basic'],
1081         dimensions="scalar",
1082         defaultval=0,
1083         mnemonics="Bethe-Salpeter Number of STATES",
1084         requires="[[optdriver]] == 99 and [[bs_algorithm]] in [2, 3]",
1085         text="""
1086     **bs_nstates** defines the maximum number of excitonic states calculated in
1087     the direct diagonalization of the excitonic matrix or in the conjugate-gradient method.
1088     The number of states should be sufficiently large for a
1089     correct description of the optical properties in the frequency range of interest.
1090     """,
1091     ),
1092     
1093     Variable(
1094         abivarname="builtintest",
1095         varset="dev",
1096         vartype="integer",
1097         topics=['Control_expert'],
1098         dimensions="scalar",
1099         defaultval=0,
1100         mnemonics="BUIT-IN TEST number",
1101         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
1102         text="""
1103     When [[builtintest]] is non-zero, the input file is a special one, that runs
1104     very quickly, and that is accompanied by a specific analysis by ABINIT, at the
1105     end of the run, against a hard-coded value of total energy (and possibly
1106     stresses, forces ...). The echo of the analysis is done in the STATUS file. In
1107     particular, such built-in tests can be used to check quickly whether ABINIT
1108     fallbacks have been connected or not (bigdft, etsf_io, libxc, wannier90). At
1109     present, [[builtintest]] = 1... 7 are allowed. See more information in tests/built-in/README.
1110     """,
1111     ),
1112     
1113     Variable(
1114         abivarname="bxctmindg",
1115         varset="paw",
1116         vartype="real",
1117         topics=['PAW_expert'],
1118         dimensions="scalar",
1119         defaultval=2.0,
1120         mnemonics="BoX CuT-off MINimum for the Double Grid (PAW)",
1121         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
1122         text="""
1123     The box cut-off ratio is the ratio between the wavefunction plane wave sphere
1124     radius, and the radius of the sphere that can be inserted in the FFT box, in
1125     reciprocal space.
1126     
1127     If the density was generated only from wavefunctions, this ratio should be at
1128     least two in order for the density to be exact. If one uses a smaller ratio,
1129     one will gain speed, at the expense of accuracy. In case of pure ground state
1130     calculation (e.g. for the determination of geometries), this is sensible.
1131     However, the wavefunctions that are obtained CANNOT be used for starting
1132     response function calculation.
1133     
1134     However, some augmentation charge is always added in PAW, and even with the
1135     box cut-off ratio larger than two, the density is never exact. Sometimes, this
1136     ratio must be much larger than two for the computation to be converged at the
1137     required level of accuracy.
1138     """,
1139     ),
1140     
1141     Variable(
1142         abivarname="cd_customnimfrqs",
1143         varset="gw",
1144         vartype="integer",
1145         topics=['FrequencyMeshMBPT_expert'],
1146         dimensions="scalar",
1147         defaultval=0,
1148         mnemonics="Contour Deformation CUSTOM IMaginary FReQuencieS",
1149         requires="([[optdriver]] ==3 or [[optdriver]] ==4) and [[gwcalctyp]] in [2,9,12,19,22,29]",
1150         text="""
1151     [[cd_customnimfrqs]] lets the user define the grid points along the imaginary
1152     axis by hand. Set this to the number of frequencies you want. The frequencies
1153     are specified with [[cd_imfrqs]].
1154     """,
1155     ),
1156     
1157     Variable(
1158         abivarname="cd_frqim_method",
1159         varset="gw",
1160         vartype="integer",
1161         topics=['FrequencyMeshMBPT_expert'],
1162         dimensions="scalar",
1163         defaultval=1,
1164         mnemonics="Contour Deformation FReQuency integration on IMaginary axis Method",
1165         requires="[[optdriver]] ==4 and [[gwcalctyp]] in [2,9,12,19,22,29]",
1166         text=r"""
1167     [[cd_frqim_method]] defines the choice of integration method along the
1168     imaginary frequency axis for Contour Deformation calculations. The default
1169     method is very robust, fast and optimal for the vast majority of cases.
1170     However, for very accurate ("paranoid level") convergence studies, ABINIT
1171     offers the possibility of a variety of methods and grids. Note that as one
1172     starts to change the defaults, one needs to carefully consider the grid used.
1173     Therefore we recommend that in addition to reading the information below, the
1174     user reads the description of the input variables [[freqim_alpha]],
1175     [[nfreqim]], [[ppmfrq]], [[gw_frqim_inzgrid]].
1176     
1177     The integration to be performed for each matrix element of the self energy
1178     along the imaginary axis is of the form:
1179     
1180     $$ \langle i|\Sigma(\omega)|j \rangle  \propto
1181        \sum_s C_s \int_0^\infty d(i\omega^\prime)
1182        \frac{(\omega - \epsilon_s)}{(\omega-\epsilon_s)^2 + i{\omega^\prime}^2}
1183        f(i\omega^\prime),
1184     $$
1185     
1186     where  $\omega$ is the frequency point along the real axis, $\epsilon_s$ is an
1187     eigenvalue, and  $i\omega^\prime$ is the variable along the imaginary axis. Thus the
1188     function to be integrated is a Lorentzian weight function centred on the
1189     origin (whose FWHM is decided by $|\omega-\epsilon_s|$), times a function. The
1190     function is related to the inverse dielectric matrix. It might have a peaked
1191     structure near the origin and is very smooth otherwise. the function decays
1192     asymptotically as  $1/i\omega^\prime$, so the whole integral converges as this to
1193     the third power.
1194     
1195       * **cd_frqim_method = 1 - Histogram:** This is the **default** method where the function  $f(i\omega^\prime)$ is approximated by a histogram, and the Lorentzian is integrated analytically in each sub-interval. See the section on grids below for a description of the default grid. This method combined with the default grid is the fastest and optimised for the use of few points along the imaginary axis.
1196       * **cd_frqim_method = 2 - Trapezoid:** The next step up from the histogram approximation in the previous method. The integration region is transformed  $[0, \infty] \rightarrow [0,1]$ with a proper weight depending on the width of the Lorentzian. In this space  $f(i\omega^\prime)$ is approximated by a linear function between grid points (trapezoids), and the integrand is integrated analytically in each sub-interval. This method tends to slightly overestimate contributions while the default method tends to slightly underestimate them, so the results from methods 1 and 2 should bracket the converged values. The asymptotic behaviour is explicitly taken into account by a fit using the last two grid points.
1197       * **cd_frqim_method = 3, 4, 5 - Natural Spline:** The function is transformed  $[0, \infty] \rightarrow [0,1]$. In this space  $f(i\omega^\prime)$ is approximated by a natural spline function whose starting and ending sections are linear. This transform is chosen so that the function should approach a linear function asymptotically as the integration interval approaches 1, so that the asymptotic behaviour is automatically taken into account. For each Lorentzian width (determined by $|\omega-\epsilon_s|$) the integrand is appropriately scaled in the interval $[0,1]$, and a nested Gauss-Kronrod (GK) numerical integration rule is performed. The integrand is evaluated at the GK nodes by means of a spline-fit. The order of the GK rule is controlled by the index of the method:
1198         * 3 --> Gauss 7 point, Kronrod 15 point rule.
1199         * 4 --> Gauss 11 point, Kronrod 23 point rule.
1200         * 5 --> Gauss 15 point, Kronrod 31 point rule.
1201     There is rarely any difference to machine precision between these rules, and
1202     the code will issue a warning if a higher-order rule is recommended.
1203     
1204     **Grids for the integral along the imaginary axis:**
1205     
1206     All the methods above should execute no matter what grid is used along the
1207     imaginary axis, so this is very much under the control of the user. The only
1208     requirement is that the grid be strictly increasing. The point at zero
1209     frequency is assumed to lie on the real axis, so the calculation of that point
1210     is controlled by [[nfreqre]] and corresponding variables. We highly recommend
1211     extracting various elements of the dielectric matrix from the _SCR file using
1212     the **Mrgscr** utility and plotting them for visual inspection.
1213     
1214       * **Default** - The default grid is an exponentially increasing grid given by the formula:
1215     
1216     $$ i\omega^\prime_k = \frac{\omega_p}{\alpha-2}\left[ e^{\frac{2k}{N+1} \ln(\alpha-1)} -1 \right]. $$
1217     
1218     Here  $\omega_p$ is the plasma frequency (by default determined by the average
1219     density of the system, but this can be overridden by setting [[ppmfrq]]).  $N$
1220     is the total number of grid points (set by [[nfreqim]]). $\alpha$ is a parameter
1221     which determines how far out the final grid point will lie. The final point
1222     will be at  $\alpha*\omega_p$ (the default is  $\alpha = 5$, and was hard-coded in
1223     older versions of ABINIT). This grid is designed so that approximately half
1224     the grid points are always distributed to values lower than the plasma
1225     frequency, in order to resolve any peaked structure. If one seeks to increase
1226     the outermost reach by increasing [[ppmfrq]] one must simultaneously take care
1227     to increase [[nfreqim]] in order to have the appropriate resolution for the
1228     low-frequency region. In more recent versions of ABINIT one can also simply
1229     adjust the parameter  $\alpha$ by using [[freqim_alpha]]. This grid is optimised
1230     for speed and accurate results with few grid points for **cd_frqim_method = 1**.
1231     
1232       * **Inverse z transform** - This grid is activated by the use of the variable [[gw_frqim_inzgrid]].
1233         This is the standard  $[0, \infty] \rightarrow [0,1]$ transform using the formula:
1234     
1235     $$ i\omega^\prime = \omega_p \frac{z}{1-z}. $$
1236     
1237     Here $\omega_p$ is the plasma frequency (default can be overridden by setting
1238     [[ppmfrq]]). The grid points are then picked by an equidistant grid (number of
1239     points set by [[nfreqim]]) in the interval  $z \subset [0,1]$. This grid can
1240     easily be uniquely converged by just increasing [[nfreqim]]. Again the points
1241     are distributed so that approximately half of them lie below the plasma
1242     frequency.
1243     
1244       * **User defined** - The user can also define their own grid using the variables [[cd_customnimfrqs]] and [[cd_imfrqs]].
1245         _With great power comes great responsibility!_
1246     
1247     The **Mrgscr** utility is handy in optimising the numerical effort expended in
1248     convergence studies. By estimating the densest grid one can afford to
1249     calculate in the SCR file, and successively removing frequencies from a single
1250     file (using the utility), one only needs to perform the screening calculation
1251     **once** on the dense mesh for a given convergence study. One can also use the
1252     utility to merge independent screening calculations over q-points and
1253     frequency sections.
1254     """,
1255     ),
1256     
1257     Variable(
1258         abivarname="cd_full_grid",
1259         varset="gw",
1260         vartype="integer",
1261         topics=['FrequencyMeshMBPT_expert'],
1262         dimensions="scalar",
1263         defaultval=0,
1264         mnemonics="Contour Deformation FULL GRID in complex plane",
1265         requires="[[optdriver]] == 3 and [[gwcalctyp]] in [2, 9, 12, 19, 22, 29]",
1266         text="""
1267     [[cd_full_grid]] enables the calculation of the screening [both chi0 and
1268     epsilon^(-1)] on a grid in the first quadrant of the complex plane. The grid
1269     is determined by the (tensor) product of the grid in real frequency and the
1270     grid in imaginary frequency. In the SUS and SCR files the grid points are
1271     stored as follows:
1272     
1273           **Index:**
1274           1   . . .   nfreqre   nfrqre+1 . . . nfreqre+nfreqim   nfreqre+nfreqim+1 . . . nfreqre*nfreqim
1275           **Entry:**
1276           | purely real freq.  |     purely imaginary freq.     |      gridpoints in complex plane        |
1277     
1278     
1279     The grid in the complex plane is stored looping over the real dimension as the
1280     inner loop and the imaginary as the outer loop. The contents of the generated
1281     SUS and SCR files can be extracted for visualisation and further analysis with
1282     the **Mrgscr** utility.
1283     """,
1284     ),
1285     
1286     Variable(
1287         abivarname="cd_halfway_freq",
1288         varset="gw",
1289         vartype="real",
1290         topics=['FrequencyMeshMBPT_expert'],
1291         dimensions="scalar",
1292         defaultval=ValueWithUnit(units='eV', value=100.0),
1293         mnemonics="Contour Deformation tangent grid HALFWAY FREQuency",
1294         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
1295         requires="([[optdriver]] == 3 or [[optdriver]] == 4) and [[gwcalctyp]] in [2,9,12,19,22,29]",
1296         text="""
1297     [[cd_halfway_freq]] determines the frequency where half of the number of
1298     points defined in [[nfreqre]] are used up. The tangent transformed grid is
1299     approximately linear up to this point. To be used in conjunction with [[gw_frqre_tangrid]].
1300     """,
1301     ),
1302     
1303     Variable(
1304         abivarname="cd_imfrqs",
1305         varset="gw",
1306         vartype="real",
1307         topics=['FrequencyMeshMBPT_expert'],
1308         dimensions=['[[cd_customnimfrqs]]'],
1309         mnemonics="Contour Deformation IMaginary FReQuencieS",
1310         requires="[[optdriver]] == 3 and [[gwcalctyp]] in [2,9,12,19,22,29] and [[cd_customnimfrqs]] != 0",
1311         text="""
1312     [[cd_imfrqs]] specifies the grid points for the imaginary axis. The number of
1313     frequencies is set by the value of [[cd_customnimfrqs]]. For example,
1314     
1315         cd_customnimfrqs   5
1316         nfreqim            5
1317         cd_imfrqs          0.1  0.2  0.5  1.0  5.0
1318     
1319     If [[nfreqim]] is not equal to [[cd_customnimfrqs]] a warning will be issued.
1320     
1321     **Use at own risk!** The use of a custom grid makes it your responsibility
1322     that the SUS and SCR files are valid in self-energy (i.e. [[optdriver]] = 4)
1323     calculations, so caution is advised. Note that frequencies have to be strictly
1324     increasing, and the point at zero frequency is **not** considered to be part
1325     of the imaginary grid, but rather the grid along the real axis. The
1326     calculation of that point should be controlled by [[nfreqre]] and related variables.
1327     """,
1328     ),
1329     
1330     Variable(
1331         abivarname="cd_max_freq",
1332         varset="gw",
1333         vartype="real",
1334         topics=['FrequencyMeshMBPT_expert'],
1335         dimensions="scalar",
1336         defaultval=ValueWithUnit(units='eV', value=1000.0),
1337         mnemonics="Contour Deformation grid MAXimum FREQuency",
1338         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
1339         requires="([[optdriver]] == 3 or [[optdriver]] == 4) and [[gwcalctyp]] in [2,9,12,19,22,29]",
1340         text="""
1341     [[cd_max_freq]] determines the frequency where all the points defined in
1342     [[nfreqre]] are used up. To be used in conjunction with [[gw_frqre_tangrid]].
1343     """,
1344     ),
1345     
1346     Variable(
1347         abivarname="cd_subset_freq",
1348         varset="gw",
1349         vartype="integer",
1350         topics=['FrequencyMeshMBPT_expert'],
1351         dimensions=[2],
1352         defaultval=[1, '[[nfreqre]]'],
1353         mnemonics="Contour Deformation grid calculate SUBSET of FREQuencies",
1354         requires="[[optdriver]] == 3 and [[gwcalctyp]] in [2,9,12,19,22,29] and  [[gw_frqre_tangrid]] == 0",
1355         text="""
1356     [[cd_subset_freq]] Specifies that only a subset of the frequencies defined by
1357     [[nfreqre]] are to be calculated. The first index is the start and the second
1358     the end, with index number 1 always being the origin. For example a
1359     calculation with **[[nfreqre]] = 100** could be separated into two datasets with:
1360     
1361         subset_freq1   1   50
1362         subset_freq2   51  100
1363     
1364     Any resulting susceptibility (_SUS) and screening (_SCR) files can then be
1365     merged with the **mrgscr** utility.
1366     """,
1367     ),
1368     
1369     Variable(
1370         abivarname="charge",
1371         varset="gstate",
1372         vartype="real",
1373         topics=['Coulomb_basic'],
1374         dimensions="scalar",
1375         defaultval=0,
1376         mnemonics="CHARGE",
1377         text="""
1378     Used to establish charge balance between the number of electrons filling the
1379     bands and the nominal [[charge]] associated with the atomic cores.
1380     The code adds up the number of valence electrons provided by the
1381     pseudopotentials of each type (call this "zval"), then add [[charge]], to get
1382     the number of electrons per unit cell, [[nelect]].
1383     Then, if [[iscf]] is positive, the code adds up the band occupancies (given in
1384     array [[occ]]) for all bands at each k point, then multiplies by the k point
1385     weight [[wtk]] at each k point. Call this sum "nelect_occ" (for the number of
1386     electrons from occupation numbers). It is then required that: nelect_occ = [[nelect]].
1387     To treat a neutral system, which is desired in nearly all cases, one must use
1388     [[charge]] = 0. To treat a system missing one electron per unit cell, set [[charge]] = +1.
1389     """,
1390     ),
1391     
1392     Variable(
1393         abivarname="chempot",
1394         varset="geo",
1395         vartype="real",
1396         topics=['Artificial_expert'],
1397         dimensions=[3, '[[nzchempot]]', '[[ntypat]]'],
1398         defaultval=0.0,
1399         mnemonics="spatially varying CHEMical POTential",
1400         requires="[[nzchempot]] /= 0",
1401         text="""
1402     For each type of atoms, from 1 to [[ntypat]], specifies the spatially varying
1403     chemical potential, through the specification of [[nzchempot]] triplets of
1404     real numbers. They give data for [[nzchempot]] delimiting planes, all parallel
1405     to each other, each determined by its z reduced coordinate.
1406     
1407     The first real number is the z reduced coordinate of the delimiting plane.
1408     The second real number is the value of the chemical potential for this type of atom on this
1409     plane. The third real number is the derivative of the chemical potential for
1410     this type of atom with respect to the z reduced coordinate, evaluated on this plane.
1411     
1412     In the space between delimiting planes, a piecewise cubic polynomial
1413     interpolation is determined: the cubic polynomial between two delimiting
1414     planes will have the imposed chemical potentials and derivatives on the two
1415     delimiting planes. The z reduced coordinates must be ordered in increasing
1416     values, and cannot span more than 1.0. There is an automatic periodic
1417     boundary condition imposed. Specifying two identical z reduced coordinates is
1418     allowed, and means that the first one applies to the adjacent space with lower
1419     values of z, while the second applies to the adjacent space with higher values
1420     of z. When the spatial chemical potential is defined only for one type of atom
1421     (and no chemical potential is present for the other atoms), simply set the
1422     related values to *0.0 in the [[chempot]] array. In the present input array,
1423     reduced positions, energies and derivatives of energies are mixed. Hence,
1424     although the chemical potential is an energy, one cannot use the usual energy
1425     definitions (i.e. the chemical potential is always to be input in Hartree atomic units).
1426     """,
1427     ),
1428     
1429     Variable(
1430         abivarname="chkdilatmx",
1431         varset="rlx",
1432         vartype="integer",
1433         topics=['GeoOpt_expert'],
1434         dimensions="scalar",
1435         defaultval=1,
1436         mnemonics="CHecK DILATMX",
1437         text="""
1438     If 0, the code will not stop execution if the threshold of [[dilatmx]] is exceeded,
1439     it will simply issue a warning. There will be no rescaling. If 1, after tentative
1440     rescaling as described in [[dilatmx]], the code will stop execution.
1441     Also, the use of [[chkdilatmx]] = 0 allows one to set [[dilatmx]] to a larger value than 1.15 ,
1442     otherwise forbidden as being a waste of CPU and memory.
1443     """,
1444     ),
1445     
1446     Variable(
1447         abivarname="chkexit",
1448         varset="gstate",
1449         vartype="integer",
1450         topics=['Control_useful'],
1451         dimensions="scalar",
1452         defaultval=0,
1453         mnemonics="CHecK whether the user want to EXIT",
1454         text="""
1455     If [[chkexit]] is 1 or 2, ABINIT will check whether the user wants to
1456     interrupt the run (using the keyword "exit" on the top of the input file or
1457     creating a file named "abinit.exit": see the end of section 3.2
1458     of the [[help:abinit#parameters]]).
1459     
1460       * If [[chkexit]] = 0, the check is not performed at all
1461       * If [[chkexit]] = 1, the check is not performed frequently (after each SCF step)
1462       * If [[chkexit]] = 2, the check is performed frequently (after a few bands, at each k point)
1463     
1464     In all cases, the check is performed at most every 2 seconds of CPU time.
1465     """,
1466     ),
1467     
1468     Variable(
1469         abivarname="chkprim",
1470         varset="gstate",
1471         vartype="integer",
1472         topics=['crystal_useful', 'UnitCell_useful', 'SmartSymm_useful'],
1473         dimensions="scalar",
1474         defaultval=1,
1475         mnemonics="CHecK whether the cell is PRIMitive",
1476         text="""
1477     If the symmetry finder is used (see [[nsym]]), a non-zero value of [[chkprim]]
1478     will make the code stop if a non-primitive cell is used. If [[chkprim]] = 0, a
1479     warning is issued, but the run does not stop.
1480     
1481     If you are generating the atomic and cell geometry using [[spgroup]], you
1482     might generate a PRIMITIVE cell using [[brvltt]] = -1.
1483     """,
1484     ),
1485     
1486     Variable(
1487         abivarname="chksymbreak",
1488         varset="gstate",
1489         vartype="integer",
1490         topics=['k-points_basic'],
1491         dimensions="scalar",
1492         defaultval=1,
1493         mnemonics="CHecK SYMmetry BREAKing",
1494         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
1495         text="""
1496     This variable governs the behaviour of the code when there are potential
1497     source of symmetry breaking, related e.g. to the k point grid or the presence
1498     of non-symmorphic translations which might not be coherent with the exchange-
1499     correlation grid.
1500     
1501     When [[chksymbreak]] = 1, the code stops (or issue a warning) if:
1502     
1503       * (1) The k point grid is non-symmetric, in case [[kptopt]] =1, 2, or 4;
1504       * (2) The non-symmorphic translation part of the symmetry operations has components that are not zero,
1505         or simple fractions, with 2, 3, 4, 6, 8 or 12 as denominators.
1506     
1507     When [[chksymbreak]] = 0, there is no such check.
1508     
1509     When [[chksymbreak]] = -1, the code stops if the condition (1) is met,
1510     but in case the condition (2) is met, there will be a trial to shift the
1511     atomic coordinates such as to obtain symmetry operations with the adequate non-symmorphic part.
1512     
1513     Explanation:
1514     In the ground-state calculation, such breaking of the symmetry is usually
1515     harmless. However, if the user is doing a calculation of phonons using DFPT
1516     ([[rfphon]] = 1), the convergence with respect to the number of k points will be
1517     much worse with a non-symmetric grid than with a symmetric one. Also, if the
1518     user is doing a GW calculation, the presence of non-symmorphic translations
1519     that are not coherent with the FFT grid might cause problems. In the GW part,
1520     indeed, one needs to reconstruct the wavefunctions in the full Brillouin zone
1521     for calculating both the polarizability and the self-energy. The wavefunctions
1522     in the full Brillouin zone are obtained from the irreducible wedge by applying
1523     the symmetry operations of the space group of the crystal. In the present
1524     implementation, the symmetrisation of the wavefunctions is done in real space
1525     on the FFT mesh that, therefore, has to be coherent both with the rotational
1526     part as well as with the fractional translation of each symmetry operation. If
1527     the condition (2) is met, the GW code will not be able to find a symmetry
1528     preserving FFT mesh.
1529     
1530     So, it was decided to warn the user about these possible problems already at
1531     the level of the ground state calculations, although such warning might be irrelevant.
1532     
1533     If you encounter a problem outlined above, you have two choices: change your
1534     atomic positions (translate them) such that the origin appears as the most
1535     symmetric point; or ignore the problem, and set [[chksymbreak]] = 0.
1536     """,
1537     ),
1538     
1539     Variable(
1540         abivarname="chneut",
1541         varset="eph",
1542         vartype="integer",
1543         topics=['Phonons_useful'],
1544         dimensions="scalar",
1545         defaultval=0,
1546         mnemonics="CHarge NEUTrality treatment",
1547         text="""
1548     Set the treatment of the Charge Neutrality requirement for the effective charges.
1549     Same meaning as the corresponding anaddb variable.
1550     """,
1551     ),
1552     
1553     Variable(
1554         abivarname="cineb_start",
1555         varset="rlx",
1556         vartype="integer",
1557         topics=['TransPath_expert'],
1558         dimensions="scalar",
1559         defaultval=7,
1560         mnemonics="Climbing-Image Nudged Elastic Band: STARTing iteration",
1561         requires="[[imgmov]] == 5 and [[neb_algo]] == 2",
1562         text="""
1563     Gives the index of the first CI-NEB iteration.
1564     The CI-NEB method constitutes a small modification to the NEB method allowing
1565     a rigorous convergence to the saddle point. As the image with the highest
1566     energy has to be identified, the calculation begins with several iterations of
1567     the standard NEB algorithm. The effective CI-NEB begins at the [[cineb_start]]
1568     iteration. See [[cite:Henkelman2000a]] for additional details of this method.
1569     """,
1570     ),
1571     
1572     Variable(
1573         abivarname="cpuh",
1574         varset="gstate",
1575         vartype="real",
1576         topics=['Control_useful'],
1577         dimensions="scalar",
1578         defaultval=0.0,
1579         mnemonics="CPU time limit in Hours",
1580         characteristics=['[[NO_MULTI]]', '[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
1581         excludes="[[cpum]] or [[cpus]]",
1582         text="""
1583     Only one of the three real parameters [[cpus]], [[cpum]] and [[cpuh]] can be
1584     defined in the input file to set up a CPU time limit. When the job reaches
1585     that limit, it will try to end smoothly. However, note that this might still
1586     take some time. If the user want a firm CPU time limit, the present parameter
1587     must be reduced sufficiently. Intuition about the actual margin to be taken
1588     into account should come with experience.
1589     A zero value has no action of the job.
1590     
1591     !!! tip
1592     
1593         One can pass the timelimit to abinit via the command line option:
1594     
1595             abinit --timelimit hours:minutes:seconds
1596     
1597         This approach is much more powerful especially when the job must be submitted
1598         to the queue via a submission script e.g. a Slurm script.
1599         In this case, indeed, one can define a shell variable for the time limit
1600         and use this variable to pass the time limit to Slurm and Abinit at the same time.
1601     
1602         Use `abinit --help` for further information.
1603     """,
1604     ),
1605     
1606     Variable(
1607         abivarname="cpum",
1608         varset="gstate",
1609         vartype="real",
1610         topics=['Control_useful'],
1611         dimensions="scalar",
1612         defaultval=0.0,
1613         mnemonics="CPU time limit in Minutes",
1614         characteristics=['[[NO_MULTI]]', '[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
1615         excludes="[[cpuh]] or [[cpus]]",
1616         text="""
1617     Only one of the three real parameters [[cpus]], [[cpum]] and [[cpuh]] can be
1618     defined in the input file to set up a CPU time limit. When the job reaches
1619     that limit, it will try to end smoothly. However, note that this might still
1620     take some time. If the user want a firm CPU time limit, the present parameter
1621     must be reduced sufficiently. Intuition about the actual margin to be taken
1622     into account should come with experience.
1623     A zero value has no action of the job.
1624     """,
1625     ),
1626     
1627     Variable(
1628         abivarname="cpus",
1629         varset="gstate",
1630         vartype="real",
1631         topics=['Control_useful'],
1632         dimensions="scalar",
1633         defaultval=0.0,
1634         mnemonics="CPU time limit in seconds",
1635         characteristics=['[[NO_MULTI]]', '[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
1636         excludes="[[cpuh]] or [[cpum]]",
1637         text="""
1638     Only one of the three real parameters [[cpus]], [[cpum]] and [[cpuh]] can be
1639     defined in the input file to set up a CPU time limit. When the job reaches
1640     that limit, it will try to end smoothly. However, note that this might still
1641     take some time. If the user want a firm CPU time limit, the present parameter
1642     must be reduced sufficiently. Intuition about the actual margin to be taken
1643     into account should come with experience...
1644     A zero value has no action of the job.
1645     """,
1646     ),
1647     
1648     Variable(
1649         abivarname="d3e_pert1_atpol",
1650         varset="dfpt",
1651         vartype="integer",
1652         topics=['nonlinear_basic'],
1653         dimensions=[2],
1654         defaultval=[1, 1],
1655         mnemonics="3rd Derivative of Energy, mixed PERTurbation 1: limits of ATomic POLarisations",

1657         text="""
1658     Controls the range of atoms for which displacements will be considered in non-
1659     linear computations (using the 2n+1 theorem), for the 1st perturbation.
1660     May take values from 1 to [[natom]], with **d3e_pert1_atpol** (1)<=

1850     Variable(
1851         abivarname="ddamp",
1852         varset="ffield",
1853         vartype="real",
1854         topics=['Berry_useful'],
1855         dimensions="scalar",
1856         defaultval=0.1,
1857         mnemonics="electric Displacement field DAMPing parameter",
1858         requires="[[berryopt]] in [6, 16]",
1859         text="""
1860     In case [[berryopt]] = 6, the electric field is updated after each SCF iteration
1861     according to $E_{n+1}=$[[ddamp]]$(D-4 \pi P_{n})+(1-$[[ddamp]]$)E_{n}$, where
1862     $P_{n}$ and $E_{n}$ are the polarization and electric field after $n_{th}$ SCF
1863     iteration. [[ddamp]] is a damping parameter used to control the convergence speed.
1864     In case [[berryopt]] = 16, the electric field is updated after each SCF
1865     iteration according to $e_{n+1}=$[[ddamp]]$(d-p_{n})+(1-$[[ddamp]]$)e_{n}$.
1866     If you have difficulty getting convergence, try to reduce this value or reduce
1867     maxestep. This parameter is used in finite electric displacement field
1868     calculations (berryopt=6,16,17).
1869     """,
1870     ),
1871     
1872     Variable(
1873         abivarname="ddb_ngqpt",
1874         varset="eph",
1875         vartype="integer",
1876         topics=['ElPhonInt_expert'],
1877         dimensions=[3],
1878         defaultval=[0, 0, 0],
1879         mnemonics="Derivative DataBase: Number of Grid points for Q-PoinTs",
1880         text="""
1881     This variable is mandatory when [[optdriver]] == 7. It defines the number of
1882     divisions in the (homogeneous) q-mesh used to generate the DDB file. See also
1883     the description of the [[getddb]] input variable.

1897     to generate the DDB file, which is defined by the [[ddb_ngqpt]] input
1898     variable. See [[shiftk]] for more information on the definition.

1901     
1902     Variable(
1903         abivarname="delayperm",
1904         varset="rlx",
1905         vartype="integer",
1906         topics=['MolecularDynamics_expert'],
1907         dimensions="scalar",
1908         defaultval=0,
1909         mnemonics="DELAY between trials to PERMUTE atoms",
1910         text="""
1911     Delay (number of time steps) between trials to permute two atoms, in view of
1912     accelerated search of minima. Still in development.
1913     
1914     See the routine moldyn.F90 and [[signperm]] for additional information.
1915     
1916     When [[delayperm]] is zero, there are no permutation trials.
1917     """,
1918     ),
1919     
1920     Variable(
1921         abivarname="densfor_pred",
1922         varset="dev",
1923         vartype="integer",
1924         topics=['SCFAlgorithms_expert', 'MolecularDynamics_expert'],
1925         dimensions="scalar",
1926         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[paral_kgb]] == 1': '6', 'defaultval': 2}),
1927         mnemonics="DENSity and FORces PREDictor",
1928         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
1929         requires="[[iscf]] > 0",
1930         text=r"""
1931     Used when [[iscf]] > 0, to define:
1932     
1933       - the way a change of density is derived from a change of atomic position,
1934       - the way forces are corrected when the SCF cycle is not converged.
1935     
1936     Supported values:
1937     
1938       * 0 --> density not changed (fixed charge), forces not corrected
1939       * 1 --> density not changed, forces corrected with rigid ion hypothesis (atomic charge moved with atom)
1940       * 2 --> density changed and forces corrected with rigid ion hypothesis (atomic charge moves with atom)
1941       * 3 --> density changed and forces corrected with a different implementation of the rigid ion hypothesis
1942       * 4 --> density not changed, forces corrected with the use of Harris functional formula (see note)
1943       * 5 --> density changed using D. Alfe 2nd-order algorithm (see notes), forces not corrected
1944       * 6 --> density changed using D. Alfe 2nd-order algorithm (see notes) and forces corrected with the use of Harris functional formula
1945     
1946     Similar negative values are also allowed (see the meaning later), for
1947     development purposes only. No meaning for RF calculations.
1948     
1949     For the time being,
1950     
1951       - [[densfor_pred]] = 3 must be used with [[ionmov]] = 4 and [[iscf]] = 5.
1952       - [[densfor_pred]] = 4, 5 or 6 must be used when band-FFT parallelism is selected.
1953       Otherwise, use [[densfor_pred]] = 2
1954     
1955     
1956     !!! note "concerning the correction of forces (use of [[densfor_pred]] = 1, 2, 3, 4 or 6)"
1957         The force on the atom located at R is corrected by the addition of the following
1958         term: $F_{residual}=\int dr V_{residual} \frac{d \rho_{atomic}}{dR}$,
1959         where $\rho_{atomic}$ is an atomic (spherical) density.
1960     
1961         - When such an atomic density ($\rho_{atomic}$) is found in the pseudopotential or
1962         PAW file, it is used. If not, a gaussian density (defined by [[densty]] parameter) is used.
1963         - When SCF mixing is done on the density ([[iscf]] >= 10), the potential
1964         residual ($V_residual$) is obtained from the density residual with the first
1965         order formula $V_{residual}=\frac{dV}{d \rho} \rho_{residual}$
1966         and uses the exchange-correlation kernel
1967         $ \frac{dV_{xc}}{d\rho}=K_{xc}$ whose computation is time-consuming for GGA
1968         functionals. By default (positive values of [[densfor_pred]]), the local-
1969         density part of the GGA exchange-correlation kernel is used (even for GGA, for
1970         which it seems to give a reasonable accuracy). Using the full GGA exchange
1971         correlation kernel (so, including derivatives with respect to the gradient of
1972         the density) is always possible by giving a negative value to
1973         [[densfor_pred]]. In case of hybrid functionals, a similar correction term is
1974         added, although in the density mixing scheme, the related GGA kernel is used
1975         instead of the hybrid functional kernel.
1976     
1977     !!! note "concerning the use of [[densfor_pred]] = 5 or 6 (density prediction)"
1978         The algorithm is described in [[cite:Alfe1999]].
1979         It uses an atomic (spherical) density. When such an atomic density
1980         is found in the pseudopotential or PAW file, it is used. If not, a gaussian
1981         density (defined by [[densty]] parameter) is used.
1982         Also note that, to be efficient, this algorithm requires a minimum convergence
1983         of the SCF cycle; Typically, vres2 (or nres2) has to be small enough (10  -4 ...10 -5  ).
1984     """,
1985     ),
1986     
1987     Variable(
1988         abivarname="densty",
1989         varset="dev",
1990         vartype="real",
1991         topics=['xc_expert'],
1992         dimensions=['[[ntypat]]'],
1993         defaultval=0.0,
1994         mnemonics="initial DENSity for each TYpe of atom",
1995         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
1996         text="""
1997     Gives a rough description of the initial GS density, for each type of atom.
1998     This value is only used to create the first exchange and correlation
1999     potential, and is not used anymore afterwards. For the time being, it
2000     corresponds to an average radius (a.u.) of the density, and is used to
2001     generate a gaussian density. If set to 0.0d0, an optimized value is used.
2002     No meaning for RF calculations.
2003     """,
2004     ),
2005     
2006     Variable(
2007         abivarname="dfield",
2008         varset="ffield",
2009         vartype="real",
2010         topics=['Berry_basic'],
2011         dimensions=[3],
2012         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=3, value=0.0),
2013         mnemonics="Displacement FIELD",
2014         requires="[[berryopt]] == 6 and [[efield]]",
2015         text="""
2016     In case [[berryopt]] = 6, [[dfield]] specifies the (unreduced) finite electric
2017     displacement field vector, in atomic units, that is to be imposed as a
2018     constraint during the calculation.
2019     """,
2020     ),
2021     
2022     Variable(
2023         abivarname="dfpt_sciss",
2024         varset="dfpt",
2025         vartype="real",
2026         topics=['DFPT_useful'],
2027         dimensions="scalar",
2028         defaultval=0,
2029         mnemonics="DFPT SCISSor operator",
2030         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
2031         text="""
2032     It is the value of the "scissors operator", the shift of conduction band
2033     eigenvalues, used in response function calculations.
2034     Can be specified in Ha (the default), Ry, eV or Kelvin, since [[ecut]] has the
2035     '[[ENERGY]]' characteristics (1 Ha=27.2113845 eV).
2036     Typical use is for response to electric field ([[rfelfd]] = 3), but NOT for d/dk
2037     ([[rfelfd]] = 2) and phonon responses.
2038     """,
2039     ),
2040     
2041     Variable(
2042         abivarname="diecut",
2043         varset="gstate",
2044         vartype="real",
2045         topics=['SCFAlgorithms_expert'],
2046         dimensions="scalar",
2047         defaultval=2.2,
2048         mnemonics="DIElectric matrix energy CUToff",
2049         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
2050         text="""
2051     Kinetic energy cutoff that controls the number of planewaves used to represent
2052     the dielectric matrix:
2053     $(1/2) [ 2 \pi \GG_{diel,max}]^2$ =[[diecut]] with $\GG_{diel,max}$ being the maximum
2054     length of the reciprocal space planewave wavevectors for the dielectric matrix.
2055     Can be specified in Ha (the default), Ry, eV or Kelvin, since [[diecut]] has
2056     the '[[ENERGY]]' characteristics. (1 Ha=27.2113845 eV)
2057     All planewaves inside this "basis sphere" centered at $\GG$=0 are included in the
2058     basis. This is useful only when [[iprcel]] > =21, which means that a
2059     preconditioning scheme based on the dielectric matrix is used.
2060     
2061     NOTE: a negative [[diecut]] will define the same dielectric basis sphere as
2062     the corresponding positive value, but the FFT grid will be identical to the
2063     one used for the wavefunctions. The much smaller FFT grid, used when
2064     [[diecut]] is positive, gives exactly the same results.\n
2065     No meaning for RF calculations yet.
2066     """,
2067     ),
2068     
2069     Variable(
2070         abivarname="diegap",
2071         varset="gstate",
2072         vartype="real",
2073         topics=['SCFAlgorithms_expert'],
2074         dimensions="scalar",
2075         defaultval=0.1,
2076         mnemonics="DIElectric matrix GAP",
2077         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
2078         text="""
2079     Gives a rough estimation of the dielectric gap between the highest energy
2080     level computed in the run, and the set of bands not represented. Used to
2081     extrapolate dielectric matrix when [[iprcel]] >= 21.
2082     Can be specified in Ha (the default), Ry, eV or Kelvin, since [[diegap]] has
2083     the '[[ENERGY]]' characteristics. (1 Ha=27.2113845 eV).\n
2084     No meaning for RF calculations yet.
2085     """,
2086     ),
2087     
2088     Variable(
2089         abivarname="dielam",
2090         varset="gstate",
2091         vartype="real",
2092         topics=['SCFAlgorithms_expert'],
2093         dimensions="scalar",
2094         defaultval=0.5,
2095         mnemonics="DIElectric matrix LAMbda",
2096         requires="[[iprcel]] >= 21",
2097         text="""
2098     Gives the amount of occupied states with mean energy given by the highest
2099     level computed in the run, included in the extrapolation of the dielectric matrix.\n
2100     No meaning for RF calculations yet.
2101     """,
2102     ),
2103     
2104     Variable(
2105         abivarname="dielng",
2106         varset="gstate",
2107         vartype="real",
2108         topics=['SCFAlgorithms_useful'],
2109         dimensions="scalar",
2110         defaultval="1.0774841d0",
2111         mnemonics="model DIElectric screening LeNGth",
2112         characteristics=['[[LENGTH]]'],
2113         text=r"""
2114     Used for screening length (in Bohr) of the model dielectric function, diagonal
2115     in reciprocal space. By default, given in Bohr atomic units (1
2116     Bohr=0.5291772108 Angstrom), although Angstrom can be specified, if preferred,
2117     since [[dielng]] has the '[[LENGTH]]' characteristics.
2118     This model dielectric function is as follows ($\kk$ being a wavevector):
2119     \begin{equation}
2120     diel(\kk) = \frac{ 1 + [[dielng]]^2 \kk^2 }{ \left( 1/[[diemac]] + [[dielng]]^2 \kk^2  \right) [[diemix]] } \nonumber
2121     \end{equation}
2122     
2123     The inverse of this model dielectric function will be applied to the residual,
2124     to give the preconditioned change of potential. Right at $\kk$=0, $diel(\kk)$ is imposed to be 1.
2125     
2126     If the preconditioning were perfect, the change of potential would lead to an
2127     exceedingly fast solution of the self-consistency problem (two or three
2128     steps). The present model dielectric function is excellent for rather
2129     homogeneous unit cells.
2130     When $\kk$->0, it tends to the macroscopic dielectric constant, eventually
2131     divided by the mixing factor [[diemix]] (or [[diemixmag]]  for magnetization).
2132     For metals, simply put [[diemac]] to a very large value ($10^6$ is OK)
2133     The screening length [[dielng]] governs the length scale to go from the
2134     macroscopic regime to the microscopic regime, where it is known that the
2135     dielectric function should tend to 1. It is on the order of 1 Bohr for metals
2136     with medium density of states at the Fermi level, like Molybdenum, and for
2137     Silicon. For metals with a larger DOS at the Fermi level (like Iron), the
2138     screening will be more effective, so that [[dielng]] has to be decreased by a factor of 2-4.
2139     This works for GS and RF calculations.
2140     """,
2141     ),
2142     
2143     Variable(
2144         abivarname="diemac",
2145         varset="gstate",
2146         vartype="real",
2147         topics=['SCFAlgorithms_useful'],
2148         dimensions="scalar",
2149         defaultval=1000000.0,
2150         mnemonics="model DIElectric MACroscopic constant",
2151         text="""
2152     A rough knowledge of the macroscopic dielectric constant [[diemac]] of the
2153     system is a useful help to speed-up the SCF procedure: a model dielectric
2154     function, see the keyword [[dielng]], is used for that purpose. It is
2155     especially useful for speeding up the treatment of rather homogeneous unit cells.
2156     
2157     Some hint:
2158     The value of [[diemac]] should usually be bigger than 1.0, on physical grounds.
2159     
2160       * For metals, simply put [[diemac]] to a very large value (the default $10^6$ is OK)
2161       * For silicon, use 12.0. A similar value is likely to work well for other semiconductors
2162       * For wider gap insulators, use 2.0 ... 4.0
2163       * For molecules in an otherwise empty big box, try 1.5 ... 3.0
2164     
2165     Systems that combine a highly polarisable part and some vacuum are rather
2166     badly treated by the model dielectric function. One has to use the
2167     "extrapolar" technique, activated by the input variable [[iprcel]].
2168     In sufficiently homogeneous systems, you might have to experiment a bit to
2169     find the best [[diemac]]. If you let [[diemac]] to its default value, you
2170     might even never obtain the self-consistent convergence !
2171     For response function calculations, use the same values as for GS. The
2172     improvement in speed can be considerable for small (but non-zero) values of the wavevector.
2173     """,
2174     ),
2175     
2176     Variable(
2177         abivarname="diemix",
2178         varset="gstate",
2179         vartype="real",
2180         topics=['SCFAlgorithms_useful'],
2181         dimensions="scalar",
2182         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[usepaw]] == 0 or [[iprcel]] !=0': 1.0,
2183      '[[usepaw]] == 1 or [[iprcel]] == 0': 0.7,
2184      'defaultval': None}),
2185         mnemonics="model DIElectric MIXing factor",
2186         requires="[[diemix]] >= 0.0 and [[diemix]] <=  1.0",
2187         text="""
2188     Gives overall factor of the preconditioned residual density/potential to be
2189     transferred in the SCF cycle.
2190     It should be between 0.0 and 1.0.
2191     
2192     If the model dielectric function were perfect, [[diemix]] should be 1.0. By
2193     contrast, if the model dielectric function does nothing (when [[diemac]] = 1.0
2194     or [[dielng]] is larger than the size of the cell), [[diemix]] can be used to
2195     damp the amplifying factor inherent to the SCF loop.
2196     For molecules, a value on the order 0.5 or 0.33 is rather usual.
2197     When mod([[iscf]],10)=3, 4,5 or 7, [[diemix]] is only important at the few
2198     first iterations when anharmonic effects are important, since these schemes
2199     compute their own mixing factor for self-consistency.
2200     Also note that a different value of diemix can be used for the magnetization
2201     (see [[diemixmag]]).
2202     """,
2203     ),
2204     
2205     Variable(
2206         abivarname="diemixmag",
2207         varset="gstate",
2208         vartype="real",
2209         topics=['spinpolarisation_useful'],
2210         dimensions="scalar",
2211         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'70 < [[iprcel]] and [[iprcel]] < 80': '[[diemix]]',
2212      '[[iprcel]] == 0': '[[diemix]]',
2213      '[[iscf]]<10': '[[diemix]]',
2214      'defaultval': '-[[diemix]]'}),
2215         mnemonics="model DIElectric MIXing factor for the MAGgnetization",
2216         text="""
2217     Gives overall factor of the preconditioned residual magnetization/magnetic
2218     field to be transferred in the SCF cycle (see [[diemix]] for further
2219     information).
2220     For the time being, apply only when the SCF mixing is done on the density ([[iscf]] > =10).
2221     
2222     A negative value of [[diemixmag]] means that magnetization is only preconditionned
2223     by ABS([[diemixmag]]), without the use of any preconditionner.
2224     
2225     When SCF cycle has some difficulties to converge, changing the value of
2226     [[diemixmag]] can have a positive effect.
2227     In particular [[diemixmag]] = -4 is a good choice (i.e. [[diemixmag]] = 4, no other
2228     preconditionner on magnetization).
2229     """,
2230     ),
2231     
2232     Variable(
2233         abivarname="diismemory",
2234         varset="rlx",
2235         vartype="integer",
2236         topics=['MolecularDynamics_expert'],
2237         dimensions="scalar",
2238         defaultval=8,
2239         mnemonics="Direct Inversion in the Iterative Subspace MEMORY",
2240         text="""
2241     Gives the maximum number of "time" steps for which the forces and stresses are
2242     stored, and taken into account in the DIIS algorithm ([[ionmov]] = 20) to find
2243     zero-force and stress configurations.
2244     """,
2245     ),
2246     
2247     Variable(
2248         abivarname="dilatmx",
2249         varset="rlx",
2250         vartype="real",
2251         topics=['GeoOpt_basic'],
2252         dimensions="scalar",
2253         defaultval=1.0,
2254         mnemonics="lattice DILATation: MaXimal value",
2255         text="""
2256     [[dilatmx]] is an auxiliary variable used to book additional memory (see detailed description later) for possible
2257     on-the-flight variations the plane wave basis set, due to cell optimization by ABINIT.
2258     Useful only when [[ionmov]] == 2 and [[optcell]]/=0, that is, cell optimization.
2259     
2260     In the default mode ([[chkdilatmx]] = 1), when the [[dilatmx]] threshold is exceeded,
2261     ABINIT will rescale uniformly the
2262     tentative new primitive vectors to a value that leads at most to 90% of the
2263     maximal allowed [[dilatmx]] deviation from 1. It will do this three times (to
2264     prevent the geometry optimization algorithms to have taken a too large trial
2265     step), but afterwards will exit. Setting [[chkdilatmx]] == 0 allows one to
2266     book a larger planewave basis, but will not rescale the tentative new primitive vectors
2267     nor lead to an exit when the [[dilatmx]] threshold is exceeded.
2268     The obtained optimized primitive vectors will not be exactly the ones corresponding to the planewave basis set
2269     determined using [[ecut]] at the latter primitive vectors. Still, as an intermediate step in a geometry search
2270     this might be sufficiently accurate. In such case, [[dilatmx]] might even be let at its default value 1.0.
2271     
2272     Detailed explanation: The memory space for the planewave basis set is defined
2273     by multiplying [[ecut]] by [[dilatmx]] squared (the result is an "effective ecut", called
2274     internally "ecut_eff". Other uses of [[ecut]] are not modified when [[dilatmx]] > 1.0.
2275     Still, operations (like scalar products) are taking into account these fake non-used planewaves,
2276     thus slowing down the ABINIT execution.
2277     Using [[dilatmx]]<1.0 is equivalent to changing [[ecut]] in all its uses. This
2278     is allowed, although its meaning is no longer related to a maximal expected scaling.
2279     
2280     Setting [[dilatmx]] to a large value leads to waste of CPU time and memory.
2281     By default, ABINIT will not accept that you define [[dilatmx]] bigger than 1.15.
2282     This behaviour will be overcome by using [[chkdilatmx]] == 0.
2283     Supposing you think that the optimized [[acell]] values might be 10% larger
2284     than your input values, use simply [[dilatmx]] 1.1. This will already lead to
2285     an increase of the number of planewaves by a factor (1.1)  3  =1.331, and a
2286     corresponding increase in CPU time and memory.
2287     It is possible to use [[dilatmx]] when [[optcell]] =0, but a value larger than
2288     1.0 will be a waste.
2289     """,
2290     ),
2291     
2292     Variable(
2293         abivarname="dipdip",
2294         varset="eph",
2295         vartype="integer",
2296         topics=['Phonons_useful'],
2297         dimensions="scalar",
2298         defaultval=1,
2299         mnemonics="DIPole-DIPole interaction",
2300         text="""
2301     This variable defines the treatment of the dipole-dipole interaction. Same
2302     meaning as the corresponding anaddb variable [[dipdip@anaddb]]
2303     """,
2304     ),
2305     
2306     Variable(
2307         abivarname="dmatpawu",
2308         varset="paw",
2309         vartype="real",
2310         topics=['DFT+U_useful', 'ElecDOS_useful'],
2311         dimensions=['2*max([[lpawu]])+1',
2312      '2*max([[lpawu]])+1',
2313      'max([[nsppol]], [[nspinor]])',
2314      '[[natpawu]]'],
2315         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=None, value=-10.0),
2316         mnemonics="initial Density MATrix for PAW+U",
2317         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1 and [[usepawu]] == 1 and [[usedmatpu]] != 0",
2318         text="""
2319     For Ground state calculations only.
2320     Gives the value of an initial density matrix used in LDA+U and kept fixed
2321     during the first abs([[usedmatpu]]) SCF iterations.
2322     Only components corresponding to [[lpawu]] angular momentum are requested.
2323     Restriction: In order to use dmatpawu, [[lpawu]] must be identical for all atom types (or -1).
2324     
2325     The occupation matrix is in the basis of real spherical harmonics Slm (note
2326     that this differs from the choice made when [[prtdosm]] = 1, that is in the
2327     basis of complex spherical harmonics). They are ordered by increasing m, and
2328     are defined e.g. in [[cite:Blancoa1997]]. For the case l=2 (d states), the five
2329     columns corresponds respectively to (the normalisation factor has been dropped)
2330     
2331       * m=-2, $xy$
2332       * m=-1, $yz$
2333       * m=0, $3z^{2}-r^{2}$
2334       * m=1, $xz$
2335       * m=2, $x^{2}-y^{2}$
2336     
2337     [[dmatpawu]] must always be given as a "spin-up" occupation matrix (and
2338     eventually a "spin-down" matrix). Be aware that its physical meaning depends
2339     on the magnetic properties imposed to the system (with [[nsppol]],
2340     [[nspinor]], [[nspden]]):
2341     
2342       * **Non-magnetic system** ([[nsppol]] = 1, [[nspinor]] = 1, [[nspden]] = 1):
2343     One (2lpawu+1)x(2lpawu+1) [[dmatpawu]] matrix is given for each atom on which
2344     +U is applied.
2345     It contains the "spin-up" occupations.
2346     
2347       * **Ferromagnetic spin-polarized (collinear) system** ([[nsppol]] = 2, [[nspinor]] = 1, [[nspden]] = 2):
2348     Two (2lpawu+1)x(2lpawu+1) [[dmatpawu]] matrices are given for each atom on
2349     which +U is applied.
2350     They contain the "spin-up" and "spin-down" occupations.
2351     
2352       * **Anti-ferromagnetic spin-polarized (collinear) system** ([[nsppol]] = 1, [[nspinor]] = 1, [[nspden]] = 2):
2353     One (2lpawu+1)x(2lpawu+1) [[dmatpawu]] matrix is given for each atom on which
2354     +U is applied.
2355     It contains the "spin-up" occupations.
2356     
2357       * **Non-collinear magnetic system** ([[nsppol]] = 1, [[nspinor]] = 2, [[nspden]] = 4):
2358     Two (2lpawu+1)x(2lpawu+1) [[dmatpawu]] matrices are given for each atom on
2359     which +U is applied.
2360     They contains the "spin-up" and "spin-down" occupations (defined as
2361     n_up=(n+|m|)/2 and n_dn=(n-|m|)/2), where m is the integrated magnetization
2362     vector).
2363     The direction of the magnetization (which is also the direction of n_up and
2364     n_dn) is given by [[spinat]].
2365     _Warning: unlike collinear case, atoms having the same magnetization magnitude
2366     with different directions must be given the same occupation matrix;
2367     the magnetization will be oriented by the value of [[spinat]] (this is the
2368     case for antiferro-magnetism). _
2369     
2370       * **Non-collinear magnetic system with zero magnetization** ([[nsppol]] = 1, [[nspinor]] = 2, [[nspden]] = 1):
2371     Two (2lpawu+1)x(2lpawu+1) [[dmatpawu]] matrices are given for each atom on
2372     which +U is applied.
2373     They contain the "spin-up" and "spin-down" occupations;
2374     But, as "spin-up" and "spin-down" are constrained identical, the "spin-down"
2375     one is ignored by the code.
2376     """,
2377     ),
2378     
2379     Variable(
2380         abivarname="dmatpuopt",
2381         varset="paw",
2382         vartype="integer",
2383         topics=['DFT+U_expert'],
2384         dimensions="scalar",
2385         defaultval=2,
2386         mnemonics="Density MATrix for PAW+U OPTion",
2387         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1 and [[usepawu]] == 1",
2388         text="""
2389     This option governs the way occupations of localized atomic levels are computed:
2390     
2391       * [[dmatpuopt]] = 1: atomic occupations are projections on atomic orbitals (Eq. (6) of [[cite:Amadon2008a]]).
2392     
2393       * [[dmatpuopt]] = 2: atomic occupations are integrated values in PAW spheres of angular-momentum-decomposed charge densities (Eq. (7) of [[cite:Amadon2008a]]).
2394     
2395       * [[dmatpuopt]] = 3: only for tests
2396     
2397       * [[dmatpuopt]] = 4: Extrapolations of occupancies outside the PAW-sphere. This Definition gives normalized operator for occupation.
2398     
2399     In the general case [[dmatpuopt]] = 2 is suitable. The use of [[dmatpuopt]] = 1 is
2400     restricted to PAW datasets in which the first atomic wavefunction of the
2401     correlated subspace is a normalized atomic eigenfunction.
2402     """,
2403     ),
2404     
2405     Variable(
2406         abivarname="dmatudiag",
2407         varset="paw",
2408         vartype="integer",
2409         topics=['DFT+U_expert'],
2410         dimensions="scalar",
2411         defaultval=0,
2412         mnemonics="Density MATrix for paw+U, DIAGonalization",
2413         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1 and [[usepawu]] == 1 and [[nspden]] != 4",
2414         text="""
2415     Relevant only for Ground-State calculations.
2416     This option can be used to diagonalize the occupation matrix Nocc_{m,m_prime}.
2417     Relevant values are:
2418     
2419       * 0: deactivated.
2420       * 1: occupation matrix is diagonalized and printed in log file at each SCF cycle
2421         (eigenvectors are also given in the log file).
2422       * 2: for testing purpose.
2423     """,
2424     ),
2425     
2426     Variable(
2427         abivarname="dmft_dc",
2428         varset="dmft",
2429         vartype="integer",
2430         topics=['DMFT_useful'],
2431         dimensions="scalar",
2432         defaultval=1,
2433         mnemonics="Dynamical Mean Field Theory: Double Counting",
2434         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
2435         text="""
2436     
2437     Value of double counting used for DMFT. Only value 1 is activated for the
2438     moment and is the FLL double counting.
2439     """,
2440     ),

2442     Variable(

2448         defaultval=0,

2451         text="""
2452     If 1, enables the calculation of the entropy within the DMFT framework and so
2453     allows one the calculation of the total energy (free energy). In the current
2454     implementation, this is only possible with [[dmft_solv]] = 5 (Continuous Time
2455     Quantum Monte Carlo). See also the input variable [[dmft_nlambda]].

2457     ),

2499     thermodynamical integration in case of free energy calculation within DMFT.
2500     Its value must be greater or equal to 3.

2504     Variable(
2505         abivarname="dmft_nwli",

2532     Variable(
2533         abivarname="dmft_read_occnd",
2534         varset="dev",
2535         vartype="integer",
2536         topics=['DMFT_expert'],
2537         dimensions="scalar",
2538         defaultval=0,
2539         mnemonics="Dynamical Mean Field Theory: READ OCCupations (Non Diagonal)",
2540         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
2541         text="""
2542     Flag to read/write Occupations as computed in DMFT. This flag is useful to
2543     restart a DFT+DMFT calculation with self-consistency over electronic density.
2544     The occupations are written each time a DMFT loop is finished. So if the
2545     calculation stops because the time limit is reached, this option offers the
2546     possibility to restart the self-consistent loop over density at the point
2547     where it stopped (assuming a restart with the wave functions, see [[getwfk]]).
2548     
2549       * 0 --> Occupations are written but never read.
2550       * 1 --> Occupations are read from I_DMFTOCCND, where I is the root for input files.
2551       * 2 --> Occupations are read from O_DMFTOCCND, where O is the root for output files.
2552     
2553     An alternative and more simple way to restart a DFT+DMFT calculation is to use
2554     the density file (obtained with [[prtden]] = 1 or [[prtden]] = -1) and the self-energy (see [[dmft_rslf]]).
2555     """,
2556     ),
2557     
2558     Variable(
2559         abivarname="dmft_rslf",
2560         varset="dmft",
2561         vartype="integer",
2562         topics=['DMFT_basic'],
2563         dimensions="scalar",
2564         defaultval=0,
2565         mnemonics="Dynamical Mean Field Theory: Read SeLF energy",
2566         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
2567         text="""
2568     Flag to read/write Self-Energy. If put to one, self-energy is written and read at each DFT iteration.
2569     If self-energy file is missing, the self-energy is initialized to the double counting at the first iteration.
2570     """,
2571     ),
2572     
2573     Variable(
2574         abivarname="dmft_solv",
2575         varset="dmft",
2576         vartype="real",
2577         topics=['DMFT_basic'],
2578         dimensions="scalar",
2579         defaultval=5,
2580         mnemonics="Dynamical Mean Field Theory: choice of SOLVer",
2581         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
2582         text="""
2583     Choice of solver for the Impurity model.
2584     
2585       * 0 --> No solver and U=0, J=0 (see [[upawu]] and [[jpawu]]).
2586       * 1 --> LDA+U self-energy is used (for testing purpose)
2587       * 2 --> Hubbard one solver. The Hubbard one solver is an approximation which gives a rough description of correlated Mott insulators. It should not be used for metals.
2588       * 5 --> Use the Continuous Time Quantum Monte Carlo (CTQMC) solver CT-Hyb of ABINIT in the density density representation, CTQMC calculations are much more time consuming that Hubbard I calculations. Nevertheless, the calculation is fully parallelised.
2589       * 6 --> Continuous Time Quantum Monte Carlo (CTQMC) solver CT-Hyb of TRIQS in the density density representation.
2590       * 7 --> Continuous Time Quantum Monte Carlo (CTQMC) solver CT-Hyb of TRIQS with the rotationally invariant formulation.
2591     
2592     The CT Hyb algorithm is described in [[cite:Werner2006]]. For a
2593     discussion of density-density approximation with respect with the
2594     rotationnally invariant formulation, see e.g. [[cite:Antipov2012]].
2595     The ABINIT/CT Hyb implementation is discussed in [[cite:Gonze2016]].
2596     The TRIQS/CT Hyb implementation is described in [[cite:Seth2016]].
2597     Before using it, it has to be installed following instructions available [here](https://triqs.ipht.cnrs.fr/1.x/install.html).
2598     Starting from release 8.6.0, the
2599     interface is valid only for TRIQS 1.4 and TRIQS/CTHYB 1.4. An example of a
2600     config.ac file to compile ABINIT with TRIQS can be found in
2601     ~/doc/build/config-examples/ubu_gnu_4.9_triqs.ac.
2602     See the useful variables for CT-QMC solver: [[dmftctqmc_basis]],
2603     [[dmftctqmc_check]], [[dmftctqmc_correl]], [[dmftctqmc_gmove]],
2604     [[dmftctqmc_grnns]], [[dmftctqmc_meas]], [[dmftctqmc_mrka]],
2605     [[dmftctqmc_mov]], [[dmftctqmc_order]], [[dmftctqmc_triqs_nleg]],
2606     [[dmftqmc_l]], [[dmftqmc_n]], [[dmftqmc_seed]], [[dmftqmc_therm]]
2607     """,
2608     ),
2609     
2610     Variable(
2611         abivarname="dmft_t2g",
2612         varset="dmft",
2613         vartype="integer",
2614         topics=['DMFT_expert'],
2615         dimensions="scalar",
2616         defaultval=0,
2617         mnemonics="Dynamical Mean Field Theory: t2g orbitals",
2618         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
2619         text="""
2620     
2621     Can be set to 1 only if in cubic symmetry. It enables one to carry a DFT+DMFT
2622     calculations only on _t<sub>2g</sub>_ orbitals.
2623     """,
2624     ),
2625     
2626     Variable(
2627         abivarname="dmft_tolfreq",
2628         varset="dmft",
2629         vartype="real",
2630         topics=['DMFT_expert'],
2631         dimensions="scalar",
2632         defaultval=0.0001,
2633         mnemonics="Dynamical Mean Field Theory: TOLerance on DFT correlated electron occupation matrix for the definition of the FREQuency grid",
2634         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
2635         text="""
2636     
2637     The LDA occupation matrix for correlated electrons can be computed directly.
2638     It can be compared to the calculation of the same quantity using LDA Green's
2639     function, a sum over Matsubara frequencies and a projection over correlated
2640     orbitals. Because the Matsubara grid is finite, the two quantities differ. If
2641     this difference is larger than dmft_tolfreq, then the code stops and an error
2642     message is given.
2643     """,
2644     ),
2645     
2646     Variable(
2647         abivarname="dmft_tollc",
2648         varset="dmft",
2649         vartype="real",
2650         topics=['DMFT_useful'],
2651         dimensions="scalar",
2652         defaultval=1e-05,
2653         mnemonics="Dynamical Mean Field Theory: TOLerance on Local Charge for convergence of the DMFT loop",
2654         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
2655         text="""
2656     Tolerance for the variation of Local Charge during iterations of the DMFT Loop.
2657     The default value is good for fast calculations. However, to obtain good
2658     convergence of the DFT Loop, the DMFT Loop needs a better convergence criterion.
2659     """,
2660     ),
2661     
2662     Variable(
2663         abivarname="dmftbandf",
2664         varset="dmft",
2665         vartype="integer",
2666         topics=['DMFT_compulsory'],
2667         dimensions="scalar",
2668         defaultval=0,
2669         mnemonics="Dynamical Mean Field Theory: BAND: Final",
2670         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
2671         text="""
2672     [[dmftbandf]] is the last band taken into account in the Projected Local
2673     Orbitals scheme of DFT+DMFT. With [[dmftbandi]], they define the energy window
2674     used to define Wannier Functions (see [[cite:Amadon2008]]).
2675     """,
2676     ),
2677     
2678     Variable(
2679         abivarname="dmftbandi",
2680         varset="dmft",
2681         vartype="integer",
2682         topics=['DMFT_compulsory'],
2683         dimensions="scalar",
2684         defaultval=0,
2685         mnemonics="Dynamical Mean Field Theory: BAND: Initial",
2686         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
2687         text="""
2688     [[dmftbandi]] is the first band taken into account in the Projected Local
2689     Orbitals scheme of LDA+DMFT. With [[dmftbandf]], they define the energy window
2690     used to define Wannier Functions (see [[cite:Amadon2008]]).
2691     """,
2692     ),
2693     
2694     Variable(
2695         abivarname="dmftcheck",
2696         varset="dmft",
2697         vartype="integer",
2698         topics=['DMFT_useful'],
2699         dimensions="scalar",
2700         defaultval=0,
2701         mnemonics="Dynamical Mean Field Theory: CHECKs",
2702         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
2703         text="""

2707     
2708     Variable(
2709         abivarname="dmftctqmc_basis",
2710         varset="dev",
2711         vartype="integer",
2712         topics=['DMFT_expert'],
2713         dimensions="scalar",
2714         defaultval=1,
2715         mnemonics="Dynamical Mean Field Theory: Continuous Time Quantum Monte Carlo BASIS",
2716         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
2717         requires="[[dmft_solv]] == 5",
2718         text="""
2719     Choose the basis to perform CTQMC calculation.
2720     
2721       * 0 --> Use the local basis in the spherical harmonics basis.
2722       Can be useful if the Hamiltonian has weak off diagonal terms and for this reason,
2723       one want to keep the original basis for simplicity and for physical insight.
2724       * 1 --> Default value, diagonalize the local Hamiltonian (but only if it is not diagonal).
2725       The best choice in general.
2726       * 2 --> Diagonalise the local correlated occupation matrix. Can lead to non
2727       diagonal Hamiltonian that cannot be handled by CTQMC. This option should be thus avoided.
2728     """,
2729     ),
2730     
2731     Variable(
2732         abivarname="dmftctqmc_check",
2733         varset="dmft",
2734         vartype="integer",
2735         topics=['DMFT_useful'],
2736         dimensions="scalar",
2737         defaultval=0,
2738         mnemonics="Dynamical Mean Field Theory: Continuous Time Quantum Monte Carlo CHECK",
2739         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
2740         requires="[[dmft_solv]] == 5",
2741         text="""
2742     Check the fast calculations during the Monte Carlo simulation with very slow
2743     but robust methods. Should only be used for debugging.
2744     
2745       * 0 --> No check.
2746       * 1 --> Check the overlap calculations (Impurity operator).
2747       * 2 --> Check the update of M matrix calculation (Bath operator).
2748       * 3 --> Check both.
2749     """,
2750     ),
