2962     Variable(
2963         abivarname="dosdeltae",
2964         varset="gstate",
2965         vartype="real",
2966         topics=['printing_prdos', 'ElecDOS_useful'],
2967         dimensions="scalar",
2968         defaultval=0.0,
2969         mnemonics="DOS DELTA in Energy",
2970         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
2971         text="""
2972     Defines the linear grid resolution (energy increment) to be used for the
2973     computation of the Density-Of-States, when [[prtdos]] is non-zero.
2974     If [[dosdeltae]] is set to zero (the default value), the actual increment is
2975     0.001 Ha if [[prtdos]] = 1, and the much smaller value 0.00005 Ha if
2976     [[prtdos]] = 2. This different default value arises because the [[prtdos]] = 1
2977     case, based on a smearing technique, gives a quite smooth DOS, while the DOS
2978     from the tetrahedron method, [[prtdos]] = 2, is rapidly varying.
2979     """,
2980     ),
2981     
2982     Variable(
2983         abivarname="dtion",
2984         varset="rlx",
2985         vartype="real",
2986         topics=['PIMD_compulsory', 'MolecularDynamics_compulsory', "GeoOpt_compulsory"],
2987         dimensions="scalar",
2988         defaultval=100,
2989         mnemonics="Delta Time for IONs",
2990         text="""
2991     Used for controlling ion time steps. If [[ionmov]] is set to 1, 6, 7 and 15, then
2992     molecular dynamics is  used to update atomic positions in response to forces.
2993     The parameter [[dtion]] is a time step in atomic units of time. (One atomic
2994     time unit is 2.418884e-17 seconds, which is the value of Planck's constant in
2995     hartree*sec.) In this case the atomic masses, in amu (given in array " [[amu]]
2996     "), are used in Newton's equation and the viscosity (for [[ionmov]] =1) and
2997     number of time steps are provided to the code using input variables "[[vis]]"
2998     and "[[ntime]]". The code actually converts from masses in amu to masses in
2999     atomic units (in units of electron masses) but the user enters masses in
3000     [[amu]]. (The conversion from amu to atomic units (electron masses) is
3001     1822.88851 electron masses/amu.)
3002     
3003     A typical good value for [[dtion]] is about 100. The user must try several
3004     values for [[dtion]] in order to establish the stable and efficient choice for
3005     the accompanying amu, atom types and positions, and [[vis]] (viscosity).
3006     For quenched dynamics ([[ionmov]] = 7), a larger time step might be taken, for
3007     example 200. No meaning for RF calculations.
3008     It is also used in geometric relaxation calculation with the FIRE alogorithm
3009     ([[ionmov]]=15), where the time is virtual. A small dtion should be set, for example 0.03.
3010     """,
3011     ),
3012     
3013     Variable(
3014         abivarname="dynimage",
3015         varset="rlx",
3016         vartype="integer",
3017         topics=['PIMD_expert', 'TransPath_expert'],
3018         dimensions=['[[nimage]]'],
3019         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=None, value=1),
3020         mnemonics="list of DYNamic IMAGEs",
3021         commentdefault="if [[imgmov]] in [2,5] (String Method, NEB), <b>dynimage(1)</b>=0 and <b>dynimage([[nimage]])</b>=0.",
3022         text="""
3023     This input variable is relevant when sets of images are activated (see
3024     [[imgmov]]). Not all images might be required to evolve from one time step to
3025     the other. Indeed, in the String Method or the Nudged Elastic Band, one might
3026     impose that the extremal configurations of the string are fixed. In case
3027     [[dynimage]](iimage)=0, the image with index "iimage" will be consider as
3028     fixed. Thus, there is no need to compute forces and stresses for this image at
3029     each time step. The purpose of defining extremal images is to make the input/output easier.
3030     
3031     In order to save CPU time, the computation of properties of static images
3032     ([[dynimage]](iimage)=0) can be avoided: see [[istatimg]] keyword.
3033     """,
3034     ),
3035     
3036     Variable(
3037         abivarname="ecut",
3038         varset="basic",
3039         vartype="real",
3040         topics=['Planewaves_compulsory'],
3041         dimensions="scalar",
3042         mnemonics="Energy CUToff",
3043         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
3044         text="""
3045     Used for kinetic energy cutoff which controls number of planewaves at given k point by:
3046     (1/2)[(2 Pi)*(k+Gmax)]  2  =[[ecut]] for Gmax.
3047     
3048     All planewaves inside this "basis sphere" centered at k are included in the basis (except if [[dilatmx]] is defined).
3049     Can be specified in Ha (the default), Ry, eV or Kelvin, since [[ecut]] has the
3050     '[[ENERGY]]' characteristics. (1 Ha=27.2113845 eV)
3051     This is the single parameter which can have an enormous effect on the quality
3052     of a calculation; basically the larger [[ecut]] is, the better converged the
3053     calculation is. For fixed geometry, the total energy MUST always decrease as
3054     [[ecut]] is raised because of the variational nature of the problem.
3055     
3056     _Usually one runs at least several calculations at various [[ecut]] to
3057     investigate the convergence needed for reliable results._
3058     
3059     For k-points whose coordinates are build from 0 or 1/2, the implementation of
3060     time-reversal symmetry that links coefficients of the wavefunctions in
3061     reciprocal space has been realized. See the input variable [[istwfk]]. If
3062     activated (which corresponds to the Default mode), this input variable
3063     [[istwfk]] will allow to divide the number of plane wave (npw) treated
3064     explicitly by a factor of two. Still, the final result should be identical
3065     with the 'full' set of plane waves.
3066     
3067     See the input variable [[ecutsm]], for the smoothing of the kinetic energy,
3068     needed to optimize unit cell parameters.
3069     """,
3070     ),
3071     
3072     Variable(
3073         abivarname="ecuteps",
3074         varset="gw",
3075         vartype="real",
3076         topics=['Susceptibility_compulsory', 'RandStopPow_compulsory'],
3077         dimensions="scalar",
3078         defaultval=0.0,
3079         mnemonics="Energy CUT-off for EPSilon (the dielectric matrix)",
3080         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
3081         requires="[[optdriver]] in [3, 4]",
3082         text=r"""
3083     [[ecuteps]] determines the cut-off energy of the planewave set used to
3084     represent the independent-particle susceptibility $\chi^{0}_{KS}$, the
3085     dielectric matrix $\epsilon$, and its inverse.
3086     It is not worth to take [[ecuteps]] bigger than four times [[ecutwfn]], this
3087     latter limit corresponding to the highest Fourier components of a wavefunction
3088     convoluted with itself. Usually, even twice the value of [[ecutwfn]] might
3089     overkill. A value of [[ecuteps]] between 5 and 10 Hartree often (but not
3090     always) leads to converged results (at the level of 0.01 eV for the energy
3091     gap). In any case, a convergence study is worth.
3092     """,
3093     ),
3094     
3095     Variable(
3096         abivarname="ecutsigx",
3097         varset="gw",
3098         vartype="real",
3099         topics=['SelfEnergy_compulsory'],
3100         dimensions="scalar",
3101         defaultval=0.0,
3102         mnemonics="Energy CUT-off for SIGma eXchange",
3103         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
3104         requires="[[optdriver]] == 4",
3105         text="""
3106     [[ecutsigx]] determines the cut-off energy of the planewave set used to
3107     generate the exchange part of the self-energy operator. For norm-conserving
3108     calculations, it is pointless to have [[ecutsigx]] bigger than 4*[[ecut]],
3109     while for PAW calculations, the maximal useful value is [[pawecutdg]]. Thus,
3110     if you do not care about CPU time, please use these values. If you want to
3111     spare some CPU time, you might try to use a value between [[ecut]] and these upper limits.
3112     """,
3113     ),
3114     
3115     Variable(
3116         abivarname="ecutsm",
3117         varset="rlx",
3118         vartype="real",
3119         topics=['Planewaves_basic'],
3120         dimensions="scalar",
3121         defaultval=0.0,
3122         mnemonics="Energy CUToff SMearing",
3123         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
3124         text="""
3125     This input variable is important when performing relaxation of unit cell size
3126     and shape (non-zero [[optcell]]). Using a non-zero [[ecutsm]], the total
3127     energy curves as a function of [[ecut]], or [[acell]], can be smoothed,
3128     keeping consistency with the stress (and automatically including the Pulay
3129     stress). The recommended value is 0.5 Ha. Actually, when [[optcell]]/=0,
3130     ABINIT requires [[ecutsm]] to be larger than zero. If you want to optimize
3131     cell shape and size without smoothing the total energy curve (a dangerous
3132     thing to do), use a very small [[ecutsm]], on the order of one microHartree.
3133     
3134     Technical information:
3135     See [[cite:Bernasconi1995]]for a related method using constant pressure molecular dynamics.
3136     [[ecutsm]] allows one to define an effective kinetic energy for plane waves, close
3137     to, but lower than the maximal kinetic energy [[ecut]]. For kinetic energies
3138     less than [[ecut]]-[[ecutsm]], nothing is modified, while between
3139     [[ecut]]-[[ecutsm]] and [[ecut]], the kinetic energy is multiplied by:
3140     1.0 / ( x  2  (3+x-6x  2  +3x  3  ))
3141     where x = ([[ecut]] - kinetic_energy)/[[ecutsm]]
3142     Note that x 2  ( 3+x-6x  2  +3x  3  ) is 0 at x=0, with vanishing derivative,
3143     and that at x=1, it is 1, with also vanishing derivative.
3144     If [[ecutsm]] is zero, the unmodified kinetic energy is used.
3145     [[ecutsm]] can be specified in Ha (the default), Ry, eV or Kelvin, since
3146     [[ecutsm]] has the '[[ENERGY]]' characteristics. (1 Ha=27.2113845 eV).
3147     A few test for Silicon (diamond structure, 2 k-points) have shown 0.5 Ha to be
3148     largely enough for [[ecut]] between 2Ha and 6Ha, to get smooth curves. It is
3149     likely that this value is OK as soon as [[ecut]] is larger than 4Ha.
3150     """,
3151     ),
3152     
3153     Variable(
3154         abivarname="ecutwfn",
3155         varset="gw",
3156         vartype="real",
3157         topics=['Susceptibility_compulsory', 'SelfEnergy_compulsory'],
3158         dimensions="scalar",
3159         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[optdriver]] in [3, 4]': '[[ecut]]', 'defaultval': 0.0}),
3160         mnemonics="Energy CUT-off for WaveFunctioNs",
3161         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
3162         requires=" [[optdriver]] in [3, 4]",
3163         text=r"""
3164     [[ecutwfn]] determines the cut-off energy of the planewave set used to
3165     represent the wavefunctions in the formula that generates the independent-
3166     particle susceptibility $\chi^{0}_{KS}$ (for [[optdriver]] = 3), or the self-
3167     energy (for [[optdriver]] = 4).
3168     Usually, [[ecutwfn]] is smaller than [[ecut]], so that the wavefunctions are
3169     filtered, and some components are ignored. As a side effect, the wavefunctions
3170     are no more normalized, and also, no more orthogonal. Also, the set of plane
3171     waves can be much smaller for [[optdriver]] = 3, than for [[optdriver]] = 4,
3172     although a convergence study is needed to choose correctly both values.
3173     
3174     The size of this set of planewaves is [[npwwfn]].
3175     """,
3176     ),
3177     
3178     Variable(
3179         abivarname="effmass_free",
3180         varset="dev",
3181         vartype="real",
3182         topics=['Artificial_expert'],
3183         dimensions="scalar",
3184         defaultval=1,
3185         mnemonics="EFFective MASS for the FREE electron",
3186         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
3187         text="""
3188     This parameter allows one to change the free electron mass, with respect to its experimental value.
3189     The electron mass is simply changed in the Schrodinger equation.
3190     Only for testing purposes, of course.
3191     """,
3192     ),
3193     
3194     Variable(
3195         abivarname="efield",
3196         varset="ffield",
3197         vartype="real",
3198         topics=['Berry_basic'],
3199         dimensions=[3],
3200         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=3, value=0.0),
3201         mnemonics="Electric FIELD",
3202         requires="[[berryopt]] in [4, 6]",
3203         text="""
3204     In case [[berryopt]] = 4, a finite electric field calculation is performed. The
3205     value of this electric field, and its direction is determined by [[efield]].
3206     It must be given in atomic units (1 a.u. of electric field= 514220624373.482
3207     V/m, see note below), in cartesian coordinates.
3208     
3209     References for the calculation under electric field (based on multi k point Berry phase):
3210     
3211       * [[cite:Nunes1994]]: real-space version of the finite-field Hamiltonian
3212       * [[cite:Nunes2001]]: reciprocal-space version of the finite-field Hamiltonian (the one presently implemented), and extensive theoretical analysis
3213       * [[cite:Souza2002]]: implementation of the finite-field Hamiltonian (reciprocal-space version)
3214       * [[cite:Zwanziger2012]]: extension to PAW formalism
3215     
3216     See also [[cite:Umari2003]].
3217     
3218     !!! note
3219     
3220         The atomic unit of electric field strength is: $\\frac{e_{Cb}}{4\pi\\varepsilon_0a_0^2}$, where
3221         $e_{Cb}$ is the electronic charge in Coulomb (1.60217653$^{-19}$), $\\varepsilon_0$ is the
3222         electric constant (8.854187817d-12 F/m), and $a_0$ is the Bohr radius in meter
3223         (0.5291772108$^{-10}$).
3224     """,
3225     ),
3226     
3227     Variable(
3228         abivarname="efmas",
3229         varset="dfpt",
3230         vartype="integer",
3231         topics=['EffectiveMass_compulsory'],
3232         dimensions="scalar",
3233         defaultval=0,
3234         mnemonics="EFfective MASs",
3235         text="""
3236     Turns on effective mass tensor calculations. Such calculations requires the
3237     non-self-consistent calculation of derivatives with respect to k, in the same
3238     dataset. It must therefore be used with [[rfelfd]] = 2 (or 1).
3239     
3240       * 0 --> no effective mass tensor calculation
3241       * 1 --> effective mass tensor calculation
3242     !!! note
3243         At the present time, both norm-conserving (NC) and PAW calculations are
3244         supported. Also, for PAW calculations only, [[nspinor]] == 2 and
3245         [[pawspnorb]] == 1 (i.e. spin-orbit (SO) calculations) is supported. NC SO
3246         calculations are NOT currently supported. Also, for both NC and PAW,
3247         [[nspden]]/=1 and [[nsppol]]/=1 are NOT supported.
3248     """,
3249     ),
3250     
3251     Variable(
3252         abivarname="efmas_bands",
3253         varset="dfpt",
3254         vartype="integer",
3255         topics=['EffectiveMass_useful'],
3256         dimensions=[2, '[[nkpt]]'],
3257         defaultval="The full range of band available in the calculation for each k-point.",
3258         mnemonics="EFfective MASs, BANDS to be treated.",
3259         requires="[[efmas]] == 1",
3260         text="""
3261     This variable controls the range of bands for which the effective mass is to
3262     be calculated. If a band is degenerate, all other bands of the degenerate
3263     group will automatically be treated, even if they were not part of the user specified range.
3264     """,
3265     ),
3266     
3267     Variable(
3268         abivarname="efmas_calc_dirs",
3269         varset="dfpt",
3270         vartype="integer",
3271         topics=['EffectiveMass_useful'],
3272         dimensions="scalar",
3273         defaultval=0,
3274         mnemonics="EFfective MASs, CALCulate along DIRectionS",
3275         requires="[[efmas]] == 1",
3276         text="""
3277     Allows the user to calculate the scalar effective mass of all bands specified
3278     by [[efmas_bands]] along specific directions in reciprocal space. This is
3279     particularly useful when considering degenerate bands, which are usually
3280     warped, and thus cannot have their dispersion (hessian) and effective mass
3281     expressed as a tensor. This allows the user to see the more complex angular
3282     behavior of effective masses in these cases, for instance.
3283     
3284     When [[efmas_calc_dirs]] == 0, no directions are read from the input file (using
3285     [[efmas_dirs]]) and the effective masses along the 3 cartesian directions are
3286     output by default.
3287     
3288     When [[efmas_calc_dirs]] == 1, 2 or 3, [[efmas_n_dirs]] directions are read from
3289     [[efmas_dirs]], assuming cartesian, reduced or angular ($\\theta$,$\phi$)
3290     coordinates, respectively. In the case [[efmas_calc_dirs]] == 3, 2 real values
3291     per directions are read, whereas 3 real values are read in the two other cases.
3292     """,
3293     ),
3294     
3295     Variable(
3296         abivarname="efmas_deg",
3297         varset="dfpt",
3298         vartype="integer",
3299         topics=['EffectiveMass_expert'],
3300         dimensions="scalar",
3301         defaultval=1,
3302         mnemonics="EFfective MASs, activate DEGenerate formalism",
3303         requires="[[efmas]] > 0",
3304         text="""
3305     Activate (==1) or not (==0) the treatment of degenerate bands
3306     (criterion [[efmas_deg_tol]] is used to determine whether bands are degenerate).
3307     Also compute the transport equivalent effective mass (see [[cite:Mecholsky2014]]).
3308     
3309     [[efmas]] = 0 should only be used for testing purposes.
3310     """,
3311     ),
3312     
3313     Variable(
3314         abivarname="efmas_deg_tol",
3315         varset="dfpt",
3316         vartype="real",
3317         topics=['EffectiveMass_useful'],
3318         dimensions="scalar",
3319         defaultval=1e-05,
3320         mnemonics="EFfective MASs, DEGeneracy TOLerance",
3321         requires="[[efmas_deg]] == 1",
3322         text="""
3323     Energy difference below which 2 bands are considered degenerate (and treated
3324     using the formalism activated with [[efmas_deg]] == 1). [[efmas_deg_tol]] has
3325     the '[[ENERGY]]' characteristics.
3326     """,
3327     ),
3328     
3329     Variable(
3330         abivarname="efmas_dim",
3331         varset="dfpt",
3332         vartype="integer",
3333         topics=['EffectiveMass_useful'],
3334         dimensions="scalar",
3335         defaultval=3,
3336         mnemonics="EFfective MASs, DIMension of the effective mass tensor",
3337         requires="[[efmas]] == 1",
3338         text="""
3339     For 2D or 1D systems, the band dispersion goes to 0 perpendicular to the
3340     system, which causes the inverse effective mass to be singular, i.e. the
3341     effective mass to be NaN. This keyword circumvents the problem by eliminating
3342     the troublesome dimensions from the inverse effective mass.
3343     
3344     In 2D, the Z axis is ignored and, in 1D, the Z and Y axis are ignored.
3345     
3346     Also, note that in the 2D degenerate case, a subtlety arises: the 'transport
3347     equivalent' effective mass does not determine the scale of the transport
3348     tensors (conductivity and others). Therefore, for this specific case, the
3349     factor by which these transport tensors should be scaled once determined from
3350     the 'transport equivalent' effective mass tensor is output separately on the
3351     line immediately after the effective mass.
3352     """,
3353     ),
3354     
3355     Variable(
3356         abivarname="efmas_dirs",
3357         varset="dfpt",
3358         vartype="real",
3359         topics=['EffectiveMass_basic'],
3360         dimensions=['3 or 2', '[[efmas_n_dirs]]'],
3361         defaultval=0,
3362         mnemonics="EFfective MASs, DIRectionS to be calculated",
3363         requires="[[efmas_calc_dirs]] > 0",
3364         text="""
3365     List of [[efmas_n_dirs]] directions to be considered according to the value of
3366     [[efmas_calc_dirs]]. The directions are specified by 3 real values if
3367     [[efmas_calc_dirs]] == 1 or 2 and by 2 real values if [[efmas_calc_dirs]] == 3.
3368     """,
3369     ),
3370     
3371     Variable(
3372         abivarname="efmas_n_dirs",
3373         varset="dfpt",
3374         vartype="integer",
3375         topics=['EffectiveMass_basic'],
3376         dimensions="scalar",
3377         defaultval=0,
3378         mnemonics="EFfective MASs, Number of DIRectionS",
3379         requires="[[efmas_calc_dirs]] > 0",
3380         text="""
3381     Number of directions in [[efmas_dirs]], to be considered according to [[efmas_calc_dirs]].
3382     """,
3383     ),
3384     
3385     Variable(
3386         abivarname="efmas_ntheta",
3387         varset="dfpt",
3388         vartype="integer",
3389         topics=['EffectiveMass_basic'],
3390         dimensions="scalar",
3391         defaultval=1000,
3392         mnemonics="EFfective MASs, Number of points for integration w/r to THETA",
3393         requires="[[efmas]] == 1 and [[efmas_bands]] == (degenerate band index)",
3394         text="""
3395     When a band is degenerate, the usual definition of effective mass becomes
3396     invalid. However, it is still possible to define a 'transport equivalent mass
3397     tensor' that reproduces the contribution of the band to the conductivity
3398     tensor. To obtain this tensor, an integration over the solid sphere is
3399     required. The angular variables are sampled using [[efmas_ntheta]] points for the theta coordinate,
3400     and twice [[efmas_ntheta]] points for the phi coordinate.
3401     The default value gives a tensor accurate to the 4th decimal in Ge.
3402     """,
3403     ),
3404     
3405     Variable(
3406         abivarname="einterp",
3407         varset="basic",
3408         vartype="real",
3409         topics=['ElecBandStructure_useful', 'SelfEnergy_expert'],
3410         dimensions=[4],
3411         defaultval=[0, 0, 0, 0],
3412         mnemonics="Electron bands INTERPolation",
3413         text="""
3414     This variable activates the interpolation of the electronic eigenvalues. It
3415     can be used to interpolate KS eigenvalues at the end of the GS run or to
3416     interpolate GW energies in sigma calculations ([[optdriver]] = 4). The k-path
3417     can be specified with [[kptbounds]] and [[nkpath]]. einterp consists of 4
3418     entries. The first element specificies the interpolation method.
3419     
3420       * 0 --> No interpolation (default)
3421       * 1 --> Star-function interpolation (Shankland-Koelling-Wood Fourier interpolation scheme, see [[cite:Pickett1988]]
3422       * 2 --> B-spline interpolation.
3423     
3424     The meaning of the other entries depend on the interpolation technique
3425     selected.
3426     In the case of star-function interpolation:
3427     
3428       * einterp(2): Number of star-functions per ab-initio k-point
3429       * einterp(3): If non-zero, activate Fourier filtering according to Eq 9 of [[cite:Uehara2000]].
3430         In this case, rcut is given by einterp(2) * Rmax where Rmax is the maximum length of
3431         the lattice vectors included in the star expansion
3432       * einterp(4): Used if einterp(2) /= 0. It defines rsigma in Eq 9
3433     
3434     For B-spline interpolation: einterp(2:4): Order of B-spline for the three
3435     reduced directions. Cubic spline (3) is the recommended value.
3436     """,
3437     ),
3438     
3439     Variable(
3440         abivarname="elph2_imagden",
3441         varset="dfpt",
3442         vartype="real",
3443         topics=['TDepES_basic'],
3444         dimensions="scalar",
3445         defaultval=0.0,
3446         mnemonics="ELectron-PHonon interaction at 2nd order: IMAGinary shift of the DENominator",
3447         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
3448         requires="[[ieig2rf]] != 0",
3449         text="""
3450     
3451     The variable [[elph2_imagden]] determines the imaginary shift of the
3452     denominator of the sum-over-states in the perturbation,
3453     $(e_{nk}-e_{n'k'}+i$[[elph2_imagden]]). One should use a width comparable with
3454     the Debye frequency or the maximum phonon frequency.
3455     Can be specified in Ha (the default), Ry, eV or Kelvin, since [[ecut]] has the
3456     '[[ENERGY]]' characteristics (1 Ha=27.2113845 eV).
3457     """,
3458     ),

3460     Variable(
3461         abivarname="enunit",

3463         vartype="integer",

3465         dimensions="scalar",
3466         defaultval=0,
3467         mnemonics="ENergy UNITs",
3468         text="""
3469     Governs the units to be used for output of eigenvalues (and eventual phonon frequencies)
3470     
3471       * 0  --> print eigenvalues in hartree;
3472       * 1  --> print eigenvalues in eV;
3473       * 2  --> print eigenvalues in both hartree and eV.
3474     
3475     If phonon frequencies are to be computed:
3476     
3477       * 0  -->  phonon frequencies in Hartree and cm-1;
3478       * 1  -->  phonon frequencies in eV and THz;
3479       * 2  -->  phonon frequencies in hartree, eV, cm-1, Thz and Kelvin.
3480     """,
3481     ),

3513     Variable(
3514         abivarname="eph_frohlichm",
3515         varset="eph",
3516         vartype="integer",
3517         topics=['ElPhonInt_useful'],
3518         dimensions="scalar",
3519         defaultval=0,
3520         mnemonics="Electron-PHonon: FROHLICH Model",
3521         text="""
3522     If set to 1, use the dynamical matrix at Gamma, the Born effective charges, the dielectric tensor, as well as
3523     the effective masses (must give a _EFMAS file as input, see [[prtefmas]]), as the parameters of a Frohlich Hamiltonian.
3524     Then use it to compute the
3525     change of electronic eigenvalues due to electron-phonon interaction,
3526     using second-order time-dependent perturbation theory. Can deliver (approximate) zero-point renormalisation
3527     as well as temperature dependence.
3528     """,
3529     ),
3530

3542     calculations ([[optdriver]] = 7). Only the states located in the energy range
3543     [efermi - eph_fsewin, efermi + eph_fsewin] are included in the e-ph calculation.

3598     Variable(
3599         abivarname="eph_ngqpt_fine",
3600         varset="eph",
3601         vartype="integer",
3602         topics=['ElPhonInt_expert'],
3603         dimensions=[3],
3604         defaultval=[0, 0, 0],
3605         mnemonics="Electron-PHonon: Number of Grid Q-PoinTs in FINE grid.",
3606         text=r"""
3607     This variable activates the **interpolation** of the first-order variation of the
3608     self-consistent potential in the electron-phonon code ([[optdriver]] == 7).
3609     
3610     If eph_nqgpt_fine differs from [0, 0, 0], the code will use the Fourier transform to interpolate
3611     the DFPT potentials on this fine q-mesh starting from the irreducible set of
3612     q-points read from the DVDB file. This approach is similar to the one used to
3613     interpolate the interatomic force constants in q-space. If **eph_ngqpt_fine** is
3614     not given, the EPH code uses the list of irreducible q-points reported in the
3615     DDB file i.e. [[ddb_ngqpt]] (default behavior).
3616     
3617     !!! important
3618     
3619         The computation of the electron-phonon matrix elements requires the knowledge of $\psi_{\bf k}$
3620         and $\psi_{\bf k + q}$. This means that the k-mesh for electrons found in the WFK must be
3621         compatible with the one given in *eph_ngqpt_fine*.
3622         The code can interpolate DFPT potentials but won't try to interpolate KS wavefunctions.
3623         and will stop if ${\bf k + q}$ is not found in the WFK file.
3624     """,
3625     ),
3626     
3627     Variable(
3628         abivarname="eph_task",
3629         varset="eph",
3630         vartype="integer",
3631         topics=['ElPhonInt_expert'],
3632         dimensions="scalar",
3633         defaultval=1,
3634         mnemonics="Electron-PHonon: Task",
3635         text="""
3636     When [[optdriver]] == 7, select the task to be performed.
3637     The choice is among:
3638     
3639      * 0 --> No computation (mainly used to access the post-processing tools)
3640      * 1 --> Compute phonon linewidths in metals.
3641      * 2 --> Compute electron-phonon matrix elements.
3642      * 3 --> Compute phonon self-energy.
3643      * 4 --> Compute EPH self-energy (Fan-Migdal + Debye-Waller).
3644      * 5 --> Interpolate DFPT potentials.
3645     """,
3646     ),

3739         dimensions="scalar",
3740         defaultval=0,

3742         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
3743         requires="[[densfor_pred]] in [5, 6]",
3744         text="""
3745     This flag activates the extrapolation of wave-functions from one Molecular
3746     Dynamics (or Structural Relaxation) step to another. The wave functions are
3747     extrapolated using 2nd-order algorithm of [[cite:Arias1992]].
3748     Note that, when activated, this extrapolation requires non-negligible
3749     additional memory resources as the wave functions are stored for the two
3750     previous time steps. Also, it can only be activated if a consistent density
3751     extrapolation is activated (see [[densfor_pred]]).
3752     ABINIT 7.10: this option is **under development** and might give wrong results.
3753     """,
3754     ),
3755     
3756     Variable(
3757         abivarname="f4of2_sla",

3763      'f electrons': 0.6681,

3789     Variable(
3790         abivarname="fband",
3791         varset="gstate",
3792         vartype="real",
3793         topics=['BandOcc_useful'],
3794         dimensions="scalar",

3796      '[[occopt]] > 2': 0.5,
3797      '[[usewvl]] == 1': 0.0,
3798      'defaultval': 0.0}),
3799         mnemonics="Factor for the number of BANDs",
3800         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
3801         text="""
3802     Governs the number of bands to be used in the code in the case the parameter
3803     [[nband]] is not defined in the input file (which means that [[occopt]] is not
3804     equal to 0 or 2).
3805     
3806     In case [[fband]] is 0.0, the code computes from the pseudopotential files
3807     and the geometry data contained in the input file, the number of electrons
3808     present in the system. Then, it computes the minimum number of bands that can
3809     accommodate them, and use that value for [[nband]].
3810     
3811     In case [[fband]] differs from zero, other bands will be added, just larger
3812     than [[fband]] times the number of atoms. This parameter is not echoed in the
3813     top of the main output file, but only the parameter [[nband]] that it allowed
3814     to compute. It is also not present in the dtset array (no internal).
3815     The default values are chosen such as to give naturally some conduction bands.
3816     This improves the robustness of the code, since this allows one to identify lack
3817     of convergence coming from (near-)degeneracies at the Fermi level. In the
3818     metallic case, the number of bands generated might be too small if the
3819     smearing factor is large. The occupation numbers of the higher bands should be
3820     small enough such as to neglect higher bands. It is difficult to automate
3821     this, so a fixed default value has been chosen.
3822     """,
3823     ),
3824     
3825     Variable(
3826         abivarname="fermie_nest",
3827         varset="dev",
3828         vartype="real",
3829         topics=['printing_prfermi'],
3830         dimensions="scalar",
3831         defaultval=0,
3832         mnemonics="FERMI Energy for printing the NESTing function",
3833         text="""
3834     This input variable is only effective when [[prtnest]] = 1.
3835     The energy is relative to the calculated Fermi energy.
3836     """,
3837     ),
3838     
3839     Variable(
3840         abivarname="fftalg",
3841         varset="dev",
3842         vartype="integer",
3843         topics=['TuningSpeed_useful'],
3844         dimensions="scalar",
3845         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[FFTW3]] and [[usedmft]] == 0': 312,
3846      '[[paral_kgb]] == 1': 401,
3847      'defaultval': 112}),
3848         mnemonics="Fast Fourier Transform ALGorithm",
3849         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
3850         text="""
3851     This keyword is **irrelevant** when Fast Fourier Transforms are done using
3852     **Graphics Processing Units** (GPU), i.e. when [[use_gpu_cuda]] = 1
3853     (in that case, it is ignored).
3854     
3855     Allows to choose the algorithm for Fast Fourier Transforms. These have to be
3856     used when applied to wavefunctions (routine `src/53_ffts/fourwf.F90`), as well as when
3857     applied to densities and potentials (routine `src/53_ffts/fourdp.F90`). Presently, it is the
3858     concatenation of three digits, labelled (A), (B) and (C).
3859     
3860     The first digit (A) is to be chosen among 1, 2, 3, 4 or 5:
3861     
3862       * 1 --> use FFT routines written by S. Goedecker.
3863       * 2 -->  not available anymore
3864       * 3 -->  use serial or multi-threaded FFTW3 fortran routines ([http://www.fftw.org ](http://www.fftw.org) ).
3865         Currently implemented with [[fftalg]] = 312.
3866       * 4 -->  use FFT routines written by S. Goedecker, 2002 version, that will be suited for MPI and OpenMP parallelism.
3867       * 5 -->  use serial or multi-threaded MKL routines Currently implemented with [[fftalg]] = 512.
3868     
3869     The second digit (B) is related to `src/53_ffts/fourdp.F90`:
3870     
3871       * 0 -->  only use Complex-to-complex FFT
3872       * 1 -->  real-to-complex is also allowed (only coded for A==1, A==3 and A==5)
3873     
3874     The third digit (C) is related to `src/53_ffts/fourwf.F90`:
3875     
3876       * 0 --> no use of zero padding
3877       * 1 --> use of zero padding (only coded for A==1, A==4)
3878       * 2 --> use of zero padding, and also combines actual FFT operations (using 2 routines from S. Goedecker)
3879         with important pre- and post-processing operations, in order to maximize cache data reuse.
3880         This is very efficient for cache architectures. (coded for A==1 and A==4, but A==4 is not yet sufficiently tested)
3881     
3882     Internal representation as [[ngfft]](7).
3883     """,
3884     ),
3885     
3886     Variable(
3887         abivarname="fftcache",
3888         varset="dev",
3889         vartype="integer",
3890         topics=['TuningSpeed_expert'],
3891         dimensions="scalar",
3892         defaultval=16,
3893         mnemonics="Fast Fourier Transform CACHE size",
3894         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
3895         commentdefault="todo: Not yet machine-dependent",
3896         text="""
3897     Gives the cache size of the current machine, in Kbytes.
3898     Internal representation as [[ngfft]](8).
3899     """,
3900     ),
3901     
3902     Variable(
3903         abivarname="fftgw",
3904         varset="gw",
3905         vartype="integer",
3906         topics=['GW_expert', 'Susceptibility_expert', 'SelfEnergy_expert'],
3907         dimensions="scalar",
3908         defaultval=21,
3909         mnemonics="FFT for GW calculation",
3910         requires=" [[optdriver]] in [3, 4]",
3911         text="""
3912     The basic ingredients needed to perform both a screening and a sigma
3913     calculation are the so-called oscillator matrix elements defined as
3914     
3915     $$ \langle \mathbf{k-q},b_1 | e^{-i (\mathbf{q+G)} \mathbf{r}} | \mathbf{k}, b_2 \\rangle $$
3916     
3917     In reciprocal space, this expression is evaluated by a convolution in which
3918     the number of reciprocal lattice vectors employed to describe the
3919     wavefunctions is given by [[ecutwfn]]. In the case of screening calculations,
3920     the number of **G** vectors in the above expression is defined by [[ecuteps]],
3921     while [[ecutsigx]] defined the number of **G** used in sigma calculations. To
3922     improve the efficiency of the code, the oscillator matrix elements are
3923     evaluated in real space through FFT techniques, and the [[fftgw]] input
3924     variable is used to select the FFT mesh to be used.
3925     
3926     [[fftgw]] is the concatenation of two digits, labelled (A) and (B) whose value
3927     is internally used to define the value of [[ngfft]](1:3) (see the setmesh.F90 routine).
3928     
3929     The first digit (A) defines the augmentation of the FFT grid. Possible values
3930     are 1, 2 and 3.
3931     
3932       * 0 --> Use the FFT grid specified by the user through [[ngfft]](1:3)
3933       * 1 --> Use a coarse FFT grid which encloses a sphere in reciprocal space whose radius
3934         depends on the largest value between [[ecutwfn]] and [[ecuteps]]
3935       * 2 --> Use a slightly augmented FFT which is sufficient for the correct treatment of the convolution
3936       * 3 --> Doubled FFT grid (same mesh as that used for GS calculations).
3937     
3938     The second digit (B) can be chosen between 0 and 1. It defines whether a FFT
3939     grid compatible with all the symmetries of the space group must be enforced or not:
3940     
3941       * 0 --> Use the smallest FFT mesh which is compatible with the FFT library (faster, save memory but is less accurate)
3942       * 1 --> Enforce a FFT grid which is compatible with all the symmetry operations of the space group.
3943         This method leads to an increase both of CPU time and memory, but the matrix elements are more accurate
3944         since the symmetry properties of the system are preserved.
3945     
3946     The behaviour of ABINIT before v5.5 corresponds to the default value 11.
3947     """,
3948     ),
3949     
3950     Variable(
3951         abivarname="fockdownsampling",
3952         varset="gstate",
3953         vartype="integer",
3954         topics=['Hybrids_useful'],
3955         dimensions=[3],
3956         defaultval="3*1",
3957         mnemonics="FOCK operator, k-grid DOWNSAMPLING",
3958         requires="[[usefock]] == 1",
3959         text="""
3960     The k wavevector grid used to compute the Fock operator in the full Brillouin
3961     Zone might be a subset of the full Brillouin Zone of the k point grid used for
3962     the wavefunctions (see [[kptopt]] for its definition). [[fockdownsampling]]
3963     allows one to define such a reduced set of k wavevectors, yielding a
3964     significant speed up at the expense (possibly) of accuracy. The final grid has
3965     [[nkpthf]] k points, with coordinates [[kptns_hf]].
3966     
3967     In the simplest case, the three values of [[fockdownsampling]] are equal, and
3968     simply gives the factor by which the initial k point grid will be downsampled
3969     along every direction. If [[fockdownsampling]] is 3*1, the sampling for the
3970     Fock operator is the same as the sampling for the wavefunctions. If
3971     [[fockdownsampling]] is 3*2 the sampling will have 8 times less k points.
3972     Conventionally, if [[fockdownsampling]] is 3*0, then the Fock operator is
3973     obtained solely from the Gamma point. Also, as soon as [[fockdownsampling]] is
3974     not 3*1 or 3*0, the k point grid from which a subset will be taken is obtained
3975     by imposing [[nshiftk]] = 1.
3976     
3977     A more accurate description is now given, as one can achieve a better control
3978     than described above, with differing values of [[fockdownsampling]] and also
3979     with negative numbers. One starts from the k point grid defined by
3980     [[kptrlatt]], with [[nshiftk]] = 1. The absolute value of each of the three
3981     numbers of [[fockdownsampling]] is used to sample the corresponding axis (in
3982     reduced coordinate), as described above. Moreover, the obtained k grid might
3983     even be further downsampled by specifying negative numbers: if all three are
3984     negative, one further downsamples each 2x2x2 subset of k points by taking its
3985     FCC subset (so, 4 points instead of 8); if two are negative, one downsamples
3986     each 2x2x2 subset of k points by taking its BCC subset (so, 2 points instead
3987     of 8); is only one is negative, then the two other axes are sampled using a
3988     face-centered sampling. Finally, some of the values might be taken as 0, in
3989     which case the corresponding direction is sampled by only one layer of points
3990     (if two are zero, a line of points is obtained).
3991     """,
3992     ),
3993     
3994     Variable(
3995         abivarname="fockoptmix",
3996         varset="gstate",
3997         vartype="integer",
3998         topics=['Hybrids_basic'],
3999         dimensions="scalar",
4000         defaultval=0,
4001         mnemonics="FOCK operator: OPTions for MIXing",
4002         requires="[[usefock]] == 1",
4003         text="""
4004     Governs the mixing algorithm at the level of the Fock operator, i.e. how to
4005     mix it, and how the underlying SCF calculation is to be performed. It is the
4006     most relevant when the Fock operator is not updated at each SCF step ([[nnsclohf]]/=0).
4007     
4008     The last digit of [[fockoptmix]] governs what happens at the level of the SCF
4009     algorithm, when the Fock operator is updated.
4010     
4011       1. If [[fockoptmix]] == 0: the SCF algorithm is not restarted
4012       (it continues to use the previous potential/density pairs without worrying).
4013       2. If [[fockoptmix]] == 1: the SCF algorithm is restarted (the previous potential/density pairs are discarted).
4014     
4015     The second-to-last (dozen) digit governs the possible modification of the XC
4016     functional inside the SCF loop to take into account the lack of update of the
4017     Fock operator. Irrelevant when the unit digit is 0. If the value 1 is used
4018     (so, e.g. [[fockoptmix]] == 11), an auxiliary xc functional is used inside the
4019     SCF loop, for a frozen ACE Fock operator. This auxiliary functional is
4020     specified thanks to [[auxc_ixc]] and [[auxc_scal]].
4021     
4022     The third-to-last (hundreds) digit governs the mixing of the Fock operator
4023     itself with its previous occurrences. Irrelevant when the unit digit is 0.
4024     """,
4025     ),
4026     
4027     Variable(
4028         abivarname="freqim_alpha",
4029         varset="gw",
4030         vartype="real",
4031         topics=['SelfEnergy_expert'],
4032         dimensions="scalar",
4033         defaultval=5.0,
4034         mnemonics="FREQuencies along the IMaginary axis ALPHA parameter",
4035         requires="[[optdriver]] == 4",
4036         text="""
4037     [[freqim_alpha]] is used only for numerical integration of the GW self-energy
4038     ([[gwcalctyp]] =  2, 12, 22, 9, 19, 29).
4039     [[freqim_alpha]] determines the location of the maximum frequency point along
4040     the imaginary axis if the default grid is used in Contour Deformation
4041     (numerical integration) calculations. It is set as  $\alpha*\omega_p$, where $\omega_p$
4042     is the plasma frequency determined by the average density of the system
4043     (this can be set by hand by using the variable [[ppmfrq]]). See the section on
4044     grids in the descriptive text for [[cd_frqim_method]] for a detailed
4045     """,
4046     ),
4047     
4048     Variable(
4049         abivarname="freqremax",
4050         varset="gw",
4051         vartype="real",
4052         topics=['FrequencyMeshMBPT_basic'],
4053         dimensions="scalar",
4054         defaultval=0.0,
4055         mnemonics="FREQuencies along the Real axis MAXimum",
4056         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
4057         requires="[[optdriver]] == 3",
4058         text="""
4059     [[freqremax]] is used only for numerical integration of the GW self-energy
4060     ([[gwcalctyp]] =  2, 12, 22, 9, 19, 29).
4061     [[freqremax]] sets the maximum real frequency used to calculate the dielectric
4062     matrix in order to perform the numerical integration of the GW self-energy.
4063     [[freqremax]], [[freqremin]] and [[nfreqre]] define the spacing of the
4064     frequency mesh along the real axis.

4068     Variable(

4071         vartype="real",
4072         topics=['FrequencyMeshMBPT_basic'],
4073         dimensions="scalar",
4074         defaultval=0.0,
4075         mnemonics="FREQuencies along the Real axis MINimum",
4076         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
4077         requires="[[optdriver]] == 3",
4078         text="""
4079     [[freqremin]] is used only for numerical integration of the GW self-energy
4080     ([[gwcalctyp]] =  2, 12, 22, 9, 19, 29).
4081     [[freqremin]] sets the minimum real frequency used to calculate the dielectric
4082     matrix in order to perform the numerical integration of the GW self-energy.
4083     [[freqremin]] can be used to split a wide frequency interval into smaller
4084     subintervals that can be calculated independently. The different subintervals
4085     can then be merged together with the **Mrgscr** utility thus obtaining a
4086     single screening file that can used for self-energy calculations. Note that
4087     [[freqremax]], [[freqremin]] and [[nfreqre]] define the spacing of the
4088     frequency mesh along the real axis.
4089     """,
4090     ),

4130     Variable(
4131         abivarname="friction",
4132         varset="rlx",
4133         vartype="real",
4134         topics=['MolecularDynamics_useful'],
4135         dimensions="scalar",
4136         defaultval=0.001,
4137         mnemonics="internal FRICTION coefficient",
4138         text="""
4139     Gives the internal friction coefficient (atomic units) for Langevin dynamics
4140     (when [[ionmov]] = 9): fixed temperature simulations with random forces.
4141     
4142     The equation of motion is:
4143     
4144         M  I  d  2  R  I  /dt  2  = F  I  - [[friction]] M  I  dR  I  /dt - F_random I
4145     
4146     where F_random  I  is a Gaussian random force with average zero, and variance 2 [[friction]] M  I  kT.
4147     The atomic unit of friction is hartrees*electronic mass*(atomic time
4148     units)/Bohr  2. See [[cite:Chelikowsky2000]] for additional information.
4149     """,
4150     ),
4151

4179     stopping criterion defined by [[tolmxf]] relates to these scaled stresses.

4193     but we plan to include, energy, electronic band gap and alchemical potentials.
4194     Right now only value of 1 (enthalpy) works.

4198     Variable(
4199         abivarname="ga_fitness",
4200         varset="rlx",
4201         vartype="integer",
4202         topics=['GeoOpt_expert'],
4203         dimensions="scalar",
4204         defaultval=1,
4205         mnemonics="Genetic Algorithm FITNESS function selection",
4206         text="""
4207     Different methodologies to perform the roulette-wheel selection of parents.
4208     Even though, the objective function is the crystalline enthalpy (H_i), the
4209     weight of the population elements to be chosen from in a roulette-wheel
4210     selection can be given through different functions. We consider the following cases.
4211     
4212     1. F = H_i / Sum H_i
4213     2. F = exp(-(H_i-H_min)) / Sum exp(-(H_i-H_min))
4214     3. F = (1/n_i) / Sum (1/n_i). Where n_i is the position in the ordered list of enthalpies
4215     """,
4216     ),
4217     
4218     Variable(
4219         abivarname="ga_n_rules",
4220         varset="rlx",
4221         vartype="integer",
4222         topics=['GeoOpt_expert'],
4223         dimensions="scalar",
4224         defaultval=1,
4225         mnemonics="Genetic Algorithm Number of RULES",
4226         text="""
4227     Different genetic rules have been implemented and the user has the change to
4228     choose between any of them. Right now we have 4 rules. See [[ga_rules]]
4229     """,
4230     ),
4231     
4232     Variable(
4233         abivarname="ga_opt_percent",
4234         varset="rlx",
4235         vartype="real",
4236         topics=['GeoOpt_expert'],
4237         dimensions="scalar",
4238         defaultval=0.2,
4239         mnemonics="Genetic Algorithm OPTimal PERCENT",
4240         text="""
4241     Percentage of the population that according to the fitness function passes to
4242     the following iteration.
