4244     ),
4245     
4246     Variable(
4247         abivarname="ga_rules",
4248         varset="rlx",
4249         vartype="integer",
4250         topics=['GeoOpt_expert'],
4251         dimensions="scalar",
4252         defaultval=1,
4253         mnemonics="Genetic Algorithm RULES",
4254         text="""
4255     Different genetic rules have been implemented and the user has the change to
4256     choose between any of them. The chosen number of rules have been defined in [[ga_n_rules]]
4257     
4258     Implemented rules are
4259     1) crossover. Two parents are randomly chosen and two springs are mixed from
4260     the two by (a) choosing randomly (through Fitness function) two parents and
4261     then randomly rotating and shifting the coordinates withing that particular
4262     cell. (b) Slice every one of the unit cell of the parents along a random
4263     direction and creating the spring offs from the pieces of the two parents.
4264     2) Vector flip mutation. From the coordinates from a given parent, a piece of
4265     it is inverted.
4266     3) Random strain. A random anisotropic deformation is given to the unit cell.
4267     4) Coordinates mutation of 1/4 of the whole coordinates.
4268     """,
4269     ),
4270     
4271     Variable(
4272         abivarname="genafm",
4273         varset="geo",
4274         vartype="real",
4275         topics=['spinpolarisation_useful', 'SmartSymm_useful'],
4276         dimensions=[3],
4277         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=3, value=0),
4278         mnemonics="GENerator of the translation for Anti-FerroMagnetic space group",
4279         text="""
4280     This input variable might be used to define a Shubnikov type IV magnetic space
4281     group (anti-ferromagnetic space group). The user is advised to consult [[cite:Bradley1972]]
4282     A Shubnikov type IV magnetic space group might be defined by its Fedorov space
4283     group (set of spatial symmetries, that do not change the magnetization), and
4284     one translation associated with a change of magnetization. [[genafm]] is
4285     precisely this translation, in reduced coordinates (like [[xred]])
4286     Thus, one way to specify a Shubnikov IV magnetic space group, is to define
4287     both [[spgroup]] and [[genafm]]. Alternatively, one might define [[spgroup]]
4288     and [[spgroupma]], or define by hand the set of symmetries, using [[symrel]],
4289     [[tnons]] and [[symafm]]
4290     """,
4291     ),
4292     
4293     Variable(
4294         abivarname="get1den",
4295         varset="files",
4296         vartype="integer",
4297         topics=['nonlinear_useful', 'ElPhonInt_useful'],
4298         dimensions="scalar",
4299         defaultval=0,
4300         mnemonics="GET the first-order density from _1DEN file",
4301         text="""
4302     Relevant only for non self consistent RF calculations (e.g. to get electron
4303     phonon matrix elements) or for non linear RF calculations (to get mixed higher
4304     order derivatives you need several perturbed densities and wave functions).
4305     Indicate the files from which first-order densities must be obtained, in
4306     multi-dataset mode (in single dataset mode, use [[ird1den]]).
4307     NOTE: a negative value of a "get" variable indicates the number of datasets
4308     to go backwards; it is not the number to be subtracted from the current
4309     dataset to find the proper dataset. As an example:
4310     
4311           ndtset 3   jdtset 1 2 4  getXXX -1
4312     
4313     refers to dataset 2 when dataset 4 is initialized.
4314     """,
4315     ),
4316     
4317     Variable(
4318         abivarname="get1wf",
4319         varset="files",
4320         vartype="integer",
4321         topics=['multidtset_useful'],
4322         dimensions="scalar",
4323         defaultval=0,
4324         mnemonics="GET the first-order wavefunctions from _1WF file",
4325         text="""
4326     Eventually used when [[ndtset]] > 0 (in the multi-dataset mode), to indicate
4327     starting wavefunctions, as an alternative to [[irdwfk]], [[irdwfq]],
4328     [[ird1wf]], [[irdddk]]. One should first read the explanations given for these
4329     latter variables.
4330     The **getwfk**, **getwfq**, [[get1wf]] and **getddk** variables are
4331     typically used to chain the calculations in the multi-dataset mode, since they
4332     describe from which dataset the OUTPUT wavefunctions are to be taken, as INPUT
4333     wavefunctions of the present dataset.
4334     
4335     We now focus on the **getwfk** input variable (the only one used in ground-
4336     state calculations), but the rules for **getwfq** and [[get1wf]] are similar,
4337     with _WFK replaced by _WFQ or _1WF.
4338     If **getwfk** ==0, no use of previously computed output wavefunction file
4339     appended with _DSx_WFK is done.
4340     If **getwfk** is positive, its value gives the index of the dataset for which
4341     the output wavefunction file appended with _WFK must be used.
4342     If **getwfk** is -1, the output wf file with _WFK of the previous dataset must
4343     be taken, which is a frequently occurring case.
4344     If **getwfk** is a negative number, it indicates the number of datasets to go
4345     backward to find the needed wavefunction file. In this case, if one refers to
4346     a non existent data set (prior to the first), the wavefunctions are not
4347     initialised from a disk file, so that it is as if **getwfk** =0 for that
4348     initialisation. Thanks to this rule, the use of **getwfk** -1 is rather
4349     straightforward: except for the first wavefunctions, that are not initialized
4350     by reading a disk file, the output wavefunction of one dataset is input of the
4351     next one.
4352     In the case of a ddk calculation in a multi dataset run, in order to compute
4353     correctly the localisation tensor, it is mandatory to give [[getddk]] the
4354     value of the current dataset (i.e. getddk3 3 ) - this is a bit strange and
4355     should be changed in the future.
4356     NOTE: a negative value of a "get" variable indicates the number of datasets
4357     to go backwards; it is not the number to be subtracted from the current
4358     dataset to find the proper dataset. As an example:
4359     
4360           ndtset 3   jdtset 1 2 4  getXXX -1
4361     
4362     refers to dataset 2 when dataset 4 is initialized.
4363     """,
4364     ),
4365     
4366     Variable(
4367         abivarname="getbscoup",
4368         varset="files",
4369         vartype="integer",
4370         topics=['multidtset_useful'],
4371         dimensions="scalar",
4372         defaultval=0,
4373         mnemonics="GET the Bethe-Salpeter COUPling block from...",
4374         text="""
4375     Eventually used when [[ndtset]] > 0 (multi-dataset mode) and, in the case of a
4376     Bethe-Salpeter calculation to indicate that the starting coupling block of the
4377     excitonic Hamiltonian will be taken from the output of a previous dataset. It
4378     is used to chain the calculations, since it describes from which dataset the
4379     OUTPUT coupling block is to be taken, as INPUT of the present dataset.
4380     If [[getbscoup]] == 0, no such use of previously computed coupling block file is done.
4381     If [[getbscoup]] is positive, its value gives the index of the dataset to be
4382     used as input.
4383     If [[getbscoup]] is -1, the output of the previous dataset must be taken,
4384     which is a frequently occurring case.
4385     If [[getbscoup]] is a negative number, it indicates the number of datasets to
4386     go backward to find the needed file. In this case, if one refers to a non
4387     existent data set (prior to the first), the coupling block is not initialised
4388     from a disk file, so that it is as if [[getbscoup]] = 0 for that initialisation.
4389     """,
4390     ),
4391     
4392     Variable(
4393         abivarname="getbseig",
4394         varset="files",
4395         vartype="integer",
4396         topics=['multidtset_useful'],
4397         dimensions="scalar",
4398         defaultval=0,
4399         mnemonics="GET the Bethe-Salpeter EIGenstates from...",
4400         text="""
4401     Eventually used when [[ndtset]] > 0 (multi-dataset mode) and, in the case of a
4402     Bethe-Salpeter calculation to indicate that the starting excitonic eigenstates
4403     are to be taken from the output of a previous dataset. It is used to chain the
4404     calculations, since it describes from which dataset the OUTPUT eigenstates are
4405     to be taken, as INPUT eigenstates of the present dataset.
4406     If [[getbseig]] == 0, no such use of previously computed output eigenstates file is done.
4407     If [[getbseig]] is positive, its value gives the index of the dataset from
4408     which the output states is to be used as input.
4409     If [[getbseig]] is -1, the output eigenstates of the previous dataset must be
4410     taken, which is a frequently occurring case.
4411     If [[getbseig]] is a negative number, it indicates the number of datasets to
4412     go backward to find the needed file. In this case, if one refers to a non
4413     existent data set (prior to the first), the eigenstates are not initialised
4414     from a disk file, so that it is as if [[getbseig]] = 0 for that initialisation.
4415     """,
4416     ),
4417     
4418     Variable(
4419         abivarname="getbsreso",
4420         varset="files",
4421         vartype="integer",
4422         topics=['multidtset_useful'],
4423         dimensions="scalar",
4424         defaultval=0,
4425         mnemonics="GET the Bethe-Salpeter RESOnant block from...",
4426         text="""
4427     Eventually used when [[ndtset]] > 0 (multi-dataset mode) and, in the case of a
4428     Bethe-Salpeter calculation to indicate that the starting resonant block of the
4429     excitonic Hamiltonian will be taken from the output of a previous dataset. It
4430     is used to chain the calculations, since it describes from which dataset the
4431     OUTPUT resonant block is to be taken, as INPUT of the present dataset.
4432     If [[getbsreso]] == 0, no such use of previously computed resonant block file is done.
4433     If [[getbsreso]] is positive, its value gives the index of the dataset to be used as input.
4434     If [[getbsreso]] is -1, the output of the previous dataset must be taken,
4435     which is a frequently occurring case.
4436     If [[getbsreso]] is a negative number, it indicates the number of datasets to
4437     go backward to find the needed file. In this case, if one refers to a non
4438     existent data set (prior to the first), the resonant block is not initialised
4439     from a disk file, so that it is as if [[getbsreso]] = 0 for that initialisation.
4440     """,
4441     ),
4442     
4443     Variable(
4444         abivarname="getcell",
4445         varset="rlx",
4446         vartype="integer",
4447         topics=['multidtset_useful'],
4448         dimensions="scalar",
4449         defaultval=0,
4450         mnemonics="GET CELL parameters from...",
4451         text="""
4452     This variable is typically used to chain the calculations, in the multi-
4453     dataset mode ([[ndtset]] > 0), since it describes from which dataset [[acell]]
4454     and [[rprim]] are to be taken, as input of the present dataset. The cell
4455     parameters are [[EVOLVING]] variables, for which such a chain of calculations is useful.
4456     If 0, no previously computed values are used.
4457     If >0, the value must be the index of the dataset from which the
4458     cell data is to be used as input data. It must be the index of a dataset already
4459     computed in the SAME run.
4460     If equal to -1, the output data of the previous dataset must be taken, which
4461     is a frequently occurring case. However, if the first dataset is treated, -1
4462     is equivalent to 0, since no dataset has been computed in the same run.
4463     If another negative number, it indicates the number of datasets to go backward
4464     to find the needed data (once again, going back beyond the first dataset is
4465     equivalent to using a null get variable).
4466     """,
4467     ),
4468     
4469     Variable(
4470         abivarname="getddb",
4471         varset="files",
4472         vartype="integer",
4473         topics=['ElPhonInt_expert', 'TDepES_useful'],
4474         dimensions="scalar",
4475         defaultval=0,
4476         mnemonics="GET the DDB from...",
4477         text="""
4478     This variable should be used when performing electron-phonon or temperature-
4479     dependence calculations. The Born effective charge as well as the dielectric
4480     tensor will be read from a previous DFPT calculations of the electric field at
4481     q=Gamma. The use of this variable will trigger the cancellation of a residual
4482     dipole that leads to an unphysical divergence of the GKK with vanishing
4483     q-points. The use of this variable greatly improves the k-point convergence
4484     speed as the density of the k-point grid required to obtain the fulfillment of
4485     the charge neutrality sum rule is usually prohibitively large.
4486     If [[getddb]] == 0, no such use of previously computed Born effective charge and
4487     dielectric tensor is done.
4488     If [[getddb]] is positive, its value gives the index of the dataset from which
4489     the output density is to be used as input.
4490     If [[getddb]] is -1, the output density of the previous dataset must be taken,
4491     which is a frequently occurring case.
4492     If [[getddb]] is a negative number, it indicates the number of datasets to go
4493     backward to find the needed file.
4494     NOTE: a negative value of a "get" variable indicates the number of datasets
4495     to go backwards; it is not the number to be subtracted from the current
4496     dataset to find the proper dataset. As an example:
4497     
4498           ndtset 3   jdtset 1 2 4  getXXX -1
4499     
4500     refers to dataset 2 when dataset 4 is initialized.
4501     """,
4502     ),
4503     
4504     Variable(
4505         abivarname="getddk",
4506         varset="files",
4507         vartype="integer",
4508         topics=['multidtset_useful'],
4509         dimensions="scalar",
4510         defaultval=0,
4511         mnemonics="GET the DDK wavefunctions from _1WF file",
4512         text="""
4513     Eventually used when [[ndtset]] > 0 (in the multi-dataset mode), to indicate
4514     starting wavefunctions, as an alternative to
4515     [[irdwfk]],[[irdwfq]],[[ird1wf]],[[irdddk]]. One should first read the
4516     explanations given for these latter variables.
4517     The **getwfk**, **getwfq**, **get1wf** and [[getddk]] variables are
4518     typically used to chain the calculations in the multi-dataset mode, since they
4519     describe from which dataset the OUTPUT wavefunctions are to be taken, as INPUT
4520     wavefunctions of the present dataset.
4521     
4522     We now focus on the **getwfk** input variable (the only one used in ground-
4523     state calculations), but the rules for **getwfq** and **get1wf** are similar,
4524     with _WFK replaced by _WFQ or _1WF.
4525     If **getwfk** ==0, no use of previously computed output wavefunction file
4526     appended with _DSx_WFK is done.
4527     If **getwfk** is positive, its value gives the index of the dataset for which
4528     the output wavefunction file appended with _WFK must be used.
4529     If **getwfk** is -1, the output wf file with _WFK of the previous dataset must
4530     be taken, which is a frequently occurring case.
4531     If **getwfk** is a negative number, it indicates the number of datasets to go
4532     backward to find the needed wavefunction file. In this case, if one refers to
4533     a non existent data set (prior to the first), the wavefunctions are not
4534     initialised from a disk file, so that it is as if **getwfk** =0 for that
4535     initialisation. Thanks to this rule, the use of **getwfk** -1 is rather
4536     straightforward: except for the first wavefunctions, that are not initialized
4537     by reading a disk file, the output wavefunction of one dataset is input of the
4538     next one.
4539     In the case of a ddk calculation in a multi dataset run, in order to compute
4540     correctly the localisation tensor, it is mandatory to declare give getddk the
4541     value of the current dataset (i.e. getddk3 3 ) - this is a bit strange and
4542     should be changed in the future.
4543     NOTE: a negative value of a "get" variable indicates the number of datasets
4544     to go backwards; it is not the number to be subtracted from the current
4545     dataset to find the proper dataset. As an example:
4546     
4547           ndtset 3   jdtset 1 2 4  getXXX -1
4548     
4549     refers to dataset 2 when dataset 4 is initialized.
4550     """,
4551     ),
4552     
4553     Variable(
4554         abivarname="getden",
4555         varset="files",
4556         vartype="integer",
4557         topics=['multidtset_useful'],
4558         dimensions="scalar",
4559         defaultval=0,
4560         mnemonics="GET the DENsity from...",
4561         text="""
4562     Eventually used when [[ndtset]] > 0 (multi-dataset mode) and, in the case of a
4563     ground-state calculation, if [[iscf]]<0 (non-SCF calculation), to indicate
4564     that the starting density is to be taken from the output of a previous
4565     dataset. It is used to chain the calculations, since it describes from which
4566     dataset the OUTPUT density are to be taken, as INPUT density of the present dataset.
4567     
4568     If [[getden]] == 0, no such use of previously computed output density file is done.
4569     
4570     If [[getden]] is positive, its value gives the index of the dataset from which
4571     the output density is to be used as input.
4572     
4573     If [[getden]] is -1, the output density of the previous dataset must be taken,
4574     which is a frequently occurring case.
4575     
4576     If [[getden]] is a negative number, it indicates the number of datasets to go
4577     backward to find the needed file. In this case, if one refers to a non
4578     existent data set (prior to the first), the density is not initialised from a
4579     disk file, so that it is as if [[getden]] = 0 for that initialisation. Thanks to
4580     this rule, the use of [[getden]] -1 is rather straightforward: except for the
4581     first density, that is not initialized by reading a disk file, the output
4582     density of one dataset is input of the next one.
4583     Be careful: the output density file of a run with non-zero [[ionmov]] does
4584     not have the proper name (it has a "TIM" indication) for use as an input of an
4585     [[iscf]]<0 calculation.
4586     One should use the output density of a [[ionmov]] == 0 run.
4587     NOTE: a negative value of a "get" variable indicates the number of datasets
4588     to go backwards; it is not the number to be subtracted from the current
4589     dataset to find the proper dataset. As an example:
4590     
4591           ndtset 3   jdtset 1 2 4  getXXX -1
4592     
4593     refers to dataset 2 when dataset 4 is initialized.
4594     """,
4595     ),
4596     
4597     Variable(
4598         abivarname="getgam_eig2nkq",
4599         varset="dev",
4600         vartype="integer",
4601         topics=['multidtset_useful', 'TDepES_useful'],
4602         dimensions="scalar",
4603         defaultval=0,
4604         mnemonics="GET the GAMma phonon data EIG2NKQ from dataset",
4605         requires="[[ieig2rf]] != 0 and [[qpt]] != (0.0, 0.0, 0.0)",
4606         text="""
4607     Relevant for second-order eigenvalue calculations using response-functions
4608     ([[ieig2rf]] != 0), and only for non-zero wavevectors [[qpt]].
4609     From the electron-phonon matrix elements at some wavevector only, it is not
4610     possible to determine the Debye-Waller contribution: one has to know also the
4611     q=Gamma electron-phonon matrix elements.
4612     The variable [[getgam_eig2nkq]] allows one to transmit the information about the
4613     second-order derivatives of the eigenvalues for q=Gamma from the dataset where
4614     the calculation at Gamma was done, to the datasets for other wavevectors.
4615     """,
4616     ),
4617     
4618     Variable(
4619         abivarname="gethaydock",
4620         varset="files",
4621         vartype="integer",
4622         topics=['multidtset_useful'],
4623         dimensions="scalar",
4624         defaultval=0,
4625         mnemonics="GET the HAYDOCK restart file from...",
4626         text="""
4627     Eventually used when [[ndtset]] > 0 (multi-dataset mode) and, in the case of a
4628     Bethe-Salpeter calculation to indicate that the Haydock iterative technique
4629     will be restarted from the output of a previous dataset.
4630     If [[gethaydock]] == 0, no such use of previously computed coupling block file is done.
4631     If [[gethaydock]] is positive, its value gives the index of the dataset to be used as input.
4632     If [[gethaydock]] is -1, the output of the previous dataset must be taken,
4633     which is a frequently occurring case.
4634     If [[gethaydock]] is a negative number, it indicates the number of datasets to
4635     go backward to find the needed file. In this case, if one refers to a non
4636     existent data set (prior to the first), the coupling block is not initialised
4637     from a disk file, so that it is as if [[gethaydock]] = 0 for that initialisation.
4638     """,
4639     ),
4640     
4641     Variable(
4642         abivarname="getocc",
4643         varset="files",
4644         vartype="integer",
4645         topics=['multidtset_useful'],
4646         dimensions="scalar",
4647         defaultval=0,
4648         mnemonics="GET OCC parameters from...",
4649         text="""
4650     This variable is typically used to chain the calculations, in the multi-
4651     dataset mode ([[ndtset]] > 0), since it describes from which dataset the array
4652     [[occ]] is to be taken, as input of the present dataset. The occupation
4653     numbers are [[EVOLVING]] variables, for which such a chain of calculations is useful.
4654     If [[getocc]] == 0, no such use of previously computed output occupations is done.
4655     If [[getocc]] is positive, its value gives the index of the dataset from which
4656     the data are to be used as input data. It must be the index of a dataset
4657     already computed in the SAME run.
4658     If [[getocc]] is -1, the output data of the previous dataset must be taken,
4659     which is a frequently occurring case.
4660     If [[getocc]] is a negative number, it indicates the number of datasets to go
4661     backward to find the needed data. In this case, if one refers to a non
4662     existent data set (prior to the first), the date is not initialised from a
4663     disk file, so that it is as if [[getocc]] == 0 for that initialisation.
4664     NOTE that a non-zero [[getocc]] MUST be used with [[occopt]] == 2, so that the
4665     number of bands has to be initialized for each k point. Of course, these
4666     numbers of bands must be identical to the numbers of bands of the dataset from
4667     which [[occ]] will be copied. The same is true for the number of k points.
4668     NOTE: a negative value of a "get" variable indicates the number of datasets
4669     to go backwards; it is not the number to be subtracted from the current
4670     dataset to find the proper dataset. As an example:
4671     
4672           ndtset 3   jdtset 1 2 4  getXXX -1
4673     
4674     refers to dataset 2 when dataset 4 is initialized.
4675     """,
4676     ),
4677     
4678     Variable(
4679         abivarname="getqps",
4680         varset="files",
4681         vartype="integer",
4682         topics=['multidtset_useful', 'GW_useful', 'Susceptibility_useful', 'SelfEnergy_useful'],
4683         dimensions="scalar",
4684         defaultval=0,
4685         mnemonics="GET QuasiParticle Structure",
4686         text="""
4687     Used when [[ndtset]] > 0 (multi-dataset mode) and [[optdriver]] = 3, or 4
4688     (screening or sigma step of a GW calculation), to indicate that the
4689     eigenvalues and possibly the wavefunctions have to be taken from a previous
4690     quasiparticle calculation (instead of the usual LDA starting point). This is
4691     to achieve quasiparticle self-consistency. See also [[irdqps]]
4692     NOTE: a negative value of a "get" variable indicates the number of datasets
4693     to go backwards; it is not the number to be subtracted from the current
4694     dataset to find the proper dataset. As an example:
4695     
4696           ndtset 3   jdtset 1 2 4  getXXX -1
4697     
4698     refers to dataset 2 when dataset 4 is initialized.
4699     """,
4700     ),
4701     
4702     Variable(
4703         abivarname="getscr",
4704         varset="files",
4705         vartype="integer",
4706         topics=['multidtset_useful', 'GW_useful', 'SelfEnergy_useful'],
4707         dimensions="scalar",
4708         defaultval=0,
4709         mnemonics="GET SCReening (the inverse dielectric matrix) from...",
4710         text="""
4711     Used when [[ndtset]] > 0 (multi-dataset mode) and [[optdriver]] = 4 (sigma step of
4712     a GW calculation), to indicate that the dielectric matrix (_SCR file) is to be
4713     taken from the output of a previous dataset. It is used to chain the
4714     calculations, since it describes from which dataset the OUTPUT dielectric
4715     matrix is to be taken, as INPUT of the present dataset.
4716     If [[getscr]] == 0, no such use of previously computed output _SCR file is done.
4717     If [[getscr]] is positive, its value gives the index of the dataset from which
4718     the output _SCR file is to be used as input.
4719     If [[getscr]] is -1, the output _SCR file of the previous dataset must be
4720     taken, which is a frequently occurring case.
4721     If [[getscr]] is a negative number, it indicates the number of datasets to go
4722     backward to find the needed file. In this case, if one refers to a non
4723     existent data set (prior to the first), the _SCR file is not initialised from
4724     a disk file, so that it is as if [[getscr]] = 0 for that initialisation.
4725     NOTE: a negative value of a "get" variable indicates the number of datasets
4726     to go backwards; it is not the number to be subtracted from the current
4727     dataset to find the proper dataset. As an example:
4728     
4729           ndtset 3   jdtset 1 2 4  getXXX -1
4730     
4731     refers to dataset 2 when dataset 4 is initialized.
4732     """,
4733     ),
4734     
4735     Variable(
4736         abivarname="getsuscep",
4737         varset="files",
4738         vartype="integer",
4739         topics=['multidtset_useful', 'GW_useful', 'SelfEnergy_useful'],
4740         dimensions="scalar",
4741         defaultval=0,
4742         mnemonics="GET SUSCEPtibility (the irreducible polarizability) from...",
4743         text="""
4744     Used when [[ndtset]] > 0 (multi-dataset mode) and [[optdriver]] = 4 (sigma step of
4745     a GW calculation), to indicate that the irreducible polarizability (_SUSC
4746     file) is to be taken from the output of a previous dataset. It is used to
4747     chain the calculations, since it describes from which dataset the OUTPUT
4748     susceptibility is to be taken, as INPUT of the present dataset. Performing a
4749     GW calculations starting from the _SUSC file instead of the _SCR file presents
4750     the advantage that starting from the irreducible polarizability, one can
4751     calculate the screened interaction using different expressions without having
4752     to perform a screening calculation from scratch. For example, it is possible
4753     to apply a cutoff to the Coulomb interaction in order to facilitate the
4754     convergence of the GW correction with respect to the size of the supercell
4755     (see [[vcutgeo]] and [[icutcoul]])
4756     If [[getsuscep]] == 0, no such use of previously computed output _SUSC file is done.
4757     If [[getsuscep]] is positive, its value gives the index of the dataset from
4758     which the output _SUSC file is to be used as input.
4759     If [[getsuscep]] is -1, the output _SUSC file of the previous dataset must be
4760     taken, which is a frequently occurring case.
4761     If [[getsuscep]] is a negative number, it indicates the number of datasets to
4762     go backward to find the needed file. In this case, if one refers to a non
4763     existent data set (prior to the first), the _SUSC file is not initialised from
4764     a disk file, so that it is as if [[getsuscep]] = 0 for that initialisation.
4765     NOTE: a negative value of a "get" variable indicates the number of datasets
4766     to go backwards; it is not the number to be subtracted from the current
4767     dataset to find the proper dataset. As an example:
4768     
4769           ndtset 3   jdtset 1 2 4  getXXX -1
4770     
4771     refers to dataset 2 when dataset 4 is initialized.
4772     """,
4773     ),
4774     
4775     Variable(
4776         abivarname="getvel",
4777         varset="rlx",
4778         vartype="integer",
4779         topics=['multidtset_useful'],
4780         dimensions="scalar",
4781         defaultval=0,
4782         mnemonics="GET VEL from...",
4783         text="""
4784     These variables are typically used to chain the calculations, in the multi-
4785     dataset mode ([[ndtset]] > 0) since they describe from which dataset the
4786     corresponding output variables are to be taken, as input of the present
4787     dataset. The atomic positions and velocities are [[EVOLVING]] variables, for
4788     which such a chain of calculation is useful.
4789     Note that the use of [[getxcart]] and [[getxred]] differs when [[acell]] and
4790     [[rprim]] are different from one dataset to the other.
4791     If 0, no previously computed values are used.
4792     If >0, the integer should correspond to the index of the dataset from which the VEL data should be used. It must be the index of a dataset already computed in the SAME run.
4793     If equal to -1, the output data of the previous dataset is taken, which
4794     is a frequently occurring case. However, if the first dataset is treated, -1
4795     is equivalent to 0, since no dataset has yet been computed in the same run.
4796     If another negative number, it indicates the number of datasets to go backward
4797     to find the needed data (once again, going back beyond the first dataset is
4798     equivalent to using a null get variable).
4799     Note: [[getxred]] and [[getxcart]] cannot be simultaneously non-zero for the
4800     same dataset. On the other hand the use of [[getvel]] with [[getxred]] is
4801     allowed, despite the different coordinate system.
4802     """,
4803     ),
4804     
4805     Variable(
4806         abivarname="getwfk",
4807         varset="files",
4808         vartype="integer",
4809         topics=['multidtset_useful'],
4810         dimensions="scalar",
4811         defaultval=0,
4812         mnemonics="GET the wavefunctions from _WFK file",
4813         text="""
4814     Eventually used when [[ndtset]] > 0 (in the multi-dataset mode), to indicate
4815     starting wavefunctions, as an alternative to [[irdwfk]],[[irdwfq]],[[ird1wf]],
4816     or [[irdddk]]. One should first read the explanations given for these latter variables.
4817     The [[getwfk]], **getwfq**, **get1wf** and **getddk** variables are typically
4818     used to chain the calculations in the multi-dataset mode, since they describe
4819     from which dataset the OUTPUT wavefunctions are to be taken, as INPUT
4820     wavefunctions of the present dataset.
4821     
4822     We now focus on the [[getwfk]] input variable (the only one used in ground-
4823     state calculations), but the rules for **getwfq** and **get1wf** are similar,
4824     with _WFK replaced by _WFQ or _1WF.
4825     If [[getwfk]] == 0, no use of previously computed output wavefunction file
4826     appended with _DSx_WFK is done.
4827     If [[getwfk]] is positive, its value gives the index of the dataset for which
4828     the output wavefunction file appended with _WFK must be used.
4829     If [[getwfk]] is -1, the output wf file with _WFK of the previous dataset must
4830     be taken, which is a frequently occurring case.
4831     If [[getwfk]] is a negative number, it indicates the number of datasets to go
4832     backward to find the needed wavefunction file. In this case, if one refers to
4833     a non existent data set (prior to the first), the wavefunctions are not
4834     initialised from a disk file, so that it is as if [[getwfk]] = 0 for that
4835     initialisation. Thanks to this rule, the use of [[getwfk]] -1 is rather
4836     straightforward: except for the first wavefunctions, that are not initialized
4837     by reading a disk file, the output wavefunction of one dataset is input of the
4838     next one.
4839     In the case of a ddk calculation in a multi dataset run, in order to compute
4840     correctly the localisation tensor, it is mandatory to declare give getddk the
4841     value of the current dataset (i.e. getddk3 3 ) - this is a bit strange and
4842     should be changed in the future.
4843     NOTE: a negative value of a "get" variable indicates the number of datasets
4844     to go backwards; it is not the number to be subtracted from the current
4845     dataset to find the proper dataset. As an example:
4846     
4847           ndtset 3   jdtset 1 2 4  getXXX -1
4848     
4849     refers to dataset 2 when dataset 4 is initialized.
4850     """,
4851     ),
4852     
4853     Variable(
4854         abivarname="getwfkfine",
4855         varset="dev",
4856         vartype="integer",
4857         topics=['multidtset_useful', 'DFPT_useful', 'TDepES_useful'],
4858         dimensions="scalar",
4859         defaultval=0,
4860         mnemonics="GET the fine grid wavefunctions from _WFK file",
4861         text="""
4862     Eventually used when [[ndtset]] > 0 (in the multi-dataset mode), to indicate
4863     starting wavefunctions, as an alternative to [[irdwfkfine]]. One should first
4864     read the explanations given for these latter variables.
4865     The [[getwfkfine]] variables is typically used to chain the calculations in
4866     the multi-dataset mode, since they describe from which dataset the OUTPUT
4867     wavefunctions are to be taken, as INPUT wavefunctions of the present dataset.
4868     If [[getwfkfine]] == 0, no use of previously computed output wavefunction file
4869     appended with _DSx_WFK is done.
4870     If [[getwfkfine]] is positive, its value gives the index of the dataset for
4871     which the output wavefunction file appended with _WFK must be used.
4872     If [[getwfkfine]] is -1, the output wf file with _WFK of the previous dataset
4873     must be taken, which is a frequently occurring case.
4874     If [[getwfkfine]] is a negative number, it indicates the number of datasets to
4875     go backward to find the needed wavefunction file. In this case, if one refers
4876     to a non existent data set (prior to the first), the wavefunctions are not
4877     initialised from a disk file, so that it is as if [[getwfkfine]] = 0 for that
4878     initialisation. Thanks to this rule, the use of [[getwfkfine]] -1 is rather
4879     straightforward: except for the first wavefunctions, that are not initialized
4880     by reading a disk file, the output wavefunction of one dataset is input of the
4881     next one.
4882     NOTE: a negative value of a "get" variable indicates the number of datasets
4883     to go backwards; it is not the number to be subtracted from the current
4884     dataset to find the proper dataset. As an example:
4885     
4886          ndtset 3   jdtset 1 2 4  getXXX -1
4887     
4888     refers to dataset 2 when dataset 4 is initialized. Response-function calculation:
4889     
4890       * one and only one of [[getwfkfine]] or [[irdwfkfine]] MUST be non-zero
4891       * if [[getwfkfine]] = 1: read ground state k -wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _WFK,
4892         produced in a previous ground state calculation.
4893       * Reading the fine grid wavefunction will trigger the k-points interpolation
4894       technique of the temperature dependent calculations.
4895     
4896     Bethe-Salpeter calculation:
4897     
4898       * one and only one of [[getwfkfine]] or [[irdwfkfine]] MUST be non-zero
4899       * if [[getwfkfine]] = 1: read ground state k -wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _WFK,
4900         produced in a previous ground state calculation
4901       * This variable or [[irdwfkfine]] is mandatory when [[bs_interp_mode]] == 1
4902     
4903     For further information about the *files file*, consult the [[help:abinit#files-file]].
4904     
4905     **This variable is experimental. In development.**
4906     """,
4907     ),
4908     
4909     Variable(
4910         abivarname="getwfq",
4911         varset="files",
4912         vartype="integer",
4913         topics=['multidtset_useful'],
4914         dimensions="scalar",
4915         defaultval=0,
4916         mnemonics="GET the wavefunctions from _WFQ file",
4917         text="""
4918     Eventually used when [[ndtset]] > 0 (in the multi-dataset mode), to indicate
4919     starting wavefunctions, as an alternative to [[irdwfk]],[[irdwfq]],[[ird1wf]]
4920     or [[irdddk]]. One should first read the explanations given for these latter
4921     variables.
4922     The **getwfk**, [[getwfq]], **get1wf** and **getddk** variables are typically
4923     used to chain the calculations in the multi-dataset mode, since they describe
4924     from which dataset the OUTPUT wavefunctions are to be taken, as INPUT
4925     wavefunctions of the present dataset.
4926     
4927     We now focus on the **getwfk** input variable (the only one used in ground-
4928     state calculations), but the rules for [[getwfq]] and **get1wf** are similar,
4929     with _WFK replaced by _WFQ or _1WF.
4930     If **getwfk** ==0, no use of previously computed output wavefunction file
4931     appended with _DSx_WFK is done.
4932     If **getwfk** is positive, its value gives the index of the dataset for which
4933     the output wavefunction file appended with _WFK must be used.
4934     If **getwfk** is -1, the output wf file with _WFK of the previous dataset must
4935     be taken, which is a frequently occurring case.
4936     If **getwfk** is a negative number, it indicates the number of datasets to go
4937     backward to find the needed wavefunction file. In this case, if one refers to
4938     a non existent data set (prior to the first), the wavefunctions are not
4939     initialised from a disk file, so that it is as if **getwfk** =0 for that
4940     initialisation. Thanks to this rule, the use of **getwfk** -1 is rather
4941     straightforward: except for the first wavefunctions, that are not initialized
4942     by reading a disk file, the output wavefunction of one dataset is input of the
4943     next one.
4944     In the case of a ddk calculation in a multi dataset run, in order to compute
4945     correctly the localisation tensor, it is mandatory to declare give getddk the
4946     value of the current dataset (i.e. getddk3 3 ) - this is a bit strange and
4947     should be changed in the future.
4948     NOTE: a negative value of a "get" variable indicates the number of datasets
4949     to go backwards; it is not the number to be subtracted from the current
4950     dataset to find the proper dataset. As an example:
4951     
4952           ndtset 3   jdtset 1 2 4  getXXX -1
4953     
4954     refers to dataset 2 when dataset 4 is initialized.
4955     """,
4956     ),
4957     
4958     Variable(
4959         abivarname="getxcart",
4960         varset="rlx",
4961         vartype="integer",
4962         topics=['multidtset_useful'],
4963         dimensions="scalar",
4964         defaultval=0,
4965         mnemonics="GET XCART from...",
4966         text="""
4967     These variables are typically used to chain the calculations, in the multi-
4968     dataset mode ([[ndtset]] > 0) since they describe from which dataset the
4969     corresponding output variables are to be taken, as input of the present
4970     dataset. The atomic positions and velocities are [[EVOLVING]] variables, for
4971     which such a chain of calculation is useful.
4972     Note that the use of [[getxcart]] and [[getxred]] differs when [[acell]] and
4973     [[rprim]] are different from one dataset to the other.
4974     If 0, no previously computed values are used.
4975     If >0, the integer must correspond to the index of the dataset from which the
4976     data are to be used as input data. It must be the index of a dataset already
4977     computed in the SAME run.
4978     If equal to -1, the output data of the previous dataset must be taken, which
4979     is a frequently occurring case. However, if the first dataset is treated, -1
4980     is equivalent to 0, since no dataset has yet been computed in the same run.
4981     If another negative number, it indicates the number of datasets to go backward
4982     to find the needed data (once again, going back beyond the first dataset is
4983     equivalent to using a null get variable).
4984     Note: [[getxred]] and [[getxcart]] cannot be simultaneously non-zero for the
4985     same dataset. On the other hand the use of [[getvel]] with [[getxred]] is
4986     allowed, despite the different coordinate system.
4987     """,
4988     ),
4989     
4990     Variable(
4991         abivarname="getxred",
4992         varset="rlx",
4993         vartype="integer",
4994         topics=['multidtset_useful'],
4995         dimensions="scalar",
4996         defaultval=0,
4997         mnemonics="GET XRED from...",
4998         text="""
4999     These variables are typically used to chain the calculations, in the multi-
5000     dataset mode ([[ndtset]] > 0) since they describe from which dataset the
5001     corresponding output variables are to be taken, as input of the present
5002     dataset. The atomic positions and velocities are [[EVOLVING]] variables, for
5003     which such a chain of calculation is useful.
5004     Note that the use of [[getxcart]] and [[getxred]] differs when [[acell]] and
5005     [[rprim]] are different from one dataset to the other.
5006     If 0, no use of previously computed values must occur.
5007     If >0, the integer must correspond to the index of the dataset from which the
5008     data are to be used as input data. It must be the index of a dataset already
5009     computed in the SAME run.
5010     If equal to -1, the output data of the previous dataset must be taken, which
5011     is a frequently occurring case. However, if the first dataset is treated, -1
5012     is equivalent to 0, since no dataset has yet been computed in the same run.
5013     If another negative number, it indicates the number of datasets to go backward
5014     to find the needed data (once again, going back beyond the first dataset is
5015     equivalent to using a null get variable).
5016     Note: [[getxred]] and [[getxcart]] cannot be simultaneously non-zero for the
5017     same dataset. On the other hand the use of [[getvel]] with [[getxred]] is
5018     allowed, despite the different coordinate system.
5019     """,
5020     ),
5021     
5022     Variable(
5023         abivarname="goprecon",
5024         varset="rlx",
5025         vartype="integer",
5026         topics=['GeoOpt_expert'],
5027         dimensions="scalar",
5028         defaultval=0,
5029         mnemonics="Geometry Optimization PRECONditioner equations",
5030         text="""
5031     Set the kind of preconditioner to be used for Geometry Optimization
5032     (Note: Under development now (2011.05.20))
5033     
5034       * [[goprecon]] = 0: No preconditioner
5035       * [[goprecon]] = [1-9]: Linear preconditioner
5036       * [[goprecon]] = [11-19]: Non-linear preconditioner
5037     """,

5044         topics=['GeoOpt_expert'],
5045         dimensions=[3],
