5054     
5055     Variable(
5056         abivarname="gpu_devices",
5057         varset="paral",
5058         vartype="integer",
5059         topics=['parallelism_expert'],
5060         dimensions=[5],
5061         defaultval=[-1, -1, -1, -1, -1],
5062         mnemonics="GPU: choice of DEVICES on one node",
5063         requires="[[use_gpu_cuda]] == 1 (CUDA functionality)",
5064         text="""
5065     To be used when several GPU devices are present on each node, assuming the
5066     same number of devices on all nodes.
5067     Allows to choose in which order the GPU devices are chosen and distributed
5068     among MPI processes (see examples below). When the default value (-1) is set,
5069     the GPU devices are chosen by order of performance (FLOPS, memory).
5070     
5071     Examples:
5072     
5073       * 2 GPU devices per node, 4 MPI processes per node, **gpu_device** =[-1,-1,-1,-1,-1] (default):
5074     MPI processes 0 and 2 use the best GPU card, MPI processes 1 and 3 use the
5075     slowest GPU card.
5076     
5077       * 3 GPU devices per node, 5 MPI processes per node, **gpu_device** =[1,0,2,-1,-1]:
5078     MPI processes 0 and 3 use GPU card 1, MPI processes 1 and 4 use GPU card 0,
5079     MPI process 2 uses GPU card 2.
5080     
5081       * 3 GPU devices per node, 5 MPI processes per node, **gpu_device** =[0,1,-1,-1,-1]:
5082     MPI processes 0, 2 and 4 use GPU card 0, MPI processes 1 and 3 use GPU card 1;
5083     the 3rd GPU card is not used.
5084     
5085     GPU card are numbered starting from 0; to get the GPU devices list, type
5086     "nvidia-smi" or "lspci | grep -i nvidia".
5087     """,
5088     ),
5089     
5090     Variable(
5091         abivarname="gpu_linalg_limit",
5092         varset="paral",
5093         vartype="integer",
5094         topics=['parallelism_expert'],
5095         dimensions="scalar",
5096         defaultval=2000000,
5097         mnemonics="GPU (Cuda): LINear ALGebra LIMIT",
5098         requires="[[use_gpu_cuda]] == 1 (CUDA functionality)",
5099         text="""
5100     Use of linear algebra and matrix algebra on GPU is only efficient if the size
5101     of the involved matrices is large enough. The [[gpu_linalg_limit]] parameter
5102     defines the threshold above which linear (and matrix) algebra operations are
5103     done on the Graphics Processing Unit.
5104     The considered matrix size is equal to:
5105     
5106     * SIZE=([[mpw]] $\\times$ [[nspinor]] / [[npspinor]]) $\\times$ ([[npband]] $\\times$ [[bandpp]]) $^2$
5107     
5108     When SIZE>=[[gpu_linalg_limit]], [[wfoptalg]] parameter is automatically set
5109     to 14 which corresponds to the use of LOBPCG algorithm for the calculation of
5110     the eigenstates.
5111     """,
5112     ),
5113     
5114     Variable(
5115         abivarname="gw_customnfreqsp",
5116         varset="gw",
5117         vartype="integer",
5118         topics=['FrequencyMeshMBPT_expert'],
5119         dimensions="scalar",
5120         defaultval=0,
5121         mnemonics="GW CUSTOM FREQuencies for SPectral function",
5122         requires="[[optdriver]] == 4 and [[gwcalctyp]] in [2,9,12,19,22,29]",
5123         text="""
5124     [[gw_customnfreqsp]] lets the user define the grid points along the real
5125     frequency axis by hand for the calculation of the self-energy along the real
5126     axis. Set this to the number of frequencies you want. The frequencies are
5127     specified with [[gw_freqsp]].
5128     """,
5129     ),
5130     
5131     Variable(
5132         abivarname="gw_freqsp",
5133         varset="gw",
5134         vartype="real",
5135         topics=['FrequencyMeshMBPT_expert'],
5136         dimensions=['[[gw_customnfreqsp]]'],
5137         defaultval=Range({'start': 1, 'stop': '[[gw_customnfreqsp]]'}),
5138         mnemonics="GW SPectral FREQuencies",
5139         requires="[[optdriver]] == 4 and [[gw_customnfreqsp]] > 0",
5140         text="""
5141     [[gw_freqsp]] specifies the grid points for the real frequency axis when the
5142     real and imaginary (spectral function) parts of sigma are calculated explicitly
5143     for post-processing or plotting. Only activated if [[gw_customnfreqsp]] is not
5144     equal to 0. The number of frequencies is set by the value of
5145     [[gw_customnfreqsp]]. Example:
5146     
5147         gw_customnfreqsp   5
5148         nfreqsp            5
5149         gw_freqsp         -0.5  -0.1  0.0  1.0  10.0 eV
5150     
5151     If [[nfreqsp]] is not equal to [[gw_customnfreqsp]] a warning will be issued.
5152     """,
5153     ),
5154     
5155     Variable(
5156         abivarname="gw_frqim_inzgrid",
5157         varset="gw",
5158         vartype="integer",
5159         topics=['FrequencyMeshMBPT_expert'],
5160         dimensions="scalar",
5161         defaultval=0,
5162         mnemonics="GW Contour Deformation FReQuencies on IMaginary axis Inverse Z Grid",
5163         requires="[[optdriver]] in [3,4] and [[gwcalctyp]] in [2,9,12,19,22,29]",
5164         text="""
5165     [[gw_frqim_inzgrid]] creates grid points along the **imaginary** frequency axis
5166     by using an equidistant grid in the variable  $z \subset [0,1]$ where the transform
5167     is:
5168     
5169     $$ i\omega^\prime = w_p \\frac{z}{1-z}. $$
5170     
5171     Here  $\omega_p$ is the plasma frequency (default can be overridden by setting
5172     [[ppmfrq]]). The equidistant grid in z is determined uniquely by [[nfreqim]])
5173     and the points are distributed so that half of them lie below the plasma frequency.
5174     """,
5175     ),
5176     
5177     Variable(
5178         abivarname="gw_frqre_inzgrid",
5179         varset="gw",
5180         vartype="integer",
5181         topics=['FrequencyMeshMBPT_expert'],
5182         dimensions="scalar",
5183         defaultval=0,
5184         mnemonics="GW Contour Deformation FReQuencies on REal axis Inverse Z Grid",
5185         requires="[[optdriver]] in [3,4] and [[gwcalctyp]] in [2,9,12,19,22,29]",
5186         text="""
5187     [[gw_frqre_inzgrid]] creates grid points along the **real** frequency axis by
5188     using an equidistant grid in the variable  $z \subset [0,1]$ where the transform
5189     is:
5190     
5191     $$ \omega = \omega_p \\frac{z}{1-z}. $$
5192     
5193     Here $\omega_p$ is the plasma frequency (default can be overridden by setting
5194     [[ppmfrq]]). The equidistant grid in z is determined uniquely by [[nfreqre]] )
5195     and the points are distributed so that half of them lie below the plasma
5196     frequency. This is useful in conjunction with [[gw_frqim_inzgrid]] if one needs
5197     to use a grid which maps $[0, \infty] \\rightarrow [0,1]$. Note that typically _many_ more
5198     points are needed along the real axis in order to properly resolve peak
5199     structures. In contrast, both the screening and self-energy are very smooth
5200     along the imaginary axis. Also, please note that this is **not** an efficient
5201     grid for **standard** Contour Deformation calculations, where typically only a
5202     smaller range of frequencies near the origin is required. The maximum value
5203     needed along the real frequency axis is output in the logfile during Contour
5204     Deformation sigma calculations.
5205     """,
5206     ),
5207     
5208     Variable(
5209         abivarname="gw_frqre_tangrid",
5210         varset="gw",
5211         vartype="integer",
5212         topics=['FrequencyMeshMBPT_expert'],
5213         dimensions="scalar",
5214         defaultval=0,
5215         mnemonics="GW Contour Deformation FReQencies on REal axis - Use Tangent Grid",
5216         requires="[[optdriver]] in [3,4] and [[gwcalctyp]] in [2,9,12,19,22,29]",
5217         text="""
5218     [[gw_frqre_tangrid]] defines a nonuniform grid to be used in frequency, with
5219     stepsize increasing proportional to $\\tan(x)$. This makes the grid approximately
5220     linear to start with, with a rapid increase towards the end. Also, this is the
5221     grid which gives equal importance to each point used in the integration of a
5222     function which decays as $1/x^2$. To be used in conjunction with [[nfreqre]],
5223     [[cd_max_freq]] and [[cd_halfway_freq]] which determine the parameters of the
5224     transformed grid.
5225     """,
5226     ),
5227     
5228     Variable(
5229         abivarname="gw_invalid_freq",
5230         varset="gw",
5231         vartype="integer",
5232         topics=['Susceptibility_expert', 'SelfEnergy_expert'],
5233         dimensions="scalar",
5234         defaultval=0,
5235         mnemonics="GW treatment of INVALID FREQuency for Hybertsen-Louie PPM",
5236         requires="[[optdriver]] in [3,4] and [[ppmodel]] in [2]",
5237         text="""
5238     [[gw_invalid_freq]] sets the procedure to follow when a PPM frequency is
5239     invalid (negative or imaginary).
5240     
5241       * [[gw_invalid_freq]] = 0: Drop them as proposed in Appendix B of [[cite:Hybertsen1986]].
5242       * [[gw_invalid_freq]] = 1: Set them to 1 hartree, as done for the PPM of Godby-Needs [[cite:Godby1989]].
5243       * [[gw_invalid_freq]] = 2: Set them to infinity.
5244     """,
5245     ),
5246     
5247     Variable(
5248         abivarname="gw_nqlwl",
5249         varset="gw",
5250         vartype="integer",
5251         topics=['GW_expert', 'BSE_expert', 'Susceptibility_expert', 'SelfEnergy_expert'],
5252         dimensions="scalar",
5253         defaultval=1,
5254         mnemonics="GW, Number of Q-points for the Long Wave-Length Limit",
5255         requires="[[optdriver]] in [3,4,99]",
5256         text="""
5257     Only relevant if [[optdriver]] = 3,4,99 that is, screening, sigma or Bethe-
5258     Salpeter calculations, although the actual meaning of the variable depends on
5259     the particular run-level (see discussion below).
5260     
5261     [[gw_nqlwl]] defines the number of directions in reciprocal space used to
5262     describe the non-analytical behaviour of the heads ($G = G'=0$) and the wings
5263     ($G=0$ or $G'=0$) of the dielectric matrix in the optical limit (i.e. for $q$
5264     tending to zero). The number of directions is specified by the additional
5265     variable [[gw_qlwl]].
5266     
5267     When [[optdriver]] = 3, [[gw_nqlwl]] and **gw_qlwl** define the set of "small" $q$
5268     that will be calculated and stored in the final SCR file. Therefore, the two
5269     variables can be used to analyze how the optical spectra depend on the
5270     direction of the incident phonon (useful especially in anisotropic systems).
5271     
5272     When [[optdriver]] = 4, [[gw_nqlwl]] and **gw_qlwl** can be used to specify the
5273     heads and the wings to be used to perform the quadrature of the correlated
5274     part of the self-energy in the small region around the origin. (NB: not yet
5275     available, at present the quadrature is performed using a single direction in
5276     q-space)
5277     
5278     When [[optdriver]] = 99, [[gw_nqlwl]] and **gw_qlwl** define the set of
5279     directions in q-space along which the macroscopic dielectric function is
5280     evaluated. By default the Bethe-Salpeter code calculates the macroscopic
5281     dielectric function using six different directions in q-space (the three basis
5282     vectors of the reciprocal lattice and the three Cartesian axis).
5283     """,
5284     ),
5285     
5286     Variable(
5287         abivarname="gw_nstep",
5288         varset="gw",
5289         vartype="integer",
5290         topics=['GW_basic'],
5291         dimensions="scalar",
5292         defaultval=30,
5293         mnemonics="GW Number of self-consistent STEPs",
5294         requires="[[optdriver]] == 8",
5295         text="""
5296     Gives the maximum number of self-consistent GW cycles (or "iterations"). in
5297     which G and/or W will be updated until the quasi-particle energies are
5298     converged within [[gw_toldfeig]]. [[gwcalctyp]] and [[gw_sctype]] are used to
5299     define the type of self-consistency.
5300     """,
5301     ),
5302     
5303     Variable(
5304         abivarname="gw_qlwl",
5305         varset="gw",
5306         vartype="real",
5307         topics=['Susceptibility_expert', 'SelfEnergy_expert', 'BSE_expert'],
5308         dimensions=[3, '[[gw_nqlwl]]'],
5309         defaultval=[1e-05, 2e-05, 3e-05],
5310         mnemonics="GW, Q-points for the Long Wave-Length limit",
5311         requires="[[optdriver]] in [3,4,99]",
5312         text="""
5313     When [[optdriver]] = 3, [[gw_qlwl]] defines the set of q-points around Gamma
5314     that are considered during the evaluation of the non-analytical behaviour of
5315     the dielectric matrix. Optical spectra (with and without non-local field
5316     effects) are evaluated for each direction specified by [[gw_qlwl]].
5317     """,
5318     ),
5319     
5320     Variable(
5321         abivarname="gw_qprange",
5322         varset="gw",
5323         vartype="integer",
5324         topics=['SelfEnergy_useful'],
5325         dimensions="scalar",
5326         defaultval=0,
5327         mnemonics="GW QuasiParticle RANGE policy",
5328         requires="[[optdriver]] == 4",
5329         text="""
5330     [[gw_qprange]] is active only when [[nkptgw]] is equal to zero (default
5331     value). This variable simplifies the specification of the list of kpoints and
5332     of the bands to be used for the computation of the quasi-particle corrections.
5333     The possible values are:
5334     
5335       * 0 --> Compute the QP corrections only for the fundamental and the optical gap
5336       * +num --> Compute the QP corrections for all the k-points in the irreducible zone,
5337          and include `num` bands above and below the Fermi level.
5338       * -num --> Compute the QP corrections for all the k-points in the irreducible zone.
5339          Include all occupied states and `num` empty states.
5340     
5341     The default value is 0 and is very handy for one-shot calculations. It is
5342     important to stress, however, that the position of the optical/fundamental
5343     gaps is deduced from the energies computed on the k-mesh used for the WFK
5344     file. Therefore the computed gaps might differ from the correct ones that can
5345     only be obtained with an appropriate sampling of the irreducible zone.
5346     Positive values are useful if we do not know the position of the GW HOMO, LOMO
5347     and we want to investigate the effect of the GW corrections on the states
5348     close to the gap Negative values are usually used for self-consistent
5349     calculations Note that, in the case of self-consistency or [[symsigma]] == 1, the
5350     code might change the bands range so that all the degenerate states are
5351     included. Note also that [[kptgw]], and [[bdgw]] are ignored when this options
5352     is used. If you want to select manually the list of k-points and bands, you
5353     have to provide the three variables [[nkptgw]], [[kptgw]], and [[bdgw]].
5354     """,
5355     ),
5356     
5357     Variable(
5358         abivarname="gw_sctype",
5359         varset="gw",
5360         vartype="integer",
5361         topics=['GW_basic'],
5362         dimensions="scalar",
5363         defaultval=1,
5364         mnemonics="GW, Self-Consistency TYPE",
5365         requires="[[optdriver]] in [3,4]",
5366         text="""
5367     This variable is used to partially define the kind of self-consistency for GW
5368     calculations. The other piece of information is given by [[gwcalctyp]] that
5369     defines the particular approximation for the self-energy operator as well as
5370     whether the wavefunctions have to replaced by quasi-particle amplitudes.
5371     
5372     If [[gw_sctype]] is specified in the input file, the code will perform an
5373     iterative update of the quantities entering the GW equations until the quasi-
5374     particle energies are converged within [[gw_toldfeig]]. The maximum number of
5375     iterations is specified by [[gw_nstep]]. Possible values are:
5376     
5377       * 1 --> standard one-shot method (one screening calculation followed by a single sigma run)
5378       * 2 --> self-consistency only on W (iterative update of W followed by a sigma run in which G is approximated with the Kohn-Sham independent-particle Green's function G0)
5379       * 3 --> self-consistency only of G (a single screening calculation to obtain the Kohn-Sham polarizability followed by an iterative update of the Green's functions in the self-energy)
5380       * 4 --> fully self-consistent algorithm (iterative update of both G and W)
5381     
5382     It is possible to initialize the self-consistent procedure by reading a
5383     previously calculated SCR or SUSC file via the variables [[getscr]] or
5384     [[getsuscep]], respectively. [[getqps]] can be used to read a previous QPS
5385     file thus initializing the Green functions to be used in the first self-
5386     consistent iteration.
5387     """,
5388     ),
5389     
5390     Variable(
5391         abivarname="gw_sigxcore",
5392         varset="gw",
5393         vartype="integer",
5394         topics=['SelfEnergy_expert'],
5395         dimensions="scalar",
5396         defaultval=0,
5397         mnemonics="GW, SIGma (self-energy) for the CORE contribution",
5398         requires="[[optdriver]] == 4 and [[usepaw]] == 1",
5399         text="""
5400     Only available for PAW and relevant if [[optdriver]] = 4 that is, sigma
5401     calculations.
5402     
5403     Theoretical introduction: GW calculations performed on top of electronic
5404     calculations relying when the frozen-core approximation is used to separate
5405     inner-core electrons from valence electrons, only the contribution to the
5406     self-energy arising from valence electrons is explicitly accounted for. In the
5407     standard approach based on pseudopotentials the contribution to the self-
5408     energy due to core electrons is approximated by means of the KS exchange-
5409     correlation potential generated by the core density. In the case of GW
5410     calculations employing the PAW method, the core contribution to the self-
5411     energy can be more accurately estimated in terms of the Fock operator
5412     generated by the core wavefunctions. In the simplest approach, the only
5413     ingredients required for this more refined treatment are the wave functions of
5414     the core electrons in the reference atomic configuration that are calculated
5415     during the generation of the PAW setup. This is a good approximation provided
5416     that the core wave functions are strictly localized inside the PAW spheres.
5417     
5418     [[gw_sigxcore]] defines the approximation used to evaluate the core
5419     contribution to sigma.
5420     
5421       * [[gw_sigxcore]] = 0, standard approach, the core contribution is approximated with vxc.
5422       * [[gw_sigxcore]] = 1, the core term is approximated with the Fock operator inside the PAW spheres.
5423     """,
5424     ),
5425     
5426     Variable(
5427         abivarname="gw_toldfeig",
5428         varset="gw",
5429         vartype="real",
5430         topics=['GW_basic'],
5431         dimensions="scalar",
5432         defaultval=ValueWithUnit(units='eV', value=0.1),
5433         mnemonics="GW TOLerance on the DiFference of the EIGenvalues",
5434         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
5435         requires="[[optdriver]] == 8",
5436         text="""
5437     Sets a tolerance for absolute differences of QP energies that will cause one
5438     self-consistent GW cycle to stop.
5439     Can be specified in Ha (the default), Ry, eV or Kelvin, since **toldfe** has
5440     the '[[ENERGY]]' characteristics (1 Ha=27.2113845 eV)
5441     """,
5442     ),
5443     
5444     Variable(
5445         abivarname="gwcalctyp",
5446         varset="gw",
5447         vartype="integer",
5448         topics=['GW_basic', 'SelfEnergy_basic', 'RPACorrEn_compulsory'],
5449         dimensions="scalar",
5450         defaultval=0,
5451         mnemonics="GW CALCulation TYPe",
5452         requires="[[optdriver]] in [3,4]",
5453         text="""
5454     [[gwcalctyp]] governs the choice between the different capabilities of the GW
5455     code.
5456     
5457       * 0 <= [[gwcalctyp]] <= 9: standard "1 shot" quasiparticle method.
5458       * 10 <= [[gwcalctyp]] <= 19: self-consistent quasiparticle method on energies only.
5459       * 20 <= [[gwcalctyp]] <= 29: self-consistent quasiparticle method on energies and wavefunctions.
5460     
5461       * [[gwcalctyp]] = 0, 10, or 20: standard Plasmon-Pole model GW calculation.
5462       * [[gwcalctyp]] = 1: GW calculation where the self-energy along the real axis is obtained by performing the analytic continuation from the imaginary axis to the full complex plane via the Pade approximant. Only available for standard "1 shot" quasiparticle method.
5463       * [[gwcalctyp]] = 2, 12, or 22: GW calculation using numerical integration (contour deformation method, see e.g. [[cite:Lebegue2003]]).
5464       * [[gwcalctyp]] = 5, 15, or 25: Hybrid functional or Hartree-Fock calculation, with the identifier of the functional given by [[ixc_sigma]]. See the latter for the definition of other related variables.
5465       * [[gwcalctyp]] = 6, 16, or 26: Screened Exchange calculation.
5466       * [[gwcalctyp]] = 7, 17, or 27: COHSEX calculation.
5467       * [[gwcalctyp]] = 8, 18, or 28: model GW calculation following [[cite:Faleev2004]] using a Plasmon-Pole model.
5468       * [[gwcalctyp]] = 9, 19, or 29: model GW calculation following [[cite:Faleev2004]] using numerical integration (contour deformation method).
5469     """,
5470     ),
5471     
5472     Variable(
5473         abivarname="gwcomp",
5474         varset="gw",
5475         vartype="integer",
5476         topics=['SelfEnergy_useful'],
5477         dimensions="scalar",
5478         defaultval=0,
5479         mnemonics="GW COMPleteness",
5480         requires="[[optdriver]] in [3,4]",
5481         text="""
5482     [[gwcomp]] governs the use of an extrapolar approximation. If [[gwcomp]] == 1,
5483     one improves the completeness in a truncated sum over states. In practice,
5484     this permits one to reduce quite much the number of bands required in the
5485     calculation of the screening or of the self-energy. The energy parameter
5486     needed in the extrapolar approximation is set by [[gwencomp]]. See
5487     [[cite:Bruneval2008]] for a description of the methodology.
5488     """,
5489     ),
5490     
5491     Variable(
5492         abivarname="gwencomp",
5493         varset="gw",
5494         vartype="real",
5495         topics=['SelfEnergy_useful', 'Susceptibility_useful'],
5496         dimensions="scalar",
5497         defaultval=2.0,
5498         mnemonics="GW ENergy for COMPleteness",
5499         requires="[[optdriver]] in [3,4] and [[gwcomp]] == 1",
5500         text="""
5501     [[gwencomp]] sets the energy parameter used in the extrapolar approximation
5502     used to improve completeness and make the convergence against the number of
5503     bands much faster.
5504     
5505     See [[cite:Bruneval2008]] for a description of the methodology.
5506     """,
5507     ),
5508     
5509     Variable(
5510         abivarname="gwgamma",
5511         varset="gw",
5512         vartype="integer",
5513         topics=['Susceptibility_expert', 'SelfEnergy_expert'],
5514         dimensions="scalar",
5515         defaultval=0,
5516         mnemonics="GW GAMMA",
5517         requires="[[optdriver]] = 3 or 4 (Sigma calculations)",
5518         text="""
5519     If [[gwgamma]] is 1, the vertex correction will be included leading to what is
5520     known as "GW-Gamma" approximation. see R. Del Sole, L. Reining, and R. W.
5521     Godby, Phys. Rev. B 49, 8024 (1994). Note that, in order to include the vertex
5522     correction in W, one has to start the sigma calculation from the
5523     susceptibility file_SUSC instead of the _SCR file (see [[getsuscep]]   and
5524     [[irdsuscep]]  ) Not available for PAW calculations.
5525     
5526     [[gwgamma]] = -4 activates the bootstrap kernel of Sharma et al. [[cite:Sharma2011]]
5527     in the test-charge-test-charge dielectric function [[cite:Chen2015]].
5528     
5529     [[gwgamma]] = -6 uses the same bootstrap kernel as with [[gwgamma]] = -4
5530     but with only the head of the kernel. As such, the self-consistent iteration in the kernel
5531     can be disregarded [[cite:Chen2016]].
5532     
5533     [[gwgamma]] = -8 activates the RPA bootstrap-like kernel (one-shot) (see [[cite:Berger2015]]
5534     and [[cite:Rigamonti2015]]).
5535     """,
5536     ),
5537     
5538     Variable(
5539         abivarname="gwls_band_index",
5540         varset="gw",
5541         vartype="integer",
5542         topics=['GWls_expert'],
5543         dimensions="scalar",
5544         defaultval=1,
5545         mnemonics="GWLS BAND INDEX",
5546         requires="[[optdriver]] == 66",
5547         text="""
5548     Governs the DFT eigenstate $|e\\rangle$ in which the self-energy will be evaluated, as
5549     shown in Eq. (7) of [[cite:Laflamme2015]]. That is, it is the state
5550     to be corrected in the G0W0 scheme.
5551     """,
5552     ),
5553     
5554     Variable(
5555         abivarname="gwls_correlation",
5556         varset="gw",
5557         vartype="integer",
5558         topics=['GWls_expert'],
5559         dimensions="scalar",
5560         defaultval=3,
5561         mnemonics="GWLS CORRELATION",
5562         requires="[[optdriver]] == 66",
5563         text="""
5564     Governs the use of a dielectric model (as explained in Sec. V of
5565     [[cite:Laflamme2015]] and the use of the Lanczos scheme to solve Eqs. (30) and
5566     (35) of the same reference at all external [[gw_freqsp]] and integration (as
5567     generated from [[gwls_npt_gauss_quad]]) frequencies. The different choices
5568     are:
5569     
5570       * [[gwls_correlation]] == 1: GWLS calculation **with** the dielectric model and **without** the shift Lanczos technique,
5571       * [[gwls_correlation]] == 2: GWLS calculation **without** the dielectric model and **without** the shift Lanczos technique,
5572       * [[gwls_correlation]] == 3: GWLS calculation **with** the dielectric model and **with** the shift Lanczos technique,
5573       * [[gwls_correlation]] == 4: GWLS calculation **without** the dielectric model and **with** the shift Lanczos technique,
5574       * [[gwls_correlation]] == 5: Not a GWLS calculation; just calculate and print the eigenvalues of the (static) dielectric matrix (for debugging purposes).
5575     
5576     The default, ([[gwls_correlation]] == 3), is the most performant option and
5577     should be kept by the user. Option 1, 2 and 5 are deprecated and will be
5578     removed.
5579     """,
5580     ),
5581     
5582     Variable(
5583         abivarname="gwls_diel_model",
5584         varset="gw",
5585         vartype="integer",
5586         topics=['GWls_expert'],
5587         dimensions="scalar",
5588         defaultval=2,
5589         mnemonics="GWLS dielectric model",
5590         requires="[[optdriver]] == 66",
5591         text="""
5592     Not used yet.
5593     """,
5594     ),
5595     
5596     Variable(
5597         abivarname="gwls_exchange",
5598         varset="gw",
5599         vartype="integer",
5600         topics=['GWls_expert'],
5601         dimensions="scalar",
5602         defaultval=1,
5603         mnemonics="GWLS exact EXCHANGE",
5604         requires="[[optdriver]] == 66",
5605         text="""
5606     Governs whether the exact exchange for the state to be corrected
5607     ([[gwls_band_index]]) is calculated ([[gwls_exchange]] == 1) or not
5608     ([[gwls_exchange]] = =0).
5609     """,
5610     ),
5611     
5612     Variable(
5613         abivarname="gwls_first_seed",
5614         varset="gw",
5615         vartype="integer",
5616         topics=['GWls_expert'],
5617         dimensions="scalar",
5618         defaultval="[[gwls_band_index]]",
5619         mnemonics="GWLS FIRST SEED vector",
5620         requires="[[optdriver]] == 66",
5621         text="""
5622     This variable sets the band index to be used to generate the first seed vector
5623     to be used in the construction of the Lanczos basis for the (static)
5624     dielectric matrix in a GWLS calculation. See Sec. IV of [[cite:Laflamme2015]].
5625     Together with [[gwls_nseeds]], this defines the seeds for the
5626     Lanczos procedure. That is, the states associated to band index
5627     [[gwls_first_seed]] to [[gwls_first_seed]]+[[gwls_nseeds]]-1 are used to
5628     generate the seed vectors.
5629     
5630     The default [[gwls_first_seed]] == [[gwls_band_index]] and [[gwls_nseeds]] == 1
5631     has been thoroughly tested and seems to be the most performant. Users should
5632     therefore keep the default value.
5633     """,
5634     ),
5635     
5636     Variable(
5637         abivarname="gwls_kmax_analytic",
5638         varset="gw",
5639         vartype="integer",
5640         topics=['GWls_expert'],
5641         dimensions="scalar",
5642         defaultval=8,
5643         mnemonics="GWLS KMAX for the ANALYTIC term",
5644         requires="[[optdriver]] == 66",
5645         text="""
5646     Governs the number of iterations to be done in the shift Lanczos solution of
5647     Eq. (35) of [[cite:Laflamme2015]] to solve it at all external
5648     frequencies requested by the user ([[gw_freqsp]]). The default value is
5649     converged to a few 10s of meV for all molecules studied so far.
5650     """,
5651     ),
5652     
5653     Variable(
5654         abivarname="gwls_kmax_complement",
5655         varset="gw",
5656         vartype="integer",
5657         topics=['GWls_expert'],
5658         dimensions="scalar",
5659         defaultval=1,
5660         mnemonics="GWLS KMAX for the COMPLEMENT space.",
5661         requires="[[optdriver]] == 66",
5662         text="""
5663     The G0W0 formalism involves the calculation of a summation conceptually linked
5664     to the trace of the dielectric matrix [see Eq. (38) of [[cite:Laflamme2015]]\].
5665     Since the eigenvalues spectrum of the dielectric matrix of formed by a
5666     few large discrete eigenvalues and an integrable divergence in the density of
5667     eigenvalues around 0, it is expensive to sample accurately this divergence
5668     using the exact dielectric operator. It this becomes interesting to calculate
5669     the 'trace' of the 'exact - model' dielectric matrix in a small basis and add
5670     it to the 'trace' of the 'model' dielectric matrix obtained in a large basis.
5671     In the context where the model dielectric matrix is used in the calculations,
5672     [[gwls_stern_kmax]] determines the size of the 'small' basis and
5673     [[gwls_kmax_complement]] determines the size of the 'large' basis.
5674     
5675     For more information on the exact role of these bases and on the model
5676     dielectric operator used, see Sec. V of [[cite:Laflamme2015]].
5677     """,
5678     ),
5679     
5680     Variable(
5681         abivarname="gwls_kmax_numeric",
5682         varset="gw",
5683         vartype="integer",
5684         topics=['GWls_expert'],
5685         dimensions="scalar",
5686         defaultval=16,
5687         mnemonics="GWLS KMAX for the NUMERIC term",
5688         requires="[[optdriver]] == 66",
5689         text="""
5690     Governs the number of iterations to be done in the shift Lanczos solution of
5691     Eq. (30) of [[cite:Laflamme2015]] to solve it simultaneously at all
5692     integration frequencies (generated automatically by the number of points
5693     [[gwls_npt_gauss_quad]] to use in the gaussian quadrature) and all external
5694     frequencies requested by the user ([[gw_freqsp]]). The default value is
5695     converged to a few 10s of meV for all molecules studied so far.
5696     """,
5697     ),
5698     
5699     Variable(
5700         abivarname="gwls_kmax_poles",
5701         varset="gw",
5702         vartype="integer",
5703         topics=['GWls_expert'],
5704         dimensions="scalar",
5705         defaultval=4,
5706         mnemonics="GWLS KMAX for the calculation of the POLES residue",
5707         requires="[[optdriver]] == 66",
5708         text="""
5709     The contour deformation technique, in the G0W0 context, will involve the
5710     calculation of pole residues associated to states lying between the one
5711     corrected ([[gwls_band_index]]) and the Fermi level. These residues take the
5712     form of a matrix element of the inverse dielectric matrix at a real frequency
5713     [see Eq. (11) of [[cite:Laflamme2015]]\]. Therefore, the dielectric
5714     matrix must be constructed in some basis at these frequencies and inverted to
5715     calculate the matrix element. The present input variable sets the size of the
5716     Lanczos basis to be constructed for this purpose. The default value has proven
5717     to be very robust for many molecular systems and should therefore be left to
5718     the default value by the user.
5719     
5720     For more information on the Lanczos basis constructed for the calculation of
5721     the residues, see Sec. IV of [[cite:Laflamme2015]].
5722     """,
5723     ),
5724     
5725     Variable(
5726         abivarname="gwls_list_proj_freq",
5727         varset="gw",
5728         vartype="real",
5729         topics=['GWls_expert'],
5730         dimensions=['[[gwls_n_proj_freq]]'],
5731         defaultval="*0.0",
5732         mnemonics="GWLS LIST of the PROJection FREQuencies",
5733         requires="[[optdriver]] == 66",
5734         text=r"""
5735     This variable sets the frequencies to be used to construct the basis in which
5736     the Hamiltonian is projected to accelerate the solution of the Sternheimer
5737     equations involved by the construction of the dielectric matrix at finite
5738     frequencies. See Sec. VI of [[cite:Laflamme2015]]. For most cases,
5739     since the frequencies $\infty$ and 0.0 (if [[gwls_recycle]] > 0) are used at no
5740     computational cost, [[gwls_n_proj_freq]] == 0 (which means no ADDITIONAL
5741     frequency is to be used) is fine and no frequencies need to be picked up.
5742     """,
5743     ),
5744     
5745     Variable(
5746         abivarname="gwls_model_parameter",
5747         varset="gw",
5748         vartype="real",
5749         topics=['GWls_expert'],
5750         dimensions="scalar",
5751         defaultval=1.0,
5752         mnemonics="GWLS MODEL PARAMETER",
5753         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
5754         requires="[[optdriver]] == 66",
5755         text=r"""
5756     This is the width of the lorentzian, in Ha, used to model the frequency
5757     dependence of the dielectric matrix in the GWLS calculation [see Eqs. (12-16)
5758     and (34) of [[cite:Laflamme2015]]\]. More
5759     precisely, this parameter is the value of $\alpha$ used in Eq. (34). This model
5760     is then used to separate the integration over frequencies into a 'model' part
5761     [second term of Eq. (12)] and an 'exact - model' part [first term of Eq. (12)].
5762     Since the 'model' part can be integrated analytically [see Eqs. (15), (16) and
5763     (34)], only the 'exact - model' part needs to be integrated numerically.
5764     
5765     The only effect of this model is therefore to alleviate the numerical cost of
5766     the integration over frequencies in the G0W0 calculation. The value of the
5767     associated parameter has thus an impact on the convergence rate of the GWLS
5768     calculation with respect to the number of frequencies of integration
5769     ([[gwls_npt_gauss_quad]]), but no impact on the converged result of the GWLS
5770     calculation. Typically, the default ([[gwls_model_parameter]] == 1.0) is optimal.
5771     """,
5772     ),
5773     
5774     Variable(
5775         abivarname="gwls_n_proj_freq",
5776         varset="gw",
5777         vartype="integer",
5778         topics=['GWls_expert'],
5779         dimensions="scalar",
5780         defaultval=0,
5781         mnemonics="GWLS Number of PROJection FREQuencies",
5782         requires="[[optdriver]] == 66",
5783         text=r"""
5784     This variable sets the number of frequencies, on top of $\infty$ and 0.0 (if
5785     [[gwls_recycle]] > 0), to be used for the construction of the basis in which
5786     the Hamiltonian is projected to accelerate the solution of the Sternheimer
5787     equations involved in the construction of the dielectric matrix at finite
5788     frequencies. See Sec. VI of [[cite:Laflamme2015]]. For most cases,
5789     the default ([[gwls_n_proj_freq]] == 0) is fine.
5790     """,
5791     ),
5792     
5793     Variable(
5794         abivarname="gwls_npt_gauss_quad",
5795         varset="gw",
5796         vartype="integer",
5797         topics=['GWls_expert'],
5798         dimensions="scalar",
5799         defaultval=10,
5800         mnemonics="GWLS Number of PoinTs to use for the GAUSSian QUADrature",
5801         requires="[[optdriver]] == 66",
5802         text="""
5803     This variable defines the number of points used for the numerical integration
5804     of the self-energy over frequencies in GWLS computations [see Eq. (12) of
5805     [[cite:Laflamme2015]]\]. The default is fine for most cases.
5806     """,
5807     ),
5808     
5809     Variable(
5810         abivarname="gwls_nseeds",
5811         varset="gw",
5812         vartype="integer",
5813         topics=['GWls_expert'],
5814         dimensions="scalar",
5815         defaultval=1,
5816         mnemonics="GWLS Number of SEED vectorS",
5817         requires="[[optdriver]] == 66",
5818         text="""
5819     This variable sets the number of seed vectors to be used in the construction
5820     of the Lanczos basis for the (static) dielectric matrix in a GWLS calculation.
5821     See Sec. IV of [[cite:Laflamme2015]]. Only [[gwls_nseeds]] == 1 has
5822     been tested for now and users should keep this value.
5823     """,
5824     ),
5825     
5826     Variable(
5827         abivarname="gwls_print_debug",
5828         varset="gw",
5829         vartype="integer",
5830         topics=['GWls_expert'],
5831         dimensions="scalar",
5832         defaultval=0,
5833         mnemonics="GWLS PRINT level for DEBUGging",
5834         requires="[[optdriver]] == 66",
5835         text="""
5836     Influences the level of verbosity for debugging purposes in a GWLS
5837     calculation. Users should keep its value at the default.
5838     """,
5839     ),
5840     
5841     Variable(
5842         abivarname="gwls_recycle",
5843         varset="gw",
5844         vartype="integer",
5845         topics=['GWls_expert'],
5846         dimensions="scalar",
5847         defaultval=2,
5848         mnemonics="GWLS RECYCLE",
5849         requires="[[optdriver]] == 66",
5850         text=r"""
5851     This variable let the user choose if and how he wants to recycle the solutions
5852     of the Sternheimer equations involved in the construction of the static dielectric matrix.
5853     
5854       * [[gwls_recycle]] = 0: No recycling of the solutions.
5855       * [[gwls_recycle]] = 1: Recycle the solutions. To do so, store them in RAM.
5856       * [[gwls_recycle]] = 2: Recycle the solutions. To do so, store them on disk.
5857     
5858     If the user choose to recycle the solutions, they are used to construct the
5859     basis in which the Hamiltonian is projected for the solution of the
5860     Sternheimer equations involved by the calculation of the dielectric matrix at
5861     finite frequencies. The other solutions used will be those at $\omega \to \infty$
5862     (always used) and those at $\omega=$[[gwls_list_proj_freq]]. For more
5863     information of the basis constructed, see Sec. IV of [[cite:Laflamme2015]].
5864     
5865     It is important to note that the solutions rapidly take much space to store.
5866     Therefore, it is often not possible to store them in RAM in production
5867     calculations, yet still desirable to retain them. This is when it becomes
5868     interesting to store them on disk. It is particularly efficient to choose the
5869     path of the file to be on disk space local to the processor in large MPI
5870     calculations, since each processor need only his own solutions in the
5871     construction of the basis.
5872     """,
5873     ),
5874     
5875     Variable(
5876         abivarname="gwls_stern_kmax",
5877         varset="gw",
5878         vartype="integer",
5879         topics=['GWls_expert'],
5880         dimensions="scalar",
5881         defaultval=1,
5882         mnemonics="GWLS Kmax",
5883         requires="[[optdriver]] == 66",
5884         text="""
5885     This variable sets the dimension of the dielectric matrix used in a GWLS
5886     calculation [see Sec. IV of [[cite:Laflamme2015]]\]. Typically
5887     converged at a value of a few hundreds to a few thousands for a convergence
5888     criterion of 50 meV on the eigenenergies.
5889     """,
5890     ),
5891     
5892     Variable(
5893         abivarname="gwmem",
5894         varset="gw",
5895         vartype="integer",
5896         topics=['Susceptibility_expert', 'SelfEnergy_expert'],
5897         dimensions="scalar",
5898         defaultval=11,
5899         mnemonics="GW MEMory",
5900         requires="[[optdriver]] in [3,4]",
5901         text="""
5902     [[gwmem]] governs the memory strategy during a screening and/or a sigma run.
5903     
5904       * [[gwmem]] = 1x, the screening matrix are read for all q-vectors and stored in the memory.
5905       * [[gwmem]] = 0x, the screening matrix are read just a q-vector after another.
5906     
5907       * [[gwmem]] = x1, the real-space wavefunctions are stored in the memory.
5908       * [[gwmem]] = x0, the real-space wavefunctions are not stored, but rather recalculated on-fly each abinit needs them using FFTs.
5909     
5910     The default is [[gwmem]] = 11, which is the fastest, but also the most memory
5911     consuming. When experiencing memory shortage, one should try [[gwmem]] = 0.
5912     The first digit is only meaningful when performing sigma calculations.
5913     """,
5914     ),
5915     
5916     Variable(
5917         abivarname="gwpara",
5918         varset="paral",
5919         vartype="integer",
5920         topics=['parallelism_useful', 'GW_basic', 'Susceptibility_basic', 'SelfEnergy_basic'],
5921         dimensions="scalar",
5922         defaultval=2,
5923         mnemonics="GW PARAllelization level",
5924         commentdefault="The default value has been changed in v8. From 1 to 2",
5925         requires="[[optdriver]] in [3,4]",
5926         text="""
5927     gwpara is used to choose between the two different parallelization levels
5928     available in the GW code. The available options are:
5929     
5930       * 1 --> parallelisation on k points.
5931       * 2 --> parallelisation on bands.
5932     
5933     In the present status of the code, only the parallelization over bands
5934     ([[gwpara]] = 2) allows one to reduce the memory allocated by each processor.
5935     Using [[gwpara]] = 1, indeed, requires the same amount of memory as a sequential
5936     run, irrespectively of the number of CPUs used.
5937     """,
5938     ),
5939     
5940     Variable(
5941         abivarname="gwrpacorr",
5942         varset="gw",
5943         vartype="integer",
5944         topics=['RPACorrEn_compulsory'],
5945         dimensions="scalar",
5946         defaultval=0,
5947         mnemonics="GW RPA CORRelation energy",
5948         requires="[[optdriver]] == 3 and [[gwcalctyp]] in [1,11,21]",
5949         text="""
5950     [[gwrpacorr]] governs the calculation of the RPA correlation energy.
5951     
5952       * [[gwrpacorr]] = 0, no RPA correlation energy is calculated.
5953       * [[gwrpacorr]] = 1, the RPA correlation energy is calculated using an exact integration
5954         over the coupling constant: it requires one diagonalization of the polarizability matrix.
5955       * [[gwrpacorr]] = $n$ > 1, the RPA correlation energy is calculated using $n$ values
5956         for the coupling constant: it requires $n$ inversions of the polarizability matrix.
5957     """,
5958     ),
5959

6025     Variable(
6026         abivarname="hyb_range_dft",
6027         varset="gstate",
6028         vartype="real",
6029         topics=['Hybrids_expert'],
6030         dimensions="scalar",
6031         defaultval="-999.0d0 or [[hyb_range_fock]] if it is defined by the user",
6032         mnemonics="HYBrid RANGE for the DFT leftover from the screened fock operator",
6033         commentdefault="With the default=-999.0d0, [[hyb_range_dft]] is initialized from [[ixc]].",
6034         requires="[[usefock]] > 0",
6035         text="""
6036     Range of the DFT leftover from the screened Fock operator in case of hybrid
6037     functionals (actually, coefficient of the distance appearing in the erf
6038     function, thus it has the dimension of an inverse distance).
6039     
6040     As described in the LibXC sources (and copied in the ABINIT doc, see
6041     [[ixc]] = -428), there is a mess due to an error in the original publication.
6042     ABINIT knows the LibXC value from [[ixc]], that might not agree with the
6043     definitions from other codes. Usually, [[hyb_range_dft]] is the same as
6044     [[hyb_range_fock]], see the latter for the different values. However, there is
6045     a noticeable exception, the HSE03 from the original paper (not the HSE03 from VASP),
6046     for which [[hyb_range_dft]] = 0.188988 while [[hyb_range_fock]] = 0.106066.
6047     """,
6048     ),
6049     
6050     Variable(
6051         abivarname="hyb_range_fock",
6052         varset="gstate",
6053         vartype="real",
6054         topics=['Hybrids_expert'],
6055         dimensions="scalar",
6056         defaultval="-999.0d0 or [[hyb_range_dft]] if it is defined by the user",
6057         mnemonics="HYBrid RANGE for the screened FOCK operator",
6058         commentdefault="With the default=-999.0d0, [[hyb_range_fock]] is initialized from [[ixc]].",
6059         requires="[[usefock]] > 0",
6060         text="""
6061     Range of the screened Fock operator in case of hybrid functionals (actually,
6062     coefficient of the distance appearing in the erf function, thus it has the
6063     dimension of an inverse distance).
6064     
6065     As described in the LibXC sources (and copied in the ABINIT doc, see
6066     [[ixc]] = -428), there is a mess due to an error in the original publication.
6067     ABINIT knows the LibXC value from [[ixc]], that might not agree with the
6068     definitions from other codes. Usually, [[hyb_range_dft]] is the same as
6069     [[hyb_range_fock]], with one exception explained in [[hyb_range_dft]].
6070     The HSE06 value from LibCX is 0.11, the one of Quantum Espresso is 0.106, the one of
6071     VASP is 0.105835 (=0.2 $\AA^{-1}$).
6072     The HSE03 value from LibCX is 0.106066 ($=0.15/\sqrt{2})$), the one of VASP is
6073     0.1587531 (=0.3 $\AA^{-1}$).
6074     """,
6075     ),
6076     
6077     Variable(
6078         abivarname="iatcon",
6079         varset="rlx",
6080         vartype="integer",
6081         topics=['GeoConstraints_useful'],
6082         dimensions=['[[natcon]]', '[[nconeq]]'],
6083         defaultval=0,
6084         mnemonics="Indices of AToms in CONstraint equations",
6085         characteristics=['[[NO_MULTI]]', '[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
6086         text="""
6087     Gives the indices of the atoms appearing in each of the [[nconeq]] independent
6088     equations constraining the motion of atoms during structural optimization or
6089     molecular dynamics (see [[nconeq]], [[natcon]], and [[wtatcon]]).
6090     (Note: combined with [[wtatcon]] to give internal representation of the latter)

6093     
6094     Variable(
6095         abivarname="iatfix",
6096         varset="rlx",
6097         vartype="integer",
6098         topics=['GeoConstraints_basic'],
6099         dimensions=['[[natfix]]'],
6100         mnemonics="Indices of AToms that are FIXed",
6101         requires="[[natfix]] > 0",
6102         text="""
6103     Give the index (in the range 1 to [[natom]] ) of each atom which is to be held
6104     fixed for structural optimization or molecular dynamics. The variable
6105     [[iatfix]] lists those fixed in the three directions, while the variables
6106     [[iatfixx]], [[iatfixy]], and [[iatfixz]], allow to fix some atoms along x, y
6107     or z directions, or a combination of these.
6108     
6109     WARNING: The implementation is inconsistent !! For [[ionmov]] ==1, the fixing
6110     of directions was done in cartesian coordinates, while for the other values of
6111     [[ionmov]], it was done in reduced coordinates. Sorry for this.
6112     
6113     There is no harm in fixing one atom in the three directions using [[iatfix]],
6114     then fixing it again in other directions by mentioning it in **iatfixx**,
6115     **iatfixy** or **iatfixz**.
6116     The internal representation of these input data is done by the mean of one
6117     variable [[iatfix]](3,[[natom]]), defined for each direction and each atom,
6118     being 0 if the atom is not fixed along the direction, and 1 if the atom is
6119     fixed along the direction. When some atoms are fixed along 1 or 2 directions,
6120     the use of symmetries is restricted to symmetry operations whose (3x3)
6121     matrices [[symrel]] are diagonal.
6122     If the atom manipulator is used, [[iatfix]] will be related to the
6123     preprocessed set of atoms, generated by the atom manipulator. The user must
6124     thus foresee the effect of this atom manipulator (see [[objarf]]).
6125     """,
6126     ),
6127     
6128     Variable(
6129         abivarname="iatfixx",
6130         varset="rlx",
6131         vartype="integer",
6132         topics=['GeoConstraints_basic'],
6133         dimensions=['[[natfixx]]'],
6134         mnemonics="Indices of AToms that are FIXed along the X direction",
6135         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
6136         requires="[[natfixx]] > 0",
6137         text="""
6138     Give the index (in the range 1 to [[natom]] ) of each atom which is to be held
6139     fixed ALONG THE X direction for structural optimization or molecular dynamics.
6140     The variable [[iatfix]] lists those fixed in the three directions, while the
6141     variables [[iatfixx]], [[iatfixy]], and [[iatfixz]], allow to fix some atoms
6142     along x, y or z directions, or a combination of these. See the variable
6143     [[iatfix]] for more information.
6144     """,
6145     ),
6146

6196     for atom-projected density-of-states will be build, in the [[prtdos]] = 3 case.
6197     The radius of these spheres is given by [[ratsph]].
6198     If [[pawfatbnd]] = 1 or 2, it gives the number of the [[natsph]] atoms around
6199     which atom-projected band structure will be built.
