6203     Variable(
6204         abivarname="iboxcut",
6205         varset="paw",
6206         vartype="integer",
6207         topics=['TuningSpeed_expert'],
6208         dimensions="scalar",
6209         defaultval=0,
6210         mnemonics="Integer governing the internal use of BOXCUT - not a very good choice of variable name",
6211         text="""
6212     Concern all summations in the reciprocal space and is allowed in PAW and norm-conserving.
6213     
6214       * if set to 0 all reciprocal space summations are done in a sphere contained in the FFT box.
6215       * if set to 1 all reciprocal space summations are done in the whole FFT box (useful for tests).
6216     """,
6217     ),
6218     
6219     Variable(
6220         abivarname="icoulomb",
6221         varset="gstate",
6222         vartype="integer",
6223         topics=['Coulomb_useful'],
6224         dimensions="scalar",
6225         defaultval=0,
6226         mnemonics="Index for the COULOMB treatment",
6227         text="""
6228     Defines the type of computation used for Hartree potential, local part of
6229     pseudo-potential and ion-ion interaction:
6230     
6231       * [[icoulomb]] = 0: usual reciprocal space computation, using $1/\GG^2$ for the Hartree potential and using Ewald correction.
6232       * [[icoulomb]] = 1: free boundary conditions are used when the Hartree potential is computed,
6233         real space expressions of pseudo-potentials are involved (restricted to GTH pseudo-potentials)
6234         and simple coulomb interaction gives the ion-ion energy.
6235     """,
6236     ),
6237     
6238     Variable(
6239         abivarname="icutcoul",
6240         varset="gw",
6241         vartype="integer",
6242         topics=['GWls_compulsory', 'Susceptibility_basic', 'Coulomb_useful', 'SelfEnergy_basic'],
6243         dimensions="scalar",
6244         defaultval=6,
6245         mnemonics="Integer that governs the CUT-off for COULomb interaction",
6246         requires="[[optdriver]] in [3,4]",
6247         text="""
6248     Many-body calculations for isolated systems present a slow convergence with
6249     respect to the size of the supercell due to the long ranged Coulomb
6250     interaction and the high degree of non-locality of the operators involved. A
6251     similar issue also occurs in fully periodic systems due to the presence of the
6252     integrable Coulomb singularity at $\mathbf{G}=0$ that hinders the convergence with
6253     respect to the number of q-points used to sample the Brillouin zone. The
6254     convergence can be accelerated by replacing the true bare Coulomb interaction
6255     with other expressions.
6256     
6257     [[icutcoul]] defines the particular expression to be used for the Coulomb term
6258     in reciprocal space. The choice of [[icutcoul]] depends on the dimensionality
6259     of the system. Possible values of [[icutcoul]] are from 0 to 6. The
6260     corresponding influential variables are [[vcutgeo]] and [[rcut]].
6261     
6262       * 0 --> sphere (molecules but also 3D-crystals).
6263       * 1 --> cylinder (nanowires, nanotubes).
6264       * 2 --> surface.
6265       * 3 --> 3D crystal (no cut-off, integration in a spherical mini-Brillouin Zone, legacy value).
6266       * 4 --> ERF, long-range only Coulomb interaction.
6267       * 5 --> ERFC, short-range only Coulomb interaction (e.g. as used in the HSE functional).
6268       * 6 --> auxiliary function integration for 3D systems from [[cite:Carrier2007]].
6269       * 7 --> auxiliary function for 3D systems of Gygi and Baldereschi [[cite:Gygi1986]].
6270     
6271     Note that Spencer and Alavi showed that the
6272     spherical cutoff can efficiently be used also for 3D systems [[cite:Spencer2008]].
6273     In the latter case, use a negative value for the cutoff radius of the sphere ([[rcut]]<0),
6274     which is automatically calculated so that the volume enclosed in the sphere is
6275     equal to the volume of the solid.
6276     """,
6277     ),
6278     
6279     Variable(
6280         abivarname="ieig2rf",
6281         varset="dfpt",
6282         vartype="integer",
6283         topics=['TDepES_compulsory'],
6284         dimensions="scalar",
6285         defaultval=0,
6286         mnemonics="Integer for second-order EIGenvalues from Response-Function",
6287         text="""
6288     If [[ieig2rf]] is greater then 0, the code will produce a file, named with the
6289     trailing suffix _EIGR2D, containing the second-order electronic eigenvalues
6290     for the perturbation. These files are used in the calculation of the thermal
6291     correction to the electronic eigenvalues.
6292     
6293       * If [[ieig2rf]] is set to 1, the second-order electronic eigenvalues will be
6294         calculated from the DFPT method (Sternheimer).
6295     
6296       * If [[ieig2rf]] is set to 2, the second-order electronic eigenvalues will be
6297         calculated from the Allen-Cardona method (sum over states).
6298     
6299       * If [[ieig2rf]] is set to 3, the second-order electronic eigenvalues will be
6300         calculated from the DFPT method (sum over states) but using a different part
6301         of the code. This is equivalent to [[ieig2rf]] = 1 [debuging].
6302     
6303       * If [[ieig2rf]] is set to 4, the second-order electronic eigenvalues will be
6304         calculated from the dynamical DFPT method (Sternheimer). The code will
6305         generate _EIGR2D.nc files that contain the electron-phonon matrix element
6306         squared on the space orthogonal to the active space. The code will also
6307         produce _FAN.nc files that contain the electron-phonon matrix elements
6308         squared.
6309     
6310       * If [[ieig2rf]] is set to 5, the second-order electronic eigenvalues will be
6311         calculated from the dynamical DFPT method (Sternheimer). The code will
6312         generate _EIGR2D.nc files that contain the electron-phonon matrix element
6313         square on the space orthogonal to the active space. The code will also produce
6314         _GKK.nc files that contain electron-phonon matrix elements. This option is
6315         preferable for large system to [[ieig2rf]] = 4 as the GKK files take much
6316         less disk space and memory (but run a little bit slower).
6317     
6318     !!! note
6319         [[ieig2rf]] = 4 and 5 can only be used if Abinit is compiled with NETCDF support.
6320     
6321     
6322     Related variables:
6323     [[bdeigrf]],[[elph2_imagden]],[[getgam_eig2nkq]],[[smdelta]]
6324     """,
6325     ),
6326     
6327     Variable(
6328         abivarname="imgmov",
6329         varset="rlx",
6330         vartype="integer",
6331         topics=['CrossingBarriers_useful', 'PIMD_compulsory', 'TransPath_compulsory'],
6332         dimensions="scalar",
6333         defaultval=0,
6334         mnemonics="IMaGe MOVEs",
6335         text="""
6336     Control the collective changes of images (see [[nimage]],[[npimage]],
6337     [[dynimage]], [[ntimimage]], [[tolimg]], [[istatimg]], [[prtvolimg]]).
6338     Similar to [[ionmov]] in spirit, although here, a population of self-consistent
6339     calculations for possibly different (evolving) geometries is managed, while with
6340     [[ionmov]], only self-consistent calculation for one (evolving) geometry is managed.
6341     In this respect the maximal number of time step for image propagation is
6342     [[ntimimage]], corresponding to the input variable [[ntime]] of the single
6343     geometry case. Also, the stopping criterion is governed by [[tolimg]],
6344     corresponding to the input variable [[toldfe]] of the single geometry case.
6345     The stopping condition is crude: the image propagation is stopped when the
6346     mean value (over dynamic images) of the absolute difference of total energy
6347     (previous and current time step) is less than [[tolimg]].
6348     
6349     Actually, there might be combinations of [[ionmov]] and [[imgmov]] in which
6350     the two mechanisms are at work. Usually, however, only one mechanism will be
6351     activated (so, usually, either [[ntimimage]] is bigger than one OR [[ntime]]
6352     is bigger than one). In order for the user to acquire a mental representation
6353     of the interplay between [[ionmov]] and [[imgmov]], here is a F90 pseudo-code
6354     presenting the interplay between the different above-mentioned input
6355     variables, as well as with the parallelism (see input variable [[npimage]]).
6356     
6357     ```fortran
6358         do itimimage=1,ntimimage
6359           do iimage=1,nimage
6360             (possibly, parallelisation over images)
6361             do itime=1,ntime
6362               Compute the forces and stresses for image(iimage)
6363               Examine whether the stopping criterion defined by tolmxf is fulfilled
6364               Predict the next geometry for image(iimage) using ionmov
6365             enddo
6366           enddo
6367           Examine whether the stopping criterion defined by tolimg is fulfilled
6368           Predict the next geometries for all images using imgmov
6369         enddo
6370     ```
6371     
6372       * = 0 --> simply **copy** images from previous itimimage step.
6373       * = 1 --> move images according to **Steepest Descent** following the (scaled) forces,
6374         the scaling factor being [[fxcartfactor]].
6375       * = 2 --> **String Method** for finding Minimal Energy Path (MEP) connecting two minima
6376         (see [[cite:Weinan2002]]), or even two configurations that are not local minima; the algorithm variant can be selected with the [[string_algo]] keyword
6377         (Simplified String Method by default). The solver for the Ordinary Differential Equation (ODE)
6378         can be selected with [[mep_solver]] (steepest-descent by default). See also [[mep_mxstep]] keyword.
6379       * = 3 --> (tentatively, not yet coded) **Metadynamics**.
6380       * = 4 --> (tentatively, not yet coded) **Genetic Algorithm**.
6381       * = 5 --> **Nudged Elastic Band (NEB)** for finding Minimal Energy Path (MEP) connecting two minima;
6382         the algorithm variant can be selected with the [[neb_algo]] keyword (NEB+improved tangent by default).
6383         The solver for the Ordinary Differential Equation (ODE) can be selected with [[mep_solver]] (steepest-descent by default).
6384         The spring constant connecting images along the path is defined by [[neb_spring]]. See also [[mep_mxstep]] keyword.
6385       * = 6 --> **Linear Combination of Constrained DFT Energies**. The images can have different electronic structure ([[occ]] can differ),
6386         and their total energies are combined linearly using the factors in [[mixesimgf]], giving the actual total energy of the ensemble
6387         of constrained DFT images. The geometry is the same for all images, forces and stresses are computed, and all usual
6388         algorithms for MD or geometry optimization are allowed, using [[ionmov]] (instead of [[imgmov]], this is the exception to the rule)
6389         and related variables.
6390       * = 9 or 13 --> **Path-Integral Molecular Dynamics** (see e.g. [[cite:Marx1996]]).
6391         Will use 9 for **Langevin thermostat** (associated friction coefficient given by [[vis]])
6392         and 13 for **Nose-Hoover thermostat chains** (associated input variables are the number of thermostats in the chains,
6393         [[nnos]], and the masses of these thermostats [[qmass]]). [[nimage]] is the Trotter number
6394         (no use of [[dynimage]]); possible transformations of coordinates are defined by [[pitransform]];
6395         Fictitious masses of the atoms (possibly different from the true masses given by [[amu]]) can be specified by [[pimass]].
6396         At present, it is only possible to perform calculations in the (N,V,T) ensemble ([[optcell]] = 0).
6397     
6398     No meaning for RF calculations.
6399     """,
6400     ),
6401     
6402     Variable(
6403         abivarname="imgwfstor",
6404         varset="rlx",
6405         vartype="integer",
6406         topics=['CrossingBarriers_useful', 'PIMD_useful', 'TransPath_useful'],
6407         dimensions="scalar",
6408         defaultval=0,
6409         mnemonics="IMaGe WaveFunction STORage",
6410         requires="[[extrapwf]] == 0 and [[ntimimage]] > 0",
6411         text="""
6412     Govern the storage of wavefunctions at the level of the loop over images, see [[ntimimage]].
6413     Possible values of [[imgwfstor]] are 0 or 1.
6414     If [[imgwfstor]] is 1, the wavefunctions for each image are stored in a big array of
6415     size [[nimage]] more than the storage needed for one set of wavefunctions..
6416     When the specific computation (optimization/SCF cycle ...) for this image is started,
6417     the past wavefunctions are used, to speed up the computation. If [[imgwfstor]]==0,
6418     the wavefunctions are reinitialised, either at random or from the initial wavefunction file (so, without
6419     any modification to take into account the computations at the previous value of itimimage.
6420     
6421     If [[nimage]] is large, the increase of memory need can be problematic, unless the wavefunctions
6422     are spread over many processors, which happens when [[paral_kgb]] == 1.
6423     For some algorithms, e.g. when some geometry optimization
6424     is performed, [[imgmov]]==2 or 5, the gain in speed of choosing [[imgwfstor]]=1 can be quite large, e.g. two to four.
6425     For algorithms of the molecular dynamics type, [[imgmov]]==9 or 13, the expected gain is smaller.
6426     Of course, with adequate memory resources, [[imgwfstor]]==1 should always be preferred.
6427     """,
6428     ),
6429     
6430     Variable(
6431         abivarname="inclvkb",
6432         varset="gw",
6433         vartype="integer",
6434         topics=['Susceptibility_expert', 'BSE_expert'],
6435         dimensions="scalar",
6436         defaultval=2,
6437         mnemonics="INCLude VKB",
6438         requires="[[optdriver]] in [3,99]",
6439         text="""
6440     Possible values of [[inclvkb]] are 0,1,2. If [[inclvkb]] is 1 or 2, the
6441     commutator of the non-local part of the pseudopotential with the position
6442     operator is correctly included in the q --> 0 contribution. This is
6443     unfortunately time-consuming and in particular when the old algorithm
6444     implemented by [[inclvkb]] = 1 is used ([[inclvkb]] = 2 is the recommended option). When
6445     [[inclvkb]] is 0, this contribution is incorrectly omitted, but the computation is much faster.
6446     
6447     The importance of this contribution depends on the number of k points. Turning
6448     off [[inclvkb]] is to let to the choice of the user.
6449     
6450     In general, the use of [[inclvkb]] = 0 is fine for GW calculations in
6451     crystalline systems provided that the k-point sampling is sufficiently converged.
6452     
6453     The use of [[inclvkb]] = 2 is strongly recommended for the calculation of optical properties.
6454     """,
6455     ),
6456     
6457     Variable(
6458         abivarname="intxc",
6459         varset="dev",
6460         vartype="integer",
6461         topics=['xc_expert'],
6462         dimensions="scalar",
6463         defaultval=0,
6464         mnemonics="INTerpolation for eXchange-Correlation",
6465         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
6466         text="""
6467       * 0 --> do "usual" xc quadrature on fft grid
6468       * 1 --> do higher accuracy xc quadrature using fft grid and additional points at the centers of each cube
6469        (doubles number of grid points)--the high accuracy version is only valid for boxcut>=2. If boxcut < 2, the code stops.
6470     
6471     For RF calculations only [[intxc]] = 0 is allowed yet. Moreover, the GS
6472     preparation runs (giving the density file and zero-order wavefunctions) must
6473     be done with [[intxc]] = 0
6474     
6475     Prior to ABINITv2.3, the choice [[intxc]] = 1 was favoured (it was the default),
6476     but the continuation of the development of the code lead to prefer the default
6477     [[intxc]] = 0. Indeed, the benefit of [[intxc]] = 1 is rather small, while making
6478     it available for all cases is a non-negligible development effort. Other
6479     targets are prioritary... You will notice that many automatic tests use
6480     [[intxc]] = 1. Please, do not follow this historical choice for your production runs.
6481     """,
6482     ),
6483     
6484     Variable(
6485         abivarname="iomode",
6486         varset="dev",
6487         vartype="integer",
6488         topics=['parallelism_expert'],
6489         dimensions="scalar",
6490         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[MPI_IO]] and [[paral_kgb]] == 1': 1, 'defaultval': 0}),
6491         mnemonics="Input-Output MODE",
6492         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
6493         text="""
6494     This option selects the format used to produce the output wavefunction files
6495     and the files containing densities and potentials. It mainly affects the
6496     creation of the output files since several parts of Abinit are able to read
6497     data from files independently of their format (either binary files or netcdf
6498     files). The possible values are:
6499     
6500       * 0 --> Use standard Fortran IO (ok for sequential runs, not suitable for large parallel runs)
6501       * 1 --> Use MPI/IO routines (ok both for sequential and large parallel runs)
6502       * 3 --> Use NetCDF library to produce files according to the ETSF specification [[cite:Gonze2008]]
6503         (ok for sequential, requires netcdf4 + hdf5 + MPI-IO support for large parallel runs)
6504     
6505     By default, Abinit produces Fortran files and uses parallel MPI-IO under the
6506     hood when these operations cannot be implemented in terms of simple Fortran
6507     write/read statements. For example, [[paral_kgb]] = 1 uses the MPI-IO API
6508     provided by your MPI library.
6509     
6510     In a nutshell, use the default value and make sure that your MPI library
6511     supports MPI-IO before embarking yourself in large parallel runs (HAVE_MPI_IO
6512     should be set to 1 in ~abinit/config.h). Many MPI libraries, nowadays, support
6513     the MPI-2 standard so it's very likely that your MPI supports parallel IO. If
6514     you encounter problems, please ask your sysadmin to install a MPI library with MPI-IO capabilities.
6515     
6516     There are cases, however, in which you would like to change the default
6517     behaviour. For example, you may want to generate WFK or DEN files in etsf-io
6518     format because you need data in this format. In this case, you have to use
6519     iomode==3 in the input file to override the default behaviour. Note however
6520     that you still need parallel IO capabilities enabled in the netcdf library if
6521     you want to produce netcdf files in parallel with [[paral_kgb]] = 1 (i.e.
6522     netcdf4 + hdf5 + MPI-IO). At present, the internal fallbacks provided by
6523     Abinit do not support netcdf4 so you have to link against an external netcdf
6524     library that supports hdf5+MPI-IO and is compatible with the mpif90 used to
6525     compile Abinit. See ~abinit/doc/build/config-examples/ubu_gnu_4.9_mpich.ac for a typical configuration file.
6526     
6527     Additional note : The use of the ETSF_IO library [[cite:Caliste2008]] has been disabled, and replaced by direct NetCDF calls.
6528     The ETSF_IO library was indeed not maintained anymore.
6529     """,
6530     ),
6531     
6532     Variable(
6533         abivarname="ionmov",
6534         varset="rlx",
6535         vartype="integer",
6536         topics=['MolecularDynamics_compulsory', 'GeoOpt_compulsory'],
6537         dimensions="scalar",
6538         defaultval=0,
6539         mnemonics="IONic MOVEs",
6540         text="""
6541     Choice of algorithm to control the displacements of ions, and eventually (see
6542     [[optcell]]) changes of cell shape and size.
6543     
6544       * 0 --> Do not move ions;
6545     
6546       * 1 --> Move atoms using molecular dynamics with optional viscous damping (friction linearly proportional to velocity). The viscous damping is controlled by the parameter "[[vis]]". If actual undamped molecular dynamics is desired, set [[vis]] to 0. The implemented algorithm is the generalisation of the Numerov technique (6th order), but is NOT invariant upon time-reversal, so that the energy is not conserved. The value [[ionmov]] = 6 will usually be preferred, although the algorithm that is implemented is lower-order. The time step is governed by [[dtion]].
6547     **Purpose:** Molecular dynamics (if [[vis]] = 0), Structural optimization (if
6548     [[vis]] >0)
6549     **Cell optimization:** No (Use [[optcell]] = 0 only)
6550     **Related variables:** Viscous parameter [[vis]], time step [[dtion]], index
6551     of atoms fixed [[iatfix]]
6552     
6553       * 2 --> Conduct structural optimization using the Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno minimization (BFGS). This is much more efficient for structural optimization than viscous damping, when there are less than about 10 degrees of freedom to optimize.
6554     **Purpose:** Structural optimization
6555     **Cell optimization:** Yes (if [[optcell]]/=0)
6556     **Related variables:**
6557     
6558       * 3 --> Conduct structural optimization using the Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno minimization (BFGS), modified to take into account the total energy as well as the gradients (as in usual BFGS).
6559     See [[cite:Schlegel1982]]. Might be better than [[ionmov]] = 2 for few degrees of freedom (less than 3 or 4). Can be very
6560     unstable - use with caution!
6561     **Purpose:** Structural optimization
6562     **Cell optimization:** Yes (if [[optcell]]/=0)
6563     **Related variables:**
6564     
6565       * 4 --> Conjugate gradient algorithm for simultaneous optimization of potential and ionic degrees of freedom. It can be used with [[iscf]] = 2 and [[iscf]] =5 or 6 (WARNING: this is under development, and does not work very well in many cases).
6566     **Purpose:** Structural optimization
6567     **Cell optimization:** No (Use [[optcell]] = 0 only)
6568     **Related variables:**
6569     
6570       * 5 --> Simple relaxation of ionic positions according to (converged) forces. Equivalent to [[ionmov]] = 1 with zero masses, albeit the relaxation coefficient is not [[vis]], but [[iprcfc]].
6571     **Purpose:** Structural optimization
6572     **Cell optimization:** No (Use [[optcell]] = 0 only)
6573     **Related variables:**
6574     
6575       * 6 --> Molecular dynamics using the Verlet algorithm, see [[cite:Allen1987a]] p 81]. The only related parameter is the time step ([[dtion]]).
6576     **Purpose:** Molecular dynamics
6577     **Cell optimization:** No (Use [[optcell]] = 0 only)
6578     **Related variables:** time step [[dtion]], index of atoms fixed [[iatfix]]
6579     
6580       * 7 --> Quenched Molecular dynamics using the Verlet algorithm, and stopping each atom for which the scalar product of velocity and force is negative. The only related parameter is the time step ([[dtion]]). The goal is not to produce a realistic dynamics, but to go as fast as possible to the minimum. For this purpose, it is advised to set all the masses to the same value (for example, use the Carbon mass, i.e. set [[amu]] to 12 for all type of atoms).
6581     **Purpose:** Structural optimization
6582     **Cell optimization:** No (Use [[optcell]] = 0 only)
6583     **Related variables:** time step [[dtion]], index of atoms fixed [[iatfix]]
6584     
6585       * 8 --> Molecular dynamics with Nose-Hoover thermostat, using the Verlet algorithm.
6586     **Purpose:** Molecular dynamics
6587     **Cell optimization:** No (Use [[optcell]] = 0 only)
6588     **Related variables:** time step ([[dtion]]), Temperatures ([[mdtemp]]), and
6589     thermostat mass ([[noseinert]]).
6590     
6591       * 9 --> Langevin molecular dynamics.
6592     **Purpose:** Molecular dynamics
6593     **Cell optimization:** No (Use [[optcell]] = 0 only)
6594     **Related variables:** time step ([[dtion]]), temperatures ([[mdtemp]]) and
6595     friction coefficient ([[friction]]).
6596     
6597       * 10 --> Delocalized internal coordinates. with BFGS simple
6598     **Purpose:** Structural optimization
6599     **Cell optimization:** No (Use [[optcell]] = 0 only)
6600     **Related variables:**
6601     
6602       * 11 --> Delocalized internal coordinates. with BFGS using total energy
6603     **Purpose:** Structural optimization
6604     **Cell optimization:** No (Use [[optcell]] = 0 only)
6605     **Related variables:**
6606     
6607       * 12 --> Isokinetic ensemble molecular dynamics.
6608     The equation of motion of the ions in contact with a thermostat are solved with the algorithm proposed in [[cite:Zhang1997]],
6609     as worked out in [cite:Minary2003]].
6610     The conservation of the kinetic energy is obtained within machine precision, at each step.
6611     As in [[cite:Evans1983]], when there is no fixing of atoms, the number of degrees of freedom in which the
6612     microscopic kinetic energy is hosted is 3*natom-4. Indeed, the total kinetic energy is constrained, which accounts for
6613     minus one degree of freedom (also mentioned in [cite:Minary2003]]), but also there are three degrees of freedom
6614     related to the total momentum in each direction, that cannot be counted as microscopic degrees of freedom, since the
6615     total momentum is also preserved (but this is not mentioned in [cite:Minary2003]]). When some atom is fixed in one or more direction,
6616     e.g. using [[natfix]], [[natfixx]], [[natfixy]], or [[natfixz]], the number of degrees of freedom is decreased accordingly,
6617     albeit taking into account that the total momentum is not preserved
6618     anymore (e.g. fixing the position of one atom gives 3*natom-4, like in the non-fixed case).
6619     **Purpose:** Molecular dynamics
6620     **Cell optimization:** No (Use [[optcell]] = 0 only)
6621     **Related variables:** time step ([[dtion]]) and the first temperature in [[mdtemp]] in case the velocities [[vel]] are not initialized, or all initialized to zero.
6622     
6623       * 13 --> Isothermal/isenthalpic ensemble. The equation of motion of the ions in contact with a thermostat and a barostat are solved with the algorithm proposed in [[cite:Martyna1996]].
6624     If optcell=1 or 2, the mass of the barostat ([[bmass]]) must be given in
6625     addition.
6626     **Purpose:** Molecular dynamics
6627     **Cell optimization:** Yes (if [[optcell]]/=0)
6628     **Related variables:** The time step ([[dtion]]), the temperatures
6629     ([[mdtemp]]), the number of thermostats ([[nnos]]), and the masses of
6630     thermostats ([[qmass]]).
6631     
6632       * 14 --> Simple molecular dynamics with a symplectic algorithm proposed in [[cite:Blanes2002]]  (called SRKNa14] of the kind first published in [[cite:Yoshida1990]]This algorithm requires at least 14 evaluation of the forces (actually 15 are done within Abinit) per time step. At this cost it usually gives much better energy conservation than the verlet algorithm ([[ionmov]] 6) for a 30 times bigger value of [[dtion]]. Notice that the potential energy of the initial atomic configuration is never evaluated using this algorithm.
6633     **Purpose:** Molecular dynamics
6634     **Cell optimization:** No (Use [[optcell]] = 0 only)
6635     **Related variables:**
6636     
6637       * 15 --> Fast inertial relaxation engine (FIRE) algorithm proposed by Erik Bitzek, Pekka Koskinen, Franz Gähler, Michael Moseler, and Peter Gumbsch in [[cite:Bitzek2006]]. This efficiency of this method is competible with bfgs. It is based on conventional molecular dynamics with additional velocity modifications and adaptive time steps. The initial time step is set with [[dtion]]. Note that here the physical meaning and unit of dtion are different from the default one. The purpose of this ionmov is for relaxation, not molecular dynamics. It is still the step of moving the ions, but the cellparameters change as well. The positions are in the reduced coordinates instead of in cartesian coordinates. The suggested first guess of dtion is 0.03.
6638     **Purpose:** Relaxation
6639     **Cell optimization:** Yes (if [[optcell]]/=0)
6640     **Related variables:** The initial time step [[dtion]]
6641     
6642       * 20 --> Direct inversion of the iterative subspace. Given a starting point [[xred]] that is a vector of length 3*[[natom]] (reduced nuclei coordinates), and unit cell parameters ([[rprimd]]) this routine uses the DIIS (direct inversion of the iterative subspace) to minimize the gradient (forces) on atoms. The preconditioning used to compute errors from gradients is using an inverse hessian matrix obtained by a BFGS algorithm. This method is known to converge to the nearest point where gradients vanish. This is efficient to refine positions around a saddle point for instance.
6643     **Purpose:** Structural optimization
6644     **Cell optimization:** No (Use [[optcell]] = 0 only)
6645     **Related variables:** DIIS memory [[diismemory]]
6646     
6647       * 22 --> Conduct structural optimization using the Limited-memory Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno minimization (L-BFGS). The working routines were based on the original implementation of J. Nocera available on netlib.org. This algorithm can be much better than the native implementation of BFGS in ABINIT ([[ionmov]] = 2) when one approaches convergence, perhaps because of better treatment of numerical details.
6648     **Purpose:** Structural optimization
6649     **Cell optimization:** Yes (if [[optcell]]/=0)
6650     **Related variables:**
6651     
6652       * 23 --> Use of Learn on The Fly method (LOTF) for Molecular Dynamics. In the framework of isokinetic MD, the atomic forces and positions are computed by using LOTF interpolation. A SCF computation is performed only any [[lotf_nitex]] steps. The results of the SCF are used to compute the parameters of a short range classical potential (for the moment only the glue potential for gold is implemented). Then these parameters are continuously tuned to compute atomic trajectories. LOTF has to be enabled at configure time. If LOTF is not enabled and [[ionmov]] = 23, abinit will set automatically [[ionmov]] = 12.
6653     The LOTF cycle is divided in the following steps:
6654     a) Initialization (SFC at t=0) and computation of potential parameters.
6655     b) Extrapolation of the atomic forces and positions for [[lotf_nitex]] time
6656     step. To perform this extrapolation, the potential computed in a) is used
6657     (Verlet algorithm).
6658     c) SFC at t=[[lotf_nitex]]. Computation of the potential parameters.
6659     d) LOTF interpolation, linear interpolation of the potential parameters and
6660     computation of the atomic forces and positions between t=0 and t=lotf_nitex.
6661     
6662     **Purpose:** Molecular Dynamics
6663     **Cell optimization:** No (Use [[optcell]] = 0 only)
6664     **Related variables:** [[dtion]], [[lotf_classic]], [[lotf_nitex]],
6665     [[lotf_nneigx]], [[lotf_version]].
6666     
6667       * 24 --> Simple constant energy molecular dynamics using the velocity Verlet symplectic algorithm (second order), see [[cite:Hairer2003]]. The only related parameter is the time step ([[dtion]]).
6668     **Purpose:** Molecular dynamics
6669     **Cell optimization:** No (Use [[optcell]] = 0 only)
6670     **Related variables:** time step [[dtion]]
6671     
6672       * 25 --> Hybrid Monte Carlo sampling of the ionic positions at fixed temperature and unit cell geometry (NVT ensemble). The underlying molecular dynamics corresponds to ionmov=24. The related parameters are the time step ([[dtion]]) and thermostat temperature ([[mdtemp]]).
6673     **Purpose:** Monte Carlo sampling
6674     **Cell optimization:** No (Use [[optcell]] = 0 only)
6675     **Related variables:** time step [[dtion]], thermostat temperature [[mdtemp]],
6676     
6677     No meaning for RF calculations.
6678     """,
6679     ),
6680     
6681     Variable(
6682         abivarname="iprcel",
6683         varset="gstate",
6684         vartype="integer",
6685         topics=['SCFAlgorithms_expert'],
6686         dimensions="scalar",
6687         defaultval=0,
6688         mnemonics="Integer for PReConditioning of ELectron response",
6689         text=r"""
6690     Used when [[iscf]] > 0, to define the SCF preconditioning scheme. Potential-
6691     based preconditioning schemes for the SCF loop (electronic part) are still a
6692     subject of active research. The present parameter (electronic part) describes
6693     the way the change of potential is derived from the residual.
6694     The possible values of [[iprcel]] correspond to:
6695     
6696       * 0 --> model dielectric function described by [[diemac]], [[dielng]] and [[diemix]].
6697       * larger or equal to 21 --> will compute the dielectric matrix according to [[diecut]], [[dielam]], [[diegap]]. This methodology is described in [[cite:Anglade2008]].
6698       * Between 21 and 29 --> for the first few steps uses the same as option 0 then compute RPA dielectric function, and use it as such.
6699       * Between 31 and 39 --> for the first few steps uses the same as option 0 then compute RPA dielectric function, and use it, with the mixing factor [[diemix]].
6700       * Between 41 and 49 --> compute the RPA dielectric matrix at the first step, and recompute it at a later step, and take into account the mixing factor [[diemix]].
6701       * Between 51 and 59 --> same as between 41 and 49, but compute the RPA dielectric matrix by another mean
6702       * Between 61 and 69 --> same as between 41 and 49, but compute the electronic dielectric matrix instead of the RPA one.
6703       * Between 71 and 78 --> STILL UNDER DEVELOPMENT -- NOT USABLE; Use the modified Kerker preconditioner with a real-space formulation (basic formulation is shown at [[dielng]]). The dielectric matrix is approximated thanks to [[diemac]] and [[dielng]]. Note that [[diemix]] is also used.
6704       * 79 --> STILL UNDER DEVELOPMENT -- NOT USABLE; same as previous but with an alternate algorithm.
6705       * 141 to 169 --> same as Between 41 and 69 (but, the dielectric matrix is also recomputed every iprcel modulo 10 step).
6706     
6707     The computation of the dielectric matrix (for 0 [100]< [[iprcel]] < 70 [100])
6708     is based on the **extrapolar** approximation, see [[cite:Anglade2008]]. This approximation can be tuned
6709     with [[diecut]], [[dielam]], and [[diegap]]. Yet its accuracy mainly depends
6710     on the number of conduction bands included in the system. Having 2 to 10 empty
6711     bands in the calculation is usually enough (use [[nband]]).
6712     
6713     NOTES:
6714     
6715       * The step at which the dielectric matrix is computed or recomputed is determined by modulo([[iprcel]],10). The recomputation happens just once in the calculation for [[iprcel]]  < 100.
6716       * For non-homogeneous relatively large cells [[iprcel]] = 45 will likely give a large improvement over [[iprcel]] = 0.
6717       * In case of PAW and [[iprcel]] > 0, see [[pawsushat]] input variable. By default, an approximation (which can be suppressed) is done for the computation of susceptibility matrix.
6718       * For extremely large inhomogeneous cells where computation of the full dielectric matrix takes too many weeks, 70 < [[iprcel]] < 80 is advised.
6719       * For [[nsppol]] = 2 or [[nspinor]] = 2 with metallic [[occopt]], only **mod(iprcel,100)** <50 is allowed.
6720       * No meaning for RF calculations yet.
6721       * The exchange term in the full dielectric matrix diverges for vanishing densities. Therefore the values of [[iprcel]] beyond 60 must not be used for cells containing vacuum, unless ones computes this matrix for every step ([[iprcel]] = 161).
6722     """,
6723     ),
6724     
6725     Variable(
6726         abivarname="iprcfc",
6727         varset="dev",
6728         vartype="integer",
6729         topics=['GeoOpt_useful'],
6730         dimensions="scalar",
6731         defaultval=0,
6732         mnemonics="Integer for PReConditioner of Force Constants",
6733         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
6734         text="""
6735     Used when [[iscf]] > 0, to define the SCF preconditioning scheme. Potential-
6736     based preconditioning schemes for the SCF loop are still under development.
6737     The present parameter (force constant part) describes the way a change of
6738     force is derived from a change of atomic position.
6739     Supported values:
6740     
6741       * 0 --> hessian is the identity matrix
6742       * 1 --> hessian is 0.5 times the identity matrix
6743       * 2 --> hessian is 0.25 times the identity matrix
6744       * -1 --> hessian is twice the identity matrix
6745       *... (simply corresponding power of 2 times the identity matrix)
6746     
6747     No meaning for RF calculations.
6748     """,
6749     ),
6750     
6751     Variable(
6752         abivarname="iqpt",
6753         varset="gstate",
6754         vartype="integer",
6755         topics=['q-points_basic'],
6756         dimensions="scalar",
6757         defaultval=0,
6758         mnemonics="Index for QPoinT generation",
6759         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
6760         text="""
6761     Only used if [[nqpt]] = 1, and [[qptopt]] = 1 to 4.
6762     
6763     Defines the index of the Q point to be selected in the list of q points
6764     generated by [[ngqpt]], [[qptrlatt]], [[nshiftq]], and [[shiftq]].
6765     
6766     If [[iqpt]] = 0, then the q point is Gamma (0 0 0).
6767     
6768     The usual working mode is to define a series of values for [[iqpt]], starting
6769     with [[iqpt]] = 0 or 1 (so through the definition of **iqpt:** ), and increasing
6770     it by one for each dataset (thanks to **iqpt+** ).
6771     """,
6772     ),
6773     
6774     Variable(
6775         abivarname="irandom",
6776         varset="dev",
6777         vartype="integer",
6778         topics=['PIMD_expert'],
6779         dimensions="scalar",
6780         defaultval=3,
6781         mnemonics="Integer for the choice of the RANDOM number generator",
6782         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
6783         text="""
6784     For the time being, only used when [[imgmov]] = 9 (Langevin Path-Integral Molecular Dynamics).
6785     [[irandom]] defines the random number generator.
6786     
6787     Supported values:
6788     
6789       * 1 --> "uniformrandom", delivered with ABINIT package (initially comes from numerical recipes).
6790       * 2 --> intrinsic Fortran 90 random number generator.
6791       * 3 --> "ZBQ" non-deterministic random number generator by R. Chandler and P. Northrop.
6792       [Documentation](http://www.ucl.ac.uk/~ucakarc/work/software/randgen.txt) and
6793       [Source code](http://www.ucl.ac.uk/~ucakarc/work/software/randgen.f)
6794     
6795     [[irandom]] = 3 is strongly advised when performing Molecular Dynamics restarts (avoids bias).
6796     """,
6797     ),
6798     
6799     Variable(
6800         abivarname="ird1den",
6801         varset="files",
6802         vartype="integer",
6803         topics=['nonlinear_useful'],
6804         dimensions="scalar",
6805         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[iscf]] < 0': 1, 'defaultval': 0}),
6806         mnemonics="Integer that governs the ReaDing of 1st-order DEN file",
6807         text="""
6808     If first order density is needed in single dataset mode (for example in
6809     nonlinear optical response), use [[ird1den]] = 1 to read first-order densities
6810     from _DENx files produced in other calculations. In multi-dataset mode use [[get1den]].
6811     
6812     When [[iscf]] < 0, the reading of a DEN file is always enforced.
6813     
6814     A non-zero value of **ird1den** is treated in the same way as other "ird" variables.
6815     For further information about the *files file*, consult the [[help:abinit#files-file]].
6816     """,
6817     ),
6818     
6819     Variable(
6820         abivarname="ird1wf",
6821         varset="files",
6822         vartype="integer",
6823         topics=['DFPT_useful'],
6824         dimensions="scalar",
6825         defaultval=0,
6826         mnemonics="Integer that governs the ReaDing of _1WF files",
6827         text="""
6828     Indicates eventual starting wavefunctions. As alternative, one can use the
6829     input variables [[getwfk]], [[getwfq]], [[get1wf]] or [[getddk]].
6830     
6831     Ground-state calculation:
6832     
6833       * only **irdwfk** and [[getwfk]] have a meaning
6834       * at most one of **irdwfk** or [[getwfk]] can be non-zero
6835       * if **irdwfk** and [[getwfk]] are both zero, initialize wavefunctions with random numbers for ground state calculation.
6836       * if **irdwfk** = 1: read ground state wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _WFK,
6837          produced in a previous ground state calculation.
6838     
6839     Response-function calculation:
6840     
6841       * one and only one of **irdwfk** or [[getwfk]] MUST be non-zero
6842       * if **irdwfk** = 1: read ground state k -wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _WFK,
6843         produced in a previous ground state calculation.
6844       * only one of **irdwfq** or [[getwfq]] can be non-zero, if both of them are non-zero,
6845          use as k + q file the one defined by **irdwfk** and/or [[getwfk]]
6846       * if **irdwfq** = 1: read ground state k+q -wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _WFQ,
6847         produced in a previous ground state calculation.
6848       * at most one of [[ird1wf]] or [[get1wf]] can be non-zero
6849       * if both are zero, initialize first order wavefunctions to zeroes
6850       * if [[ird1wf]] = 1: read first-order wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _1WFx,
6851         produced in a previous response function calculation.
6852       * at most one of **irdddk** or [[getddk]] can be non-zero
6853       * one of them must be non-zero if an homogeneous electric field calculation is done
6854          (presently, a ddk calculation in the same dataset is not allowed)
6855       * if **irdddk** = 1: read first-order ddk wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _1WFx,
6856         produced in a previous response function calculation.
6857     
6858     For further information about the *files file*, consult the [[help:abinit#files-file]].
6859     """,
6860     ),
6861     
6862     Variable(
6863         abivarname="irdbscoup",
6864         varset="files",
6865         vartype="integer",
6866         topics=['BSE_useful'],
6867         dimensions="scalar",
6868         defaultval=0,
6869         mnemonics="Integer that governs the ReaDing of COUPling block",
6870         text="""
6871     Start the Bethe-Salpeter calculation from the BSC file containing the coupling block produced in a previous run.

6890         varset="files",
6891         vartype="integer",

6894         defaultval=0,

6902     Variable(
6903         abivarname="irdddb",
6904         varset="files",
6905         vartype="integer",
6906         topics=['ElPhonInt_useful'],
6907         dimensions="scalar",
6908         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[iscf]] < 0': '1', 'defaultval': 0}),
6909         mnemonics="Integer that governs the ReaDing of DDB file",
6910         text="""
6911     This variable should be used when performing electron-phonon or temperature-
6912     dependence calculations. The Born effective charge as well as the dielectric
6913     tensor will be read from a previous DFPT calculations of the electric field at
6914     q=Gamma. The use of this variable will trigger the cancellation of a residual
6915     dipole that leads to an unphysical divergence of the GKK with vanishing
6916     q-points. The use of this variable greatly improves the k-point convergence
6917     speed as the density of the k-point grid required to obtain the fulfillment of
6918     the charge neutrality sum rule is usually prohibitively large.
6919     
6920     A non-zero value of [[irdddb]] is treated in the same way as other "ird" variables.
6921     For further information about the *files file*, consult the [[help:abinit#files-file]].
6922     """,
6923     ),
6924     
6925     Variable(
6926         abivarname="irdddk",
6927         varset="files",
6928         vartype="integer",
6929         topics=['DFPT_useful'],
6930         dimensions="scalar",
6931         defaultval=0,
6932         mnemonics="Integer that governs the ReaDing of DDK wavefunctions, in _1WF files",
6933         text="""
6934     Indicates eventual starting wavefunctions. As alternative, one can use the
6935     input variables [[getwfk]], [[getwfq]], [[get1wf]] or [[getddk]].
6936     
6937     Ground-state calculation:
6938     
6939       * only **irdwfk** and [[getwfk]] have a meaning
6940       * at most one of **irdwfk** or [[getwfk]] can be non-zero
6941       * if **irdwfk** and [[getwfk]] are both zero, initialize wavefunctions with random numbers for ground state calculation.
6942       * if **irdwfk** = 1: read ground state wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _WFK,
6943         produced in a previous ground state calculation
6944     
6945     Response-function calculation:
6946     
6947       * one and only one of **irdwfk** or [[getwfk]] MUST be non-zero
6948       * if **irdwfk** = 1: read ground state k -wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _WFK,
6949         produced in a previous ground state calculation
6950       * only one of **irdwfq** or [[getwfq]] can be non-zero, if both of them are non-zero,
6951         use as k + q file the one defined by **irdwfk** and/or [[getwfk]]
6952       * if **irdwfq** = 1: read ground state k+q -wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _WFQ,
6953         produced in a previous ground state calculation
6954       * at most one of **ird1wf** or [[get1wf]] can be non-zero
6955       * if both are zero, initialize first order wavefunctions to zeroes
6956       * if **ird1wf** = 1: read first-order wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _1WFx,
6957         produced in a previous response function calculation
6958       * at most one of [[irdddk]] or [[getddk]] can be non-zero
6959       * one of them must be non-zero if an homogeneous electric field calculation is done (presently,
6960         a ddk calculation in the same dataset is not allowed)
6961       * if [[irdddk]] = 1: read first-order ddk wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _1WFx,
6962         produced in a previous response function calculation
6963     
6964     For further information about the *files file*, consult the [[help:abinit#files-file]].
6965     """,
6966     ),

7070     Variable(
7071         abivarname="irdwfk",
7072         varset="files",
7073         vartype="integer",
7074         topics=['multidtset_useful'],
7075         dimensions="scalar",
7076         defaultval=0,
7077         mnemonics="Integer that governs the ReaDing of _WFK files",
7078         text="""
7079     Indicates eventual starting wavefunctions. As alternative, one can use the
7080     input variables [[getwfk]], [[getwfq]], [[get1wf]] or [[getddk]].
7081     
7082     Ground-state calculation:
7083     
7084       * only [[irdwfk]] and [[getwfk]] have a meaning
7085       * at most one of [[irdwfk]] or [[getwfk]] can be non-zero
7086       * if [[irdwfk]] and [[getwfk]] are both zero, initialize wavefunctions with random numbers for ground state calculation.
7087       * if [[irdwfk]] = 1: read ground state wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _WFK,
7088         produced in a previous ground state calculation.
7089     
7090     Response-function calculation:
7091     
7092       * one and only one of [[irdwfk]] or [[getwfk]] MUST be non-zero
7093       * if [[irdwfk]] = 1: read ground state k -wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _WFK,
7094         produced in a previous ground state calculation
7095       * only one of **irdwfq** or [[getwfq]] can be non-zero, if both of them are non-zero,
7096          use as k + q file the one defined by [[irdwfk]] and/or [[getwfk]]
7097       * if **irdwfq** = 1: read ground state k+q -wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _WFQ,
7098         produced in a previous ground state calculation
7099       * at most one of **ird1wf** or [[get1wf]] can be non-zero
7100       * if both are zero, initialize first order wavefunctions to 0's.
7101       * if **ird1wf** = 1: read first-order wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _1WFx,
7102         produced in a previous response function calculation
7103       * at most one of **irdddk** or [[getddk]] can be non-zero
7104       * one of them must be non-zero if an homogeneous electric field calculation is done
7105         (presently, a ddk calculation in the same dataset is not allowed)
7106       * if **irdddk** = 1: read first-order ddk wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _1WFx,
7107         produced in a previous response function calculation
7108     
7109     For further information about the *files file*, consult the [[help:abinit#files-file]].
7110     """,
7111     ),

7113     Variable(
7114         abivarname="irdwfkfine",
7115         varset="dev",
7116         vartype="integer",
7117         topics=['multidtset_useful', 'TDepES_useful'],
7118         dimensions="scalar",
7119         defaultval=0,
7120         mnemonics="Integer that governs the ReaDing of the grid _WFK file on the FINE grid",
7121         text="""
7122     Indicates eventual starting wavefunctions. As alternative, one can use the input variables [[getwfkfine]].
7123

7125     
7126       * only [[irdwfkfine]] and [[getwfkfine]] have a meaning
7127       * at most one of [[irdwfkfine]] or [[getwfkfine]] can be non-zero
7128       * if [[irdwfkfine]] = 1: read ground state wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _WFK,
7129         produced in a previous ground state fine grid calculation
7130     
7131     Response-function calculation:
7132     
7133       * one and only one of [[irdwfkfine]] or [[getwfkfine]] MUST be non-zero
7134       * if [[irdwfkfine]] = 1: read ground state k -wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _WFK,
7135         produced in a previous ground state calculation
7136       * Reading the fine grid wavefunction will trigger the k-points interpolation technique of the temperature dependent calculations.
7137     
7138     Bethe-Salpeter calculation:
7139     
7140       * one and only one of [[irdwfkfine]] or [[getwfkfine]] MUST be non-zero
7141       * if [[irdwfkfine]] = 1: read ground state k -wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _WFK,
7142          produced in a previous ground state calculation
7143       * This variable or [[getwfkfine]] is mandatory when [[bs_interp_mode]] = 1
7144     
7145     For further information about the *files file*, consult the [[help:abinit#files-file]].
7146     
7147     **This variable is experimental. In development.**
7148     """,
