7150     
7151     Variable(
7152         abivarname="irdwfq",
7153         varset="files",
7154         vartype="integer",
7155         topics=['DFPT_useful'],
7156         dimensions="scalar",
7157         defaultval=0,
7158         mnemonics="Integer that governs the ReaDing of _WFQ files",
7159         text="""
7160     Indicates eventual starting wavefunctions. As alternative, one can use the
7161     input variables [[getwfk]], [[getwfq]], [[get1wf]] or [[getddk]].
7162     
7163     Ground-state calculation:
7164     
7165       * only **irdwfk** and [[getwfk]] have a meaning
7166       * at most one of **irdwfk** or [[getwfk]] can be non-zero
7167       * if **irdwfk** and [[getwfk]] are both zero, initialize wavefunctions with random numbers for ground state calculation.
7168       * if **irdwfk** = 1: read ground state wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _WFK,
7169         produced in a previous ground state calculation
7170     
7171     Response-function calculation:
7172     
7173       * one and only one of **irdwfk** or [[getwfk]] MUST be non-zero
7174       * if **irdwfk** = 1: read ground state k -wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _WFK,
7175         produced in a previous ground state calculation
7176       * only one of [[irdwfq]] or [[getwfq]] can be non-zero, if both of them are non-zero,
7177         use as k + q file the one defined by **irdwfk** and/or [[getwfk]]
7178       * if [[irdwfq]] = 1: read ground state k+q -wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _WFQ,
7179         produced in a previous ground state calculation
7180       * at most one of **ird1wf** or [[get1wf]] can be non-zero
7181       * if both are zero, initialize first order wavefunctions to 0's.
7182       * if **ird1wf** = 1: read first-order wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _1WFx,
7183         produced in a previous response function calculation
7184       * at most one of **irdddk** or [[getddk]] can be non-zero
7185       * one of them must be non-zero if an homogeneous electric field calculation is done (presently,
7186         a ddk calculation in the same dataset is not allowed)
7187       * if **irdddk** = 1: read first-order ddk wavefunctions from a disk file appended with _1WFx,
7188         produced in a previous response function calculation
7189     
7190     For further information about the *files file*, consult the [[help:abinit#files-file]].
7191     """,
7192     ),
7193     
7194     Variable(
7195         abivarname="iscf",
7196         varset="basic",
7197         vartype="integer",
7198         topics=['SCFAlgorithms_basic', 'TDDFT_compulsory', 'ElecBandStructure_basic'],
7199         dimensions="scalar",
7200         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[usepaw]] == 1': 17, '[[usewvl]] == 1': 0, 'defaultval': 7}),
7201         mnemonics="Integer for Self-Consistent-Field cycles",
7202         text=r"""
7203     Controls the self-consistency.
7204     Positive values --> this is the usual choice for doing the usual ground state
7205     (GS) calculations or for structural relaxation, where the potential has to be
7206     determined self-consistently. The choice between different algorithms for SCF
7207     is possible:
7208     
7209       * 0 --> SCF cycle, direct minimization scheme on the gradient of the wavefunctions. This algorithm is faster than diagonalisation and mixing but is working only for systems with a gap. It is implemented only on the wavelet basis set, when [[usewvl]] = 1.
7210       * 1 --> get the largest eigenvalue of the SCF cycle
7211     ([[DEVELOP]] option, used with [[irdwfk]] = 1 or [[irdwfq]] = 1)
7212     
7213       * 2 --> SCF cycle, simple mixing of the potential with the preconditioned potential residual (in the usual case, the latter is defined by [[diemix]], [[diemac]] and [[dielng]])
7214       * 3 --> SCF cycle, Anderson mixing of the potential
7215       * 4 --> SCF cycle, Anderson mixing of the potential based on the two previous iterations
7216       * 5 --> SCF cycle, CG based on the minim. of the energy with respect to the potential
7217       * 7 --> SCF cycle, Pulay mixing of the potential based on the [[npulayit]] previous iterations
7218       * 12 --> SCF cycle, simple mixing of the density
7219       * 13 --> SCF cycle, Anderson mixing of the density
7220       * 14 --> SCF cycle, Anderson mixing of the density based on the two previous iterations
7221       * 15 --> SCF cycle, CG based on the minim. of the energy with respect to the density
7222       * 17 --> SCF cycle, Pulay mixing of the density based on the [[npulayit]] previous iterations
7223     
7224     !!! warning
7225     
7226         Other positive values, including zero ones, are not allowed.
7227     
7228     Such algorithms for treating the "SCF iteration history" should be coupled
7229     with accompanying algorithms for the SCF "preconditioning". See the input
7230     variable [[iprcel]]. The default value [[iprcel]] = 0 is often a good choice,
7231     but for inhomogeneous systems, you might gain a lot with [[iprcel]] = 45.
7232     
7233     (Warning: if [[iscf]] > 10, at present (v4.6), the energy printed at each SCF
7234     cycle is not variational - this should not affect the other properties, and at
7235     convergence, all values are OK)
7236     
7237     - In the norm-conserving case, the default option is [[iscf]] = 7, which is a
7238     compromise between speed and reliability. The value [[iscf]] =  2 is safer but
7239     slower.
7240     - In the PAW case, default option is [[iscf]] = 17. In PAW you have the
7241     possibility to mix density/potential on the fine or coarse FFT grid (see
7242     [[pawmixdg]]).
7243     - Note that a Pulay mixing ([[iscf]] = 7 or 17) with [[npulayit]] =1 (resp. 2)
7244     is equivalent to an Anderson mixing with [[iscf]] = 3 or 13 (resp. 4 or 14).
7245     - Also note that:
7246     * when mixing is done on potential (iscf <10), total energy is computed by "direct" decomposition.
7247     * when mixing is done on density (iscf >=10), total energy is computed by "double counting" decomposition.
7248     "Direct" and "double counting" decomposition of energy are equal when SCF
7249     cycle is converged. Note that, when using GGA XC functionals, these
7250     decompositions of energy can be slightly different due to imprecise
7251     computation of density gradients on FFT grid (difference decreases as size of
7252     FFT grid increases - see [[ecut]] for NC pseudopotentials, [[pawecutdg]] for PAW).
7253     
7254     Other (negative) options:
7255     
7256       * -2 --> a non-self-consistent calculation is to be done; in this case an electron density rho(r) on a real space grid (produced in a previous calculation) will be read from a disk file (automatically if [[ndtset]] = 0, or according to the value of [[getden]] if [[ndtset]]/=0).
7257     The name of th density file must be given as indicated [[help:abinit#files-file|here]].
7258     [[iscf]] = -2 would be used for band structure calculations, to permit
7259     computation of the eigenvalues of occupied and unoccupied states at arbitrary
7260     k points in the fixed self consistent potential produced by some integration
7261     grid of k points. Due to this typical use, ABINIT insist that either
7262     [[prtvol]] > 2 or [[prteig]] does not vanish when there are more than 50 k points.
7263     To compute the eigenvalues (and wavefunctions) of unoccupied states in a
7264     separate (non-selfconsistent) run, the user should save the self-consistent
7265     rho(r) and then run [[iscf]] = -2 for the intended set of k-points and bands.
7266     To prepare a run with [[iscf]] = -2, a density file can be produced using the
7267     parameter [[prtden]] (see its description). When a self-consistent set of
7268     wavefunctions is already available, abinit can be used with [[nstep]] = 0 (see
7269     Test_v2/t47.in), and the adequate value of [[prtden]].
7270     
7271       * -3 --> like -2, but initialize [[occ]] and [[wtk]], directly or indirectly (using [[ngkpt]] or [[kptrlatt]]) depending on the value of [[occopt]].
7272     For GS, this option might be used to generate Density-of-states (thanks to
7273     [[prtdos]]), or to produce STM charge density map (thanks to [[prtstm]]).
7274     For RF, this option is needed to compute the response to ddk perturbation.
7275     
7276       * -1 --> like -2, but the non-self-consistent calculation is followed by the determination of excited states within TDDFT. This is only possible for [[nkpt]] = 1, with [[kpt]] = 0 0 0. Note that the oscillator strength needs to be defined with respect to an origin of coordinate, thanks to the input variable [[boxcenter]]. The maximal number of Kohn-Sham excitations to be used to build the excited state TDDFT matrix can be defined by [[td_mexcit]], or indirectly by the maximum Kohn-Sham excitation energy [[td_maxene]].
7277     """,
7278     ),
7279     
7280     Variable(
7281         abivarname="isecur",
7282         varset="dev",
7283         vartype="integer",
7284         topics=['SCFAlgorithms_expert'],
7285         dimensions="scalar",
7286         defaultval=0,
7287         mnemonics="Integer for level of SECURity choice",
7288         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
7289         text="""
7290     In the presently used algorithms, there is a compromise between speed and
7291     robustness, that can be tuned by using [[isecur]].
7292     If [[isecur]] =0, an extrapolation of out-of-line data is allowed, and might
7293     save one non-SCF calculation every two line minimisation when some stability
7294     conditions are fulfilled (since there are 2 non-SCF calculations per line
7295     minimisation, 1 out of 4 is saved)
7296     Using [[isecur]] = 1 or higher integers will raise gradually the threshold to make extrapolation.
7297     Using [[isecur]] = -2 will allow to save 2 non-SCF calculations every three line
7298     minimisation, but this can make the algorithm unstable. Lower values of
7299     [[isecur]] allows one for more (tentative) savings. In any case, there must be one
7300     non-SCF computation per line minimisation.
7301     No meaning for RF calculations yet.
7302     """,
7303     ),
7304     
7305     Variable(
7306         abivarname="istatimg",
7307         varset="rlx",
7308         vartype="integer",
7309         topics=['PIMD_expert'],
7310         dimensions="scalar",
7311         defaultval=1,
7312         mnemonics="Integer governing the computation of STATic IMaGes",
7313         text="""
7314     This input variable is relevant when sets of images are activated (see [[imgmov]]).
7315     Not all images might be required to evolve from one time step to the other
7316     (see[[dynimage]]): these are static images.
7317     If [[istatimg]] = 0, the total energy of static images is not computed (but
7318     static images are used to make the dynamic images evolve).
7319     This can be useful to save CPU time.
7320     If [[istatimg]] = 1, the total energy of static images is computed.
7321     """,
7322     ),
7323     
7324     Variable(
7325         abivarname="istatr",
7326         varset="dev",
7327         vartype="integer",
7328         topics=['printing_prmisc'],
7329         dimensions="scalar",
7330         defaultval=0,
7331         mnemonics="Integer for STATus file rate",
7332         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]', '[[NO_MULTI]]'],
7333         commentdefault="Values lower than 10 may not work on some machines.",
7334         text="""
7335     Govern the rate of output of the status file. This status file is written when
7336     the number of the call to the status subroutine is equal to [[istatshft]]
7337     modulo [[istatr]], so that it is written once every [[istatr]] call.
7338     When [[istatr]] = 0, there is no writing of a status file (which is the default).
7339     """,
7340     ),
7341     
7342     Variable(
7343         abivarname="istatshft",
7344         varset="dev",
7345         vartype="integer",
7346         topics=['printing_prmisc'],
7347         dimensions="scalar",
7348         defaultval=1,
7349         mnemonics="Integer for STATus file SHiFT",
7350         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]', '[[NO_MULTI]]'],
7351         text="""
7352     Govern the rate of output of the status file. This status file is written when
7353     the number of the call to the status subroutine is equal to '[[istatshft]]'
7354     modulo ' **istatr** ', so that it is written once every ' **istatr** ' call.
7355     There is also a writing for each of the 5 first calls, and the 10th call.
7356     """,
7357     ),
7358     
7359     Variable(
7360         abivarname="istwfk",
7361         varset="dev",
7362         vartype="integer",
7363         topics=['k-points_useful', 'TuningSpeed_basic'],
7364         dimensions=['[[nkpt]]'],
7365         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=None, value=0),
7366         mnemonics="Integer for choice of STorage of WaveFunction at each k point",
7367         commentdefault="For RF calculations, the Default is not used: <b>istwfk</b> is forced to be 1 deep inside the code, for all k points. For spin-orbit calculations ([[nspinor]] = 2), <b>istwfk</b> is also forced to be 1, for all k points.",
7368         text="""
7369     Control the way the wavefunction for each k-point is stored inside ABINIT, in reciprocal space.
7370     For the GS calculations, in the "cg" array containing the wavefunction
7371     coefficients, there is for each k-point and each band, a segment
7372     cg(1:2,1:npw). The 'full' number of plane wave is determined by [[ecut]].
7373     
7374     However, if the k-point coordinates are build only from zeroes and halves (see
7375     list below), the use of time-reversal symmetry (that connects coefficients)
7376     has been implemented, in order to use real-to-complex FFTs (see [[fftalg]]),
7377     and to treat explicitly only half of the number of plane waves (this being used as 'npw').
7378     For the RF calculations, there is not only the "cg" array, but also the "cgq"
7379     and "cg1" arrays. For the time-reversal symmetry to decrease the number of
7380     plane waves of these arrays, the q vector MUST be (0 0 0). Then, for each k
7381     point, the same rule as for the RF can be applied.
7382     WARNING (991018): for the time being, the time-reversal symmetry cannot be
7383     used in the RF calculations.
7384     
7385       * 1 --> do NOT take advantage of the time-reversal symmetry
7386       * 2 --> use time-reversal symmetry for k=( 0 0 0 )
7387       * 3 --> use time-reversal symmetry for k=(1/2 0 0 )
7388       * 4 --> use time-reversal symmetry for k=( 0 0 1/2)
7389       * 5 --> use time-reversal symmetry for k=(1/2 0 1/2)
7390       * 6 --> use time-reversal symmetry for k=( 0 1/2 0 )
7391       * 7 --> use time-reversal symmetry for k=(1/2 1/2 0 )
7392       * 8 --> use time-reversal symmetry for k=( 0 1/2 1/2)
7393       * 9 --> use time-reversal symmetry for k=(1/2 1/2 1/2)
7394       * 0 --> (preprocessed) for each k point, choose automatically the appropriate time-reversal
7395         option when it is allowed, and chose [[istwfk]] = 1 for all the other k points.
7396     """,
7397     ),
7398     
7399     Variable(
7400         abivarname="ixc",
7401         varset="basic",
7402         vartype="integer",
7403         topics=['xc_basic', 'Hybrids_compulsory', 'TDDFT_useful'],
7404         dimensions="scalar",
7405         defaultval=1,
7406         mnemonics="Index of eXchange-Correlation functional",
7407         commentdefault="Default corresponds to Teter parametrization. However, if all the pseudopotentials have the same value of pspxc, the initial value of ixc will be that common value",
7408         text=r"""
7409     Controls the choice of exchange and correlation (xc). The list of XC
7410     functionals is given below. Positive values are for ABINIT native library of
7411     XC functionals, while negative values are for calling the much wider set of
7412     functionals from the ETSF LibXC library (by M. Marques), available at the [
7413     LibXC home page ](http://octopus-code.org/wiki/Libxc)
7414     Note that the choice made here should preferably agree with the choice made in
7415     generating the original pseudopotential, except for [[ixc]] = 0 (usually only
7416     used for debugging). A warning is issued if this is not the case.
7417     Unfortunately, pseudopotential (or PAW) generators for hybrid functionals and
7418     mGGA are currently under development, so that one usually uses GGA or LDA
7419     pseudopotentials instead. The error should be limited when GGA or LDA
7420     pseudopotentials with semi-core states are used. Still this is a non-
7421     controlled error.. Moreover, the choices [[ixc]] = 1, 2, 3 and 7 are fits to the
7422     same data, from Ceperley-Alder, and are rather similar, at least for spin-
7423     unpolarized systems.
7424     The choice between the non-spin-polarized and spin-polarized case is governed
7425     by the value of [[nsppol]] (see below).
7426     
7427     **Native ABINIT XC functionals**
7428     
7429     NOTE: in the implementation of the spin-dependence of these functionals, and
7430     in order to avoid divergences in their derivatives, the interpolating function
7431     between spin-unpolarized and fully-spin-polarized function has been slightly
7432     modified, by including a zeta rescaled by 1.d0-1.d-6. This should affect total
7433     energy at the level of 1.d-6Ha, and should have an even smaller effect on
7434     differences of energies, or derivatives.
7435     The value [[ixc]] = 10 is used internally: gives the difference between
7436     [[ixc]] = 7 and [[ixc]] = 9, for use with an accurate RPA correlation energy.
7437     
7438       * 0 --> NO xc.
7439     
7440       * 1 --> LDA or LSD, Teter Pade parametrization (4/93, published in [[cite:Goedecker1996]], which reproduces Perdew-Wang 92 [[cite:Perdew1992a]] (which reproduces Ceperley-Alder [[cite:Ceperley1980]]!).
7441       * 2 --> LDA, Perdew-Zunger-Ceperley-Alder (no spin-polarization) [[cite:Perdew1981]]
7442       * 3 --> LDA, old Teter rational polynomial parametrization (4/91) fit to Ceperley-Alder data (no spin-polarization) [[cite:Ceperley1980]]
7443       * 4 --> LDA, Wigner functional (no spin-polarization)
7444       * 5 --> LDA, Hedin-Lundqvist functional (no spin-polarization) [[cite:Hedin1971]]
7445       * 6 --> LDA, "X-alpha" functional (no spin-polarization)
7446       * 7 --> LDA or LSD, Perdew-Wang 92 functional [[cite:Perdew1992a]]
7447       * 8 --> LDA or LSD, x-only part of the Perdew-Wang 92 functional [[cite:Perdew1992a]]
7448       * 9 --> LDA or LSD, x- and RPA correlation part of the Perdew-Wang 92 functional [[cite:Perdew1992a]]
7449     
7450       * 11 --> GGA, Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof GGA functional [[cite:Perdew1996]]
7451       * 12 --> GGA, x-only part of Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof GGA functional [[cite:Perdew1996]]
7452       * 13 --> GGA potential of van Leeuwen-Baerends [[cite:VanLeeuwen1994]], while for energy, Perdew-Wang 92 functional [[cite:Perdew1992a]]
7453       * 14 --> GGA, revPBE of [[cite:Zhang1998]]
7454       * 15 --> GGA, RPBE of [[cite:Hammer1999]]
7455       * 16 --> GGA, HTCH93 of [[cite:Hamprecht1998]]
7456       * 17 --> GGA, HTCH120 of [[cite:Boese2000]] - The usual HCTH functional.
7457       * 18 --> (NOT AVAILABLE: used internally for GGA BLYP pseudopotentials from [[cite:Krack2005]], available from the [ CP2K repository ](https://github.com/cp2k/cp2k/tree/master/potentials/Goedecker/abinit/blyp) \- use the LibXC instead, with [[ixc]] = -106131.
7458       * 19 --> (NOT AVAILABLE: used internally for GGA BP86 pseudopotentials from [[cite:Krack2005]], available from the [ CP2K repository ](https://github.com/cp2k/cp2k/tree/master/potentials/Goedecker/abinit/bp) \- use the LibXC instead, with [[ixc]] = -106132.
7459     
7460       * 20 --> Fermi-Amaldi xc ( -1/N Hartree energy, where N is the number of electrons per cell; G=0 is not taken into account however),
7461                                 for TDDFT tests. No spin-pol. Does not work for RF.
7462       * 21 --> same as 20, except that the xc-kernel is the LDA ([[ixc]] = 1) one, for TDDFT tests.
7463       * 22 --> same as 20, except that the xc-kernel is the Burke-Petersilka-Gross hybrid, for TDDFT tests.
7464       * 23 --> GGA of [[cite:Wu2006]].
7465       * 24 --> GGA, C09x exchange of [[cite:Cooper2010]].
7466       * 26 --> GGA, HTCH147 of [[cite:Boese2000]].
7467       * 27 --> GGA, HTCH407 of [[cite:Boese2001]].
7468       * 28 --> (NOT AVAILABLE: used internally for GGA OLYP pseudopotentials from [[cite:Krack2005]], available from the [ CP2K repository ](https://github.com/cp2k/cp2k/tree/master/potentials/Goedecker/abinit/olyp) \- use the LibXC instead, with [[ixc]] = -110131.
7469     
7470       * 40 --> Hartree-Fock
7471       * 41 --> PBE0, [[cite:Perdew1996]].
7472       * 42 --> PBE0-1/3, [[cite:Guido2013]].
7473     
7474     **ETSF Lib XC functionals**
7475     
7476     Note that you must compile ABINIT with the LibXC plug-in in order to be able
7477     to access these functionals.
7478     The LibXC functionals are accessed by **negative values** of [[ixc]]. The
7479     LibXC contains functional forms for either exchange-only functionals,
7480     correlation-only functionals, or combined exchange and correlation
7481     functionals. Each of them is to be specified by a three-digit number. In case
7482     of a combined exchange and correlation functional, only one such three-digit
7483     number has to be specified as value of [[ixc]], with a minus sign (to indicate
7484     that it comes from the LibXC). In the case of separate exchange functional
7485     (let us represent its identifier by XXX) and correlation functional (let us
7486     represent its identified by CCC), a six-digit number will have to be specified
7487     for [[ixc]], by concatenation, be it XXXCCC or CCCXXX. As an example,
7488     [[ixc]] = -020 gives access to the Teter93 LDA, while [[ixc]] = -101130 gives
7489     access to the PBE GGA. In version 0.9 of LibXC (December 2008), there are 16
7490     three-dimensional (S)LDA functionals (1 for X, 14 for C, 1 for combined XC),
7491     and there are 41 three-dimensional GGA (23 for X, 8 for C, 10 for combined
7492     XC). Note that for a meta-GGA, the kinetic energy density is needed.
7493     This means having [[usekden]] = 1.
7494     
7495     (S)LDA functionals (do not forget to add a minus sign, as discussed above)
7496     
7497       * 001 --> XC_LDA_X  [[cite:Dirac1930]], [[cite:Bloch1929]]
7498       * 002 --> XC_LDA_C_WIGNER  Wigner parametrization [[cite:Wigner1938]]
7499       * 003 --> XC_LDA_C_RPA  Random Phase Approximation [[cite:GellMann1957]]
7500       * 004 --> XC_LDA_C_HL  Hedin & Lundqvist [[cite:Hedin1971]]
7501       * 005 --> XC_LDA_C_GL  Gunnarson & Lundqvist [[cite:Gunnarsson1976]]
7502       * 006 --> XC_LDA_C_XALPHA  Slaters Xalpha
7503       * 007 --> XC_LDA_C_VWN  [[cite:Vosko1980]]
7504       * 008 --> XC_LDA_C_VWN_RPA  [[cite:Vosko1980]]
7505       * 009 --> XC_LDA_C_PZ  Perdew & Zunger [[cite:Perdew1981]]
7506       * 010 --> XC_LDA_C_PZ_MOD  Perdew & Zunger (Modified) [[cite:Perdew1981]] Modified to improve the matching between the low and high rs part
7507       * 011 --> XC_LDA_C_OB_PZ  Ortiz & Ballone (PZ) [[cite:Ortiz1994]] [[cite:Ortiz1997]] [[cite:Perdew1981]]
7508       * 012 --> XC_LDA_C_PW  Perdew & Wang [[cite:Perdew1992a]]
7509       * 013 --> XC_LDA_C_PW_MOD  Perdew & Wang (Modified) [[cite:Perdew1992a]]; Added extra digits to some constants as in the PBE routine.
7510       * 014 --> XC_LDA_C_OB_PW  Ortiz & Ballone (PW) [[cite:Ortiz1994]] [[cite:Ortiz1997]] [[cite:Perdew1992a]]
7511       * 017 --> XC_LDA_C_vBH  von Barth & Hedin [[cite:Barth1972]]
7512       * 020 --> XC_LDA_XC_TETER93  Teter 93 parametrization [[cite:Goedecker1996]]
7513       * 022 --> XC_LDA_C_ML1  Modified LSD (version 1) of Proynov and Salahub [[cite:Proynov1994]]
7514       * 023 --> XC_LDA_C_ML2  Modified LSD (version 2) of Proynov and Salahub [[cite:Proynov1994]]
7515       * 024 --> XC_LDA_C_GOMBAS  Gombas parametrization [[cite:Gombas1967]]
7516       * 025 --> XC_LDA_C_PW_RPA  Perdew & Wang fit of the RPA [[cite:Perdew1992a]]
7517       * 027 --> XC_LDA_C_RC04  Ragot-Cortona [[cite:Ragot2004]]
7518       * 028 --> XC_LDA_C_VWN_1  Vosko, Wilk, & Nussair (1) [[cite:Vosko1980]]
7519       * 029 --> XC_LDA_C_VWN_2  Vosko, Wilk, & Nussair (2) [[cite:Vosko1980]]
7520       * 030 --> XC_LDA_C_VWN_3  Vosko, Wilk, & Nussair (3) [[cite:Vosko1980]]
7521       * 031 --> XC_LDA_C_VWN_4  Vosko, Wilk, & Nussair (4) [[cite:Vosko1980]]
7522     
7523     GGA functionals (do not forget to add a minus sign, as discussed above)
7524     
7525       * 84 --> XC_GGA_C_OP_XALPHA  one-parameter progressive functional (G96 version) [[cite:Tsuneda1999]]
7526       * 85 --> XC_GGA_C_OP_G96  one-parameter progressive functional (G96 version) [[cite:Tsuneda1999]]
7527       * 86 --> XC_GGA_C_OP_PBE  one-parameter progressive functional (PBE version) [[cite:Tsuneda1999]]
7528       * 87 --> XC_GGA_C_OP_B88  one-parameter progressive functional (B88 version) [[cite:Tsuneda1999]]
7529       * 88 --> XC_GGA_C_FT97  Filatov & Thiel correlation [[cite:Filatov1997a]]  [[cite:Filatov1997]]
7530     
7531     !!! warning
7532         this functional is not tested. Use at your own risks.
7533     
7534       * 89 --> XC_GGA_C_SPBE  PBE correlation to be used with the SSB exchange [[cite:Swart2009]]
7535       * 90 --> XC_GGA_X_SSB_SW  Swart, Sola and Bickelhaupt correction to PBE [[cite:Swart2009a]]
7536       * 91 --> XC_GGA_X_SSB  [[cite:Swart2009]]
7537     
7538     !!! warning
7539         This functional gives NaN on IBM (XG20130608).
7540     
7541       * 92 -->  XC_GGA_X_SSB_D  [[cite:Swart2009]]
7542     
7543     !!! warning
7544         This functional gives NaN on IBM (XG20130608).
7545     
7546       * 93 -->  XC_GGA_XC_HCTH_407P  HCTH/407+ [[cite:Boese2003]]
7547       * 94 -->  XC_GGA_XC_HCTH_P76  HCTH p=7/6 [[cite:Menconi2001]]
7548       * 95 -->  XC_GGA_XC_HCTH_P14  HCTH p=1/4 [[cite:Menconi2001]]
7549       * 96 -->  XC_GGA_XC_B97_GGA1  Becke 97 GGA-1 [[cite:Cohen2000]]
7550       * 97 -->  XC_GGA_XC_HCTH_A  HCTH-A [[cite:Hamprecht1998]]
7551       * 98 -->  XC_GGA_X_BPCCAC  BPCCAC (GRAC for the energy) [[cite:Bremond2012]]
7552       * 99 -->  XC_GGA_C_REVTCA  Tognetti, Cortona, Adamo (revised) [[cite:Tognetti2008]]
7553       * 100 -->  XC_GGA_C_TCA  Tognetti, Cortona, Adamo [[cite:Tognetti2008a]]
7554       * 101 -->  XC_GGA_X_PBE  Perdew, Burke & Ernzerhof exchange [[cite:Perdew1996]]  [[cite:Perdew1997]]
7555       * 102 -->  XC_GGA_X_PBE_R  Perdew, Burke & Ernzerhof exchange (revised) [[cite:Zhang1998]]
7556       * 103 -->  XC_GGA_X_B86  Becke 86 Xalfa,beta,gamma [[cite:Becke1986]]
7557       * 104 -->  XC_GGA_X_HERMAN  Herman Xalphabeta GGA [[cite:Herman1969]]  [[cite:Herman2009]]
7558       * 105 -->  XC_GGA_X_B86_MGC  Becke 86 Xalfa,beta,gamma (with mod. grad. correction) [[cite:Becke1986]]  [[cite:Becke1986a]]
7559       * 106 -->  XC_GGA_X_B88  Becke 88 [[cite:Becke1988]]
7560       * 107 -->  XC_GGA_X_G96  Gill 96 [[cite:Gill1996]]
7561       * 108 -->  XC_GGA_X_PW86  Perdew & Wang 86 [[cite:Perdew1986a]]
7562       * 109 -->  XC_GGA_X_PW91  Perdew & Wang 91 [JP Perdew, in Proceedings of the 21st Annual International Symposium on the Electronic Structure of Solids, ed. by P Ziesche and H Eschrig (Akademie Verlag, Berlin, 1991), p. 11. ]  [[cite:Perdew1992]]  [[cite:Perdew1993]]
7563       * 110 -->  XC_GGA_X_OPTX  Handy & Cohen OPTX 01 [[cite:Handy2001]]
7564       * 111 -->  XC_GGA_X_DK87_R1  dePristo & Kress 87 (version R1) [[cite:DePristo1987]]
7565       * 112 -->  XC_GGA_X_DK87_R2  dePristo & Kress 87 (version R2) [[cite:DePristo1987]]
7566       * 113 -->  XC_GGA_X_LG93  Lacks & Gordon 93 [[cite:Lacks1993]]
7567       * 114 -->  XC_GGA_X_FT97_A  Filatov & Thiel 97 (version A) [[cite:Filatov1997a]]
7568       * 115 -->  XC_GGA_X_FT97_B  Filatov & Thiel 97 (version B) [[cite:Filatov1997a]]
7569       * 116 -->  XC_GGA_X_PBE_SOL  Perdew, Burke & Ernzerhof exchange (solids) [[cite:Perdew2008]]
7570       * 117 -->  XC_GGA_X_RPBE  Hammer, Hansen & Norskov (PBE-like) [[cite:Hammer1999]]
7571       * 118 -->  XC_GGA_X_WC  Wu & Cohen [[cite:Wu2006]]
7572       * 119 -->  XC_GGA_X_mPW91  Modified form of PW91 by Adamo & Barone [[cite:Adamo1998]]
7573       * 120 -->  XC_GGA_X_AM05  Armiento & Mattsson 05 exchange [[cite:Armiento2005]]  [[cite:Mattsson2008]]
7574       * 121 -->  XC_GGA_X_PBEA  Madsen (PBE-like) [[cite:Madsen2007]]
7575       * 122 -->  XC_GGA_X_MPBE  Adamo & Barone modification to PBE [[cite:Adamo2002]]
7576       * 123 -->  XC_GGA_X_XPBE  xPBE reparametrization by Xu & Goddard [[cite:Xu2004]]
7577       * 125 -->  XC_GGA_X_BAYESIAN  Bayesian best fit for the enhancement factor [[cite:Mortensen2005]]
7578       * 126 -->  XC_GGA_X_PBE_JSJR  PBE JSJR reparametrization by Pedroza, Silva & Capelle [[cite:Pedroza2009]]
7579       * 130 -->  XC_GGA_C_PBE  Perdew, Burke & Ernzerhof correlation [[cite:Perdew1996]]  [[cite:Perdew1997]]
7580       * 131 -->  XC_GGA_C_LYP  Lee, Yang & Parr [[cite:Lee1988]]  [[cite:Miehlich1989]]
7581       * 132 -->  XC_GGA_C_P86  Perdew 86 [[cite:Perdew1986]]
7582       * 133 -->  XC_GGA_C_PBE_SOL  Perdew, Burke & Ernzerhof correlation SOL [[cite:Perdew2008]]
7583       * 134 -->  XC_GGA_C_PW91  Perdew & Wang 91 [[cite:Perdew1992]]
7584       * 135 -->  XC_GGA_C_AM05  Armiento & Mattsson 05 correlation [[cite:Armiento2005]]  [[cite:Mattsson2008]]
7585       * 136 -->  XC_GGA_C_XPBE  xPBE reparametrization by Xu & Goddard [[cite:Xu2004]]
7586       * 137 -->  XC_GGA_C_LM  Langreth and Mehl correlation [[cite:Langreth1981]]
7587       * 138 -->  XC_GGA_C_PBE_JRGX  JRGX reparametrization by Pedroza, Silva & Capelle [[cite:Pedroza2009]]
7588       * 139 -->  XC_GGA_X_OPTB88_VDW  Becke 88 reoptimized to be used with vdW functional of Dion et al [[cite:Klimes2011]]
7589       * 140 -->  XC_GGA_X_PBEK1_VDW  PBE reparametrization for vdW [[cite:Klimes2011]]
7590       * 141 -->  XC_GGA_X_OPTPBE_VDW  PBE reparametrization for vdW [[cite:Klimes2011]]
7591       * 142 -->  XC_GGA_X_RGE2  Regularized PBE [[cite:Ruzsinszky2009]]
7592       * 143 -->  XC_GGA_C_RGE2  Regularized PBE [[cite:Ruzsinszky2009]]
7593       * 144 -->  XC_GGA_X_RPW86  refitted Perdew & Wang 86 [[cite:Murray2009]]
7594       * 145 -->  XC_GGA_X_KT1  Keal and Tozer version 1 [[cite:Keal2003]]
7595       * 146 -->  XC_GGA_XC_KT2 Keal and Tozer version 2 [[cite:Keal2003]]
7596     
7597     !!! warning
7598         This functional gives NaN on IBM (XG20130608).
7599     
7600       * 147 -->  XC_GGA_C_WL  Wilson & Levy [[cite:Wilson1990]]
7601       * 148 -->  XC_GGA_C_WI  Wilson & Ivanov [[cite:Wilson1998]]
7602       * 149 -->  XC_GGA_X_MB88  Modified Becke 88 for proton transfer [[cite:Tognetti2009]]

7604       * 151 -->  XC_GGA_X_SOGGA11  Second-order generalized gradient approximation 2011 [[cite:Peverati2011]]
7605       * 152 -->  XC_GGA_C_SOGGA11  Second-order generalized gradient approximation 2011 [[cite:Peverati2011]]

7665     
7666     MetaGGA functionals (do not forget to add a minus sign, as discussed above).
7667     See [[cite:Sun2011]] for the formulas.

7669       * 202 -->  XC_MGGA_X_TPSS  Tao, Perdew, Staroverov & Scuseria [[cite:Tao2003]]  [[cite:Perdew2004]]
7670       * 203 -->  XC_MGGA_X_M06L  Zhao, Truhlar exchange [[cite:Zhao2006]]  [[cite:Zhao2007]]

7676         This Vxc-only mGGA can only be used with a LDA correlation, typically Perdew-Wang 92 [[cite:Perdew1992a]].

7686         This Vxc-only mGGA can only be used with a LDA correlation, typically Perdew-Wang 92 [[cite:Perdew1992a]].
7687     
7688       * 232 -->  XC_MGGA_C_VSXC  VSxc from Van Voorhis and Scuseria (correlation part) [[cite:Voorhis1998]]
7689     
7690     Hybrid functionals (do not forget to add a minus sign, as discussed above).
7691     
7692       * 402 -->  XC_HYB_GGA_XC_B3LYP  The (in)famous B3LYP [[cite:Stephens1994]]
7693       * 406 -->  XC_HYB_GGA_XC_PBEH  PBEH (PBE0) [[cite:Adamo1999]]  [[cite:Ernzerhof1999]]
7694       * 427 -->  XC_HYB_GGA_XC_HSE03  The 2003 version of the screened hybrid HSE
7695                                       (in this case one should use $\omega^{HF} = 0.15/\sqrt{2}$
7696                                       and $\omega^{PBE} = 0.15*(2.0)^{1/3}$ )
7697       * 428 -->  XC_HYB_GGA_XC_HSE06  The 2006 version of the screened hybrid HSE
7698                                       (in this case one should use $\omega^{HF} = \omega^{PBE} = 0.11$)
7699                                       (The following section is taken from the LibXC sources. In ABINIT, we stick to the LibXC choice.)
7700                                       Note that there is an enormous mess in the literature
7701                                       concerning the values of omega in HSE. This is due to an error in the original
7702                                       paper that stated that they had used $\omega=0.15$. This was in fact not true,
7703                                       and the real value used was $\omega^{HF} = 0.15 / \sqrt{2} \sim 0.1061$
7704                                       and $\omega^{PBE} = 0.15 * (2.0)^{1/3} \sim 0.1890$.
7705                                       In 2006 Krukau et al [[cite:Krukau2006]] tried
7706                                       to clarify the situation, and called HSE03 to the above choice of parameters,
7707                                       and called HSE06 to the functional where $\omega^{HF}=\omega^{PBE}$. By testing
7708                                       several properties for atoms they reached the conclusion that the best value
7709                                       for $\omega=0.11$. Of course, codes are just as messy as the papers. In Quantum Espresso
7710                                       HSE06 has the value $\omega=0.106.$ VASP, on the other hand, uses for HSE03 the
7711                                       same value $\omega^{HF} = \omega^{PBE} = 0.3 (A^{-1}) \sim 0.1587$,
7712                                       and for HSE06 $\omega^{HF} = \omega^{PBE} = 0.2 (A^{-1}) \sim 0.1058$.
7713                                       [[cite:Heyd2003]] [[cite:Heyd2006]] [[cite:Krukau2006]]
7714     
7715       * 456 -->  XC_HYB_GGA_XC_PBE0_13  PBE0-1/3 [[cite:Cortona2012]]
7716     """,
7717     ),
7718     
7719     Variable(
7720         abivarname="ixc_sigma",
7721         varset="gw",
7722         vartype="integer",
7723         topics=['xc_expert', 'Hybrids_expert'],
7724         dimensions="scalar",
7725         defaultval=1,
7726         mnemonics="Index of eXchange-Correlation functional used for self-energy calculations (SIGMA)",
7727         commentdefault="Default corresponds to Teter parametrization.",
7728         requires="mod([[gwcalctyp]],10)==5",
7729         text="""
7730     When [[gwcalctyp]] == 5, 15 or 25, [[ixc_sigma]] gives the identifier of the
7731     advanced functional (usually a hybrid) that is used perturbatively or self-
7732     consistently to obtain the improved electronic structure.
7733     
7734     The meaning of the values of [[ixc_sigma]] is the same as the ones of [[ixc]],
7735     so we refer to the latter for the list of possible values.
7736     
7737     This input variable is introduced because in such calculation with
7738     [[gwcalctyp]] == 5, 15 or 25, there is an underlying primary exchange-
7739     correlation functional, that was used to obtain the starting wavefunctions and
7740     eigenenergies, whose identified is [[ixc]]. The definition of both [[ixc]] and
7741     [[ixc_sigma]] allows one to bypass possible sources of confusion.
7742     
7743     Note however that in the case where [[gwcalctyp]] == 5, 15 or 25, the values of
7744     the input variables [[auxc_ixc]], [[hyb_mixing]], [[hyb_mixing_sr]],
7745     [[hyb_range_fock]] and [[hyb_range_dft]] refers to the advanced functional,
7746     and not the primary one. Also, [[icutcoul]] and [[rcut]] have precedence over
7747     [[hyb_mixing]], [[hyb_mixing_sr]], [[hyb_range_fock]] and [[hyb_range_dft]] to
7748     define the parameters of the hybrid functional.
7749     """,
7750     ),
7751     
7752     Variable(
7753         abivarname="ixcpositron",
7754         varset="gstate",
7755         vartype="integer",
7756         topics=['positron_basic'],
7757         dimensions="scalar",
7758         defaultval=1,
7759         mnemonics="Integer for the eXchange-Correlation applied to the electron-POSITRON interaction",
7760         commentdefault="(Teter parameterization). However, if all the pseudopotentials have the same value of pspxc, the initial value of ixc will be that common value",
7761         requires="[[positron]]/=0",
7762         text="""
7763     Relevant only when [[positron]]/=0.
7764     Define the type of electron-positron correlation that is used in case of a
7765     electron-positron two-component DFT calculation.
7766     Define also the analytical formula of the enhancement factor used to compute
7767     the electron-positron annhilation rate:
7768     
7769     Electron-positron correlation functional:
7770     
7771       * ixcpositron=1: LDA zero positron density limit parametrized by
7772     Arponen & Pajanne and provided by Boronski & Nieminen [[cite:Arponen1979a]],[[cite:Boronski1986]]
7773       * ixcpositron=11: LDA zero positron density limit parametrized by
7774     Arponen & Pajanne and fitted by Sterne & Kaiser [[cite:Arponen1979a]],[[cite:Sterne1991]]
7775       * ixcpositron=2: LDA electron-positron correlation provided by
7776     Puska, Seitsonen, and Nieminen [[cite:Arponen1979a]],[[cite:Puska1995]]
7777       * ixcpositron=3: GGA zero positron density limit parametrized by
7778     Arponen & Pajanne and provided by Boronski & Nieminen [[cite:Arponen1979a]],[[cite:Boronski1986]],[[cite:Barbiellini1995]]
7779       * ixcpositron=31: GGA zero positron density limit parametrized
7780     by Arponen & Pajanne and fitted by Sterne & Kaiser [[cite:Arponen1979a]],[[cite:Sterne1991]],[[cite:Barbiellini1995]]
7781     
7782     Annihilation rate enhancement factor:
7783     
7784       * ixcpositron=1: Boronski and Nieminen full modelisation and RPA limit [[cite:Arponen1979a]]
7785       * ixcpositron=11: Sterne and Kaiser [[cite:Boronski1986]]
7786       * ixcpositron=2: Puska, Seitsonen and Nieminen [[cite:Sterne1991]]
7787       * ixcpositron=3: Boronski and Nieminen full modelisation and RPA limit [[cite:Arponen1979a]], with GGA corrections
7788       * ixcpositron=31: Sterne and Kaiser [[cite:Boronski1986]], with GGA corrections
7789     """,
7790     ),
7791     
7792     Variable(
7793         abivarname="ixcrot",
7794         varset="dfpt",
7795         vartype="integer",
7796         topics=['DFPT_expert', 'xc_expert'],
7797         dimensions="scalar",
7798         defaultval=3,
7799         mnemonics="Index of the XC ROTation method used to calculate first-order exchange-correlation potential in non-collinear DFPT calculations",
7800         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
7801         text="""
7802     Method of calculation of the 1st order XC potential in non-collinear DFPT
7803     calculations. The possible values 1,2 and 3 correspond to the following
7804     methods
7805     
7806       * If ixcrot=1, the spinor rotation matrix U at each fft point is not calculated explicitly. Instead the needed expressions involving U are derived based on the general properties of the U matrix.
7807       * If ixcrot=2, U is computed explicitly
7808       * If ixcrot=3, the brute force evaluation of the 1st order XC potential as a functional derivative is used. Rotation matrices are not computed.
7809     
7810     In theory, all methods give identical results. However, due to different
7811     implementation approaches, the round-off errors can lead to slight differences
7812     intermediate and final results obtained using methods 1,2 and 3. The choice of
7813     the method can also affect the convergence.
7814     
7815     !!! note
7816         For non-zero perturbation wavevector, only ixcrot=3 implementation is currently available.
7817     """,
7818     ),
7819     
7820     Variable(
7821         abivarname="jdtset",
7822         varset="basic",
7823         vartype="integer",
7824         topics=['multidtset_basic'],
7825         dimensions=['[[ndtset]]'],
7826         defaultval=Range({'start': 1, 'stop': '[[ndtset]]'}),
7827         mnemonics="index -J- for DaTaSETs",
7828         characteristics=['[[NO_MULTI]]'],
7829         text="""
7830     Gives the dataset index of each of the datasets. This index will be used:
7831     
7832       * to determine which input variables are specific to each dataset, since the variable names for this dataset will be made from the bare variable name concatenated with this index, and only if such a composite variable name does not exist, the code will consider the bare variable name, or even, the Default;
7833       * to characterize output variable names, if their content differs from dataset to dataset;
7834       * to characterize output files ( root names appended with _DSx where 'x' is the dataset index ).
7835     
7836     The allowed index values are between 1 and 9999.
7837     An input variable name appended with 0 is not allowed.
7838     When [[ndtset]] == 0, this array is not used, and moreover, no input variable
7839     name appended with a digit is allowed. This array might be initialized thanks
7840     to the use of the input variable [[udtset]]. In this case, [[jdtset]] cannot be used.
7841     """,
7842     ),
7843     
7844     Variable(
7845         abivarname="jellslab",
7846         varset="gstate",
7847         vartype="integer",
7848         topics=['Artificial_expert'],
7849         dimensions="scalar",
7850         defaultval=0,
7851         mnemonics="include a JELLium SLAB in the cell",
7852         text="""
7853     If set to 1, a slab of uniform positive background charge density, that is, a
7854     jellium slab, is included in the calculation cell. A portion of the unit cell
7855     is filled with such positive charge density distribution which is equal to a
7856     bulk-mean value $n_{bulk}$ between two edges and zero in the vacuum region if present.
7857     For the sake of convenience the unit cell is supposed to have the third
7858     crystal primitive lattice vector orthogonal to the other ones so that the
7859     portion of the cell filled by the jellium slab can be defined through its edges along z.
7860     The bulk-mean positive charge density is fixed by the input variable
7861     [[slabwsrad]], while the position of the slab edges along z is defined through
7862     the input variables [[slabzbeg]] and [[slabzend]].
7863     """,
7864     ),
7865     
7866     Variable(
7867         abivarname="jfielddir",
7868         varset="ffield",
7869         vartype="integer",
7870         topics=['Berry_basic'],
7871         dimensions=[3],
7872         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=3, value=0),
7873         mnemonics="electric/displacement FIELD DIRection",
7874         requires="[[berryopt]] = 17",
7875         text="""
7876     When specifying mixed electric field boundary conditions ( [[berryopt]] = 17),
7877     [[jfielddir]] controls whether reduced electric field ([[jfielddir]] = 1) or reduced
7878     electric displacement field ([[jfielddir]] = 2) is chosen to be fixed, in each
7879     of the three lattice directions (i.e., in the reduced, not the Cartesian,
7880     frame). For example, [[jfielddir]] = (1 1 2) tells the code to use fixed $\\bar{e}_1$
7881     and $\\bar{e}_2$ along the first two lattice directions and fixed $d_3$ along the third.
7882     For the case of mixed electric field boundary conditions, [[red_efieldbar]]
7883     and [[red_dfield]] are used to control $\\bar{e}$ and $d$, respectively. For example,
7884     for electric boundary conditions corresponding to a material in a parallel-
7885     plate capacitor, if you want to control $d_3=d_0$, while fixing $\\bar{e}_1=\\bar{e}_1=0$,
7886     then the input files should have [[berryopt]] = 17, [[jfielddir]] = (1 1 2),
7887     [[red_efieldbar]] = (0.0 0.0 a), and [[red_dfield]] = ($b\ c\ d_0$). Here a, b, and c
7888     are the starting values. They can be chosen in this way: do a single run for
7889     fixed d calculation ([[red_dfield]] = 0,0,$d_0$), from the final results you will
7890     have $\\bar{e}_3$, which is a good guess for a. Then do another single run for fixed
7891     ebar calculation ([[red_efieldbar]] = (0 0 0)), from the final results you will
7892     have $d_1$,$d_2$, these are good guesses for b, c.
7893     """,
7894     ),
7895     
7896     Variable(
7897         abivarname="jpawu",
7898         varset="paw",
7899         vartype="real",
7900         topics=['DFT+U_compulsory'],
7901         dimensions=['[[ntypat]]'],
7902         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=None, value=0),
7903         mnemonics="value of J for PAW+U",
7904         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
7905         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1 and [[usepawu]] == 1",
7906         text="""
7907     Gives the value of the screened exchange interaction between correlated
7908     electrons corresponding to [[lpawu]] for each species.
7909     In the case where [[lpawu]] =-1, the value is not used.
7910     """,
7911     ),
7912     
7913     Variable(
7914         abivarname="kberry",
7915         varset="ffield",
7916         vartype="integer",
7917         topics=['Berry_basic'],
7918         dimensions=[3, '[[nberry]]'],
7919         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=None, value=0),
7920         mnemonics="K wavevectors for BERRY phase computation",
7921         requires="[[berryopt]] = 1, 2, or 3",
7922         text="""
7923     Used for values of [[berryopt]] = 1, 2, or 3.
7924     
7925     This array defines, for each Berry phase calculation (the number of such
7926     calculations is defined by [[nberry]]), the difference of wavevector between k
7927     points for which the overlap matrix must be computed. The polarisation vector
7928     will be projected on the direction of that wavevector, and the result of the
7929     computation will be the magnitude of this projection. Doing more than one
7930     wavevector, with different independent direction, allows one to find the full
7931     polarisation vector. However, note that converged results need oriented grids,
7932     denser along the difference wavevector than usual Monkhorst-Pack grids.
7933     
7934     The difference of wavevector is computed in the coordinate system defined by
7935     the k-points grid (see [[ngkpt]] and [[kptrlatt]]), so that the values of
7936     [[kberry]] are integers. Of course, such a k point grid must exist, and all
7937     the corresponding wavefunctions must be available, so that the computation is
7938     allowed only when [[kptopt]] is equal to 3. In order to save computing time,
7939     it is suggested to make a preliminary calculation of the wavefunctions on the
7940     irreducible part of the grid, with [[kptopt]] equal to 1, and then use these
7941     converged wavefunctions in the entire Brillouin zone, by reading them to
7942     initialize the [[kptopt]] = 3 computation.
7943     """,
7944     ),
7945     
7946     Variable(
7947         abivarname="kpt",
7948         varset="basic",
7949         vartype="real",
7950         topics=['k-points_useful'],
7951         dimensions=[3, '[[nkpt]]'],
7952         defaultval=[0, 0, 0],
7953         mnemonics="K - PoinTs",
7954         commentdefault="Adequate for one molecule in a supercell",
7955         text="""
7956     Contains the k points in terms of reciprocal space primitive translations (NOT
7957     in cartesian coordinates!).
7958     Needed ONLY if [[kptopt]] = 0, otherwise deduced from other input variables.
7959     
7960     It contains dimensionless numbers in terms of which the cartesian coordinates
7961     would be:
7962     k_cartesian = k1*G1+k2*G2+k3*G3
7963     where  (k1,k2,k3)  represent the dimensionless "reduced coordinates" and  G1,
7964     G2, G3  are the cartesian coordinates of the primitive translation vectors.
7965     G1,G2,G3 are related to the choice of direct space primitive translation
7966     vectors made in [[rprim]]. Note that an overall norm for the k points is
7967     supplied by [[kptnrm]]. This allows one to avoid supplying many digits for the
7968     k points to represent such points as (1,1,1)/3.
7969     Note: one of the algorithms used to set up the sphere of G vectors for the
7970     basis needs components of k-points in the range [-1,1], so the remapping is
7971     easily done by adding or subtracting 1 from each component until it is in the
7972     range [-1,1]. That is, given the k point normalization [[kptnrm]] described
7973     below, each component must lie in [ -[[kptnrm]], [[kptnrm]] ].
7974     Note: a global shift can be provided by [[qptn]]
7975     Not read if [[kptopt]]/=0.
7976     """,
7977     ),
7978     
7979     Variable(
7980         abivarname="kptbounds",
7981         varset="gstate",
7982         vartype="real",
7983         topics=['k-points_useful', 'ElecBandStructure_basic'],
7984         dimensions=[3, 'abs([[kptopt]])+1)'],
7985         mnemonics="K PoinT BOUNDarieS",
7986         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
7987         text="""
7988     It is used to generate the circuit to be followed by the band structure, when
7989     [[kptopt]] is negative (it is not read if [[kptopt]] is zero or positive).
7990     
7991     There are abs([[kptopt]]) segments to be defined, each of which starting from
7992     the end point of the preceeding one. Thus, the number of points to be input is
7993     abs([[kptopt]])+1. They form a circuit starting at
7994     [[kptbounds]](1:3,1)/[[kptnrm]] and ending at
7995     [[kptbounds]](1:3,abs([[kptopt]])+1)/[[kptnrm]]. The number of divisions of
7996     each segment can be defined either using the array [[ndivk]] or the variable
7997     [[ndivsm]] that just defines the number of divisions for the smallest segment
7998     
7999     As for [[kpt]], [[kptbounds]] is specified using the primitive vectors in
8000     reciprocal space. If your Bravais lattice is simple, then it should be quite
8001     easy to find the coordinates of the end points. On the other hand, for
8002     centered, body-centered, face-centered, hexagonal, and rhombohedral Bravais
8003     lattice, the conversion might be more difficult. See the description of
8004     [[kpt]] for an explanation of how to convert data from the "conventional"
8005     cartesian coordinates to the primitive vectors in the reciprocal space. In
8006     order to help a bit, we list below a series of typical values, for the FCC,
8007     BCC, hexagonal and rhombohedral Bravais lattices. Note: all the data below
8008     are given in dimensionless units; they have to be rescaled by the actual
8009     lengths defined by the [[acell]] values. However, [[kptbounds]] values can be
8010     used as such, if the values of [[rprim]] given below are adopted.
8011     
8012     A. **FCC lattice**
8013     
8014     Suppose the primitive vectors in real space are given by
8015     
8016           rprim   0 1 1    1 0 1    1 1 0
8017     or
8018     
8019           rprim   0 1/2 1/2    1/2 0 1/2    1/2 1/2 0
8020     
8021     (these two possibilities only differ by a scaling factor, irrelevant for the
8022     definition of the k points in the primitive vectors in reciprocal space).
8023     Then, the reciprocal primitive vectors (in conventional cartesian coordinates) are
8024     
8025           (-1/2 1/2 1/2), (1/2 -1/2 1/2), (1/2 1/2 -1/2)
8026     
8027     or
8028     
8029           (-1 1 1), (1 -1 1), (1 1 -1)
8030     
8031     and, in both cases, the coordinates of several special points with respect to
8032     primitive vectors in reciprocal space are
8033     
8034           X (0   1/2 1/2)   (conventional cartesian coordinate 1/2 0 0)
8035           X'(1/2 1/2 1  )   (conventional cartesian coordinate 1/2 1/2 0)  (an other instance of X, in another Brillouin zone)
8036           L (1/2 1/2 1/2)   (conventional cartesian coordinate  1/4 1/4 1/4)
8037           L'(1/2 0   0  )   (conventional cartesian coordinate -1/4 1/4 1/4) (an other instance of L, on another face of the BZ)
8038           W (1/4 1/2 3/4)   (conventional cartesian coordinate 1/2 1/4 0)
8039           U (1/4 5/8 5/8)   (conventional cartesian coordinate 1/2 1/8 1/8)
8040           K (3/8 3/8 3/4)   (conventional cartesian coordinate 3/8 3/8 0)
8041     
8042     Note that K is actually equivalent to U, by spatial and translational
8043     symmetry. So, if you want to specify a typical circuit, the following might do
8044     the work: L-Gamma-X-W-K,U-L-W-X-K,U-Gamma with
8045     
8046           kptbounds  1/2 0 0  0 0 0  0 1/2 1/2  1/4 1/2 3/4  3/8 3/8 3/4  1/2 1/2 1/2  1/4 1/2 3/4  1/2 1/2 1  3/8 3/8 3/4  0 0 0
8047     
8048     The lengths of segments (this information is useful to draw the band
8049     structure, with the correct relative scale between special points) can be
8050     found using the conventional cartesian coordinates:\n
8051     $l$(L-Gamma)=$\sqrt{3}/4=$0.433... \n
8052     $l$(Gamma-X)=$1/2$=0.5 \n
8053     $l$(X-W)=$1/4$=0.25 \n
8054     $l$(W-K)=$\sqrt{2}/8$=0.177... \n
8055     $l$(K-L)=$\sqrt{6}/8$=0.306... \n
8056     $l$(L-W)=$\sqrt{2}/4$=0.354... \n
8057     $l$(W-X)=$1/4$=0.25 \n
8058     $l$(X-K)=$\sqrt{2}/8$=0.177... \n
8059     $l$(K-Gamma)=$3\sqrt{2}/8$=0.530... \n
8060     
8061     B. **BCC lattice**
8062     
8063     Suppose the primitive vectors in real space are given by
8064     
8065           rprim  -1 1 1    1 -1 1    1 1 -1
8066     
8067     (as for the FCC lattice, there is a scale invariance). Then, the reciprocal
8068     primitive vectors (in conventional cartesian coordinates) are (0 1/2 1/2),
8069     (1/2 0 1/2), and (1/2 1/2 0) and the coordinates of several special points
8070     with respect to primitive vectors in reciprocal space are
8071     
8072           H (-1/2 1/2 1/2)   (conventional cartesian coordinate 1/2 0 0)
8073           N ( 0   0   1/2)   (conventional cartesian coordinate 1/4 1/4 0)
8074           P ( 1/4 1/4 1/4)   (conventional cartesian coordinate 1/4 1/4 1/4)
8075     
8076     So, if you want to specify a typical circuit, the following might do the work: Gamma-H-N-Gamma-P-N-P-H
8077     
8078           kptbounds  0 0 0  -1/2 1/2 1/2  0 0 1/2  0 0 0   1/4 1/4 1/4  0 0 1/2  1/4 1/4 1/4  -1/2 1/2 1/2
8079     
8080     The lengths of segments (this information is useful to draw the band
8081     structure, with the correct relative scale between special points) can be
8082     found using the conventional cartesian coordinates:\n
8083     $l$(Gamma-H)=$1/2$=0.5 \n
8084     $l$(H-N)=$\sqrt{2}/4$=0.354... \n
8085     $l$(N-Gamma)=$\sqrt{2}/4$=0.354... \n
8086     $l$(Gamma-P)=$\sqrt{3}/4$=0.433... \n
8087     $l$(P-N)=$1/4$=0.25 \n
8088     $l$(N-P)=$1/4$=0.25 \n
8089     $l$(P-H)=$\sqrt{3}/4$=0.433... \n
8090     
8091     C. **Hexagonal lattices**
8092     
8093     Suppose the primitive vectors in real space are given by
8094     
8095           rprim  1 0 0    -1/2 sqrt(0.75) 0    0 0 1
8096     
8097     The coordinates of several special points with respect to primitive vectors in
8098     reciprocal space are
8099     
8100           M (1/2 0 0) or (0 1/2 0) or (-1/2 1/2 0)
8101           L (1/2 0 1/2) or (0 1/2 1/2) or (-1/2 1/2 1/2)
8102           K (1/3 1/3 0) or (2/3 -1/3 0) or (-1/3 2/3 0)
8103           H (1/3 1/3 1/2) or (2/3 -1/3 1/2) or (-1/3 2/3 1/2)
8104           A (0 0 1/2)
8105     
8106     So, if you want to specify a typical circuit, the following
8107     might do the work: K-Gamma-M-K-H-A-L-H-L-M-Gamma-A
8108     
8109           kptbounds  1/3 1/3 0  0 0 0  1/2 0 0  1/3 1/3 0  1/3 1/3 1/2  0 0 1/2  1/2 0 1/2  1/3 1/3 1/2  1/2 0 1/2  1/2 0 0  0 0 0  0 0 1/2
8110     
8111     In order to find the lengths of segments (this information is useful to draw
8112     the band structure, with the correct relative scale between special points)
8113     one needs to know the a and c lattice parameters. Also, in what follows, we
8114     omit the 2$\pi$ factor sometimes present in the definition of the reciprocal
8115     space vectors. The reciprocal vectors are $(1/a\: 1/(\sqrt{3}a)\: 0)$, $(0\: 2/(\sqrt{3}a)\: 0)$,
8116      $(0\: 0\: 1/c)$. The lengths of the above-mentioned segments can
8117     be computed as:\n
8118     $l$(K-Gamma)=$2/(3a)$=0.666.../a \n
8119     $l$(Gamma-M)=$1/(\sqrt{3}a)$=0.577.../a \n
8120     $l$(M-K)=$1/(3a)$=0.333.../a \n
8121     $l$(K-H)=$1/(2c)$=0.5.../c \n
8122     $l$(H-A)=$2/(3a)$=0.666.../a \n
8123     $l$(A-L)=$1/(\sqrt{3}a)$=0.577.../a \n
8124     $l$(L-H)=$1/(3a)$=0.333.../a \n
8125     $l$(H-L)=$1/(3a)$=0.333.../a \n
8126     $l$(L-M)=$1/(2c)$=0.5.../c \n
8127     $l$(M-Gamma)=$1/(\sqrt{3}a)$=0.577.../a \n
8128     $l$(Gamma-A)=$1/(2c)$=0.5.../c \n
8129     
8130     D. **Rhombohedral lattices**
8131     
8132     Rhombohedral lattices are characterised by two parameters, the length of the
8133     primitive vectors, that we will denote a0, and the angle they form, $\gamma$.
8134     These can be directly input of ABINIT, as [[acell]] and [[angdeg]]
8135     
8136     This will generate the primitive vectors in real space, with
8137     
8138           acell a0 a0 a0    and      rprim  a 0 c    -a/2 a*sqrt(0.75) c    -a/2 -a*sqrt(0.75) c
8139     
8140     with,
8141     
8142      * $a^2+c^2=1$,
8143      * $a^2=2/3(1-\cos(\gamma))$,
8144      * $c^2=1/3(1+2\cos(\gamma))$,
8145      * $(a/c)^2=2(1-\cos(\gamma))/(1+2\cos(\gamma))$, and also
8146      * $\cos(\gamma)=(1-(a/c)^2/2)/(1+(a/c)^2)$.
8147     
8148     Alternatively, these values of [[rprim]]
8149     might directly be the input of ABINIT (then, the balance of the scaling factor
8150     might be adjusted between [[acell]] and [[rprim]]).
8151     
8152     Unlike for the simple cubic, FCC, BCC, hexagonal (and some other) Bravais
8153     lattice, the topology of the Brillouin zone will depend on the $\gamma$ (or $a/c$)
8154     value. We give below information concerning the case when $\cos(\gamma)$ is
8155     positive, that is, $(a/c)^2$ lower than 2.
8156     
8157     The coordinates of several special points with respect to primitive vectors in
8158     reciprocal space will not depend on the $a/c$ ratio, but some others will depend
8159     on it. So, some care has to be exercised. Notations for the Brillouin Zone
8160     special points are the same as in [[cite:Gonze1990]].
8161     
8162           L (1/2 0 0) or (0 1/2 0) or (0 0 1/2) (or with negative signs)
8163           T (1/2 1/2 1/2)
8164           X (1/2 1/2 0) or (1/2 0 1/2) or (0 1/2 1/2) (or with separate negative signs)
8165           W (5/6 - (a/c)^2/6, 1/2, 1/6 + (a/c)^2/6 ) = (1 0 -1)*(1-(a/c)^2/2)/3 + (1 1 1)/2
8166           U ( (1+(a/c)^2)/6, (8-(a/c)^2)/12, (8-(a/c)^2)/12 ) = (-1 1/2 1/2)*(1-(a/c)^2/2)/3 + (1 1 1)/2
8167           K (1 0 -1)*(1+(a/c)^2/4)/3
8168     
8169     So, if you want to specify a typical circuit, the following might do the work
8170     (the representative points on lines of symmetry are indicated - there are
8171     sometimes more than one way to go from one point to another): X-V-K-Sigma-
8172     Gamma-Lambda-T-Q-W-Y-L-sigma-Gamma-sigma-X. The suggestion is to sample this
8173     path with the following coordinates for the special points X, Gamma, T, L, Gamma, X:
8174     
8175           kptbounds  1/2 0 -1/2   0 0 0    1/2 1/2 1/2  1 1/2 0   1 0 0  1 1/2 1/2
8176     
8177     In order to find the lengths of segments (this information is useful to draw
8178     the band structure, with the correct relative scale between special points)
8179     one needs to know the a and c lattice parameters. Also, in what follows, we
8180     omit the $2\pi$ factor sometimes present in the definition of the reciprocal
8181     space vectors. The reciprocal vectors are $( 2/(3a)\: 0\: 1/(3c) )$, $( -1/(3a)\:
8182     1/(\sqrt{3}a)\: 1/(3c) )$, $( -1/(3a)\: -1/(\sqrt{3}a)\: 1/(3c) )$. The lengths of the
8183     above-mentioned segments can be computed as:\n
8184     $l$(X-Gamma)=$2/(\sqrt{3}a)$=1.155.../a \n
8185     $l$(K-Gamma)=$4(1+(a/c)^2/4)/(3\sqrt{3}a)$ \n
8186     $l$(Gamma-T)=$1/(2c)$ \n
8187     $l$(T-L)=$2/(\sqrt{3}a)$=1.155.../a \n
8188     $l$(T-W)=$4(1-(a/c)^2/2)/(3\sqrt{3}a)$ \n
8189     $l$(L-Gamma)=$\sqrt{4/(a^2)+1/(c^2)}/3$ \n
8190     $l$(Gamma-X)=$2\sqrt{1/(a^2)+1/(c^2)}/3$ \n
8191     """,
8192     ),
8193     
8194     Variable(
8195         abivarname="kptgw",
8196         varset="gw",
8197         vartype="real",
8198         topics=['SelfEnergy_basic'],
8199         dimensions=[3, '[[nkptgw]]'],
8200         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=None, value=0.0),
8201         mnemonics="K-PoinTs for GW calculations",
8202         requires="[[optdriver]] in [4, 7]",
8203         text="""
8204     For each k-point with number igwpt in the range (1:[[nkptgw]]),
8205     [[kptgw]](1,igwpt) is the reduced coordinate of the k-point where the self-energy
8206     corrections are required while [[bdgw]] (1:2,igwpt) specifies the range of
8207     bands to be considered.
8208     
8209     At present, not all k-points are possible. Only those corresponding to the
8210     k-point grid defined with the same repetition parameters ( [[kptrlatt]], or
8211     [[ngkpt]] ) than the GS one, but **without** any shift, are allowed.
8212     """,
8213     ),
8214     
8215     Variable(
8216         abivarname="kptnrm",
8217         varset="basic",
8218         vartype="real",
8219         topics=['k-points_useful'],
8220         dimensions="scalar",
8221         defaultval=1,
8222         mnemonics="K - PoinTs NoRMalization",
8223         text="""
8224     Establishes a normalizing denominator for each k point. Needed only if
8225     [[kptopt]]<=0, otherwise deduced from other input variables.
8226     The k point coordinates as fractions of reciprocal lattice translations are
8227     therefore [[kpt]](mu,ikpt)/[[kptnrm]]. [[kptnrm]] defaults to 1 and can be
8228     ignored by the user. It is introduced to avoid the need for many digits in
8229     representing numbers such as 1/3. It cannot be smaller than 1.0d0
8230     """,
8231     ),
8232     
8233     Variable(
8234         abivarname="kptns",
8235         varset="internal",
8236         vartype="real",
8237         topics=['k-points_internal'],
8238         dimensions=[3, '[[nkpt]]'],
8239         mnemonics="K-PoinTs re-Normalized and Shifted",
8240         characteristics=['[[INTERNAL_ONLY]]'],
8241         text="""
8242     If [[nqpt]] = 0, or if one is doing a reponse calculation, this internal
8243     variable is derived from [[kpt]] and [[kptnrm]]: [[kptns]](1:3,:)=
8244     [[kpt]](1:3,:)/ [[kptnrm]], so that it is [[kpt]] renormalized by [[kptnrm]].
8245     
8246     If [[nqpt]] = 1 and one is not doing a ground-state calculation, this internal
8247     variable is derived from [[kpt]], [[kptnrm]] and [[qptn]] : [[kptns]](1:3,:)=
8248     [[kpt]](1:3,:)/ [[kptnrm]]+ [[qptn]](1:3), so that it is [[kpt]] renormalized
8249     by [[kptnrm]], then shifted by [[qptn]](1:3).
8250     """,
8251     ),
8252     
8253     Variable(
8254         abivarname="kptns_hf",
8255         varset="internal",
8256         vartype="real",
8257         topics=['k-points_internal'],
8258         dimensions=[3, '[[nkpthf]]'],
8259         mnemonics="K-PoinTs re-Normalized and Shifted, for the Hartree-Fock operator",
8260         characteristics=['[[INTERNAL_ONLY]]'],
8261         text="""
8262     [[kptns_hf]] is the subset of the full Brillouin Zone k point grid for
8263     wavefunctions, used to build the Fock operator, see [[fockdownsampling]].
8264     """,
8265     ),
8266     
8267     Variable(
8268         abivarname="kptopt",
8269         varset="basic",
8270         vartype="integer",
8271         topics=['k-points_basic', 'ElecBandStructure_basic'],
8272         dimensions="scalar",
8273         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[nspden]] == 4': 4, 'defaultval': 1}),
8274         mnemonics="KPoinTs OPTion",
8275         text="""
8276     Controls the set up of the k-points list. The aim will be to initialize, by
8277     straight reading or by a preprocessing approach based on other input
8278     variables, the following input variables, giving the k points, their number,
8279     and their weight: [[kpt]], [[kptnrm]], [[nkpt]], and, for [[iscf]]/=-2, [[wtk]].
8280     
8281     Often, the k points will form a lattice in reciprocal space. In this case, one
8282     will also aim at initializing input variables that give the reciprocal of this
8283     k-point lattice, as well as its shift with respect to the origin: [[ngkpt]] or
8284     [[kptrlatt]], as well as on [[nshiftk]] and [[shiftk]].
8285     
8286     A global additional shift can be provided by [[qptn]]
8287     
8288       * 0 --> read directly [[nkpt]], [[kpt]], [[kptnrm]] and [[wtk]].
8289       * 1 --> rely on [[ngkpt]] or [[kptrlatt]], as well as on [[nshiftk]] and [[shiftk]] to set up the k points.
8290         Take fully into account the symmetry to generate the k points in the Irreducible Brillouin Zone only,
8291         with the appropriate weights. (This is the usual mode for GS calculations)
8292     
8293       * 2 --> rely on [[ngkpt]] or [[kptrlatt]], as well as on [[nshiftk]] and [[shiftk]] to set up the k points.
8294         Take into account only the time-reversal symmetry: k points will be generated in half the Brillouin zone,
8295         with the appropriate weights.
8296         (This is to be used when preparing or executing a RF calculation at q=(0 0 0))
8297     
8298       * 3 --> rely on [[ngkpt]] or [[kptrlatt]], as well as on [[nshiftk]] and [[shiftk]] to set up the k points.
8299         Do not take into account any symmetry: k points will be generated in the full Brillouin zone, with the appropriate weights.
8300         (This is to be used when preparing or executing a RF calculation at non-zero q)
8301     
8302       * 4 --> rely on [[ngkpt]] or [[kptrlatt]], as well as on [[nshiftk]] and [[shiftk]] to set up the k points.
8303        Take into account all the symmetries EXCEPT the time-reversal symmetry to generate the k points
8304        in the Irreducible Brillouin Zone, with the appropriate weights.
8305        This has to be used when performing calculations with non-collinear magnetism allowed ([[nspden]] = 4)
8306     
8307       * A negative value  --> rely on [[kptbounds]], and [[ndivk]] ([[ndivsm]]) to set up a band structure calculation
8308         along different lines (allowed only for [[iscf]] == -2). The absolute value of [[kptopt]] gives
8309         the number of segments of the band structure. Weights are usually irrelevant with this option,
8310         and will be left to their default value.
8311     
8312     In the case of a grid of k points, the auxiliary variables [[kptrlen]],
8313     [[ngkpt]] and [[prtkpt]] might help you to select the optimal grid.
8314     """,
8315     ),
8316     
8317     Variable(
8318         abivarname="kptrlatt",
8319         varset="gstate",
8320         vartype="integer",
8321         topics=['k-points_useful'],
8322         dimensions=[3, 3],
8323         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=None, value=0),
8324         mnemonics="K - PoinTs grid: Real space LATTice",
8325         excludes="[[ngkpt]]",
8326         text="""
8327     This input variable is used only when [[kptopt]] is positive. It partially
8328     defines the k point grid. The other piece of information is contained in
8329     [[shiftk]]. [[kptrlatt]] cannot be used together with [[ngkpt]].
8330     
8331     The values [[kptrlatt]](1:3,1), [[kptrlatt]](1:3,2), [[kptrlatt]](1:3,3) are the
8332     coordinates of three vectors in real space, expressed in the [[rprimd]]
8333     coordinate system (reduced coordinates). They defines a super-lattice in real
8334     space. The k point lattice is the reciprocal of this super-lattice, possibly shifted (see [[shiftk]]).
8335     
8336     If neither [[ngkpt]] nor [[kptrlatt]] are defined, ABINIT will automatically
8337     generate a set of k point grids, and select the best combination of
8338     [[kptrlatt]] and [[shiftk]] that allows one to reach a sufficient value of
8339     [[kptrlen]]. See this latter variable for a complete description of this procedure.
8340     """,
8341     ),
8342     
8343     Variable(
8344         abivarname="kptrlen",
8345         varset="gstate",
8346         vartype="real",
8347         topics=['k-points_useful'],
8348         dimensions="scalar",
8349         defaultval=30.0,
8350         mnemonics="K - PoinTs grid: Real space LENgth",
8351         text="""
8352     This input variable is used only when [[kptopt]] is positive and non-zero.
8353     
8354     Preliminary explanation:
8355     The k point lattice defined by [[ngkpt]] or [[kptrlatt]] is used to perform
8356     integrations of periodic quantities in the Brillouin Zone, like the density or
8357     the kinetic energy. One can relate the error made by replacing the continuous
8358     integral by a sum over k point lattice to the Fourier transform of the
8359     periodic quantity. Erroneous contributions will appear only for the vectors in
8360     real space that belong to the reciprocal of the k point lattice, except the
8361     origin. Moreover, the expected size of these contributions usually decreases
8362     exponentially with the distance. So, the length of the smallest of these real
8363     space vectors is a measure of the accuracy of the k point grid.
8364     
8365     When either [[ngkpt]] or [[kptrlatt]] is defined, [[kptrlen]] is not used as
8366     an input variable, but the length of the smallest vector will be placed in
8367     this variable, and echoed in the output file.
8368     
8369     On the other hand, when neither [[ngkpt]] nor [[kptrlatt]] are defined, ABINIT
8370     will automatically generate a large set of possible k point grids, and select
8371     among this set, the grids that give a length of smallest vector LARGER than
8372     [[kptrlen]], and among these grids, the one that, when used with [[kptopt]] = 1,
8373     reduces to the smallest number of k points. Note that this procedure can be
8374     time-consuming. It is worth doing it once for a given unit cell and set of
8375     symmetries, but not use this procedure by default. The best is then to set
8376     [[prtkpt]] = 1, in order to get a detailed analysis of the set of grids.
8377     
8378     If some layer of vacuum is detected in the unit cell (see the input variable
8379     [[vacuum]]), the computation of [[kptrlen]] will ignore the dimension related
8380     to the direction perpendicular to the vacuum layer, and generate a bi-
8381     dimensional k point grid. If the system is confined in a tube, a one-
8382     dimensional k point grid will be generated. For a cluster, this procedure will
8383     only generate the Gamma point.
8384     """,
8385     ),
8386     
8387     Variable(
8388         abivarname="kssform",
8389         varset="files",
8390         vartype="integer",
8391         topics=['Susceptibility_expert', 'SelfEnergy_expert'],
8392         dimensions="scalar",
8393         defaultval=1,
8394         mnemonics="Kohn Sham Structure file FORMat",
8395         text="""
8396     Governs the choice of the format for the file that contains the Kohn-Sham
8397     electronic structure information, for use in GW calculations, see the input
8398     variables [[optdriver]] and [[nbandkss]].
8399     
8400       * [[kssform]] = 1, a single file.kss (double precision) containing complete information on the Kohn Sham Structure (eigenstates and the pseudopotentials used) will be generated through full diagonalization of the complete Hamiltonian matrix. The file has at the beginning the standard abinit header.
8401       * [[kssform]] = 3, a single file.kss (double precision) containing complete information on the Kohn Sham Structure (eigenstates and the pseudopotentials used) will be generated through the usual conjugate gradient algorithm (so, a restricted number of states). The file has at the beginning the standard abinit header.
8402     
8403     !!! warning
8404     
8405         For the time being, [[istwfk]] must be 1 for all the k-points.
8406     """,
8407     ),
8408     
8409     Variable(
8410         abivarname="ldaminushalf",
8411         varset="paw",
8412         vartype="integer",

8415         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=None, value=0),
8416         mnemonics="LDA minus half",
8417         text="""
8418     For each type of atom, gives whether a LDA-${\\frac{1}{2}}$ calculation is to be performed.
8419     [[ldaminushalf]] =0: the LDA-$\\frac{1}{2}$ approach is not used.
8420     [[ldaminushalf]] =1: the LDA-$\\frac{1}{2}$ approach is used.
8421     """,
8422     ),

8439     Variable(
8440         abivarname="localrdwf",
8441         varset="paral",
8442         vartype="integer",
8443         topics=['parallelism_expert'],
8444         dimensions="scalar",
8445         defaultval=1,
8446         mnemonics="LOCAL ReaD WaveFunctions",
8447         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
8448         text="""
8449     This input variable is used only when running abinit in parallel. If
8450     [[localrdwf]] = 1, the input wavefunction disk file or the KSS/SCR file in case
8451     of GW calculations, is read locally by each processor, while if
8452     [[localrdwf]] = 0, only one processor reads it, and broadcast the data to the
8453     other processors.
8454     
8455     The option [[localrdwf]] = 0 is NOT allowed when parallel I/O are activated
8456     (MPI-IO access), i.e. when [[iomode]] == 1.
8457     
8458     In the case of a parallel computer with a unique file system, both options are
8459     as convenient for the user. However, if the I/O are slow compared to
8460     communications between processors,, [[localrdwf]] = 0 should be much more
8461     efficient; if you really need temporary disk storage, switch to localrdwf=1 ).
8462     
8463     In the case of a cluster of nodes, with a different file system for each
8464     machine, the input wavefunction file must be available on all nodes if
8465     [[localrdwf]] = 1, while it is needed only for the master node if [[localrdwf]] = 0.
8466     """,
8467     ),
8468

8537     are allowed)  on which to apply the LDA+U correction.
8538     
8539       * If equal to 2 (d-orbitals)  or 3 (f-orbitals), values of [[upawu]] and  [[jpawu]] are used in the calculation.
8540       * If equal to -1: do not apply LDA+U correction on the species.

8544     Variable(
8545         abivarname="macro_uj",
8546         varset="dev",
8547         vartype="integer",
8548         topics=['DFT+U_expert'],
8549         dimensions="scalar",
8550         defaultval=0,
8551         mnemonics="MACRO variable that activates the determination of the U and J parameter (for the PAW+U calculations)",
8552         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
8553         text="""
8554     Sets proper input values for the determination of U and J i.e. for [[pawujat]]
8555     (first atom treated with PAW+U), [[irdwfk]] (=1), [[tolvrs]] (=10^(-8)),
8556     [[nstep]] (=255), [[diemix]] (=0.45), [[atvshift]] ([[pawujat]]) [[pawujv]]).
8557     Do not overwrite these variables manually unless you know what you are doing.
8558     
8559       * [[macro_uj]] = 1 (and [[nsppol]] = 2) Standard procedure to determine U on atom pawujat through a shift of the potential on both spin channels.
8560       * [[macro_uj]] = 1 (and [[nsppol]] = 1) Non standard procedure to determine U from potential shift on atom pawujat (experimental).
8561       * [[macro_uj]] = 2 (and [[nsppol]] = 2) Non standard procedure to determine U from potential shift on atom pawujat through a shift on spin channel 1 on this atom and the response on this channel (experimental).
8562       * [[macro_uj]] = 3 (and [[nsppol]] = 2) Standard procedure to determine J from potential shift on spin channel 1 on atom pawujat and response on spin channel 2 (experimental).
8563     
8564     Determination of U and J can be done only if the symmetry of the atomic
8565     arrangement is reduced and the atom pawujat is not connected to any other atom
8566     by symmetry relations (either input reduced symmetries manually, define
8567     concerned atom as a separate atomic species or shift concerned atom from ideal
8568     position).
8569     """,
8570     ),
8571     
8572     Variable(
8573         abivarname="magcon_lambda",
8574         varset="gstate",
8575         vartype="real",
8576         topics=['MagMom_useful'],
8577         dimensions="scalar",
8578         defaultval=0.01,
8579         mnemonics="MAGnetization CONstraint LAMBDA parameter",
8580         text="""
8581     This variable gives the amplitude of the constraint imposed on the
8582     magnetization vectors on each atom (turned on with flag variable
8583     [[magconon]]). Typical values for [[magcon_lambda]] are 0.001 to 0.1. The SCF convergence
8584     will be difficult if [[magcon_lambda]] is too large. If [[magcon_lambda]] is too small, the
8585     constraint will not be very effective and it will give magnetization not close
8586     to the desired [[spinat]] target. In case of convergence problem, it can help
8587     to start with a small value of [[magcon_lambda]] and to increase it by reading the
8588     wavefunction obtained with a lower [[magcon_lambda]] value. See variable [[magconon]] for more details.
8589     """,
8590     ),
8591     
8592     Variable(
8593         abivarname="magconon",
8594         varset="gstate",
8595         vartype="integer",
8596         topics=['MagMom_useful'],
8597         dimensions="scalar",
8598         defaultval=0,
8599         mnemonics="turn MAGnetization CONstraint ON",
8600         text="""
8601     Turns on the imposition of a Lagrangian constraint on the magnetization. For
8602     each atom, the magnetization is calculated in a sphere (radius [[ratsph]]) and
8603     a constraint is applied to bring it closer to the input values of [[spinat]].
8604     The constraint can be either on the direction only ([[magconon]] = 1) or on the full
8605     vector ([[magconon]] = 2). The Lagrangian constraint has an amplitude
8606     [[magcon_lambda]] which should be neither too big (bad or impossible
8607     convergence) nor too small (no effect).
8608     """,
8609     ),
8610
