8707     Variable(
8708         abivarname="mdtemp",
8709         varset="rlx",
8710         vartype="real",
8711         topics=['PIMD_compulsory', 'MolecularDynamics_compulsory'],
8712         dimensions=[2],
8713         defaultval=[300, 300],
8714         mnemonics="Molecular Dynamics TEMPeratures",
8715         text="""
8716     Give the initial and final temperature of the Nose-Hoover thermostat
8717     ([[ionmov]] = 8) and Langevin dynamics ([[ionmov]] = 9), in Kelvin. This
8718     temperature will change linearly from the initial temperature **mdtemp(1)** at
8719     itime=1 to the final temperature **mdtemp(2)** at the end of the [[ntime]] timesteps.
8720     
8721     In the case of the isokinetic molecular dynamics ([[ionmov]] = 12), **mdtemp(1)** allows ABINIT
8722     to generate velocities ([[vel]]) to start the run if they are not provided by the user or if they all vanish. However **mdtemp(2)** is not used (even if it must be defined to please the parser). If some velocities are non-zero, **mdtemp** is not used, the kinetic energy computed from the velocities is kept constant during the run.
8723     """,
8724     ),
8725     
8726     Variable(
8727         abivarname="mdwall",
8728         varset="rlx",
8729         vartype="real",
8730         topics=['MolecularDynamics_expert'],
8731         dimensions="scalar",
8732         defaultval=10000.0,
8733         mnemonics="Molecular Dynamics WALL location",
8734         commentdefault="the walls are extremely far away",
8735         text="""
8736     Gives the location (atomic units) of walls on which the atoms will bounce
8737     back. when [[ionmov]] = 6, 7, 8 or 9. For each cartesian direction idir=1, 2 or
8738     3, there is a pair of walls with coordinates xcart(idir)=-wall and
8739     xcart(idir)=rprimd(idir,idir)+wall. Supposing the particle will cross the
8740     wall, its velocity normal to the wall is reversed, so that it bounces back.
8741     By default, given in Bohr atomic units (1 Bohr=0.5291772108 Angstroms),
8742     although Angstrom can be specified, if preferred, since [[mdwall]] has the
8743     '[[LENGTH]]' characteristics.
8744     """,
8745     ),
8746     
8747     Variable(
8748         abivarname="mem_test",
8749         varset="dev",
8750         vartype="integer",
8751         topics=['Control_expert'],
8752         dimensions="scalar",
8753         defaultval=1,
8754         mnemonics="MEMory TEST",
8755         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
8756         text="""
8757     This variable controls the memory test done in the `memana` routine. Possible
8758     values:
8759     
8760       * 0 no test on the available memory is performed
8761       * 1 the routine tries to allocate the estimated memory, for testing purposes, and if a failure occurs, the routine stops.
8762       * 2 like 1, but before stopping, the routine will provide an estimation of the available memory.
8763     """,
8764     ),
8765     
8766     Variable(
8767         abivarname="mep_mxstep",
8768         varset="rlx",
8769         vartype="real",
8770         topics=['TransPath_useful'],
8771         dimensions="scalar",
8772         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[imgmov]] == 5': 0.4, 'defaultval': 100.0}),
8773         mnemonics="Minimal Energy Path search: MaXimum allowed STEP size",
8774         characteristics=['[[LENGTH]]'],
8775         text="""
8776     Relevant only when [[imgmov]] = 1 (Steepest-Descent), 2 (String Method) or 5
8777     (Nudged Elastic Band).
8778     The optimizer used to solve the Ordinary Differential Equation (ODE) can be
8779     constrained with a maximum allowed step size for each image. By default this
8780     feature is only activated for Nudged Elastic Band (NEB) and the value is
8781     inspired by [[cite:Sheppard2008]].
8782     Note that the step size is defined for each image as _step = SQRT[SUM(R_i dot
8783     R_i)]_ where the _R_i_ are the positions of the atoms in the cell.
8784     """,
8785     ),
8786     
8787     Variable(
8788         abivarname="mep_solver",
8789         varset="rlx",
8790         vartype="integer",
8791         topics=['TransPath_basic'],
8792         dimensions="scalar",
8793         mnemonics="Minimal Energy Path ordinary differential equation SOLVER",
8794         text="""
8795     Relevant only when [[imgmov]] = 2 (String Method) or 5 (Nudged Elastic Band).
8796     Gives the algorithm used to solve the Ordinary Differential Equation (ODE)
8797     when searching for a Minimal Energy Path (MEP).
8798     Possible values can be:
8799     
8800       * 0 --> **Steepest-Descent algorithm** following the (scaled) forces, the scaling factor being [[fxcartfactor]] (forward Euler method).
8801     Compatible with all MEP search methods.
8802     
8803       * 1 --> **Quick-min optimizer** following the (scaled) forces, the scaling factor being [[fxcartfactor]]. The "quick minimizer" improves upon the steepest-descent method by accelerating the system in the direction of the forces. The velocity (of the image) is projected long the force and cancelled if antiparallel to it.
8804     Compatible only with Nudged Elastic Band ([[imgmov]] = 5).
8805     See [[cite:Sheppard2008]].
8806     
8807       * 2 --> **Local Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno (L-BFGS) algorithm**; each image along the band is minimized with a different instance of the BFGS optimizer.
8808     Compatible only with Nudged Elastic Band ([[imgmov]] = 5).
8809     See [[cite:Sheppard2008]].
8810     IN [[DEVELOP]]PMENT - NOT RELIABLE
8811     
8812       * 3 --> **Global Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno (GL-BFGS) algorithm**; all images along the band are minimized with a single instance of the BFGS optimizer.
8813     Compatible only with Nudged Elastic Band ([[imgmov]] = 5).
8814     See [[cite:Sheppard2008]].
8815     IN [[DEVELOP]]PMENT - NOT RELIABLE
8816     
8817       * 4 --> **Fourth-order Runge-Kutta method**; the images along the band are moved every four steps (1 <=istep<=[[ntimimage]]) following the Runge-Kutta algorithm, the time step being [[fxcartfactor]].
8818     Compatible only with Simplified String Method ([[imgmov]] = 2 and
8819     [[string_algo]] = 1 or 2).
8820     See [[cite:Weinan2007]].
8821     
8822     All of the optimizers can be constrained with a maximum allowed step size for
8823     each image; see [[mep_mxstep]]. This is by default the case of the Nudged
8824     Elastic Band ([[imgmov]] = 5).
8825     """,
8826     ),
8827     
8828     Variable(
8829         abivarname="mgfft",
8830         varset="internal",
8831         vartype="integer",
8832         topics=['Planewaves_internal'],
8833         dimensions="scalar",
8834         mnemonics="Maximum of nGFFT",
8835         characteristics=['[[INTERNAL_ONLY]]'],
8836         text="""
8837     This internal variable contains the maximum of [[ngfft]](1:3).
8838     """,
8839     ),
8840     
8841     Variable(
8842         abivarname="mgfftdg",
8843         varset="internal",
8844         vartype="integer",
8845         topics=['Planewaves_internal'],
8846         dimensions="scalar",
8847         mnemonics="Maximum of nGFFT for the Double Grid",
8848         characteristics=['[[INTERNAL_ONLY]]'],
8849         text="""
8850     This internal variable contains the maximum of [[ngfftdg]](1:3).
8851     """,
8852     ),
8853     
8854     Variable(
8855         abivarname="mixalch",
8856         varset="gstate",
8857         vartype="real",
8858         topics=['AtomTypes_useful'],
8859         dimensions=['[[npspalch]]', '[[ntypalch]]'],
8860         mnemonics="MIXing coefficients for ALCHemical potentials",
8861         characteristics=['[[EVOLVING]]'],
8862         text="""
8863     Used for the generation of alchemical pseudoatoms, that is, when [[ntypalch]]
8864     is non-zero.
8865     
8866     This array gives, for each type of alchemical pseudatom (there are
8867     [[ntypalch]] such pseudoatoms), the mixing coefficients of the basic
8868     [[npspalch]] pseudopotentials for alchemical use. For each type of alchemical
8869     pseudoatom, the sum of the mixing coefficients must equal 1.
8870     
8871     The actual use of the mixing coefficients is defined by the input variable
8872     [[algalch]]. Note that the masses of the atoms, [[amu]] are also mixed
8873     according to the value of [[mixalch]], by default.
8874     
8875     Example 1. Suppose that we want to describe Ba(0.25) Sr(0.75) Ti O$_3$.
8876     The input variables related to the construction of the alchemical Ba(0.25)
8877     Sr(0.75) potential will be:
8878     
8879           npsp   4                 ! 4 pseudopotentials should be read.
8880           znucl  8 40 56 38        ! The nuclear charges. Note that the two
8881                                    ! atoms whose pseudopotentials are to be mixed
8882                                    ! are mentioned at the end of the series.
8883           ntypat  3                ! There will be three types of atoms.
8884           ntypalch   1             ! One pseudoatom will be alchemical.
8885                                    ! Hence, there will be ntyppure=2 pure pseudoatoms,
8886                                    ! with znucl 8 (O) and 40 (Ti), corresponding to
8887                                    ! the two first pseudopotentials. Out of the
8888                                    ! four pseudopotentials, npspalch=2 are left
8889                                    ! for alchemical purposes, with znucl 56 (Ba)
8890                                    ! and 38 (Sr).
8891           mixalch    0.25  0.75    ! For that unique pseudoatom to be
8892                                    ! generated, here are the mixing coeeficients,
8893                                    ! to be used to combine the Ba and Sr pseudopotentials.
8894     
8895     
8896     Example 2. More complicated, and illustrate some minor drawback of the design
8897     of input variables. Suppose that one wants to generate Al(0.25)Ga(0.75)
8898     As(0.10)Sb(0.90).
8899     The input variables will be:
8900     
8901           npsp  4                  ! 4 pseudopotentials should be read
8902           znucl  13 31 33 51       ! The atomic numbers. All pseudopotentials
8903                                    ! will be used for some alchemical purpose
8904           ntypat  2                ! There will be two types of atoms.
8905           ntypalch   2             ! None of the atoms will be "pure".
8906                                    ! Hence, there will be npspalch=4 pseudopotentials
8907                                    !  to be used for alchemical purposes.
8908           mixalch    0.25  0.75 0.0  0.0   ! This array is a (4,2) array, arranged in the
8909                      0.0   0.0  0.1  0.9   ! usual Fortran order.
8910     
8911     Minor drawback: one should not forget to fill [[mixalch]] with the needed
8912     zero's, in this later case.
8913     
8914     In most cases, the use of [[mixalch]] will be as a static (non-evolving)
8915     variable. However, the possibility to have different values of [[mixalch]] for
8916     different images has been coded. A population of cells with different atomic
8917     characteristics can thus be considered, and can be made to evolve, e.g. with a
8918     genetic algorithm (not coded in v7.0.0 though). There is one restriction to
8919     this possibility: the value of [[ziontypat]] for the atoms that are mixed
8920     should be identical.
8921     """,
8922     ),
8923     
8924     Variable(
8925         abivarname="mixesimgf",
8926         varset="rlx",
8927         vartype="real",
8928         topics=['CrossingBarriers_useful'],
8929         dimensions=['[[nimage]]'],
8930         mnemonics="MIXing Electronic Structure IMAGE Factors",
8931         text="""
8932     Used in the algorithm Linear Combination of Constrained DFT Energies, that is, when [[imgmov]]==6.
8933     
8934     This array gives, for each one of the [[nimage]] images, the factor
8935     by which the total energies for systems with same geometry but different electronic structures (occupation numbers) are linearly combined.
8936     The sum of these factors must equal 1.
8937     """,
8938     ),
8939     
8940     Variable(
8941         abivarname="mpw",
8942         varset="internal",
8943         vartype="integer",
8944         topics=['Planewaves_internal'],
8945         dimensions="scalar",
8946         mnemonics="Maximum number of Plane Waves",
8947         characteristics=['[[INTERNAL_ONLY]]'],
8948         text="""
8949     This internal variable gives the maximum of the number of plane waves over all
8950     k-points. It is computed from [[ecut]] and the description of the cell,
8951     provided by [[acell]], [[rprim]], and/or [[angdeg]].
8952     """,
8953     ),
8954     
8955     Variable(
8956         abivarname="mqgrid",
8957         varset="dev",
8958         vartype="integer",
8959         topics=['Planewaves_expert'],
8960         dimensions="scalar",
8961         defaultval=3001,
8962         mnemonics="Maximum number of Q-space GRID points for pseudopotentials",
8963         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
8964         text="""
8965     Govern the size of the one-dimensional information related to
8966     pseudopotentials, in reciprocal space: potentials, or projector functions.
8967     """,
8968     ),

8982     the latter... See also [[mqgrid]]

9081     irreducible set of atoms in the unit cell (using symmetry operations, this set

9120     Variable(
9121         abivarname="natsph",

9131     density-of-states will be built, in the [[prtdos]] = 3 case. The
9132     indices of these atoms are given by [[iatsph]]. The radius of these spheres is
9133     given by [[ratsph]].

9135     band structure will be built (the indices of these atoms are given
9136     by [[iatsph]]).
9137     """,

9140     Variable(
9141         abivarname="natsph_extra",
9142         varset="gstate",
9143         vartype="integer",
9144         topics=['printing_prdos'],
9145         dimensions="scalar",
9146         defaultval=0,
9147         mnemonics="Number of ATomic SPHeres for the l-projected density-of-states in EXTRA set",
9148         requires="[[prtdos]] == 3 or [[pawfatbnd]] in [1,2]",
9149         text="""
9150     [[natsph_extra]] gives the number of extra spheres for which the angular-
9151     momentum-projected density-of-states will be built, in the [[prtdos]] = 3 case.
9152     The radius of these spheres is given by [[ratsph_extra]]. This simulates the
9153     STS signal for an STM tip atom placed at the sphere position, according to the
9154     chemical nature of the tip (s- p- d- wave etc...).
9155     If [[pawfatbnd]] = 1 or 2, it gives the number of spheres in which $l$-projected
9156     band structure will be built.
9157     The position of the spheres is given by the [[xredsph_extra]] variable.
9158     """,
9159     ),

9161     Variable(
9162         abivarname="natvshift",
9163         varset="ffield",

9166         dimensions="scalar",
9167         defaultval=0,
9168         mnemonics="Number of ATomic potential (V) energy SHIFTs (per atom)",

9170         text="""
9171     Number of atomic potential energy shifts (per atom), to be used to define the
9172     array [[atvshift]]. If non-zero, only two possibilities exist: 5 for d states
9173     (with [[lpawu]] = 2), and 7 for f states (with [[lpawu]] = 3). If non-zero, one
9174     should define [[usepawu]], [[lpawu]] and [[atvshift]].
9175     """,
9176     ),
9177     
9178     Variable(
9179         abivarname="nband",
9180         varset="basic",
9181         vartype="integer",
9182         topics=['BandOcc_basic', 'GW_basic', 'RPACorrEn_basic', 'Susceptibility_basic'],
9183         dimensions="scalar",
9184         mnemonics="Number of BANDs",
9185         commentdefault=" the estimated number of occupied bands +1 (TODO provide the mathematical formulation)",
9186         text="""
9187     Gives number of bands, occupied plus possibly unoccupied, for which
9188     wavefunctions are being computed along with eigenvalues.
9189     Note: if the parameter [[occopt]] (see below) is not set to 2, [[nband]] is a
9190     scalar integer, but if the parameter [[occopt]] is set to 2, then [[nband]]
9191     must be an array [[nband]]([[nkpt]]* [[nsppol]]) giving the number of bands
9192     explicitly for each k point. This option is provided in order to allow the
9193     number of bands treated to vary from k point to k point.
9194     For the values of [[occopt]] not equal to 0 or 2, [[nband]] can be omitted.
9195     The number of bands will be set up thanks to the use of the variable
9196     [[fband]]. The present Default will not be used.
9197     
9198     If [[nspinor]] is 2, nband must be even for each k point.
9199     
9200     In the case of a GW calculation ([[optdriver]] = 3 or 4), [[nband]] gives the
9201     number of bands to be treated to generate the screening (susceptibility and
9202     dielectric matrix), as well as the self-energy. However, to generate the _KSS
9203     file (see [[kssform]]) the relevant number of bands is given by [[nbandkss]].
9204     """,
9205     ),
9206     
9207     Variable(
9208         abivarname="nbandhf",
9209         varset="basic",
9210         vartype="integer",
9211         topics=['Hybrids_useful'],
9212         dimensions="scalar",
9213         mnemonics="Number of BANDs for (Hartree)-Fock exact exchange",
9214         commentdefault="the estimated number of occupied bands (TODO: provide the mathematical formulation)",
9215         text="""
9216     Gives the maximum number of occupied bands with which Fock exact exchange is
9217     being computed for the wavefunctions.
9218     """,
9219     ),
9220     
9221     Variable(
9222         abivarname="nbandkss",
9223         varset="gw",
9224         vartype="integer",
9225         topics=['GW_useful', 'Susceptibility_useful', 'SelfEnergy_useful'],
9226         dimensions="scalar",
9227         defaultval=0,
9228         mnemonics="Number of BANDs in the KSS file",
9229         text=r"""
9230     This input variable is used for the preparation of a GW calculation: it is
9231     used in a GS run (where [[optdriver]] = 0) to generate a _KSS file. In this run,
9232     [[nbandkss]] should be non-zero. The generated _KSS file can be subsequently
9233     used to calculate the irreducible polarizabilty $\chi^{(0)}_{KS}$ using
9234     [[optdriver]] = 3 or to calculate GW corrections setting [[optdriver]] = 4.
9235     
9236       * If [[nbandkss]] = 0, no _KSS file is created.
9237       * If [[nbandkss]] = -1, all the available eigenstates (energies and eigenfunctions) are stored in the abo_KSS file at the end of the ground state calculation. The number of states is forced to be the same for all k-points: it will be the minimum of the number of plane waves over all k-points.
9238       * If [[nbandkss]] is greater than 0, abinit stores (about) [[nbandkss]] eigenstates in the abo_KSS file. This number of states is forced to be the same for all k-points.
9239     
9240     See [[npwkss]] for the selection of the number of the planewave components of
9241     the eigenstates to be stored.
9242     The input variable [[iomode]] can be used to read and write KSS files
9243     according to different fileformat (presently only [[iomode]] = 0 and 3 are
9244     available in the GW part).
9245     The precision of the KSS file can be tuned through the input variable [[kssform]].
9246     For more details about the format of the abo_KSS file, see the routine outkss.F90.
9247     
9248     !!! warning
9249     
9250         For the time being, [[istwfk]] must be 1 for all the k-points in order to generate a _KSS file.
9251     """,
9252     ),
9253     
9254     Variable(
9255         abivarname="nbdblock",
9256         varset="dev",
9257         vartype="integer",
9258         topics=['TuningSpeed_expert'],
9259         dimensions="scalar",
9260         defaultval=1,
9261         mnemonics="Number of BanDs in a BLOCK",
9262         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
9263         text="""
9264     In case of non-standard, blocked algorithms for the optimization of the
9265     wavefunctions (that is, if [[wfoptalg]] = 4):
9266     
9267       * if [[wfoptalg]] = 4, [[nbdblock]] defines the number of blocks (the number of bands in the block is then [[nband]]/[[nbdblock]] ).
9268     """,
9269     ),
9270     
9271     Variable(
9272         abivarname="nbdbuf",
9273         varset="gstate",
9274         vartype="integer",
9275         topics=['SCFControl_useful', 'BandOcc_useful'],
9276         dimensions="scalar",
9277         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[optdriver]] == 0 and [[iscf]]<0': '2*[[nspinor]]',
9278      '[[optdriver]] == 1 and 3<=[[occopt]] and [[occopt]]<= 8': '2*[[nspinor]]',
9279      'defaultval': 0}),
9280         mnemonics="Number of BanDs for the BUFfer",
9281         text="""
9282     [[nbdbuf]] gives the number of bands, the highest in energy, that, among the
9283     [[nband]] bands, are to be considered as part of a buffer. This concept is
9284     useful in three situations: in non-self-consistent calculations, for the
9285     determination of the convergence tolerance; for response functions of metals,
9286     to avoid instabilities, and also when finite electric fields or non-linear
9287     responses (with electric field perturbations) are considered. For the two
9288     first, the need of a buffer is a natural requirement of the problem, so that
9289     the default value is changed to 2 automatically, as explained in the
9290     following. The third case is only for implementation convenience.
9291     
9292     In non-self-consistent GS calculations ([[iscf]]<0), the highest levels might
9293     be difficult to converge, if they are degenerate with another level, that does
9294     not belong to the set of bands treated. Then, it might take extremely long to
9295     reach [[tolwfr]], although the other bands are already extremely well-
9296     converged, and the energy of the highest bands (whose residual are not yet
9297     good enough), is also rather well converged.
9298     In response to this problem, for non-zero [[nbdbuf]], the largest residual
9299     (residm), to be later compared with [[tolwfr]], will be computed only in the
9300     set of non-buffer bands (this modification applies for non-self-consistent as
9301     well as self-consistent calculation, for GS as well as RF calculations).
9302     For a GS calculation, with [[iscf]]<0, supposing [[nbdbuf]] is not initialized
9303     in the input file, then ABINIT will overcome the default [[nbdbuf]] value, and
9304     automatically set [[nbdbuf]] to 2.
9305     
9306     In metallic RF calculations, in the conjugate gradient optimisation of first-
9307     order wavefunctions, there is an instability situation when the q wavevector
9308     of the perturbation brings the eigenenergy of the highest treated band at some
9309     k point higher than the lowest untreated eigenenergy at some k+q point. If one
9310     accepts a buffer of frozen states, this instability can be made to disappear.
9311     Frozen states receive automatically a residual value of -0.1d0.
9312     For a RF calculation, with 3<=[[occopt]]<=7, supposing [[nbdbuf]] is not
9313     initialized in the input file, then ABINIT will overcome the default
9314     [[nbdbuf]] value, and automatically set [[nbdbuf]] to 2. This value might be
9315     too low in some cases.
9316     
9317     Also, the number of active bands, in all cases, is imposed to be at least 1,
9318     irrespective of the value of [[nbdbuf]].
9319     """,
9320     ),
9321     
9322     Variable(
9323         abivarname="nberry",
9324         varset="ffield",
9325         vartype="integer",
9326         topics=['Berry_basic'],
9327         dimensions="scalar",
9328         defaultval=1,
9329         mnemonics="Number of BERRY phase computations",
9330         requires="[[berryopt]] = 1, 2, or 3",
9331         text="""
9332     Gives the number of Berry phase computations of polarisation, or finite-
9333     difference estimations of the derivative of wavefunctions with respect to the
9334     wavevector, each of which might be characterized by a different change of
9335     wavevector [[kberry]].
9336     
9337     When equal to 0, no Berry phase calculation of polarisation is performed. The
9338     maximal value of [[nberry]] is 20.
9339     
9340     Note that the computation of the polarisation for a set of bands having
9341     different occupation numbers is meaningless (although in the case of spin-
9342     polarized calculations, the spin up bands might have an identical occupation
9343     number, that might differ from the identical occupation number of spin down
9344     bands). Although meaningless, ABINIT will perform such computation, if
9345     required by the user. The input variable [[bdberry]] governs the set of bands
9346     for which a Berry phase is computed.
9347     
9348     For the [[berryopt]] = 1, 2, and 3 cases, spinor wavefunctions are not
9349     allowed, nor are parallel computations.
9350     """,
9351     ),
9352     
9353     Variable(
9354         abivarname="nc_xccc_gspace",
9355         varset="dev",
9356         vartype="integer",
9357         topics=['Planewaves_expert'],
9358         dimensions="scalar",
9359         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[usepaw]] == 0': 0, '[[usepaw]] == 1': 1, 'defaultval': 0}),
9360         mnemonics="Norm-Conserving pseudopotentials - use XC Core-Correction in G-SPACE",
9361         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
9362         commentdefault="0 when [[usepaw]] = 0, 1 when [[usepaw]] = 1",
9363         text="""
9364     Historically, Abinit treats the model core charge used for the non-linear core
9365     correction in real space. Alternatively, it is possible to instruct the code
9366     to compute the core charge in G-space following the same approach used in the
9367     PAW code. The G-space formalism is more accurate than the interpolation in
9368     real space, especially when derivatives of the model core charge are needed,
9369     e.g. DFPT. Preliminary tests showed that the violation of the acoustic sum
9370     rule is reduced when [[nc_xccc_gspace]] == 1, especially for LDA. It is worth
9371     stressing, however, that [[nc_xccc_gspace]] == 1 should be used only in
9372     conjunction with NC pseudos whose model core charge that decays quickly in
9373     G-space. Several NC pseudos available in the Abinit table are not optimized
9374     for the G-space formalism and users are strongly invited to perform
9375     convergence studies with respect to ecut before using this option.
9376     """,
9377     ),
9378     
9379     Variable(
9380         abivarname="nconeq",
9381         varset="rlx",
9382         vartype="integer",
9383         topics=['GeoConstraints_useful'],
9384         dimensions="scalar",
9385         defaultval=0,
9386         mnemonics="Number of CONstraint EQuations",
9387         characteristics=['[[NO_MULTI]]'],
9388         text="""
9389     Gives the number of independent equations constraining the motion of atoms
9390     during structural optimization or molecular dynamics (see [[natcon]],
9391     [[iatcon]], and [[wtatcon]]).
9392     """,
9393     ),
9394     
9395     Variable(
9396         abivarname="nctime",
9397         varset="dev",
9398         vartype="integer",
9399         topics=['MolecularDynamics_useful'],
9400         dimensions="scalar",
9401         defaultval=0,
9402         mnemonics="NetCdf TIME between output of molecular dynamics informations",
9403         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
9404         text="""
9405     When [[nctime]] is non-zero, the molecular dynamics information is output in
9406     NetCDF format, every [[nctime]] time step. Here is the content of an example
9407     file:
9408     
9409     ```
9410         netcdf md32.outH_moldyn1 {
9411         dimensions:
9412            time = UNLIMITED; // (11 currently)
9413            DimTensor = 6;
9414            DimCoord = 3;
9415            NbAtoms = 32;
9416            DimVector = 3;
9417            DimScalar = 1;
9418         variables:
9419            double E_pot(time);
9420               E_pot:units = "hartree";
9421            double E_kin(time);
9422               E_kin:units = "hartree";
9423            double Stress(time, DimTensor);
9424               Stress:units = "hartree/Bohr^3";
9425            double Position(time, DimCoord, NbAtoms);
9426               Position:units = "Bohr";
9427            double Celerity(time, DimCoord, NbAtoms);
9428               Celerity:units = "Bohr/(atomic time unit)";
9429            double PrimitiveVector1(DimVector);
9430            double PrimitiveVector2(DimVector);
9431            double PrimitiveVector3(DimVector);
9432            double Cell_Volume(DimScalar);
9433               Cell_Volume:units = "Bohr^3";
9434         }
9435     ```
9436     """,
9437     ),
9438     
9439     Variable(
9440         abivarname="ndivk",
9441         varset="gstate",
9442         vartype="integer",
9443         topics=['k-points_useful', 'ElecBandStructure_useful'],
9444         dimensions=['abs([[kptopt]])'],
9445         mnemonics="Number of DIVisions of K lines",
9446         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
9447         commentdefault="Will be generated automatically from [[ndivsm]] if the latter is defined.",
9448         excludes="[[ndivsm]]",
9449         requires="[[kptopt]] < 0",
9450         text="""
9451     Gives the number of divisions of each of the segments of the band structure,
9452     whose path is determined by [[kptopt]] and [[kptbounds]]. In this case, the
9453     absolute value of [[kptopt]] is the number of such segments.
9454     
9455     For example, suppose that the number of segment is just one ([[kptopt]] = -1), a
9456     value [[ndivk]] = 4 will lead to the computation of points with relative
9457     coordinates 0.0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75 and 1.0, along the segment in consideration.
9458     
9459     Now, suppose that there are two segments ([[kptopt]] = -2), with [[ndivk]](1)=4
9460     and [[ndivk]](2)=2, the computation of the eigenvalues will be done at 7
9461     points, 5 belonging to the first segment, with relative coordinates 0.0, 0.25,
9462     0.5, 0.75 and 1.0, the last one being also the starting point of the next
9463     segment, for which two other points must be computed, with relative
9464     coordinates 0.5 and 1.0.
9465     
9466     It is easy to compute disconnected circuits (non-chained segments), by
9467     separating the circuits with the value [[ndivk]] = 1 for the intermediate
9468     segment connecting the end of one circuit with the beginning of the next one
9469     (in which case no intermediate point is computed along this segment).
9470     
9471     Alternatively it is possible to generate automatically the array [[ndivk]] by
9472     just specifying the number of divisions for the smallest segment. See the
9473     related input variable [[ndivsm]].
9474     """,
9475     ),
9476     
9477     Variable(
9478         abivarname="ndivsm",
9479         varset="gstate",
9480         vartype="integer",
9481         topics=['k-points_useful', 'ElecBandStructure_basic'],
9482         dimensions="scalar",
9483         mnemonics="Number of DIVisions for the SMallest segment",
9484         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
9485         text="""
9486     This variable defines the number of divisions used to sample the smallest
9487     segment of the circuit employed in a band structure calculations (see related
9488     input variables [[kptopt]] and [[kptbounds]]). If [[ndivsm]] is given in the
9489     input file, there is no need to specify the number of divisions to be used for
9490     the other segments. Indeed [[ndivk]] is automatically calculated inside the
9491     code in order to generate a path where the number of divisions in each segment
9492     is proportional to the length of the segment itself. This option is activated
9493     only when [[kptopt]] is negative. In this case, the absolute value of
9494     [[kptopt]] is the number of such segments.
9495     """,
9496     ),
9497     
9498     Variable(
9499         abivarname="ndtset",
9500         varset="basic",
9501         vartype="integer",
9502         topics=['multidtset_compulsory'],
9503         dimensions="scalar",
9504         defaultval=0,
9505         mnemonics="Number of DaTaSETs",
9506         characteristics=['[[NO_MULTI]]'],
9507         text="""
9508     Gives the number of data sets to be treated.
9509     If 0, means that the multi-data set treatment is not used, so that the root
9510     filenames will not be appended with _DSx, where 'x' is the dataset index
9511     defined by the input variable [[jdtset]], and also that input names with a
9512     dataset index are not allowed. Otherwise, [[ndtset]] = 0 is equivalent to
9513     [[ndtset]] = 1.
9514     """,
9515     ),
9516     
9517     Variable(
9518         abivarname="ndynimage",
9519         varset="internal",
9520         vartype="integer",
9521         topics=['PIMD_internal'],
9522         dimensions="scalar",
9523         mnemonics="Number of DYNamical IMAGEs",
9524         characteristics=['[[INTERNAL_ONLY]]'],
9525         text="""
9526     This internal variable gives the number of dynamical images, immediately
9527     deduced from the number of non-zero values present in [[dynimage]]. It is used
9528     to dimension many memory-consuming arrays (one copy for each image), e.g. the
9529     wavefunction array (cg), the density array (rho), etc.
9530     """,
9531     ),
9532     
9533     Variable(
9534         abivarname="neb_algo",
9535         varset="rlx",
9536         vartype="integer",
9537         topics=['TransPath_useful'],
9538         dimensions="scalar",
9539         defaultval=1,
9540         mnemonics="Nudged Elastic Band ALGOrithm",
9541         requires="[[imgmov]] == 5",
9542         text="""
9543     Gives the variant of the NEB method used. Possible values can be:
9544     
9545       * 0 --> **Original NEB method**.
9546     See [[cite:Berne1998]] pp. 385-404
9547     
9548       * 1 --> **NEB + improved tangent**.
9549     The Improved Tangent Method builds on the NEB with an improved estimate of the
9550     tangent direction and a resulting change of the component of the spring force
9551     acting on the images.
9552     See [[cite:Henkelman2000]]
9553     
9554       * 2 --> **Climbing-Image NEB (CI-NEB)**.
9555     XG 20180813 : This algorithm seems to be BROKEN.
9556     The CI-NEB method constitutes a small modification to the NEB method.
9557     Information about the shape of the MEP is retained, but a rigorous convergence
9558     to a saddle point is also obtained. By default the spring constants are
9559     variable (see [[neb_spring]]). As the image with the highest energy has to be
9560     identified, the calculation begins with several iterations of the standard NEB
9561     algorithm. The effective CI-NEB begins at the [[cineb_start]] iteration.
9562     See [[cite:Henkelman2000a]]
9563     
9564     Note that, in all cases, it is possible to define the value of the spring
9565     constant connecting images with [[neb_spring]], keeping it constant or
9566     allowing it to vary between 2 values (to have higher resolution close to the saddle point).
9567     """,
9568     ),
9569     
9570     Variable(
9571         abivarname="neb_spring",
9572         varset="rlx",
9573         vartype="real",
9574         topics=['TransPath_useful'],
9575         dimensions=[2],
9576         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[neb_algo]] == 2': [0.02, 0.15], 'defaultval': [0.05, 0.05]}),
9577         mnemonics="Nudged Elastic Band: SPRING constant",
9578         requires="[[imgmov]] == 5",
9579         text="""
9580     Gives the minimal and maximal values of the spring constant connecting images
9581     for the NEB method.
9582     In the standard "Nudged Elastic Band" method, the spring constant is constant
9583     along the path, but, in order to have higher resolution close to the saddle
9584     point, it can be better to have stronger springs close to it.
9585     See [[cite:Henkelman2000a]]
9586     """,
9587     ),
9588     
9589     Variable(
9590         abivarname="nelect",
9591         varset="internal",
9592         vartype="real",
9593         topics=['BandOcc_internal'],
9594         dimensions="scalar",
9595         defaultval="[[AUTO_FROM_PSP]]",
9596         mnemonics="Number of ELECTrons",
9597         characteristics=['[[INTERNAL_ONLY]]'],
9598         text="""
9599     This internal variable gives the number of electrons per unit cell, as
9600     computed from the sum of the valence electrons related to each atom (given in
9601     the pseudopotential, where it is called "zion"), and the input variable [[charge]]:
9602     [[nelect]] = zion-[[charge]].
9603     """,
9604     ),
9605     
9606     Variable(
9607         abivarname="nfft",
9608         varset="internal",
9609         vartype="integer",
9610         topics=['Planewaves_internal'],
9611         dimensions="scalar",
9612         mnemonics="Number of FFT points",
9613         characteristics=['[[INTERNAL_ONLY]]'],
9614         text="""
9615     If space parallelization is not used (that is, if [[paral_kgb]] == 0), this
9616     internal variable gives the number of Fast Fourier Transform points in the
9617     grid generated by [[ngfft]](1:3). It is simply the product of the three
9618     components of [[ngfft]].
9619     
9620     If space parallelisation is used (that is, if [[paral_kgb]] == 1), then it
9621     becomes the number of Fast Fourier Transform points attributed to the
9622     particular processor. It is no longer the above-mentioned simple product, but
9623     a number usually close to this product divided by the number of processors on
9624     which the space is shared.
9625     """,
9626     ),
9627     
9628     Variable(
9629         abivarname="nfftdg",
9630         varset="internal",
9631         vartype="integer",
9632         topics=['Planewaves_internal'],
9633         dimensions="scalar",
9634         mnemonics="Number of FFT points for the Double Grid",
9635         characteristics=['[[INTERNAL_ONLY]]'],
9636         text="""
9637     If space parallelisation is not used (that is, if [[paral_kgb]] == 0), this
9638     internal variable gives the number of Fast Fourier Transform points in the
9639     (double) grid generated by [[ngfftdg]](1:3). It is simply the product of the
9640     three components of [[ngfftdg]].
9641     
9642     If space parallelisation is used (that is, if [[paral_kgb]] == 1), then it
9643     becomes the number of Fast Fourier Transform points attributed to the
9644     particular processor. It is no longer the above-mentioned simple product, but
9645     a number usually close to this product divided by the number of processors on
9646     which the space is shared.
9647     """,
9648     ),
9649     
9650     Variable(
9651         abivarname="nfreqim",
9652         varset="gw",
9653         vartype="integer",
9654         topics=['FrequencyMeshMBPT_basic', 'RPACorrEn_compulsory'],
9655         dimensions="scalar",
9656         defaultval=0,
9657         mnemonics="Number of FREQuencies along the IMaginary axis",
9658         requires="[[optdriver]] == 3 and [[gwcalctyp]] in [2,12,22,9,19,29]",
9659         text="""
9660     [[nfreqim]] sets the number of pure imaginary frequencies used to calculate
9661     the dielectric matrix in order to perform the numerical integration of the GW self-energy.
9662     """,
9663     ),
9664     
9665     Variable(
9666         abivarname="nfreqmidm",
9667         varset="gw",
9668         vartype="integer",
9669         topics=['FrequencyMeshMBPT_basic'],
9670         dimensions="scalar",
9671         mnemonics="Nth FREQuency Moment of the Imaginary part of the Dielectric Matrix",
9672         requires="[[optdriver]] == 4",
9673         text="""
9674     depending on the value of [[nfreqmidm]] will calculate the frequency moment of
9675     the dielectric matrix or its inverse,
9676     
9677       * if [[nfreqmidm]] is positive: calculate (nth=[[nfreqmidm]]) frequency moment of the dielectric matrix.
9678       * if [[nfreqmidm]] is negative: calculate (nth=[[nfreqmidm]]) frequency moment of the inverse dielectric matrix.
9679       * if [[nfreqmidm]] = 0: calculate first frequency moment of the full polarizability.
9680     
9681     See [[cite:Taut1985]].
9682     """,
9683     ),
9684     
9685     Variable(
9686         abivarname="nfreqre",
9687         varset="gw",
9688         vartype="integer",
9689         topics=['FrequencyMeshMBPT_basic'],
9690         dimensions="scalar",
9691         defaultval=0,
9692         mnemonics="Number of FREQuencies along the REal axis",
9693         requires="[[optdriver]] == 3 and [[gwcalctyp]] in [2,12,22,9,19,29]",
9694         text=r"""
9695     [[nfreqre]] sets the number of real frequencies used to calculate the
9696     dielectric matrix in order to perform the numerical integration of the GW self-energy.
9697     
9698     It can be used also in case of GW calculations with plasmon-pole models, _i.e._
9699     [[gwcalctyp]]<10, to reduce the number of frequencies used to evaluate the
9700     dielectric matrix from the (default) two to one frequency (omega=0) by setting
9701     [[nfreqre]] = 1. This might be a good idea in case one is planning to use
9702     [[ppmodel]] > 1. This will force the calculation of the screening on a single
9703     frequency ($\omega=0$) and hence reduce memory and disk space requirement. The
9704     only draw back is that the user will not be able to perform self energy
9705     calculation using [[ppmodel]] = 1, since in the last case the dielectric matrix
9706     calculated on two frequencies is required. If the user is not sure which
9707     ppmodel to use, then s/he is not advised to use this input variable. Using the
9708     default values, one must be able to get a screening file that can be used with any [[ppmodel]].
9709     """,
9710     ),
9711     
9712     Variable(
9713         abivarname="nfreqsp",
9714         varset="gw",
9715         vartype="integer",
9716         topics=['SelfEnergy_basic'],
9717         dimensions="scalar",
9718         defaultval=0,
9719         mnemonics="Number of FREQuencies for the SPectral function",
9720         requires="[[optdriver]] == 4",
9721         text="""
9722     [[nfreqsp]] defines the number of real frequencies used to calculate the
9723     spectral function of the GW Green's function.
9724     """,
9725     ),
9726     
9727     Variable(
9728         abivarname="ngfft",
9729         varset="gstate",
9730         vartype="integer",
9731         topics=['Planewaves_useful'],
9732         dimensions=[3],
9733         defaultval=[0, 0, 0],
9734         mnemonics="Number of Grid points for Fast Fourier Transform",
9735         commentdefault="(automatic selection of optimal values)",
9736         text="""
9737     Gives the size of fast Fourier transform (FFT) grid in three dimensions. Each
9738     number must be composed of the factors 2, 3, and 5 to be consistent with the
9739     radices available in our FFT.
9740     
9741     If no [[ngfft]] is provided or if [[ngfft]] is set to 0 0 0, the code will automatically
9742     provide an optimal set of [[ngfft]] values, based on [[acell]], [[rprim]] and [[ecut]]
9743     (see also [[boxcutmin]] for speed/accuracy concerns).
9744     This is the recommended procedure, of course.
9745     The total number of FFT points is the product: [[ngfft]](1) x [[ngfft]](2) x [[ngfft]](3)=[[nfft]].
9746     
9747     When [[ngfft]] is made smaller than recommended values (e.g. by setting
9748     [[boxcutmin]] to a value smaller than 2.0 or by setting [[ngfft]] manually),
9749     the code runs faster and the equations in effect are approximated by a low
9750     pass Fourier filter. The code reports to standard output (unit 06) a parameter
9751     "boxcut" which is the smallest ratio of the FFT box side to the $\GG$ vector basis
9752     sphere diameter. When boxcut is less than 2 the Fourier filter approximation
9753     is being used. When boxcut gets less than about 1.5 the approximation may be
9754     too severe for realistic results and should be tested against larger values of
9755     [[ngfft]]. When boxcut is larger than 2, [[ngfft]] could be reduced without
9756     loss of accuracy. In this case, the small variations that are observed are
9757     solely due to the xc quadrature, that may be handled with [[intxc]] = 1 to even
9758     reduce this effect.
9759     
9760     Internally, [[ngfft]] is an array of size 18. The present components are
9761     stored in [[ngfft]](1:3), while
9762     
9763       * [[ngfft]](4:6) contains slightly different (larger) values, modified for efficiency of the FFT
9764       * [[ngfft]](7) is [[fftalg]]
9765       * [[ngfft]](8) is [[fftcache]]
9766       * [[ngfft]](9) is set to 0 if the parallelization of the FFT is not activated, while it is set to 1 if it is activated.
9767       * [[ngfft]](10) is the number of processors of the FFT group
9768       * [[ngfft]](11) is the index of the processor in the group of processors
9769       * [[ngfft]](12) is n2proc, the number of x-z planes, in reciprocal space, treated by the processor
9770       * [[ngfft]](13) is n3proc, the number of x-y planes, in real space, treated by the processor
9771       * [[ngfft]](14) is mpi_comm_fft, the handle on the MPI communicator in charge of the FFT parallelisation
9772       * [[ngfft]](15:18) are not yet used
9773     
9774     The number of points stored by this processor in real space is n1*n2*n3proc,
9775     while in reciprocal space, it is n1*n2proc*n3.
9776     """,
9777     ),
9778     
9779     Variable(
9780         abivarname="ngfftdg",
9781         varset="paw",
9782         vartype="integer",
9783         topics=['PAW_useful'],
9784         dimensions=[3],
9785         defaultval=[0, 0, 0],
9786         mnemonics="Number of Grid points for Fast Fourier Transform: Double Grid",
9787         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
9788         text="""
9789     This variable has the same meaning as ngfft (gives the size of fast Fourier
9790     transform (fft) grid in three dimensions) but concerns the "double grid" only
9791     used for PAW calculations.
9792     """,
9793     ),
9794     
9795     Variable(
9796         abivarname="ngkpt",
9797         varset="basic",
9798         vartype="integer",
9799         topics=['k-points_basic'],
9800         dimensions=[3],
9801         defaultval=[0, 0, 0],
9802         mnemonics="Number of Grid points for K PoinTs generation",
9803         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
9804         excludes="[[kptrlatt]]",
9805         requires="[[kptopt]] >=0,",
9806         text="""
9807     Used when [[kptopt]] >= 0, if [[kptrlatt]] has not been defined ([[kptrlatt]]
9808     and [[ngkpt]] are exclusive of each other).
9809     Its three positive components give the number of k points of Monkhorst-Pack
9810     grids (defined with respect to primitive axis in reciprocal space) in each of
9811     the three dimensions. [[ngkpt]] will be used to generate the corresponding
9812     [[kptrlatt]] input variable. The use of [[nshiftk]] and [[shiftk]], allows one to
9813     generate shifted grids, or Monkhorst-Pack grids defined with respect to
9814     conventional unit cells.
9815     
9816     When [[nshiftk]] = 1, [[kptrlatt]] is initialized as a diagonal (3x3) matrix,
9817     whose diagonal elements are the three values [[ngkpt]](1:3). When [[nshiftk]]
9818     is greater than 1, ABINIT will try to generate [[kptrlatt]] on the basis of
9819     the primitive vectors of the k-lattice: the number of shifts might be reduced,
9820     in which case [[kptrlatt]] will not be diagonal anymore.
9821     
9822     Monkhorst-Pack grids are usually the most efficient when their defining
9823     integer numbers are even. For a measure of the efficiency, see the input
9824     variable [[kptrlen]].
9825     """,
9826     ),
9827     
9828     Variable(
9829         abivarname="ngqpt",
9830         varset="gstate",
9831         vartype="integer",
9832         topics=['q-points_basic'],
9833         dimensions=[3],
9834         defaultval=[0, 0, 0],
9835         mnemonics="Number of Grid points for Q PoinTs generation",
9836         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
9837         excludes="[[qptrlatt]]",
9838         requires="[[nqpt]] == 1 and [[kptopt]] >= 0",
9839         text="""
9840     At variance with [[ngkpt]], note that only one q point is selected per dataset
9841     (see [[iqpt]]).
9842     Its three positive components give the number of q points of Monkhorst-Pack
9843     grids (defined with respect to primitive axis in reciprocal space) in each of
9844     the three dimensions. The use of [[nshiftq]] and [[shiftq]], allows one to
9845     generate shifted grids, or Monkhorst-Pack grids defined with respect to
9846     conventional unit cells.
9847     
9848     For more information on Monkhorst-Pack grids, see [[ngkpt]].
9849     """,
9850     ),
9851     
9852     Variable(
9853         abivarname="nimage",
9854         varset="rlx",
9855         vartype="integer",
9856         topics=['PIMD_compulsory', 'TransPath_compulsory'],
9857         dimensions="scalar",
9858         defaultval=1,
9859         mnemonics="Number of IMAGEs",
9860         text="""
9861     Give the number of images (or replicas) of the system, for which the forces
9862     and stresses might be computed independently, in the context of the string
9863     method, the genetic algorithm, hyperdynamics or Path-Integral Molecular
9864     Dynamics depending on the value of [[imgmov]]). Related input variables:
9865     [[dynimage]], [[npimage]], [[ntimimage]] and [[prtvolimg]].
9866     Images might differ by the position of atoms in the unit cell, their velocity,
9867     as well as by their cell geometry. The following input variables might be used
9868     to define the images:
9869     
9870       * [[acell]]
9871       * [[amu]]
9872       * [[angdeg]]
9873       * [[dmatpawu]]
9874       * [[jpawu]]
9875       * [[mixalch]]
9876       * [[rprim]]
9877       * [[upawu]]
9878       * [[vel]]
9879       * [[vel_cell]]
9880       * [[xangst]]
9881       * [[xcart]]
9882       * [[xred]]
9883     
9884     These input variables, non-modified, will be used to define the image with
9885     index 1. For the image with the last index, the input file might specify the
9886     values of such input variables, appended with "_lastimg", e.g.:
9887     
9888       * acell_lastimg
9889       * rprim_lastimg
9890       * xcart_lastimg
9891       * ...
9892     
9893     By default, these values will be interpolated linearly to define values for
9894     the other images, unless there exist specific values for some images, for
9895     which the string "last" has to be replaced by the index of the image, e.g. for
9896     the image number 4:
9897     
9898       * acell_4img
9899       * rprim_4img
9900       * xcart_4img
9901       * ...
9902     
9903     It is notably possible to specify the starting point and the end point of the
9904     path (of images), while specifying intermediate points.
9905     
9906     It usually happen that the images do not have the same symmetries and space
9907     group. ABINIT has not been designed to use different set of symmetries for
9908     different images. ABINIT will use the symmetry and space group of the image
9909     number 2, that is expected to have a low number of symmetries. This might lead
9910     to erroneous calculations, in case some image has even less symmetry. By
9911     contrast, there is no problem if some other image has more symmetries than
9912     those of the second image.
9913     """,
9914     ),
9915     
9916     Variable(
9917         abivarname="nkpath",
9918         varset="basic",
9919         vartype="integer",
9920         topics=['k-points_useful'],
9921         dimensions="scalar",
9922         defaultval=0,
9923         mnemonics="Number of K-points defining the PATH",
9924         text="""
9925     This variable is used to define the number of high-symmetry k-points in the
9926     [[kptbounds]] array when [[kptopt]] > 0. Historically, [[kptbounds]] is used
9927     in conjuction with a negative value of [[kptopt]] when performing a NSCF band
9928     structure calculation. In this case, the number of k-points in kptbounds is
9929     given by abs(kptopt) + 1. There are, however, other cases in which one has to
9930     specify a k-path in the input file in order to activate some kind of post-
9931     processing tool. Typical examples are the interpolation of the GW corrections
9932     at the end of the sigma run or the interpolation of the KS eigenvalues along a
9933     path at the end of the SCF run (see also [[einterp]]) In a nutshell, nkpath
9934     replaces [[kptopt]] when we are not performing a NSCF calculation. Note that,
9935     unlike [[kptopt]], nkpath represents the total number of points in the
9936     [[kptbounds]] array.
9937     """,
9938     ),
9939     
9940     Variable(
9941         abivarname="nkpt",
9942         varset="basic",
9943         vartype="integer",
9944         topics=['k-points_useful'],
9945         dimensions="scalar",
9946         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[kptopt]] == 0': 1, 'defaultval': 0}),
9947         mnemonics="Number of K - Points",
9948         text="""
9949     If non-zero, [[nkpt]] gives the number of k points in the k point array
9950     [[kpt]]. These points are used either to sample the Brillouin zone, or to
9951     build a band structure along specified lines.
9952     
9953     If [[nkpt]] is zero, the code deduces from other input variables (see the list
9954     in the description of [[kptopt]]) the number of k points, which is possible
9955     only when [[kptopt]]/=0. If [[kptopt]]/=0 and the input value of [[nkpt]]/=0,
9956     then ABINIT will check that the number of k points generated from the other
9957     input variables is exactly the same than [[nkpt]].
9958     
9959     If [[kptopt]] is positive, [[nkpt]] must be coherent with the values of
9960     [[kptrlatt]], [[nshiftk]] and [[shiftk]].
9961     For ground state calculations, one should select the k point in the
9962     irreducible Brillouin Zone (obtained by taking into account point symmetries
9963     and the time-reversal symmetry).
9964     For response function calculations, one should select k points in the full
9965     Brillouin zone, if the wavevector of the perturbation does not vanish, or in a
9966     half of the Brillouin Zone if q=0. The code will automatically decrease the
9967     number of k points to the minimal set needed for each particular perturbation.
9968     
9969     If [[kptopt]] is negative, [[nkpt]] will be the sum of the number of points on
9970     the different lines of the band structure. For example, if [[kptopt]] = -3, one
9971     will have three segments; supposing [[ndivk]] is 10 12 17, the total number of
9972     k points of the circuit will be 10+12+17+1(for the final point)=40.
9973     """,
9974     ),
9975     
9976     Variable(
9977         abivarname="nkptgw",
9978         varset="gw",
9979         vartype="integer",
9980         topics=['SelfEnergy_basic'],
9981         dimensions="scalar",
9982         defaultval=0,
9983         mnemonics="Number of K-PoinTs for GW corrections",
9984         requires="[[optdriver]] == 4",
9985         text="""
9986     [[nkptgw]] gives the number of k-points for which the GW calculation must be
9987     done. It is used to dimension [[kptgw]].
9988     """,
9989     ),
9990     
9991     Variable(
9992         abivarname="nkpthf",
9993         varset="basic",
9994         vartype="integer",
9995         topics=['Hybrids_expert'],
9996         dimensions="scalar",
9997         mnemonics="Number of K - Points for (Hartree) Fock exact exchange",
9998         text="""
9999     [[nkpthf]] gives the number of k points used to sample the full Brillouin zone
10000     for the Fock exact exchange contribution. It is obtained from the
10001     specification of the wavefunction k point grid (see [[kptopt]]), possibly
10002     downfolded as specified by [[fockdownsampling]].
10003     """,
10004     ),
10005     
10006     Variable(
10007         abivarname="nline",
10008         varset="gstate",
10009         vartype="integer",
10010         topics=['SCFControl_expert'],
10011         dimensions="scalar",
10012         defaultval=4,
10013         mnemonics="Number of LINE minimisations",
10014         text="""
10015     Gives maximum number of line minimizations allowed in preconditioned conjugate
10016     gradient minimization for each band. The default, 4, is fine.
10017     Special cases, with degeneracies or near-degeneracies of levels at the Fermi
10018     energy may require a larger value of [[nline]] (5 or 6 ?). Line minimizations
10019     will be stopped anyway when improvement gets small (governed by [[tolrde]]).
10020     With the input variable [[nnsclo]], governs the convergence of the
10021     wavefunctions for fixed potential.
10022     Note that [[nline]] = 0 can be used to diagonalize the Hamiltonian matrix in the
10023     subspace spanned by the input wavefunctions.
10024     """,
10025     ),
10026     
10027     Variable(
10028         abivarname="nloc_alg",
10029         varset="dev",
10030         vartype="integer",
10031         topics=['TuningSpeed_expert'],
10032         dimensions="scalar",
10033         defaultval=4,
10034         mnemonics="Non LOCal ALGorithm",
10035         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
10036         text=r"""
10037     Allows to choose the algorithm for non-local operator application. On super-
10038     scalar architectures, the default [[nloc_alg]] = 4 is the best.
10039     More detailed explanations:
10040     
10041     - [[nloc_alg]] = 2: Should be efficient on vector machines. It is indeed the
10042       fastest algorithm for the NEC, but actual tests on Fujitsu machine did not
10043       gave better performances than the other options.
10044     - [[nloc_alg]] = 3: same as [[nloc_alg]] == 2, but the loop order is inverted.
10045     - [[nloc_alg]] = 4: same as [[nloc_alg]] == 3, but maximal use of registers has
10046        been coded. This should be especially efficient on scalar and super-scalar
10047        machines. This has been confirmed by tests.
10048     
10049     Note: internally, [[nloc_alg]] is stored in `dtset%nloalg(1)`. See also
10050     [[nloc_mem]] for the tuning of the memory used in the non-local operator application.
10051     """,
10052     ),
10053     
10054     Variable(
10055         abivarname="nloc_mem",
10056         varset="dev",
10057         vartype="integer",
10058         topics=['TuningSpeed_expert'],
10059         dimensions="scalar",
10060         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[usepaw]] == 1': 2, 'defaultval': 1}),
10061         mnemonics="Non LOCal MEMOry",
10062         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
10063         text=r"""
10064     Controls the memory use for the application of the non-local operator.
10065     More detailed explanations:
10066     
10067     - [[nloc_mem]] == 1: (k+G) vectors are not precomputed, in order to save memory space.
10068     - [[nloc_mem]] == 2: (k+G) vectors are precomputed, once per k-point.
10069     - [[nloc_mem]] == -1 or -2: Negative values of [[nloc_mem]] correspond
10070       positive ones, where the phase precomputation has been suppressed, in order to
10071       save memory space, as an array `double precision: ph3d(2,npw,[[natom]])` is
10072       saved (typically half the space needed for the wavefunctions at 1 k point -
10073       this corresponds to the silicon case). However, the computation of phases
10074       inside nonlop is somehow time-consuming.
10075     
10076     Note: internally, sign([[nloc_mem]]) is stored in `dtset%nloalg(2)` and
10077     abs([[nloc_mem]])-1 is stored in `dtset%nloalg(3)`. See also [[nloc_alg]] for the
10078     algorithm for the non-local operator application.
10079     """,
10080     ),
10081     
10082     Variable(
10083         abivarname="nnos",
10084         varset="rlx",
10085         vartype="integer",
10086         topics=['PIMD_basic', 'MolecularDynamics_basic'],
10087         dimensions="scalar",
10088         defaultval=0,
10089         mnemonics="Number of NOSe masses",
10090         text="""
10091     Gives the number of thermostats in the chain of oscillators
10092     thermostats as proposed in [[cite:Martyna1996]]. The thermostat chains can be used either to perform Molecular Dynamics (MD) ([[ionmov]] = 13) or to perform Path Integral Molecular Dynamics
10093     (PIMD) ([[imgmov]] = 13).
10094     The mass of these thermostats is given by [[qmass]].
10095     """,
10096     ),
10097     
10098     Variable(
10099         abivarname="nnsclo",
10100         varset="dev",
10101         vartype="integer",
10102         topics=['SCFControl_expert'],
10103         dimensions="scalar",
10104         defaultval=0,
10105         mnemonics="Number of Non-Self Consistent LOops",
10106         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
10107         text="""
10108     Gives the maximum number of non-self-consistent loops of [[nline]] line
10109     minimisations, in the SCF case (when [[iscf]] >0). In the case [[iscf]] <=0,
10110     the number of non-self-consistent loops is determined by [[nstep]].
10111     
10112         * The Default value of 0 -- for standard plane-wave calculations -- corresponds
10113         to make the two first fixed potential determinations of wavefunctions have 2
10114         non-self consistent loops, and the next ones to have only 1 non-self
10115         consistent loop.
10116     
10117         * The Default value of 0 -- for wavelets calculations ([[usewvl]] = 1) --
10118         corresponds to make 2 steps with 3 non-self consistent loops, 2 steps with 2
10119         non-self consistent loops, then the next ones with 1 non-self consistent loop.
10120     """,
10121     ),
10122     
10123     Variable(
10124         abivarname="nnsclohf",
10125         varset="dev",
10126         vartype="integer",
10127         topics=['Hybrids_expert'],
10128         dimensions="scalar",
10129         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[usefock]] == 1': 1, 'defaultval': 0}),
10130         mnemonics="Number of Non-Self Consistent LOops for (Hartree)-Fock exact exchange",
10131         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
10132         text="""
10133     Gives the maximum number of loops with non-self-consistent occupied states
10134     used to calculate Fock exact exchange, in the SCF case.
10135     The Default value is 0 when [[usefock]] = 0. Default value is 1 when
10136     [[usefock]] = 1 and correspond to update occupied wavefunctions at each self-
10137     consistent loop.
10138     """,
10139     ),
10140     
10141     Variable(
10142         abivarname="nobj",
10143         varset="geo",
10144         vartype="integer",
10145         topics=['AtomManipulator_compulsory'],
10146         dimensions="scalar",
10147         defaultval=0,
10148         mnemonics="Number of OBJects",
10149         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
10150         text="""
10151     Gives the number of 'objects' to be used by the atom manipulator in order to
10152     find the full set of atoms. At present, only one or two objects can be
10153     defined, identified as objects 'a' and 'b'.
10154     Related variables for object 'a' are: [[objan]], [[objaat]], [[objarf]],
10155     [[objatr]], [[objaro]], [[objaax]]. Related variables for object 'b' are:
10156     [[objbn]], [[objbat]], [[objbrf]], [[objbtr]], [[objbro]], [[objbax]].
10157     
10158     More detailed explanation: when the atom manipulator is used (i.e. when
10159     [[nobj]] == 1 or [[nobj]] == 2), the code will be given a primitive set of atoms,
10160     from which it will have to deduce the full set of atoms.
10161     An object will be specified by the number of atoms it includes ([[objan]] or
10162     [[objbn]] ), and the list of these atoms ([[objaat]] or [[objbat]] ).
10163     Examples of physical realisation of an object can be a molecule, or a group of
10164     atom to be repeated, or a part of a molecule to be rotated. The atom
10165     amnipulator can indeed repeat these objects ([[objarf]] or [[objbrf]] ),
10166     rotate them ([[objaro]] or [[objbro]] ) with respect to an axis ([[objaax]] or
10167     [[objbax]] ), and translate them ([[objatr]] or [[objbtr]] ). After having
10168     generated a geometry thanks to rotation, translation and repetition of
10169     objects, it is possible to remove some atoms, in order to create vacancies
10170     ([[vacnum]] and [[vaclst]]). The number of atoms in the primitive set, those
10171     that will be read from the input file, is specified by the variable [[natrd]].
10172     It will be always smaller than the final number of atoms, given by the
10173     variable [[natom]]. The code checks whether the primitive number of atoms plus
10174     those obtained by the repetition operation is coherent with the variable
10175     [[natom]], taking into account possible vacancies.
10176     You should look at the other variables for more information.
10177     Go to [[objan]], for example.
10178     """,
10179     ),
10180     
10181     Variable(
10182         abivarname="nomegasf",
10183         varset="gw",
10184         vartype="integer",
10185         topics=['Susceptibility_basic'],
10186         dimensions="scalar",
10187         defaultval=0,
10188         mnemonics="Number of OMEGA to evaluate the Spectral Function",
10189         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
10190         requires="[[optdriver]] == 3 and [[spmeth]]!=0",
10191         text=r"""
10192     [[nomegasf]] defines the number of real frequencies used to describe the
10193     spectral function associated to the irreducible polarizability
10194     $\chi^{(0)}_{KS}$. The frequency mesh will cover the interval between 0 and
10195     the maximum (positive) transition energy between occupied and empty states.
10196     The delta function entering the expression defining the spectral function is
10197     approximated using two different methods according to the value of the
10198     [[spmeth]] input variable.
10199     
10200     It is important to notice that an accurate description of the imaginary part
10201     of $\chi^{(0)}_{KS}$ requires an extremely dense frequency mesh. It should be
10202     kept in mind, however, that the memory required grows fast with the value of [[nomegasf]].
10203     """,
10204     ),
10205     
10206     Variable(
10207         abivarname="nomegasi",
10208         varset="gw",
10209         vartype="integer",
10210         topics=['SelfEnergy_basic'],
10211         dimensions="scalar",
10212         defaultval=12,
10213         mnemonics="Number of OMEGA(S) along the Imaginary axis",
10214         requires="[[optdriver]] == 4 and [[gwcalctyp]] == 1",
10215         text="""
10216     [[nomegasi]] defines the number of frequency points used to sample the self-
10217     energy along the imaginary axis. The frequency mesh is linear and covers the
10218     interval between `omegasimin`=0.01 Hartree and [[omegasimax]].
10219     """,
10220     ),
10221     
10222     Variable(
10223         abivarname="nomegasrd",
10224         varset="gw",
10225         vartype="integer",
10226         topics=['SelfEnergy_useful'],
10227         dimensions="scalar",
10228         defaultval=9,
10229         mnemonics="Number of OMEGA to evaluate the Sigma Real axis Derivative",
10230         requires="[[optdriver]] == 4",
10231         text="""
10232     The number of real frequencies around the KS energy where the self-energy
10233     $\Sigma$ is evaluated. From these values, the derivative of $\Sigma$ at the KS
10234     energy is numerically estimated through linear interpolation.
10235     """,
10236     ),
10237     
10238     Variable(
10239         abivarname="normpawu",
10240         varset="dev",
10241         vartype="integer",
10242         topics=['DFT+U_expert'],
10243         dimensions=['[[ntypat]]'],
10244         defaultval=0,
10245         mnemonics="NORMalize atomic PAW+U projector",
10246         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
10247         text="""
10248     Defines whether the atomic wave function (used as projectors in PAW+U) should
10249     be renormalized to 1 within PAW sphere.
10250     
10251       * [[normpawu]] = 0: leave projector

10256     Variable(
10257         abivarname="noseinert",
10258         varset="rlx",
10259         vartype="real",
10260         topics=['MolecularDynamics_useful'],
10261         dimensions="scalar",
10262         defaultval=100000,
10263         mnemonics="NOSE thermostat INERTia factor",
10264         requires="[[ionmov]] == 8",
10265         text="""
10266     Give the inertia factor WT of the Nose-Hoover thermostat (when [[ionmov]] = 8),
10267     in atomic units of weight*length2, that is (electron mass)*(Bohr)2. The
10268     equations of motion are: MI d2RI/dt2= FI - dX/dt MI dRI/dt and WT d2X/dt2=
10269     Sum(I) MI (dRI/dt)2 - 3NkBT where I represent each nucleus, MI is the mass of
10270     each nucleus (see [[amu]]), RI is the coordinate of each nucleus (see
10271     [[xcart]]), dX/dt is a dynamical friction coefficient, and T is the
10272     temperature of the thermostat (see [[mdtemp]]).
10273     """,
10274     ),
10275     
10276     Variable(
10277         abivarname="np_slk",
10278         varset="paral",
10279         vartype="integer",
10280         topics=['parallelism_expert'],
10281         dimensions="scalar",
10282         defaultval=1000000,
10283         mnemonics="Number of mpi Processors used for ScaLapacK calls",
10284         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
10285         requires="[[optdriver]] == 1 and [[paral_kgb]] == 1 (Ground-state calculations with LOBPCG algorithm)",
10286         text="""
10287     When using Scalapack (or any similar Matrix Algebra library), the efficiency
10288     of the eigenproblem resolution saturates as the number of CPU cores increases.
10289     It is better to use a smaller number of CPU cores for the LINALG calls.
10290     This maximum number of cores can be set with [[np_slk]].
10291     A large number for [[np_slk]] (i.e. 1000000) means that all cores are used for
10292     the Linear Algebra calls.
10293     np_slk must divide the number of processors involved in diagonalizations
10294     ([[npband]] $\\times$ [[npfft]] $\\times$ [[npspinor]]).
10295     Note (bef v8.8): an optimal value for this parameter can be automatically found by using
10296     the [[autoparal]] input keyword.
10297     Note (since v8.8 and only for LOBPCG ([[wfoptalg]] == 114) with [[paral_kgb]] = 1):
10298     * If set to ***0*** then scalapack is disabled.
10299     * If set to its ***default value***, then abinit uses between 2 and [[npband]]*[[npfft]]*[[npspinor]] cpus according to the system size (default auto behaviour).
10300       See [[slk_rankpp]] for more customization.
10301     * If set to a number ***>1** then forces abinit to use exactly this number of cpus.
10302       Due to legacy behaviour, although it is not mandatory in theory, this value *must* divide [[npband]]*[[npfft]]*[[npspinor]].
10303     See also [[slk_rankpp]] for a better tuning instead of this variable.
10304     """,
10305     ),
10306     
10307     Variable(
10308         abivarname="npband",
10309         varset="paral",
10310         vartype="integer",
10311         topics=['parallelism_useful'],
10312         dimensions="scalar",
10313         defaultval=1,
10314         mnemonics="Number of Processors at the BAND level",
10315         requires="[[paral_kgb]] == 1",
10316         text="""
10317     Relevant only for the band/FFT parallelisation (see the [[paral_kgb]] input
10318     variable).
10319     [[npband]] gives the number of processors among which the work load over the
10320     band level is shared. [[npband]], [[npfft]], [[npkpt]] and [[npspinor]] are
10321     combined to give the total number of processors (nproc) working on the
10322     band/FFT/k-point parallelisation.
10323     See [[npfft]], [[npkpt]], [[npspinor]] and [[paral_kgb]] for the additional
10324     information on the use of band/FFT/k-point parallelisation. [[npband]] has to
10325     be a divisor or equal to [[nband]]
10326     Note: an optimal value for this parameter can be automatically found by using
10327     the [[autoparal]] input keyword.
10328     """,
10329     ),
10330     
10331     Variable(
10332         abivarname="npfft",
10333         varset="paral",
10334         vartype="integer",
10335         topics=['parallelism_useful'],
10336         dimensions="scalar",
10337         defaultval=1,
10338         mnemonics="Number of Processors at the FFT level",
10339         requires="[[paral_kgb]] == 1",
10340         text="""
10341     Relevant only for the band/FFT/k-point parallelisation (see the [[paral_kgb]]
10342     input variable).
10343     [[npfft]] gives the number of processors among which the work load over the
10344     FFT level is shared. [[npfft]], [[npkpt]], [[npband]] and [[npspinor]] are
10345     combined to give the total number of processors (nproc) working on the
10346     band/FFT/k-point parallelisation.
10347     See [[npband]], [[npkpt]], [[npspinor]], and [[paral_kgb]] for the additional
10348     information on the use of band/FFT/k-point parallelisation.
10349     
10350     Note: [[ngfft]] is automatically adjusted to [[npfft]]. If the number of
10351     processor is changed from a calculation to another one, [[npfft]] may change,
10352     and then [[ngfft]] also.
10353     Note: an optimal value for this parameter can be automatically found by using
10354     the [[autoparal]] input keyword.
10355     """,
10356     ),
10357     
10358     Variable(
10359         abivarname="nphf",
10360         varset="paral",
10361         vartype="integer",
10362         topics=['Hybrids_useful', 'parallelism_useful'],
10363         dimensions="scalar",
10364         defaultval=1,
10365         mnemonics="Number of Processors for (Hartree)-Fock exact exchange",
10366         text="""
10367     Relevant only for the k-point/fock parallelisation (option [[paral_kgb]] input
10368     variable).
10369     [[nphf]] gives the number of processors among which the work load over the
10370     occupied states level is shared. [[nphf]] and [[npkpt]] are combined to give
10371     the total number of processors (nproc) working on the parallelisation.
10372     
10373     Note: [[nphf]] should be a divisor or equal to the number of k-point times
10374     the number of bands for exact exchange ([[nkpthf]] $\\times$ [[nbandhf]]) in order to
10375     have the better load-balancing and efficiency.
10376     """,

10391     image level is shared. It is compatible with all other parallelization levels
10392     available for ground-state calculations.

10406         dimensions="scalar",
10407         defaultval=1,

10410         text="""
10411     Relevant only for the band/FFT/k-point parallelisation (see the [[paral_kgb]]
10412     input variable).
10413     [[npkpt]] gives the number of processors among which the work load over the
10414     k-point/spin-component level is shared. [[npkpt]], [[npfft]], [[npband]] and
10415     [[npspinor]] are combined to give the total number of processors (nproc)
10416     working on the band/FFT/k-point parallelisation.
10417     See [[npband]], [[npfft]], [[npspinor]] and [[paral_kgb]] for the additional
10418     information on the use of band/FFT/k-point parallelisation.
10419     
10420     [[npkpt]] should be a divisor or equal to with the number of k-point/spin-
10421     components ([[nkpt]] $\\times$ [[nsppol]]) in order to have the better load-balancing
10422     and efficiency.
10423     Note: an optimal value for this parameter can be automatically found by using
10424     the [[autoparal]] input keyword.
10425     """,
10426     ),

10446     Variable(
10447         abivarname="npsp",
10448         varset="gstate",
10449         vartype="integer",
10450         topics=['AtomTypes_useful', 'PseudosPAW_expert'],
10451         dimensions="scalar",
10452         defaultval="[[ntypat]]",
10453         mnemonics="Number of PSeudoPotentials",
10454         characteristics=['[[NO_MULTI]]'],
10455         text="""
10456     Usually, the number of pseudopotentials to be read is equal to the number of
10457     type of atoms. However, in the case an alchemical mixing of pseudopotential is
10458     to be used, often the number of pseudopotentials to be read will not equal the
10459     number of types of atoms.
10460     
10461     Alchemical pseudopotentials will be present when [[ntypalch]] is non-zero. See
10462     [[ntypalch]] to understand how to use alchemical potentials in ABINIT. The
10463     input variables ([[ntypalch]], [[algalch]], [[mixalch]]) are active, and
10464     generate alchemical potentials from the available pseudopotentials. Also, the
10465     inner variables ([[ntyppure]], [[npspalch]]) become active. See these input
10466     variables, especially [[mixalch]], to understand how to use alchemical
10467     potentials in ABINIT.
10468     """,
10469     ),
10470

10541     [[npvel]] sets the number of the ion velocities to be calculated via linear response.
10542     When [[npvel]] = 0, no stopping power calculation is performed.
10543     The direction and the velocity maximum are set with the input variable
10544     [[pvelmax]]. Note that the results are output for a $Z=1$ impinging ion, i.e. a proton.
10545     """,

10548     Variable(
10549         abivarname="npweps",

10553         dimensions="scalar",
10554         mnemonics="Number of PlaneWaves for EPSilon (the dielectric matrix)",
10555         characteristics=['[[INTERNAL_ONLY]]'],
10556         text=r"""
10557     [[npweps]] determines the size of the planewave set used to represent the
10558     independent-particle susceptibility $\chi^{(0)}_{KS}$, the dielectric matrix
10559     $\epsilon$ and its inverse.
10560     It is an internal variable, determined from [[ecuteps]].
10561     """,
10562     ),
10563     
10564     Variable(
10565         abivarname="npwkss",
10566         varset="gw",
10567         vartype="integer",
10568         topics=['Susceptibility_expert', 'SelfEnergy_expert'],
10569         dimensions="scalar",
10570         defaultval=0,
10571         mnemonics="Number of PlaneWaves in the KSS file",
10572         text="""
10573     This input variable is used for the preparation of a GW calculation: the GS
10574     run (where [[optdriver]] = 1 and [[nbandkss]]/=0) should be followed with a run
10575     where [[optdriver]] = 3. Also, if [[nbandkss]] = 0, no use of [[npwkss]].
10576     
10577     [[npwkss]] defines the number of planewave components of the Kohn-Sham states
10578     to build the Hamiltonian, in the routine outkss.F90, and so, the size of the
10579     matrix, the size of eigenvectors, and the number of available states, to be
10580     stored in the abo_KSS file. If it is set to 0, then, the planewave basis set
10581     defined by the usual Ground State input variable [[ecut]] is used to generate
10582     the superset of all planewaves used for all k points. Note that this (large)
10583     planewave basis is the same for all k points.
10584     
10585     !!! warning
10586
