10587         For the time being, [[istwfk]] must be 1 for all the k points.
10588     """,
10589     ),
10590     
10591     Variable(
10592         abivarname="npwsigx",
10593         varset="internal",
10594         vartype="integer",
10595         topics=['SelfEnergy_internal'],
10596         dimensions="scalar",
10597         mnemonics="Number of PlaneWaves for SIGma eXchange",
10598         characteristics=['[[INTERNAL_ONLY]]'],
10599         text="""
10600     [[npwsigx]] determines the cut-off energy of the planewave set used to
10601     generate the exchange part of the self-energy operator.
10602     It is an internal variable, determined from [[ecutsigx]].
10603     """,
10604     ),
10605     
10606     Variable(
10607         abivarname="npwwfn",
10608         varset="internal",
10609         vartype="integer",
10610         topics=['Susceptibility_internal', 'SelfEnergy_internal'],
10611         dimensions="scalar",
10612         mnemonics="Number of PlaneWaves for WaveFunctioNs",
10613         characteristics=['[[INTERNAL_ONLY]]'],
10614         text=r"""
10615     [[npwwfn]] is the size of the planewave set used to represent the
10616     wavefunctions in the formula that generates the independent-particle
10617     susceptibility $\chi^{(0)}_{KS}$. It is an internal variable, determined from [[ecutwfn]].
10618     """,
10619     ),
10620     
10621     Variable(
10622         abivarname="nqpt",
10623         varset="gstate",
10624         vartype="integer",
10625         topics=['q-points_basic'],
10626         dimensions="scalar",
10627         defaultval=0,
10628         mnemonics="Number of Q - POINTs",
10629         text="""
10630     Determines whether one q point must be read (See the variable [[qptn]]).
10631     Can be either 0 or 1.
10632     
10633     If 1 and used in ground-state calculation, a global shift of all the k-points
10634     is applied, to give calculation at k+q. In this case, the output wavefunction
10635     will be appended by _WFQ instead of _WFK
10636     Also, if 1 and a RF calculation is done, defines the wavevector of the perturbation.
10637     
10638     For further information about the *files file*, consult the [[help:abinit#files-file]].
10639     """,
10640     ),
10641     
10642     Variable(
10643         abivarname="nqptdm",
10644         varset="gw",
10645         vartype="integer",
10646         topics=['Susceptibility_useful'],
10647         dimensions="scalar",
10648         defaultval=0,
10649         mnemonics="Number of Q-PoinTs for the Dielectric Matrix",
10650         requires="[[optdriver]] == 3",
10651         text="""
10652     If [[nqptdm]] is equal to 0, the set of q points for computing the dielectric
10653     matrix is determined automatically considering all the possible differences
10654     between the k-points contained in the _KSS file. When [[nqptdm]] is non-zero,
10655     the list of q points is read from [[qptdm]]. This allows one to split the big
10656     calculation of all the dielectric matrices into smaller calculations that can
10657     be performed independently. The _SCR files generated in different runs can be
10658     merged thanks to the **Mrgscr** utility. If [[nqptdm]] is equal to -1, the
10659     code reports the list of q-points in the log file (YAML format) and then stops.
10660     """,
10661     ),
10662     
10663     Variable(
10664         abivarname="nscforder",
10665         varset="dev",
10666         vartype="integer",
10667         topics=['Coulomb_expert'],
10668         dimensions="scalar",
10669         defaultval=16,
10670         mnemonics="Nth - SCaling Function ORDER",
10671         text="""
10672     This variable controls the order of used scaling functions when the Hartree
10673     potential is computed using the Poisson solver (see [[icoulomb]] input
10674     variable). This variable is of seldom use since the default value is large
10675     enough. Nonetheless, possible values are 8, 14, 16, 20, 24, 30, 40, 50, 60,
10676     100. Values greater than 20 are included in ABINIT for test purposes only.
10677     """,
10678     ),
10679     
10680     Variable(
10681         abivarname="nshiftk",
10682         varset="basic",
10683         vartype="integer",
10684         topics=['k-points_useful'],
10685         dimensions="scalar",
10686         defaultval=1,
10687         mnemonics="Number of SHIFTs for K point grids",
10688         text="""
10689     This parameter gives the number of shifted grids to be used concurrently to
10690     generate the full grid of k points. It can be used with primitive grids
10691     defined either from [[ngkpt]] or [[kptrlatt]]. The maximum allowed value of
10692     [[nshiftk]] is 8. The values of the shifts are given by [[shiftk]].
10693     """,
10694     ),
10695     
10696     Variable(
10697         abivarname="nshiftq",
10698         varset="gstate",
10699         vartype="integer",
10700         topics=['q-points_useful'],
10701         dimensions="scalar",
10702         defaultval=1,
10703         mnemonics="Number of SHIFTs for Q point grids",
10704         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
10705         text="""
10706     This parameter gives the number of shifted grids to be used concurrently to
10707     generate the full grid of q points. It can be used with primitive grids
10708     defined either from [[ngqpt]] or [[qptrlatt]]. The maximum allowed value of
10709     [[nshiftq]] is 8. The values of the shifts are given by [[shiftq]].
10710     """,
10711     ),
10712     
10713     Variable(
10714         abivarname="nspden",
10715         varset="gstate",
10716         vartype="integer",
10717         topics=['spinpolarisation_basic'],
10718         dimensions="scalar",
10719         defaultval="[[nsppol]]",
10720         mnemonics="Number of SPin-DENsity components",
10721         text="""
10722     If [[nspden]] = 1, no spin-magnetization the density matrix is diagonal, with
10723     same values spin-up and spin-down (compatible with [[nsppol]] = 1 only, for both
10724     [[nspinor]] = 1 or 2)
10725     
10726     If [[nspden]] = 2, scalar magnetization (the axis is arbitrarily fixed in the z
10727     direction) the density matrix is diagonal, with different values for spin-up
10728     and spin-down (compatible with [[nspinor]] = 1, either with [[nsppol]] = 2
10729     -general collinear magnetization- or [[nsppol]] = 1 -antiferromagnetism)
10730     
10731     If [[nspden]] = 4, vector magnetization: the density matrix is full, with
10732     allowed x, y and z magnetization (useful only with [[nspinor]] = 2 and
10733     [[nsppol]] = 1, either because there is spin-orbit without time-reversal
10734     symmetry - and thus spontaneous magnetization, or with spin-orbit, if one
10735     allows for spontaneous non-collinear magnetism). Not yet available for
10736     response functions. Also note that, with [[nspden]] = 4, time-reversal symmetry
10737     is not taken into account (at present; this has to be checked) and thus
10738     [[kptopt]] has to be different from 1 or 2.
10739     
10740     The default ([[nspden]] = [[nsppol]]) does not suit the case of vector magnetization.
10741     """,
10742     ),
10743     
10744     Variable(
10745         abivarname="nspinor",
10746         varset="gstate",
10747         vartype="integer",
10748         topics=['spinpolarisation_basic'],
10749         dimensions="scalar",
10750         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[pawspnorb]] == 1': 2, 'defaultval': 1}),
10751         mnemonics="Number of SPINORial components of the wavefunctions",
10752         text="""
10753     If [[nspinor]] = 1, usual case: scalar wavefunction (compatible with
10754     ([[nsppol]] = 1, [[nspden]] = 1) as well as ([[nsppol]] = 2, [[nspden]] = 2) )
10755     
10756     If [[nspinor]] = 2, the wavefunction is a spinor (compatible with [[nsppol]] = 1,
10757     with [[nspden]] = 1 or 4, but not with [[nsppol]] = 2)
10758     
10759     When [[nspinor]] is 2, the values of [[istwfk]] are automatically set to 1.
10760     Also, the number of bands, for each k-point, should be even.
10761     """,
10762     ),
10763     
10764     Variable(
10765         abivarname="nsppol",
10766         varset="basic",
10767         vartype="integer",
10768         topics=['spinpolarisation_basic'],
10769         dimensions="scalar",
10770         defaultval=1,
10771         mnemonics="Number of SPin POLarization",
10772         text="""
10773     Give the number of INDEPENDENT spin polarisations, for which there are non-
10774     related wavefunctions. Can take the values 1 or 2.
10775     
10776     If [[nsppol]] = 1, one has an unpolarized calculation ([[nspinor]] = 1,
10777     [[nspden]] = 1) or an antiferromagnetic system ([[nspinor]] = 1, [[nspden]] = 2), or
10778     a calculation in which spin up and spin down cannot be disentangled
10779     ([[nspinor]] = 2), that is, either non-collinear magnetism or presence of spin-
10780     orbit coupling, for which one needs spinor wavefunctions.
10781     
10782     If [[nsppol]] = 2, one has a spin-polarized (collinear) calculation with
10783     separate and different wavefunctions for up and down spin electrons for each
10784     band and k point. Compatible only with [[nspinor]] == 1, [[nspden]] == 2. If
10785     [[nsppol]] = 2, one usually uses a metallic value for [[occopt]], in order to
10786     let ABINIT find the magnetization. On the contrary, if [[occopt]] == 1 is used,
10787     the user has to impose the magnetization, using [[spinmagntarget]], except for
10788     the case of a single isolated Hydrogen atom.
10789     
10790     In the present status of development, with [[nsppol]] = 1, all values of [[ixc]]
10791     are allowed, while with [[nsppol]] = 2, some values of [[ixc]] might not be
10792     allowed (e.g. 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 20, 21, 22 are not allowed).
10793     
10794     See also the input variable [[nspden]] for the components of the density
10795     matrix with respect to the spin-polarization.
10796     """,
10797     ),
10798     
10799     Variable(
10800         abivarname="nstep",
10801         varset="basic",
10802         vartype="integer",
10803         topics=['SCFControl_basic'],
10804         dimensions="scalar",
10805         defaultval=30,
10806         mnemonics="Number of (non-)self-consistent field STEPS",
10807         text="""
10808     Gives the maximum number of cycles (or "iterations") in a SCF or non-SCF run.
10809     Full convergence from random numbers is usually achieved in 12-20 SCF
10810     iterations. Each can take from minutes to hours. In certain difficult cases,
10811     usually related to a small or zero bandgap or magnetism, convergence
10812     performance may be much worse. When the convergence tolerance [[tolwfr]] on
10813     the wavefunctions is satisfied, iterations will stop, so for well converged
10814     calculations you should set [[nstep]] to a value larger than you think will be
10815     needed for full convergence, e.g. if using 20 steps usually converges the
10816     system, set [[nstep]] to 30.
10817     For non-self-consistent runs ( [[iscf]] < 0) nstep governs the number of
10818     cycles of convergence for the wavefunctions for a fixed density and Hamiltonian.
10819     
10820     NOTE that a choice of [[nstep]] = 0 is permitted; this will either read
10821     wavefunctions from disk (with [[irdwfk]] = 1 or [[irdwfq]] = 1, or non-zero
10822     [[getwfk]] or [[getwfq]] in the case of multi-dataset) and compute the
10823     density, the total energy and stop, or else (with all of the above vanishing)
10824     will initialize randomly the wavefunctions and compute the resulting density
10825     and total energy. This is provided for testing purposes.
10826     Also NOTE that [[nstep]] = 0 with [[irdwfk]] = 1 will exactly give the same result
10827     as the previous run only if the latter is done with [[iscf]]<10 (potential
10828     mixing).
10829     One can output the density by using [[prtden]].
10830     The forces and stress tensor are computed with [[nstep]] = 0.
10831     """,
10832     ),
10833     
10834     Variable(
10835         abivarname="nsym",
10836         varset="basic",
10837         vartype="integer",
10838         topics=['crystal_useful', 'GW_useful'],
10839         dimensions="scalar",
10840         defaultval=0,
10841         mnemonics="Number of SYMmetry operations",
10842         text="""
10843     Gives number of space group symmetries to be applied in this problem.
10844     Symmetries will be input in array "[[symrel]]" and (nonsymmorphic)
10845     translations vectors will be input in array "[[tnons]]". If there is no
10846     symmetry in the problem then set [[nsym]] to 1, because the identity is still
10847     a symmetry.
10848     In case of a RF calculation, the code is able to use the symmetries of the
10849     system to decrease the number of perturbations to be calculated, and to
10850     decrease of the number of special k points to be used for the sampling of the
10851     Brillouin zone. After the response to the perturbations have been calculated,
10852     the symmetries are used to generate as many as possible elements of the 2DTE
10853     from those already computed.
10854     
10855     **Symmetry finder mode** (Default mode).
10856     If [[nsym]] is 0, all the atomic coordinates must be explicitly given (one
10857     cannot use the atom manipulator neither the smart symmetrizer): the code will
10858     then find automatically the symmetry operations that leave the lattice and
10859     each atomic sublattice invariant. It also checks whether the cell is primitive
10860     (see [[chkprim]]).
10861     Note that the tolerance on symmetric atomic positions and lattice is rather
10862     stringent: for a symmetry operation to be admitted, the lattice and atomic
10863     positions must map on themselves within 1.0e-8.
10864     
10865     The user is allowed to set up systems with non-primitive unit cells (i.e.
10866     conventional FCC or BCC cells, or supercells without any distortion). In this
10867     case, pure translations will be identified as symmetries of the system by the
10868     symmetry finder. Then, the combined "pure translation + usual rotation and
10869     inversion" symmetry operations can be very numerous. For example, a
10870     conventional FCC cell has 192 symmetry operations, instead of the 48 ones of
10871     the primitive cell. A maximum limit of 384 symmetry operations is hard-coded.
10872     This corresponds to the maximum number of symmetry operations of a 2x2x2
10873     undistorted supercell. Going beyond that number will make the code stop very
10874     rapidly. If you want nevertheless, for testing purposes, to treat a larger
10875     number of symmetries, change [[maxnsym]].
10876     
10877     For GW calculation, the user might want to select only the symmetry operations
10878     whose non-symmorphic translation vector [[tnons]] is zero. This can be done
10879     with the help of the input variable [[symmorphi]]
10880     """,
10881     ),
10882     
10883     Variable(
10884         abivarname="ntime",
10885         varset="rlx",
10886         vartype="integer",
10887         topics=['MolecularDynamics_basic', 'GeoOpt_basic'],
10888         dimensions="scalar",
10889         defaultval=0,
10890         mnemonics="Number of TIME steps",
10891         text="""
10892     Gives the number of molecular dynamics time steps or Broyden structural
10893     optimization steps to be done if [[ionmov]] is non-zero.
10894     Note that at the present the option [[ionmov]] = 1 is initialized with four
10895     Runge-Kutta steps which costs some overhead in the startup. By contrast, the
10896     initialisation of other [[ionmov]] values is only one SCF call.
10897     [[ntime]] is ignored if [[ionmov]] = 0.
10898     """,
10899     ),
10900     
10901     Variable(
10902         abivarname="ntimimage",
10903         varset="rlx",
10904         vartype="integer",
10905         topics=['PIMD_compulsory', 'TransPath_compulsory'],
10906         dimensions="scalar",
10907         defaultval=1,
10908         mnemonics="Number of TIME steps for IMAGE propagation",
10909         text="""
10910     Gives the maximal number of molecular dynamics time steps or structural
10911     optimization steps to be done for the set of images, referred to as 'image-
10912     timesteps'. At each image-timestep, all the images are propagated
10913     simultaneously, each according to the algorithm determined by [[imgmov]] and
10914     the usual accompanying input variables, and then the next positions and
10915     velocities for each image are determined from the set of results obtained for
10916     all images.
10917     """,
10918     ),
10919     
10920     Variable(
10921         abivarname="ntypalch",
10922         varset="gstate",
10923         vartype="integer",
10924         topics=['AtomTypes_useful'],
10925         dimensions="scalar",
10926         defaultval=0,
10927         mnemonics='Number of TYPe of atoms that are "ALCHemical"',
10928         text="""
10929     Used for the generation of alchemical pseudopotentials: when [[ntypalch]] is
10930     non-zero, alchemical mixing will be used.
10931     
10932     Among the [[ntypat]] types of atoms, the last [[ntypalch]] will be
10933     "alchemical" pseudoatoms, while only the first [[ntyppure]] will be uniquely
10934     associated with a pseudopotential (the [[ntyppure]] first of these, actually).
10935     The [[ntypalch]] types of alchemical pseudoatoms are to be made from the
10936     remaining [[npspalch]] pseudopotentials.
10937     
10938     In this case, the input variables [[algalch]], [[mixalch]] are active, and
10939     generate alchemical potentials from the available pseudopotentials. See these
10940     input variables, especially [[mixalch]], to understand how to use alchemical
10941     potentials in ABINIT.
10942     """,
10943     ),
10944     
10945     Variable(
10946         abivarname="ntypat",
10947         varset="basic",
10948         vartype="integer",
10949         topics=['AtomTypes_compulsory', 'PseudosPAW_compulsory', 'crystal_basic'],
10950         dimensions="scalar",
10951         defaultval=1,
10952         mnemonics="Number of TYPes of AToms",
10953         characteristics=['[[NO_MULTI]]'],
10954         text="""
10955     Gives the number of types of atoms.
10956     E.g. for a homopolar system (e.g. pure Si) [[ntypat]] is 1.
10957     
10958     The code tries to read the same number of pseudopotential files. The first
10959     pseudopotential is assigned type number 1, and so on...
10960     
10961     There is an exception in the case of alchemical mixing of potentials, for
10962     which there is a different number of pseudopotentials atomic types. See
10963     [[mixalch]].
10964     """,
10965     ),
10966     
10967     Variable(
10968         abivarname="ntyppure",
10969         varset="gstate",
10970         vartype="integer",
10971         topics=['AtomTypes_internal'],
10972         dimensions="scalar",
10973         defaultval="[[ntypat]]-[[ntypalch]]",
10974         mnemonics='Number of TYPe of atoms that are "PURE"',
10975         characteristics=['[[INTERNAL_ONLY]]'],
10976         text="""
10977     Gives the number of type of atoms that are "pure" when alchemical mixing is
10978     used ([[ntypalch]] /= 0):
10979     
10980     [[ntyppure]] = [[ntypat]] - [[ntypalch]]
10981     """,
10982     ),
10983     
10984     Variable(
10985         abivarname="nucdipmom",
10986         varset="gstate",
10987         vartype="real",
10988         topics=['MagField_expert'],
10989         dimensions=[3, '[[natom]]'],
10990         defaultval=0.0,
10991         mnemonics="NUClear DIPole MOMents",
10992         requires="[[usepaw]] = 1; [[pawcpxocc]] = 2; [[kptopt]] > 2",
10993         text="""
10994     Places an array of nuclear magnetic dipole moments on the atomic positions,
10995     useful for computing the magnetization in the presence of nuclear dipoles and
10996     thus the chemical shielding by the converse method. The presence of these
10997     dipoles breaks time reversal symmetry and lowers the overall spatial symmetry.
10998     """,
10999     ),
11000     
11001     Variable(
11002         abivarname="nwfshist",
11003         varset="gstate",
11004         vartype="integer",
11005         topics=['Wavelets_useful'],
11006         dimensions="scalar",
11007         defaultval=0,
11008         mnemonics="Number of WaveFunctionS HISTory",
11009         text="""
11010     In the wavelet basis set, the ground state is found by direct minimisation.
11011     The algorithm used can be either the steepest descent or the DIIS (Direct
11012     Inversion of Iteration Space). \n
11013     When [[nwfshist]] = 0, the steepest descent is
11014     used ( _i.e._ there is no history storage of the previous iterations). \n
11015     If [[nwfshist]] is strictly positive, a DIIS is used. A typical value is 6. Using
11016     a DIIS increases the memory required by the program since N previous
11017     wavefunctions are stored during the electronic minimisation.
11018     """,
11019     ),
11020     
11021     Variable(
11022         abivarname="nzchempot",
11023         varset="geo",
11024         vartype="integer",
11025         topics=['Artificial_expert'],
11026         dimensions="scalar",
11027         mnemonics="Number of Z reduced coordinates that define the spatial CHEMical POTential",
11028         text="""
11029     Defines the number of z reduced coordinates that defines the spatially varying
11030     chemical potential. See the input variable [[chempot]], of which [[nzchempot]]
11031     is the second dimension.
11032     """,
11033     ),
11034     
11035     Variable(
11036         abivarname="objaat",
11037         varset="geo",
11038         vartype="integer",
11039         topics=['AtomManipulator_basic'],
11040         dimensions=['[[objan]]'],
11041         mnemonics="OBJect A: list of AToms",
11042         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
11043         requires="'[[nobj]] == 1'",
11044         text="""
11045     Gives the list of atoms in object a. This list is specified by giving, for
11046     each atom, its index in the list of coordinates ([[xred]], [[xangst]] or
11047     [[xcart]]), that also corresponds to a type of atom (given by the array type).
11048     These objects can be thought as molecules, or groups of atoms, or parts of
11049     molecules, to be repeated, rotated and translated to generate the full set of atoms.
11050     Look at [[objarf]] for further explanations.
11051     """,
11052     ),
11053     
11054     Variable(
11055         abivarname="objaax",
11056         varset="geo",
11057         vartype="real",
11058         topics=['AtomManipulator_useful'],
11059         dimensions=[6],
11060         mnemonics="OBJect A: AXis",
11061         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]', '[[LENGTH]]'],
11062         commentdefault="""[[objaax]] must be provided if ([[nobj]] == 1 and one component of [[objaro]] != 0). Moreover,
11063     [[objaax]] AND [[objbax]] must be provided if ( [[nobj]] == 2 and one component of [[objbro]] != 0 ).""",
11064         text="""
11065     Gives, for each object, the cartesian coordinates of two points (first point:
11066     [[objaax]](1:3) second point: [[objaax]](4:6). By default, given in Bohr
11067     atomic units (1 Bohr=0.5291772108 Angstroms), although Angstrom can be
11068     specified, if preferred, since these variables have the '[[LENGTH]]'
11069     characteristics.
11070     The two points define an axis of rotation of the corresponding object.
11071     Note that the rotation of the object is done BEFORE the object is translated.
11072     The sign of the rotation angle is positive if the object is to be rotated
11073     clockwise when looking to it along the axis, from point 1 (coordinates 1:3)
11074     toward point 2 (coordinates 4:6).
11075     """,
11076     ),
11077     
11078     Variable(
11079         abivarname="objan",
11080         varset="geo",
11081         vartype="integer",
11082         topics=['AtomManipulator_basic'],
11083         dimensions="scalar",
11084         mnemonics="OBJect A: Number of atoms",
11085         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
11086         commentdefault=""" [[objan]] MUST be provided if [[nobj]] == 1.
11087      [[objan]] and [[objbn]] MUST be provided if [[nobj]] == 2.""",
11088         text="""
11089     Gives the number of atoms in object a. The list of atoms is given by the variables [[objaat]].
11090     """,
11091     ),
11092     
11093     Variable(
11094         abivarname="objarf",
11095         varset="geo",
11096         vartype="integer",
11097         topics=['AtomManipulator_basic'],
11098         dimensions=[3],
11099         defaultval=[1, 1, 1],
11100         mnemonics="OBJect A: Repetition Factors",
11101         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
11102         text="""
11103     Gives three repetition factors of the objects a.
11104     This gives the opportunity to generate a three-dimensional set of repeated
11105     objects, although a simple one-dimensional repetition will be easily obtained
11106     through the specification of `nrep 1 1`
11107     where `nrep` is the 1D repetition factor.
11108     The initial rotation and translation of the object, as well as the increment
11109     of rotation or translation from one object to the next are specified by the
11110     variable [[objaro]].
11111     Note that the atom manipulator will generate the full set of atoms from the
11112     primitive set of atoms using the following order: it will process each atom
11113     in the primitive list one by one, determine whether it belongs to either
11114     object a or object b, and then repeat it taking into account the proper
11115     rotation and translation, with the fastest varying repetition factor being the
11116     first, then the second, then the third.
11117     In the final list of atoms, one will first find the atoms generated from atom
11118     1 in the primitive list, then those generated from atom 2 in the primitive
11119     list, and so on.
11120     If the atom manipulator is only used to rotate or translate an object, without
11121     repeating it, simply use `1 1 1`, which is also the Default value.
11122     """,
11123     ),
11124     
11125     Variable(
11126         abivarname="objaro",
11127         varset="geo",
11128         vartype="real",
11129         topics=['AtomManipulator_useful'],
11130         dimensions=[4],
11131         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=4, value=0.0),
11132         mnemonics="OBJect A: ROtations",
11133         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
11134         commentdefault="(no rotation)",
11135         text="""
11136     Give, for each object, the angles of rotation in degrees to be applied to the
11137     corresponding object.
11138     The rotation is applied before the translation, and the axis is defined by the
11139     variable [[objaax]]. See the latter variable for the
11140     definition of the sign of the rotation.
11141     The first component [[objaro]](1) gives the angle of
11142     rotation to be applied to the first instance of the object. The second, third
11143     or fourth component (resp.) gives the increment of rotation angle from one
11144     instance to the next instance, defined by the first, second or third
11145     repetition factor (resp.). This allows one to generate 3D arrays of molecules
11146     with different rotation angles.
11147     """,
11148     ),
11149     
11150     Variable(
11151         abivarname="objatr",
11152         varset="geo",
11153         vartype="real",
11154         topics=['AtomManipulator_useful'],
11155         dimensions=[12],
11156         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=12, value=0.0),
11157         mnemonics="OBJect A: TRanslations",
11158         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]', '[[LENGTH]]'],
11159         commentdefault="(no translation)",
11160         text="""
11161     Give, for each object, the vectors of translations, in cartesian coordinates,
11162     to be applied to the corresponding object. By default, given in Bohr atomic
11163     units (1 Bohr=0.5291772108 Angstroms), although Angstrom can be specified, if
11164     preferred, since these variables have the '[[LENGTH]]' characteristics.
11165     The translation is applied after the rotation.
11166     The first vector [[objatr]](3,1) gives the translation to
11167     be applied to the first instance of the object. The second, third or fourth
11168     component (resp.) gives the increment of translation from one instance to the
11169     next instance, defined by the first, second or third repetition factor (resp.).
11170     This allows one to generate 3D arrays of molecules.
11171     In general, when the objects are repeated, a translation vector must be given,
11172     since otherwise, the repeated objects pack in the same region of space. As an
11173     exception, one can have a set of molecules regularly spaced on a circle, in
11174     which case, only rotations are needed.
11175     Not present in the dtset array (no internal).
11176     """,
11177     ),
11178     
11179     Variable(
11180         abivarname="objbat",
11181         varset="geo",
11182         vartype="integer",
11183         topics=['AtomManipulator_useful'],
11184         dimensions=['[[objbn]]'],
11185         mnemonics="OBJect B: list of AToms",
11186         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
11187         requires="[[nobj]] == 2",
11188         text="""
11189     Gives the list of atoms in object b. This list is specified by giving, for
11190     each atom, its index in the list of coordinates ([[xred]], [[xangst]] or
11191     [[xcart]]), that also corresponds to a type of atom (given by the array type).
11192     These objects can be thought as molecules, or groups of atoms, or parts of
11193     molecules, to be repeated, rotated and translated to generate the full set of
11194     atoms.
11195     Look at [[objbrf]] for further explanations.
11196     """,
11197     ),
11198     
11199     Variable(
11200         abivarname="objbax",
11201         varset="geo",
11202         vartype="real",
11203         topics=['AtomManipulator_useful'],
11204         dimensions=[6],
11205         mnemonics="OBJect B: AXis",
11206         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]', '[[LENGTH]]'],
11207         commentdefault="""[[objbax]] must be provided if ([[nobj]] == 1 and one component of [[objaro]] != 0). Moreover,
11208     [[objaax]] AND [[objbax]] must be provided if ( [[nobj]] == 2 and one component of [[objbro]] != 0 ).""",
11209         text="""
11210     Gives, for each object, the cartesian coordinates of two points (first point:
11211     [[objbax]](1:3) second point: [[objbax]](4:6). By default, given in Bohr
11212     atomic units (1 Bohr=0.5291772108 Angstroms), although Angstrom can be
11213     specified, if preferred, since these variables have the '[[LENGTH]]'
11214     characteristics.
11215     The two points define an axis of rotation of the corresponding object.
11216     Note that the rotation of the object is done BEFORE the object is translated.
11217     The sign of the rotation angle is positive if the object is to be rotated
11218     clockwise when looking to it along the axis, from point 1 (coordinates 1:3)
11219     toward point 2 (coordinates 4:6).
11220     """,
11221     ),
11222     
11223     Variable(
11224         abivarname="objbn",
11225         varset="geo",
11226         vartype="integer",
11227         topics=['AtomManipulator_useful'],
11228         dimensions="scalar",
11229         mnemonics="OBJect B: Number of atoms",
11230         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
11231         commentdefault=" [[objan]] and [[objbn]] MUST be provided if [[nobj]] == 2.",
11232         text="""
11233     Gives the number of atoms in either object b. The list of atoms is given by
11234     the variables [[objbat]].
11235     """,
11236     ),
11237     
11238     Variable(
11239         abivarname="objbrf",
11240         varset="geo",
11241         vartype="integer",
11242         topics=['AtomManipulator_useful'],
11243         dimensions=[3],
11244         defaultval=[1, 1, 1],
11245         mnemonics="OBJect B: Repetition Factors",
11246         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
11247         text="""
11248     Gives three repetition factors of the objects a or b.
11249     This gives the opportunity to generate a three-dimensional set of repeated
11250     objects, although a simple one-dimensional repetition will be easily obtained
11251     through the specification of
11252     `nrep 1 1` where `nrep` is the 1D repetition factor.
11253     The initial rotation and translation of the object, as well as the increment
11254     of rotation or translation from one object to the next are specified by the
11255     variables [[objbro]] and [[objbtr]], for object b.
11256     Note that the atom manipulator will generate the full set of atoms from the
11257     primitive set of atoms using the following order: it will process each atom
11258     in the primitive list one by one, determine whether it belongs to either
11259     object a or object b, and then repeat it taking into account the proper
11260     rotation and translation, with the fastest varying repetition factor being the
11261     first, then the second, then the third.
11262     In the final list of atoms, one will first find the atoms generated from atom
11263     1 in the primitive list, then those generated from atom 2 in the primitive
11264     list, and so on.
11265     If the atom manipulator is only used to rotate or translate an object, without
11266     repeating it, simply use `1 1 1`, which is also the Default value.
11267     """,
11268     ),
11269     
11270     Variable(
11271         abivarname="objbro",
11272         varset="geo",
11273         vartype="real",
11274         topics=['AtomManipulator_useful'],
11275         dimensions=[4],
11276         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=4, value=0.0),
11277         mnemonics="OBJect B: ROtations",
11278         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
11279         commentdefault="(no rotation)",
11280         text="""
11281     Give, for each object, the angles of rotation in degrees to be applied to the
11282     corresponding object.
11283     The rotation is applied before the translation, and the axis is defined by the
11284     variable [[objbax]]. See the latter variable for the
11285     definition of the sign of the rotation.
11286     The first component [[objbro]](1) gives the angle of
11287     rotation to be applied to the first instance of the object. The second, third
11288     or fourth component (resp.) gives the increment of rotation angle from one
11289     instance to the next instance, defined by the first, second or third
11290     repetition factor (resp.). This allows one to generate 3D arrays of molecules
11291     with different rotation angles.
11292     """,
11293     ),
11294     
11295     Variable(
11296         abivarname="objbtr",
11297         varset="geo",
11298         vartype="real",
11299         topics=['AtomManipulator_useful'],
11300         dimensions=[12],
11301         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=12, value=0.0),
11302         mnemonics="OBJect B: TRanslations",
11303         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]', '[[LENGTH]]'],
11304         commentdefault="(no translation)",
11305         text="""
11306     Give, for each object, the vectors of translations, in cartesian coordinates,
11307     to be applied to the corresponding object. By default, given in Bohr atomic
11308     units (1 Bohr=0.5291772108 Angstroms), although Angstrom can be specified, if
11309     preferred, since these variables have the '[[LENGTH]]' characteristics.
11310     The translation is applied after the rotation.
11311     The first vector [[objatr]](3,1) and [[objbtr]](3,1) gives the translation to
11312     be applied to the first instance of the object. The second, third or fourth
11313     component (resp.) gives the increment of translation from one instance to the
11314     next instance, defined by the first, second or third repetition factor (resp.).
11315     This allows one to generate 3D arrays of molecules.
11316     In general, when the objects are repeated, a translation vector must be given,
11317     since otherwise, the repeated objects pack in the same region of space. As an
11318     exception, one can have a set of molecules regularly spaced on a circle, in
11319     which case, only rotations are needed.
11320     """,
11321     ),
11322     
11323     Variable(
11324         abivarname="occ",
11325         varset="gstate",
11326         vartype="real",
11327         topics=['BandOcc_basic'],
11328         dimensions=['[[nband]]', "[[mband]]", "[[nsppol]]"],
11329         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=None, value=0),
11330         mnemonics="OCCupation numbers",
11331         characteristics=['[[EVOLVING]]'],
11332         text="""
11333     Gives occupation numbers for all bands in the problem. Needed if [[occopt]] == 0
11334     or [[occopt]] == 2. Ignored otherwise. Also ignored when [[iscf]] = -2.
11335     Typical band occupancy is either 2 or 0, but can be 1 for half-occupied band
11336     or other choices in special circumstances.
11337     
11338     If [[occopt]] is not 2, then the occupancies must be the same for each k point.
11339     
11340     If [[occopt]] = 2, then the band occupancies must be provided explicitly for
11341     each band, EACH k POINT, and EACH SPIN-POLARIZATION, in an array which runs
11342     over all bands, k points, and spin-polarizations.
11343     The order of entries in the array would correspond to all bands at the first k
11344     point (spin up), then all bands at the second k point (spin up), etc, then all
11345     k-points spin down.
11346     The total number of array elements which must be provided is
11347     ( [[nband]](1)+[[nband]](2)+...+ [[nband]]([[nkpt]]) ) * [[nsppol]].
11348     The occupation numbers evolve only for metallic occupations, that is, [[occopt]] ≥ 3.
11349     """,
11350     ),
11351     
11352     Variable(
11353         abivarname="occopt",
11354         varset="basic",
11355         vartype="integer",
11356         topics=['BandOcc_basic', 'STM_compulsory'],
11357         dimensions="scalar",
11358         defaultval=1,
11359         mnemonics="OCCupation OPTion",
11360         text="""
11361     Controls how input parameters [[nband]], [[occ]], and [[wtk]] are handled.
11362     
11363       * [[occopt]] = 0:
11364     All k points and spins have the same number of bands. All k points have the same occupancies of bands for a given spin
11365     (but these occupancies may differ for spin up and spin down - typical for ferromagnetic insulators).
11366     [[nband]] is given as a single number, and [[occ]]([[nband]] * [[nsppol]]) is an array of
11367     [[nband]] * [[nsppol]] elements, read in by the code.
11368     The k point weights in array [[wtk]]([[nkpt]]) are automatically normalized by
11369     the code to add to 1. They cannot differ for differing spins.
11370     
11371       * [[occopt]] = 1:
11372     Same as [[occopt]] = 0, except that the array [[occ]] is automatically generated
11373     by the code, to give a semiconductor.
11374     An error occurs when filling cannot be done with occupation numbers equal to 2
11375     or 0 in each k-point (non-spin-polarized case), or with occupation numbers
11376     equal to 1 or 0 in each k-point (spin-polarized case). If [[nsppol]] = 2 and
11377     [[occopt]] == 1 is used, the user has to impose the magnetization, using
11378     [[spinmagntarget]], except for the case of a single isolated Hydrogen atom.
11379     
11380       * [[occopt]] = 2:
11381     k points may optionally have different numbers of bands and different
11382     occupancies. [[nband]]([[nkpt]] * [[nsppol]]) is given explicitly as an array of
11383     [[nkpt]] * [[nsppol]] elements. [[occ]]() is given explicitly for all bands at
11384     each k point, and eventually for each spin -- the total number of elements is
11385     the sum of [[nband]](ikpt) over all k points and spins. The k point weights
11386     [[wtk]] ([[nkpt]]) are NOT automatically normalized under this option.
11387     
11388       * [[occopt]] = 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7:
11389     Metallic occupation of levels, using different occupation schemes (see below).
11390     The corresponding thermal broadening, or cold smearing, is defined by the
11391     input variable [[tsmear]] (see below: the variable xx is the energy in Ha,
11392     divided by [[tsmear]])
11393     Like for [[occopt]] = 1, the variable [[occ]] is not read.
11394     All k points have the same number of bands, [[nband]] is given as a single
11395     number, read by the code.
11396     The k point weights in array [[wtk]]([[nkpt]]) are automatically normalized by
11397     the code to add to 1.
11398     
11399         * [[occopt]] = 3:
11400     Fermi-Dirac smearing (finite-temperature metal) Smeared delta function:
11401     0.25d0/(cosh(xx/2.0d0)**2)
11402     
11403         * [[occopt]] = 4:
11404     "Cold smearing" of N. Marzari (see his thesis work), with a=-.5634
11405     (minimization of the bump)
11406     Smeared delta function:
11407     exp(-xx  2  )/sqrt(pi) * (1.5d0+xx*(-a*1.5d0+xx*(-1.0d0+a*xx)))
11408     
11409         * [[occopt]] = 5:
11410     "Cold smearing" of N. Marzari (see his thesis work), with a=-.8165 (monotonic
11411     function in the tail)
11412     Same smeared delta function as [[occopt]] = 4, with different a.
11413     
11414         * [[occopt]] = 6:
11415     Smearing of Methfessel and Paxton [[cite:Methfessel1989]] with Hermite polynomial
11416     of degree 2, corresponding to "Cold smearing" of N. Marzari with a=0 (so, same
11417     smeared delta function as [[occopt]] = 4, with different a).
11418     
11419         * [[occopt]] = 7:
11420     Gaussian smearing, corresponding to the 0 order Hermite polynomial of
11421     Methfessel and Paxton.
11422     Smeared delta function: 1.0d0*exp(-xx**2)/sqrt(pi)
11423     
11424         * [[occopt]] = 8:
11425     Uniform smearing (the delta function is replaced by a constant function of
11426     value one over ]-1/2,1/2[ (with one-half value at the boundaries). Used for
11427     testing purposes only.
11428     
11429     !!! warning
11430         One can use metallic occupation of levels in the case of a molecule,
11431         in order to avoid any problem with degenerate levels. However, it is advised
11432         NOT to use [[occopt]] = 6 (and to a lesser extent [[occopt]] = 4 and 5), since the
11433         associated number of electron versus the Fermi energy is NOT guaranteed to be
11434         a monotonic function. For true metals, AND a sufficiently dense sampling of
11435         the Brillouin zone, this should not happen, but be cautious ! As an indication
11436         of this problem, a small variation of input parameters might lead to a jump of
11437         total energy, because there might be two or even three possible values of the
11438         Fermi energy, and the bisection algorithm finds one or the other.
11439     """,
11440     ),
11441     
11442     Variable(
11443         abivarname="omegasimax",
11444         varset="gw",
11445         vartype="real",
11446         topics=['SelfEnergy_basic'],
11447         dimensions="scalar",
11448         defaultval=ValueWithUnit(units='eV', value=50),
11449         mnemonics="OMEGA to evaluate Sigma along the Imaginary axis D: MAXimal value",
11450         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
11451         requires="[[optdriver]] == 4 and [[gwcalctyp]] == 1",
11452         text="""
11453     [[omegasimax]] defines the maximum frequency along the imaginary the axis. In
11454     conjunction with [[nomegasi]], [[omegasimax]] uniquely defines the linear mesh
11455     employed to sample the self-energy along the imaginary axis.
11456     """,
11457     ),
11458     
11459     Variable(
11460         abivarname="omegasrdmax",
11461         varset="gw",
11462         vartype="real",
11463         topics=['SelfEnergy_basic'],
11464         dimensions="scalar",
11465         defaultval=ValueWithUnit(units='eV', value=1.0),
11466         mnemonics="OMEGA to evaluate the Sigma Real axis Derivative: MAXimal value",
11467         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
11468         requires="[[optdriver]] == 4",
11469         text="""
11470     The maximum distance from the KS energy where to evaluate Sigma. Sigma is
11471     evaluated at [ KS_energy - [[omegasrdmax]], KS_energy + [[omegasrdmax]] ]
11472     sampled [[nomegasrd]] times.
11473     """,
11474     ),
11475     
11476     Variable(
11477         abivarname="optcell",
11478         varset="rlx",
11479         vartype="integer",
11480         topics=['PIMD_basic', 'GeoOpt_compulsory'],
11481         dimensions="scalar",
11482         defaultval=0,
11483         mnemonics="OPTimize the CELL shape and dimensions",
11484         text=r"""
11485     Allows to optimize the unit cell shape and dimensions, when [[ionmov]] >= 2 or
11486     3. The configuration for which the stress almost vanishes is iteratively
11487     determined, by using the same algorithms as for the nuclei positions. Will
11488     eventually modify [[acell]] and/or [[rprim]]. The ionic positions are ALWAYS
11489     updated, according to the forces. A target stress tensor might be defined, see
11490     [[strtarget]].
11491     
11492       * [[optcell]] = 0: modify nuclear positions, since [[ionmov]] = 2 or 3, but no cell shape and dimension optimisation.
11493       * [[optcell]] = 1: optimisation of volume only (do not modify [[rprim]], and allow an homogeneous dilatation of the three components of [[acell]])
11494       * [[optcell]] = 2: full optimization of cell geometry (modify [[acell]] and [[rprim]] \- normalize the vectors of [[rprim]] to generate the [[acell]]). This is the usual mode for cell shape and volume optimization. It takes into account the symmetry of the system, so that only the effectively relevant degrees of freedom are optimized.
11495       * [[optcell]] = 3: constant-volume optimization of cell geometry (modify [[acell]] and [[rprim]] under constraint \- normalize the vectors of [[rprim]] to generate the [[acell]])
11496       * [[optcell]] = 4, 5 or 6: optimize [[acell]](1), [[acell]](2), or [[acell]](3), respectively (only works if the two other vectors are orthogonal to the optimized one, the latter being along its cartesian axis).
11497       * [[optcell]] = 7, 8 or 9: optimize the cell geometry while keeping the first, second or third vector unchanged (only works if the two other vectors are orthogonal to the one left unchanged, the latter being along its cartesian axis).
11498     
11499     A few details require attention when performing unit cell optimisation:
11500     
11501       * one has to get rid of the discontinuities due to discrete changes of plane wave number with cell size, by using a suitable value of [[ecutsm]];
11502       * one has to allow for the possibility of a larger sphere of plane waves, by using [[dilatmx]];
11503       * one might have to adjust the scale of stresses to the scale of forces, by using [[strfact]].
11504       * if all the reduced coordinates of atoms are fixed by symmetry, one cannot use [[toldff]] to stop the SCF cycle. (Suggestion: use [[toldfe]] with a small value, like 1.0d-10)
11505     
11506     It is STRONGLY suggested first to optimize the ionic positions without cell
11507     shape and size optimization ([[optcell]] = 0), then start the cell shape and
11508     size optimization from the cell with relaxed ionic positions. Presently
11509     (v3.1), one cannot restart ([[restartxf]]) a calculation with a non-zero
11510     [[optcell]] value from the (x,f) history of another run with a different non-
11511     zero [[optcell]] value. There are still a few problems at that level.
11512     """,
11513     ),
11514     
11515     Variable(
11516         abivarname="optdriver",
11517         varset="gstate",
11518         vartype="integer",
11519         topics=['nonlinear_compulsory',
11520      'GWls_compulsory',
11521      'ElPhonInt_compulsory',
11522      'GW_compulsory',
11523      'BSE_compulsory',
11524      'DFPT_compulsory',
11525      'Susceptibility_compulsory',
11526      'SelfEnergy_compulsory'],
11527         dimensions="scalar",
11528         defaultval=0,
11529         mnemonics="OPTions for the DRIVER",
11530         text="""
11531     For each dataset, choose the task to be done, at the level of the "driver"
11532     routine.
11533     
11534     The choice is among:
11535     
11536       * [[optdriver]] = 0: ground-state calculation (GS), routine "gstate"
11537       * [[optdriver]] = 1: response-function calculation (RF), routine "respfn"
11538       * [[optdriver]] = 2: susceptibility calculation (SUS), routine "suscep"
11539       * [[optdriver]] = 3: susceptibility and dielectric matrix calculation (SCR), routine "screening"
11540         (see the input variables [[ecutwfn]], [[ecuteps]], [[ppmfrq]], [[getwfk]], as
11541         well as [[nbandkss]] and [[nband]])
11542       * [[optdriver]] = 4: self-energy calculation (SIG), routine "sigma"
11543       * [[optdriver]] = 5: non-linear response functions (NONLINEAR), using the 2n+1
11544         theorem, routine "nonlinear"
11545       * [[optdriver]] =7: electron-phonon coupling (EPH)
11546       * [[optdriver]] =66: GW using Lanczos-Sternheimer, see input variables whose
11547         name start with gwls_*.
11548       * [[optdriver]] = 99: Bethe-Salpeter calculation (BSE), routine "bethe_salpeter"
11549     
11550     If one of [[rfphon]], [[rfddk]], [[rfelfd]], or [[rfstrs]] is non-zero, while
11551     [[optdriver]] is not defined in the input file, ABINIT will set [[optdriver]]
11552     to 1 automatically. These input variables ([[rfphon]], [[rfddk]], [[rfelfd]],
11553     and [[rfstrs]]) must be zero if [[optdriver]] is not set to 1.
11554     """,
11555     ),
11556     
11557     Variable(
11558         abivarname="optforces",
11559         varset="dev",
11560         vartype="integer",
11561         topics=['ForcesStresses_basic'],
11562         dimensions="scalar",
11563         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[toldff]] or [[tolrff]] != 0': 1, 'defaultval': 2}),
11564         mnemonics="OPTions for the calculation of FORCES",
11565         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
11566         text="""
11567     Allows to choose options for the calculation of forces.
11568     
11569       * [[optforces]] = 0: the forces are set to zero, and many steps of the computation of forces are skipped
11570       * [[optforces]] = 1: calculation of forces at each SCF iteration, allowing to use forces as criterion to stop the SCF cycles
11571       * [[optforces]] = 2: calculation of forces at the end of the SCF iterations (like the stresses)
11572     """,
11573     ),
11574     
11575     Variable(
11576         abivarname="optnlxccc",
11577         varset="dev",
11578         vartype="integer",
11579         topics=['xc_expert'],
11580         dimensions="scalar",
11581         defaultval=1,
11582         mnemonics="OPTion for the calculation of Non-Linear eXchange-Correlation Core Correction",
11583         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
11584         text="""
11585     Allows to choose options for the calculation of non-linear XC correction. At
11586     present, only relevant for the FHI type of pseudopotentials, with pspcod=6.
11587     
11588       * [[optnlxccc]] = 1: uses the old `psp6cc.f` routine, with inconsistent treatment of real-space derivatives of the core
11589       function (computed in this routine, while splined in the other parts of the code)
11590       * [[optnlxccc]] = 2: consistent calculation derivatives, in the `psp6cc_dhr.f` routine from DHamann.
11591     """,
11592     ),
11593     
11594     Variable(
11595         abivarname="optstress",
11596         varset="gstate",
11597         vartype="integer",
11598         topics=['ForcesStresses_basic'],
11599         dimensions="scalar",
11600         defaultval=1,
11601         mnemonics="OPTion for the computation of STRESS",
11602         text="""
11603     If set to 1, the computation of stresses is done, in the SCF case (under the
11604     conditions [[iscf]] > 0, [[prtstm]] == 0, [[positron]] == 0, and either
11605     [[nstep]] >0, or [[usepaw]] == 0 or [[irdwfk]] == 1).
11606     Otherwise, to save CPU time, if no optimization of the cell is required, one
11607     can skip the computation of stresses. The CPU time saving might be interesting
11608     for some PAW calculations.
11609     """,
11610     ),
11611     
11612     Variable(
11613         abivarname="orbmag",
11614         varset="gstate",
11615         vartype="integer",
11616         topics=['MagField_expert'],
11617         dimensions="scalar",
11618         defaultval=0,
11619         mnemonics="ORBital MAGnetization",
11620         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
11621         requires="""[[usepaw]] == 1
11622     [[kptopt]] == 3
11623     [[NPROC]] == 1""",
11624         text="""
11625     Compute quantities related to orbital magnetization. Currently only the Chern
11626     number calculated.
11627     """,
11628     ),
11629     
11630     Variable(
11631         abivarname="ortalg",
11632         varset="dev",
11633         vartype="integer",
11634         topics=['TuningSpeed_expert'],
11635         dimensions="scalar",
11636         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[wfoptalg]] >= 10 ': -2, 'defaultval': 2}),
11637         mnemonics="ORThogonalisation ALGorithm",
11638         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
11639         text="""
11640     Allows to choose the algorithm for orthogonalisation.
11641     Positive or zero values make two projections per line minimisation, one before
11642     the preconditioning, one after. This is the clean application of the band-by-
11643     band CG gradient for finding eigenfunctions.
11644     Negative values make only one projection per line minimisation.
11645     The orthogonalisation step is twice faster, but the convergence is less good.
11646     This actually calls to a better understanding of this effect.
11647     [[ortalg]] = 0, 1 or -1 is the conventional coding.
11648     [[ortalg]] = 2 or -2 try to make better use of existing registers on the
11649     particular machine one is running.
11650     More demanding use of registers is provided by [[ortalg]] = 3 or -3, and so on.
11651     The maximal value is presently 4 and -4.
11652     Tests have shown that [[ortalg]] = 2 or -2 is suitable for use on the available
11653     platforms.
11654     """,
11655     ),
11656     
11657     Variable(
11658         abivarname="papiopt",
11659         varset="dev",
11660         vartype="integer",
11661         topics=['Control_expert'],
11662         dimensions="scalar",
11663         defaultval=0,
11664         mnemonics="PAPI OPTion",
11665         text="""
11666     [PAPI](http://icl.cs.utk.edu/papi/index.html) aims to provide the tool
11667     designer and application engineer with a consistent interface and methodology
11668     for use of the performance counter hardware found in most major
11669     microprocessors. PAPI enables software engineers to see, in near real time,
11670     the relation between software performance and processor events.
11671     This option can be used only when ABINIT has been compiled with the `
11672     --enable-papi ` configure option.
11673     If [[papiopt]] = 1, then PAPI counters are used instead of the usual time()
11674     routine. All the timing output of ABINIT is then done with PAPI values. The
11675     measurements are more accurate and give also access to the flops of the calculation.
11676     """,
11677     ),
11678     
11679     Variable(
11680         abivarname="paral_atom",
11681         varset="paral",
11682         vartype="integer",
11683         topics=['parallelism_basic'],
11684         dimensions="scalar",
11685         defaultval=1,
11686         mnemonics="activate PARALelization over (paw) ATOMic sites",
11687         text="""
11688     Relevant only for PAW calculations.
11689     This keyword controls the parallel distribution of memory over atomic sites.
11690     Calculations are also distributed using the "kpt-band" communicator.
11691     Compatible with ground-state calculations and response function calculations
11692     """,
11693     ),
11694     
11695     Variable(
11696         abivarname="paral_kgb",
11697         varset="paral",
11698         vartype="integer",
11699         topics=['parallelism_basic'],
11700         dimensions="scalar",
11701         defaultval=0,
11702         mnemonics="activate PARALelization over K-point, G-vectors and Bands",
11703         text="""
11704     **If paral_kgb is not explicitely put in the input file**, ABINIT
11705     automatically detects if the job has been sent in sequential or in parallel.
11706     In this last case, it detects the number of processors on which the job has
11707     been sent and calculates values of [[npkpt]], [[npfft]], [[npband]],
11708     [[bandpp]], [[npimage]] and [[npspinor]] that are compatible with the number
11709     of processors. It then set paral_kgb to 0 or 1 (see hereunder) and launches the job.
11710     
11711     **If paral_kgb=0**, the parallelization over k-points only is activated. In
11712     this case, [[npkpt]], [[npspinor]], [[npfft]] and [[npband]] are ignored.
11713     Require compilation option --enable-mpi="yes".
11714     
11715     **If paral_kgb=1**, the parallelization over bands, FFTs, and k-point/spin-
11716     components is activated (see [[npkpt]], [[npfft]] [[npband]] and eventually
11717     [[npspinor]]). With this parallelization, the work load is split over four
11718     levels of parallelization (three level of parallelisation (kpt-band-fft )+
11719     spin) The different communications almost occur along one dimension only.
11720     Require compilation option --enable-mpi="yes".
11721     
11722     HOWTO fix the number of processors along one level of parallelisation:
11723     At first, try to parallelise over the k point and spin (see
11724     [[npkpt]],[[npspinor]]). Otherwise, for unpolarized calculation at the gamma
11725     point, parallelise over the two other levels: the band and FFT ones. For nproc $\leq$ 50, the best speed-up is achieved for [[npband]] = nproc and [[npfft]] = 1
11726     (which is not yet the default). For nproc $\geq$ 50, the best speed-up is achieved
11727     for [[npband]] $\geq$ 4 $\\times$ [[npfft]].
11728     
11729     For additional information, download F. Bottin presentation at the
11730     [ABINIT workshop 2007](https://www.abinit.org/sites/default/files/oldsites/workshop_07/program.html)
11731     
11732     Suggested acknowledgments:
11733     [[cite:Bottin2008]], also available on arXiv, http://arxiv.org/abs/0707.3405.
11734     
11735     If the total number of processors used is compatible with the four levels of
11736     parallelization, the values for [[npkpt]], [[npspinor]], [[npfft]], [[npband]]
11737     and [[bandpp]] will be filled automatically, although the repartition may not
11738     be optimal. To optimize the repartition use:
11739     
11740     **If paral_kgb=1** and **max_ncpus = n $\\ne$ 0** ABINIT will test automatically
11741     if all the processor numbers between 2 and n are convenient for a parallel
11742     calculation and print the possible values in the log file. A weight is
11743     attributed to each possible processors repartition. It is adviced to select a
11744     processor repartition for which the weight is high (as closed to the number of
11745     processors as possible). The code will then stop after the printing. This test
11746     can be done as well with a sequential as with a parallel version of the code.
11747     The user can then choose the adequate number of processor on which he can run
11748     his job. He must put again paral_kgb=1 in the input file and put the
11749     corresponding values for [[npkpt]], [[npfft]], [[npband]],[[bandpp]] and
11750     eventually [[npspinor]] in the input file.
11751     """,
11752     ),
11753     
11754     Variable(
11755         abivarname="paral_rf",
11756         varset="paral",
11757         vartype="integer",
11758         topics=['parallelism_basic'],
11759         dimensions="scalar",
11760         defaultval=0,
11761         mnemonics="activate PARALlelization over Response Function perturbations",
11762         text="""
11763     This parameter activates the parallelization over perturbations which can be
11764     used during RF-Calculation. It is possible to use this type of parallelization
11765     in combination to the parallelization over k-points.
11766     
11767     Currently total energies calculated by groups, where the master process is not
11768     in, are saved in.status_LOGxxxx files.
11769     
11770     If [[paral_rf]] is set to -1, the code reports the list of irreducible
11771     perturbations for the specified q-point in the log file (YAML format) and then stops.
11772     
11773     [[paral_rf]] can be specified separately for each dataset.
11774     """,
11775     ),
11776     
11777     Variable(
11778         abivarname="pawcpxocc",
11779         varset="paw",
11780         vartype="integer",
11781         topics=['PAW_expert'],
11782         dimensions="scalar",
11783         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[optdriver]] == 0 and [[ionmov]] < 6 and [[pawspnorb]] == 1 and [[iscf]] >= 10 and ([[kptopt]] !=1 or [[kptopt]]!=2) and [[usepaw]] == 1': 2,
11784      'defaultval': 1}),
11785         mnemonics="PAW - use ComPleX rhoij OCCupancies",
11786         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
11787         text="""
11788     The only possible values for [[pawcpxocc]] are 1 or 2.
11789     When [[pawcpxocc]] == 1, "direct" decomposition of total energy cannot be
11790     printed out.
11791     When [[pawcpxocc]] == 2, PAW augmentation occupancies are treated as
11792     COMPLEX; else they are considered as REAL.
11793     This is needed when time-reversal symmetry is broken (typically when spin-
11794     orbit coupling is activated).
11795     
11796     Note for ground-state calculations ([[optdriver]] == 0):
11797     The imaginary part of PAW augmentation occupancies is only used for the
11798     computation of the total energy by "direct scheme"; this is only necessary
11799     when SCF mixing on potential is chosen ([[iscf]] <10).
11800     When SCF mixing on density is chosen ([[iscf]] >= 10), the "direct"
11801     decomposition of energy is only printed out without being used. It is thus
11802     possible to use [[pawcpxocc]] = 1 in the latter case.
11803     In order to save CPU time, when molecular dynamics is selected ([[ionmov]] >= 6)
11804     and SCF mixing done on density ([[iscf]] >= 10), [[pawcpxocc]] = 2 is (by default)
11805     set to **1**
11806     """,
11807     ),
11808     
11809     Variable(
11810         abivarname="pawcross",
11811         varset="paw",
11812         vartype="integer",
11813         topics=['DFPT_expert'],
11814         dimensions="scalar",
11815         defaultval=0,
11816         mnemonics="PAW - add CROSS term in oscillator strengths",
11817         requires="([[optdriver]] == 3 or [[optdriver]] == 4) and [[usepaw]] == 1",
11818         text="""
11819     When **pawcross=1**, the overlap between the plane-wave part of one band and
11820     the on-site part of an other is taken into account in the computation of the
11821     oscillator strengths. Hence, the completeness of the on-site basis is no longer assumed.
11822     """,
11823     ),
11824     
11825     Variable(
11826         abivarname="pawecutdg",
11827         varset="paw",
11828         vartype="real",
11829         topics=['Planewaves_compulsory', 'PAW_compulsory'],
11830         dimensions="scalar",
11831         defaultval=-1,
11832         mnemonics="PAW - Energy CUToff for the Double Grid",
11833         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
11834         commentdefault="pawecutdg MUST be specified for PAW calculations.",
11835         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
11836         text="""
11837     Define the energy cut-off for the fine FFT grid (the "double grid", that
11838     allows one to transfer data from the normal, coarse, FFT grid to the spherical
11839     grid around each atom).
11840     [[pawecutdg]] must be larger or equal to [[ecut]]. If it is equal to it, then
11841     no fine grid is used. The results are not very accurate, but the computations
11842     proceed quite fast.
11843     For typical PAW computations, where [[ecut]] is on the order of 15 Ha,
11844     [[pawecutdg]] must be tested according to what you want to do. For
11845     calculations that do not require a high accuracy (molecular dynamics for
11846     instance) a value of 20 Ha is enough. For calculations that require a high
11847     accuracy (response functions for instance) it should be on the order of 30 Ha.
11848     Choosing a larger value should not increase the accuracy, but does not slow
11849     down the computation either, only the memory. The choice made for this
11850     variable DOES have a bearing on the numerical accuracy of the results, and, as
11851     such, should be the object of a convergence study. The convergence test might
11852     be made on the total energy or derived quantities, like forces, but also on
11853     the two values of the "Compensation charge inside spheres", a quantity written
11854     in the log file.
11855     """,
11856     ),
11857     
11858     Variable(
11859         abivarname="pawfatbnd",
11860         varset="paw",
11861         vartype="integer",
11862         topics=['PAW_useful', 'ElecBandStructure_useful'],
11863         dimensions="scalar",
11864         defaultval=0,
11865         mnemonics="PAW: print band structure in the FAT-BaND representation",
11866         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
11867         text="""
11868     For Ground-State calculations and non self-consistent calculations only.
11869     This option can be used to plot band structure. For each atom (specified by
11870     [[natsph]] and [[iatsph]]), each angular momentum, and each spin polarisation,
11871     the band structure is written in files (such as e.g.
11872     FATBANDS_at0001_Ni_is2_l2_m-1). Each file contains the eigenvalue, and the
11873     contribution of angular momentum L, and projection of angular momentum M, (for
11874     the corresponding wavefunction) to the PAW density inside the PAW sphere as a
11875     function of the index of the k-point. The output can be readily plotted with
11876     the software [xmgrace](http://plasma-gate.weizmann.ac.il/Grace/) (e.g
11877     xmgrace FATBANDS_at0001_Ni_is2_l2_m-1). Relevant values are:
11878     
11879       * 0: desactivated.
11880       * 1: The fatbands are only resolved in L.
11881       * 2: The fatbands are resolved in L and M.
11882     """,
11883     ),
11884     
11885     Variable(
11886         abivarname="pawlcutd",
11887         varset="paw",
11888         vartype="integer",
11889         topics=['PAW_expert'],
11890         dimensions="scalar",
11891         defaultval=10,
11892         mnemonics="PAW - L angular momentum used to CUT the development in moments of the Densitites",
11893         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
11894         text="""
11895     The expansion of the densities in angular momenta is performed up to
11896     l=[[pawlcutd]].
11897     Note that, for a given system, the maximum value of [[pawlcutd]] is
11898     **2*l_max**, where l_max is the maximum l of the PAW partial waves basis.
11899     
11900     The choice made for this variable DOES have a bearing on the numerical
11901     accuracy of the results, and, as such, should be the object of a convergence
11902     study. The convergence test might be made on the total energy or derived
11903     quantities, like forces, but also on the two values of the "Compensation
11904     charge inside spheres", a quantity written in the log file.
11905     """,
11906     ),
11907     
11908     Variable(
11909         abivarname="pawlmix",
11910         varset="paw",
11911         vartype="integer",
11912         topics=['PAW_expert'],
11913         dimensions="scalar",
11914         defaultval=10,
11915         mnemonics="PAW - maximum L used in the spherical part MIXing",
11916         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
11917         text="""
11918     The choice made for this variable determine how the spherical part of the
11919     density is mixed during electronic iterations.
11920     
11921     Only parts of rhoij quantities associated with l angular momenta up to
11922     l=pawlmix are mixed. Other parts of augmentation occupancies are not included
11923     in the mixing process.
11924     This option is useful to save CPU time but DOES have a bearing on the
11925     numerical accuracy of the results.
11926     """,
11927     ),
11928     
11929     Variable(
11930         abivarname="pawmixdg",
11931         varset="paw",
11932         vartype="integer",
11933         topics=['PAW_expert'],
11934         dimensions="scalar",
11935         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[npfft]] == 1': 0, 'defaultval': 1}),
11936         mnemonics="PAW - MIXing is done (or not) on the (fine) Double Grid",
11937         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
11938         text=r"""
11939     The choice made for this variable determines the grid on which the density (or
11940     potential) is mixed during the SCF cycle.
11941     
11942     If **pawmixdg=1** the density/potential is mixed in REAL space using the
11943     fine FFT grid (defined by [[pawecutdg]] or [[ngfftdg]]).
11944     
11945     If **pawmixdg=0** the density/potential is mixed in RECIPROCAL space using
11946     the coarse FFT grid (defined by [[ecut]] or [[ngfft]]). Only components of the
11947     coarse grid are mixed using the scheme defined by [[iscf]]; other components
11948     are only precondionned by [[diemix]] and simply mixed.
11949     This option is useful to save memory and does not affect numerical accuracy of
11950     converged results. If **pawmixdg=1**, density and corresponding residual are
11951     stored for previous iterations and are REAL arrays of size [[nfftdg]]. If
11952     **pawmixdg=0**, density and corresponding residual are stored for previous
11953     iterations and are COMPLEX arrays of size [[nfft]]. The memory saving is
11954     particularly efficient when using the Pulay mixing ([[iscf]] = 7 or 17).
11955     
11956     In **wavelet** calculations [[usewvl]] = 1:
11957     
11958         - pawmixdg is set to 1 by default.
11959         - A value of 0 is not allowed.
11960         - Density/potential is mixed in REAL space (Here only one grid is used).
11961     """,
11962     ),
11963     
11964     Variable(
11965         abivarname="pawnhatxc",
11966         varset="paw",
11967         vartype="integer",
11968         topics=['PAW_expert'],
11969         dimensions="scalar",
11970         defaultval=1,
11971         mnemonics="PAW - Flag for exact computation of gradients of NHAT density in eXchange-Correlation.",
11972         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
11973         text="""
11974     Relevant only when a GGA exchange-correlation functional is used.
11975     When this flag is activated, the gradients of compensation charge density
11976     (n_hat) are exactly computed (i.e. analytically); when it is deactivated, they
11977     are computed with a numerical scheme in reciprocal space (which can produce
11978     inaccurate results if the compensation charge density is highly localized).
11979     As analytical treatment of compensation charge density gradients is CPU time
11980     demanding, it is possible to bypass it with [[pawnhatxc]] = 0; but the numerical
11981     accuracy can be affected by this choice. It is recommended to test the
11982     validity of this approximation before use.
11983     """,
11984     ),
11985     
11986     Variable(
11987         abivarname="pawnphi",
11988         varset="paw",
11989         vartype="integer",
11990         topics=['PAW_expert'],
11991         dimensions="scalar",
11992         defaultval=13,
11993         mnemonics="PAW - Number of PHI angles used to discretize the sphere around each atom.",
11994         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
11995         text="""
11996     Number of phi angles (longitude) used to discretize the data on the atomic
11997     spheres. This discretization is completely defined by [[pawnphi]] and
11998     [[pawntheta]].
11999     """,
12000     ),
12001     
12002     Variable(
12003         abivarname="pawntheta",
12004         varset="paw",
12005         vartype="integer",
12006         topics=['PAW_expert'],
12007         dimensions="scalar",
12008         defaultval=12,
12009         mnemonics="PAW - Number of THETA angles used to discretize the sphere around each atom.",
12010         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
12011         text="""
12012     Number of theta angles (latitude) used to discretize the data on the atomic
12013     spheres. This discretization is completely defined by [[pawntheta]] and
12014     [[pawnphi]].
12015     """,
12016     ),
12017     
12018     Variable(
12019         abivarname="pawnzlm",
12020         varset="paw",
12021         vartype="integer",
12022         topics=['PAW_expert'],
12023         dimensions="scalar",
12024         defaultval=1,
12025         mnemonics="PAW - only compute Non-Zero LM-moments of the contributions to the density from the spheres",
12026         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
12027         text="""
12028     Concerns the computation of the contributions to the density from the spheres
12029     (named rho_1 - rho_tild_1).
12030     If set to 0, all lm-moments of the sphere contributions to the density are
12031     computed at each electronic iteration.
12032     If set to 1, only non-zero lm-moments of the sphere contributions to the
12033     density are computed at each electronic iteration (they are all computed at
12034     the first iteration then only those found to be non-zero will be computed;
12035     thus the first iteration is more cpu intensive)
12036     """,
12037     ),
12038     
12039     Variable(
12040         abivarname="pawoptmix",
12041         varset="paw",
12042         vartype="integer",
12043         topics=['PAW_expert'],
12044         dimensions="scalar",
12045         defaultval=0,
12046         mnemonics="PAW - OPTion for the MIXing of the spherical part",
12047         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
12048         text="""
12049     In the case of PAW computations, during the self-consistent cycle, ABINIT
12050     mixes the density $\\rho(r)= \\tilde{\\rho}(r) +\\hat{\\rho}(r)$ and the occupancy matrix $\\rho_{ij}$. ($\\tilde{\\rho}(r)$ is
12051     the pseudo density, $\\hat{\\rho}(r)$ is the compensation charge density). It can be
12052     redundant as $\\rho_{ij}$ is contained in $\\hat{\\rho}(r)$.
12053     
12054       * If **pawoptmix** =0:
12055     ABINIT mixes $\\rho(r)$ and $\\rho_{ij}$ but the residual used to control the mixing
12056     algorithm is only based on $\\rho(r)$.
12057     
12058       * If **pawoptmix** =1:
12059     ABINIT mixes $\\rho(r)$ and $\\rho_{ij}$ and the residual used to control the mixing
12060     algorithm is based on $\\rho(r)$ and $\\rho_{ij}$.
12061     
12062     This has only an influence on the efficiency of the mixing algorithm.
12063     In case of mixing problems, the first suggestion is to increase the size of the
12064     history (see [[npulayit]]). Then it is also possible to play with the
12065     parameters of the Kerker mixing: [[diemix]], [[diemac]], etc...
12066     """,
12067     ),
12068     
12069     Variable(
12070         abivarname="pawoptosc",
12071         varset="paw",
12072         vartype="integer",
12073         topics=['Susceptibility_expert', 'BSE_expert', 'SelfEnergy_expert'],
12074         dimensions="scalar",
12075         defaultval=0,
12076         mnemonics="PAW - OPTion for the computation of the OSCillator matrix elements",
12077         text="""
12078     Only relevant for GW or Bethe-Salpeter calculations with PAW.
12079     This variable defines the approach used for the evaluation of the oscillator
12080     matrix elements within the PAW formalism. Possible values are 0,1,2.
12081     If [[pawoptosc]] = 0 the code uses its internal default value (2 for SCREENING
12082     calculations, 1 for SIGMA calculations, 2 for Bethe-Salpeter
12083     If [[pawoptosc]] = 1 the matrix elements are computed with the expression given
12084     by [[cite:Arnaud2000]]. The equation is exact provided that the
12085     set of PAW partial waves is complete.
12086     If [[pawoptosc]] = 2 the matrix elements are computed with the approximated
12087     expression proposed by [[cite:Shishkin2006]].
12088     """,
12089     ),
12090     
12091     Variable(
12092         abivarname="pawovlp",
12093         varset="paw",
12094         vartype="real",
12095         topics=['PAW_useful'],
12096         dimensions="scalar",
12097         defaultval=5.0,
12098         mnemonics="PAW - spheres OVerLaP allowed (in percentage)",
12099         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
12100         text="""
12101     When PAW is activated, a localized atomic basis is added to describe wave
12102     functions. Spheres around atoms are defined and they are IN PRINCIPLE not
12103     allowed to overlap. However, a small overlap can be allowed without
12104     compromising the accuracy of results. Be aware that too high overlaps can lead
12105     to unphysical results.
12106     With the [[pawovlp]] variable, the user can control the (voluminal) overlap
12107     percentage allowed without stopping the execution.
12108     [[pawovlp]] is the value (in percentage: 0...100%) obtained by dividing the
12109     volume of the overlap of two spheres by the volume of the smallest sphere.
12110     The following values are permitted for [[pawovlp]]:
12111     
12112     - [[pawovlp]] < 0 --> overlap is always allowed
12113     - [[pawovlp]] = 0 --> no overlap is allowed
12114     - [[pawovlp]] > 0 and < 100 --> overlap is allowed only if it is less than [[pawovlp]] %
12115     """,
12116     ),
12117     
12118     Variable(
12119         abivarname="pawprt_b",
12120         varset="dev",
12121         vartype="integer",
12122         topics=['PAW_expert'],
12123         dimensions="scalar",
12124         defaultval=0,
12125         mnemonics="PAW PRinT band",
12126         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
12127         text="""
12128     Forces the output of the all-electron wavefunction for only a single band.
12129     To be used in conjuction with: [[pawprtwf]] = 1 and [[pawprt_k]].
12130     The indexing of the bands start with one for the lowest occupied band and goes up from there.
12131     """,
12132     ),
12133     
12134     Variable(
12135         abivarname="pawprt_k",
12136         varset="dev",
12137         vartype="integer",
12138         topics=['PAW_expert'],
12139         dimensions="scalar",
12140         defaultval=0,
12141         mnemonics="PAW PRinT K-point",
12142         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
12143         text="""
12144     Forces the output of the all-electron wavefunction for only a single k-point.
12145     To be used in conjunction with: [[pawprtwf]] = 1 and [[pawprt_b]].
