12146     The indexing follows the order in ouptput of the internal variable **kpt** in
12147     the beginning of the run.
12148     """,
12149     ),
12150     
12151     Variable(
12152         abivarname="pawprtden",
12153         varset="paw",
12154         vartype="integer",
12155         topics=['PAW_useful'],
12156         dimensions="scalar",
12157         defaultval=0,
12158         mnemonics="PAW: PRinT total physical electron DENsity",
12159         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
12160         text="""
12161     **Deprecated:** See the [[prtden]].
12162     """,
12163     ),
12164     
12165     Variable(
12166         abivarname="pawprtdos",
12167         varset="paw",
12168         vartype="integer",
12169         topics=['PAW_useful', 'ElecDOS_useful'],
12170         dimensions="scalar",
12171         defaultval=0,
12172         mnemonics="PAW: PRinT partial DOS contributions",
12173         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1 and [[prtdos]] == 3",
12174         text="""
12175     This input variable controls the computation and/or printing of contributions
12176     to the PAW partial DOS in _DOS file(s):
12177     
12178     * Plane-waves contribution
12179     
12180       $+$ "on-site" all-electron contribution ($\\phi$)
12181     
12182       $-$ "on-site" pseudo contribution ($\\tilde{\\phi}$).
12183     
12184     If **pawprtdos=0:**
12185     
12186     - The 3 contributions are computed; only the total partial DOS is output in _DOS file.
12187     
12188     If **pawprtdos=1:**
12189     
12190     - The 3 contributions are computed and output in _DOS file.
12191     - In that case, integrated DOS is not output.
12192     
12193     If **pawprtdos=2:**
12194     
12195     - Only "on-site" all-electron contribution is computed and output in _DOS file.
12196     - This a (very) good approximation of total DOS, provided that (1) the PAW
12197       local basis is complete, (2) the electronic charge is mostly contained in PAW spheres.
12198     - In that case, the [[ratsph]] variable is automatically set to the PAW radius.
12199     """,
12200     ),
12201     
12202     Variable(
12203         abivarname="pawprtvol",
12204         varset="paw",
12205         vartype="integer",
12206         topics=['PAW_expert'],
12207         dimensions="scalar",
12208         defaultval=0,
12209         mnemonics="PAW: PRinT VOLume",
12210         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
12211         text="""
12212     Control print volume and debugging output for PAW in log file or standard
12213     output. If set to 0, the print volume is at its minimum.
12214     **pawprtvol** can have values from -3 to 3:
12215     
12216     - **pawprtvol** = -1 or 1: matrices $\\rho_{ij}$ (atomic occupancies) and $D_{ij}$ (psp
12217       strength) are printed at each SCF cycle with details about their contributions.
12218     - **pawprtvol** = -2 or 2: like -1 or 1 plus additional printing: moments of
12219       "on-site" densities, details about local exact exchange.
12220     - **pawprtvol** = -3 or 3: like -2 or 2 plus additional printing: details about
12221       PAW+U, rotation matrices of spherical harmonics.
12222     
12223     When **pawprtvol** >= 0, up to 12 components of $\\rho_{ij}$ and $D_{ij}$ matrices for the
12224     1st and last atom are printed.
12225     When **pawprtvol** < 0, all components of $\\rho_{ij}$ and $D_{ij}$ matrices for all atoms are printed.
12226     """,
12227     ),
12228     
12229     Variable(
12230         abivarname="pawprtwf",
12231         varset="paw",
12232         vartype="integer",
12233         topics=['PAW_useful'],
12234         dimensions="scalar",
12235         defaultval=0,
12236         mnemonics="PAW: PRinT WaveFunctions",
12237         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
12238         text="""
12239     This input variable controls the output of the **full** PAW wave functions
12240     including the on-site contributions inside each PAW sphere needed to
12241     reconstruct the correct nodal shape in the augmentation region.
12242     **pawprtwf = 1** causes the generation of a file _PAWAVES.nc containing the full wavefunctions
12243     in **real space** on the fine FFT grid defined by [[pawecutdg]] or [[ngfftdg]].
12244     
12245     Limitations: At present (v8.0), **pawprtwf = 1** is not compatible with [[nspinor]] =2 and parallel executions
12246     Therefore the output of the _AE_WFK has to be done in sequential.
12247     Moreover, in order to use this feature, one has to enable the support for netcdf at configure-time
12248     as the _PAWAVES file is written using the NETCDF file format following the ETSF-IO
12249     specifications for wavefunctions in real space.
12250     
12251     If the code is run entirely in serial, additional output is made of various contributions to the all-electron
12252     wavefunction. By default the full available set of bands and k-points are
12253     ouput, but a single band and k-point index can be requested by using the
12254     variables [[pawprt_b]] and [[pawprt_k]].
12255     """,
12256     ),
12257     
12258     Variable(
12259         abivarname="pawspnorb",
12260         varset="paw",
12261         vartype="integer",
12262         topics=['PAW_useful', 'spinpolarisation_useful'],
12263         dimensions="scalar",
12264         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[nspinor]] == 2': 1, 'defaultval': 0}),
12265         mnemonics="PAW - option for SPiN-ORBit coupling",
12266         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
12267         text="""
12268     When PAW is activated, the **spin-orbit coupling** can be added without the
12269     use of specific PAW datasets (pseudopotentials).
12270     If [[pawspnorb]] = 1, spin-orbit will be added.
12271     If the wavefunction is spinorial (that is, if [[nspinor]] = 2), there is no
12272     reason not to include the spin-orbit interaction, so that the default value of
12273     [[pawspnorb]] becomes 1 when [[nspinor]] = 2.
12274     Note that only the all-electron "on-site" contribution to the Hamiltonian is
12275     taken into account; this is a very good approximation but requires the
12276     following conditions to be fulfilled:
12277     
12278     1- the  $\\tilde{\\phi}_{i}$  basis is complete enough
12279     
12280     2- the electronic density is mainly contained in the PAW sphere
12281     
12282     
12283     Also note that, when spin-orbit coupling is activated and there is some
12284     magnetization [[nspden]] = 4, the time-reversal symmetry is broken.
12285     The use of [[kptopt]] = 1 or [[kptopt]] = 2 is thus forbidden. It is advised to
12286     use [[kptopt]] = 3 (no symmetry used to generate k-points) or [[kptopt]] = 4 (only
12287     spatial symmetries used to generate k-points).
12288     Be careful if you choose to use [[kptopt]] = 0 (k-points given by hand); Time-
12289     reversal symmetry has to be avoided.
12290     An artificial scaling of the spin-orbit can be introduced thanks to the
12291     [[spnorbscl]] input variable.
12292     """,
12293     ),
12294     
12295     Variable(
12296         abivarname="pawstgylm",
12297         varset="paw",
12298         vartype="integer",
12299         topics=['PAW_expert'],
12300         dimensions="scalar",
12301         defaultval=1,
12302         mnemonics="PAW - option for the STorage of G_l(r).YLM(r)",
12303         requires="[[usepaw]] = 1",
12304         text=r"""
12305     When PAW is activated, the computation of compensation charge density (so
12306     called "hat" density) requires the computation of $g_{l}(r).Y_{lm}(r)$ factors (and
12307     cartesian derivatives) at each point of real space contained in PAW spheres.
12308     The number of atoms, of (l,m) quantum numbers and the sharpness of the real
12309     FFT grid can lead to a very big {$g_{l}.Y_{lm}$} datastructure. One can save memory
12310     by putting [[pawstgylm]] = 0; but, in that case, $g_{l}(r).Y_{lm}(r)$ factors a re-
12311     computed each time they are needed and CPU time increases.
12312     
12313     Possible choices:
12314     
12315     - [[pawstgylm]] = 0: $g_{l}(r).Y_{lm}(r)$ are not stored in memory and recomputed.
12316     - [[pawstgylm]] = 1: $g_{l}(r).Y_{lm}(r)$ are stored in memory.
12317     
12318     Note:
12319     $g_{l}(r)$ are shape functions (analytically known)
12320     
12321     $Y_{lm}(r)$ are real spherical harmonics
12322     """,
12323     ),
12324     
12325     Variable(
12326         abivarname="pawsushat",
12327         varset="paw",
12328         vartype="integer",
12329         topics=['PAW_expert'],
12330         dimensions="scalar",
12331         defaultval=0,
12332         mnemonics="PAW - SUSceptibility, inclusion of HAT (compensation charge) contribution",
12333         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1 and [[optdriver]] == 0",
12334         text=r"""
12335     Ground-State calculation only.
12336     When a sophisticated preconditioning scheme is selected for the SCF cycle of a
12337     Ground-State calculation ([[iprcel]] > 0), the computation of the susceptibility
12338     matrix is required several times during the cycle. This computation is
12339     computer time consuming, especially -- within PAW -- because of the inclusion
12340     of additional terms due to the compensation charge density. As only a crude
12341     valuation of the susceptibilty matrix is needed (to evaluate a preconditioning
12342     matrix), the compensation charge contribution can be neglected to save CPU
12343     time (select [[pawsushat]] = 0). This approximation could be unfavourable in
12344     some cases; in the latter, we advise to put [[pawsushat]] = 1.
12345     
12346     Possible choices:
12347     
12348     - [[pawsushat]] = 0: only plane-wave contribution to suscep. matrix is computed.
12349     - [[pawsushat]] = 1: the whole suscep. matrix (PW + PAW on-site) is computed.
12350     """,
12351     ),
12352     
12353     Variable(
12354         abivarname="pawujat",
12355         varset="dev",
12356         vartype="integer",
12357         topics=['DFT+U_expert'],
12358         dimensions="scalar",
12359         defaultval=1,
12360         mnemonics="PAW+macro_UJ, ATom number",
12361         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
12362         commentdefault=" i.e. the first atom treated with PAW+U.",
12363         text="""
12364     Determines the atom for which U (or J) should be determined. See also [[macro_uj]].
12365     """,
12366     ),
12367     
12368     Variable(
12369         abivarname="pawujrad",
12370         varset="dev",
12371         vartype="real",
12372         topics=['DFT+U_expert'],
12373         dimensions="scalar",
12374         defaultval=ValueWithUnit(units='a.u.', value=20),
12375         mnemonics="PAW+macro_UJ, sphere RADius",
12376         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
12377         text="""
12378     The sphere radius serves to extrapolate the U value calculated at r_paw to a
12379     larger sphere radius. See also [[macro_uj]]. As most projector functions are
12380     localized within r_paw to ≈80%, 20 a.u. contains ≈100% of the wavefunction and
12381     corresponds to r_paw -> ∞.
12382     """,
12383     ),
12384

12386         abivarname="pawujv",

12398     
12399     Variable(
12400         abivarname="pawusecp",
12401         varset="paw",
12402         vartype="integer",
12403         topics=['PAW_expert'],
12404         dimensions="scalar",
12405         defaultval=1,
12406         mnemonics="PAW - option for the USE of CPrj in memory (cprj=WF projected with NL projector)",
12407         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
12408         text="""
12409     When PAW is activated, the computation of cprj arrays is memory and time
12410     consuming.
12411     When [[pawusecp]] = 0, then the cprj are never kept in memory, they are
12412     recomputed when needed (this is CPU-time consuming). When [[pawusecp]] = 1, then
12413     the cprj are computed once and then kept in memory.
12414     Change the value of the keyword only if you are an experienced user
12415     (developer).
12416     Remember: $cprj = <\\tilde{\\psi}_{m}.p_{i}>$ ($\\tilde{\\psi}_{n}$=wave function, $p_{i}$=non-local projector).
12417     
12418     For the time being, only activated for RF calculations.
12419     """,
12420     ),
12421     
12422     Variable(
12423         abivarname="pawxcdev",
12424         varset="paw",
12425         vartype="integer",
12426         topics=['PAW_useful'],
12427         dimensions="scalar",
12428         defaultval=1,
12429         mnemonics="PAW - choice for eXchange-Correlation DEVelopment (spherical part)",
12430         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
12431         text="""
12432       * If set to 0, the exchange-correlation term in the spherical part of energy is totally computed on the angular mesh
12433       * If set to 1, the exchange-correlation term in the spherical part of energy is developed onto lm-moments at order 1
12434       * If set to 2, the exchange-correlation term in the spherical part of energy is developed onto lm-moments at order 2
12435         (can be memory/CPU consuming)
12436     
12437     Be careful: GGA requires [[pawxcdev]] > 0
12438     """,
12439     ),
12440     
12441     Variable(
12442         abivarname="ph_intmeth",
12443         varset="eph",
12444         vartype="integer",
12445         topics=['q-points_useful'],
12446         dimensions="scalar",
12447         defaultval=2,
12448         mnemonics="PHonons: INTegration METHod",
12449         text=r"""
12450     Select the integration technique for computing the phonon DOS and the
12451     Eliashberg function $\alpha^2F(\omega)$.
12452     
12453      * 1 --> Gaussian scheme (see also [[ph_smear]]).
12454      * 2 --> tetrahedron method (no other input is needed but requires at least 4 q-points in the BZ)
12455     """,
12456     ),

12468     define the q-path used for phonon band structures and phonon linewidths. It
12469     gives the number of points used to sample the smallest segment in the q-path

12513     code assumes a Gamma-centered mesh. The shifts are specified by [[ph_qshift]].

12571         defaultval="0.1 meV",

12573         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],

12580     Variable(
12581         abivarname="pimass",
12582         varset="rlx",
12583         vartype="real",
12584         topics=['PIMD_useful'],
12585         dimensions=['[[ntypat]]'],
12586         defaultval="[[ntypat]]",
12587         mnemonics="Path Integral fictitious MASSes",
12588         requires="[[imgmov]] = 9 or 13",
12589         text="""
12590     Only relevant if [[imgmov]] = 9 or 13 (Path-Integral Molecular Dynamics).
12591     Gives the fictitious masses ( [[cite:Marx1996]]) in atomic mass units for each kind of atom in cell. These masses are the inertial masses used in performing Path Integral Molecular
12592     Dynamics (PIMD), they are different from the true masses ([[amu]]) used to
12593     define the quantum spring that relates the different beads in PIMD. They can
12594     be chosen arbitrarily, but an appropriate choice will lead the different
12595     variables to move on the same time scale in order to optimize the sampling
12596     efficiency of the PIMD trajectory.
12597     If [[pitransform]] = 1 (normal mode transformation), or [[pitransform]] = 2
12598     (staging transformation), [[pimass]] is automatically set to its optimal value.
12599     """,
12600     ),
12601     
12602     Variable(
12603         abivarname="pimd_constraint",
12604         varset="rlx",
12605         vartype="integer",
12606         topics=['PIMD_useful'],
12607         dimensions="scalar",
12608         defaultval=0,
12609         mnemonics="Path-Integral Molecular Dynamics: CONSTRAINT to be applied on a reaction coordinate",
12610         requires="[[imgmov]] = 9 or 13",
12611         text="""
12612     Only relevant for Path-Integral Molecular Dynamics.
12613     Selects a constraint to be applied during the PIMD trajectory. The constraint
12614     is holonomic (it is a relation between the position variables). In practice,
12615     the total forces applied to the atomic positions are modified so as to respect
12616     the constraint.
12617     
12618     To date, the available constraints are:
12619     
12620       * **0**: no constraint
12621       * **1**: _"Blue Moon Ensemble" method_.
12622     The constraint is a linear combination of the positions of atomic centroids
12623     (this linear combination is kept constant during the simulation).
12624     Sum[W_i * X_i] = constant
12625     The X_i are the coordinates of the atomic centroids. The weights W_i have to
12626     be specified with the [[wtatcon]](3,[[natcon]],[[nconeq]]),
12627     [[iatcon]]([[natcon]]) and [[natcon]] input parameters (where [[nconeq]] is
12628     fixed to 1).
12629     More details on the implementation in [[cite:Komeiji2007]].
12630     """,
12631     ),
12632     
12633     Variable(
12634         abivarname="pitransform",
12635         varset="rlx",
12636         vartype="integer",
12637         topics=['PIMD_useful'],
12638         dimensions="scalar",
12639         defaultval=0,
12640         mnemonics="Path Integral coordinate TRANSFORMation",
12641         text="""
12642     Only relevant if [[imgmov]] = 9 or 13 (Path-Integral Molecular Dynamics).
12643     Coordinate transformation used in the integration of the Path Integral
12644     Molecular Dynamics equations of motion. The transformation, with an
12645     appropriate choice of fictitious masses ([[pimass]]), is used to force the
12646     different modes to move on the same time scale, and thus optimize the
12647     efficiency of the statistical sampling in the corresponding statistical
12648     ensemble. Available with a Langevin thermostat ([[imgmov]] = 9) or with Nose-
12649     Hoover chains ([[imgmov]] = 13). See [[cite:Tuckerman1996]].
12650     
12651     If equal to 0, no transformation is applied (primitive coordinates).
12652     If equal to 1, normal mode transformation (in that case, [[nimage]] must be
12653     absolutely EVEN).
12654     If equal to 2, staging transformation.
12655     """,
12656     ),
12657     
12658     Variable(
12659         abivarname="plowan_bandf",
12660         varset="dev",
12661         vartype="integer",
12662         topics=['Wannier_compulsory'],
12663         dimensions="scalar",
12664         defaultval=0,
12665         mnemonics="Projected Local Orbital WANnier functions BAND Final",
12666         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
12667         text="""
12668     
12669     Gives the upper band to include in the calculation of Wannier functions
12670     """,
12671     ),
12672     
12673     Variable(
12674         abivarname="plowan_bandi",
12675         varset="dev",
12676         vartype="integer",
12677         topics=['Wannier_compulsory'],
12678         dimensions="scalar",
12679         defaultval=0,
12680         mnemonics="Projected Local Orbital WANnier functions BAND Initial",
12681         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
12682         text="""

12684     """,

12686     
12687     Variable(
12688         abivarname="plowan_compute",
12689         varset="dev",
12690         vartype="integer",
12691         topics=['Wannier_compulsory'],
12692         dimensions="scalar",
12693         defaultval=0,
12694         mnemonics="Projected Local Orbital WANnier functions COMPUTATION",
12695         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
12696         text="""
12697     
12698     Activate computation of Projected Local Orbital Wannier functions (PLO
12699     Wannier) and corresponding band structure. Variables [[plowan_bandi]],
12700     [[plowan_bandf]], [[plowan_natom]], [[plowan_nbl]], [[plowan_iatom]],
12701     [[plowan_lcalc]], [[plowan_projcalc]] are mandatory to precise the nature of
12702     the projections.
12703     
12704       * 0 --> Default value: do not activate calculation of PLO Wannier.
12705       * 1 --> Compute PLO Wannier and band structure
12706       * 2 --> Compute PLO Wannier and band structure. In this case, the
12707       coupling in k-space between blocks of Wannier functions belonging to
12708       different angular momenta or atoms is removed.
12709     
12710     Other related variables are [[plowan_realspace]], [[plowan_nt]],
12711     [[plowan_it]]. The implementation is not symetrized over k-point and not
12712     parallelized. (The calculation of projections is detailed in [[cite:Amadon2008]] )
12713     """,
12714     ),
12715     
12716     Variable(
12717         abivarname="plowan_iatom",
12718         varset="dev",
12719         vartype="integer",
12720         topics=['Wannier_compulsory'],
12721         dimensions="scalar",
12722         defaultval=0,
12723         mnemonics="Projected Local Orbital WANnier functions, Index of ATOM",
12724         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
12725         text="""
12726     
12727     Gives the indices of the [[plowan_natom]] atoms on which the projections will be done.
12728     """,
12729     ),
12730     
12731     Variable(
12732         abivarname="plowan_it",
12733         varset="dev",
12734         vartype="integer",
12735         topics=['Wannier_useful'],
12736         dimensions=[3, '[[plowan_nt]]'],
12737         defaultval=0,
12738         mnemonics="Projected Local Orbital WANnier functions,  Index of Translation.",
12739         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
12740         text="""
12741     Requires [[plowan_realspace]] to be greater than 0 and [[plowan_nt]] to be
12742     greater than 0. Precise a given set of selected real space translation by
12743     using the real space vectors basis. These atoms are used to define Wannier
12744     functions in real space. These real space Wannier functions are used as a
12745     basis to compute the Hamiltonian.
12746     """,
12747     ),
12748     
12749     Variable(
12750         abivarname="plowan_lcalc",
12751         varset="dev",
12752         vartype="integer",
12753         topics=['Wannier_compulsory'],
12754         dimensions=['sum([[plowan_nbl]])'],
12755         defaultval=-1,
12756         mnemonics="Projected Local Orbital WANnier functions,  L values to use for CALCulation",
12757         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
12758         text="""
12759     Gives the [[plowan_nbl]] values of angular momenta for each atom, in the order
12760     of the atoms as given in [[plowan_iatom]].
12761     """,
12762     ),
12763     
12764     Variable(

12769         dimensions="scalar",
12770         defaultval=0,
12771         mnemonics="Projected Local Orbital WANnier functions, Number of ATOMs",

12789     """,

12791     
12792     Variable(
12793         abivarname="plowan_nt",

12797         dimensions="scalar",
12798         defaultval=0,
12799         mnemonics="""Projected Local Orbital WANnier functions,  Number of Translation on which the real space values of
12800     energy are computed""",

12804     atoms. These atoms are used to define Wannier functions in real space. These
12805     real space Wannier functions are used as a basis to compute the Hamiltonian.
12806     """,
12807     ),
12808     
12809     Variable(
12810         abivarname="plowan_projcalc",
12811         varset="dev",
12812         vartype="integer",
12813         topics=['Wannier_compulsory'],
12814         dimensions=['sum([[plowan_nbl]])'],
12815         defaultval=-1,
12816         mnemonics="Projected Local Orbital WANnier functions,  PROJectors values to use for CALCulation",
12817         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
12818         text="""
12819     Gives the [[plowan_nbl]] values of projectors for each atom, in the order of
12820     the atoms as given in [[plowan_iatom]]. The index i for the projectors refers
12821     to the ith number on line orbitals of the PAW atomic data file.
12822     """,
12823     ),
12824     
12825     Variable(
12826         abivarname="plowan_realspace",
12827         varset="dev",
12828         vartype="integer",
12829         topics=['Wannier_useful'],
12830         dimensions="scalar",
12831         defaultval=0,
12832         mnemonics="Projected Local Orbital WANnier functions,  activate REAL SPACE calculation.",
12833         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
12834         text="""
12835     Can take the following values:
12836     
12837       * 0 --> Default value: do not activate calculation of real space Wannier functions.
12838       * 1 --> Compute PLO Wannier in real space for analysis. These data can also be used
12839         in a following dataset to perform a Wannier interpolation.
12840       * 2 --> Do simple Wannier Interpolation for a given k points starting from real space Wannier function
12841         Hamiltonian computed in a preceding dataset.
12842     """,
12843     ),
12844     
12845     Variable(
12846         abivarname="polcen",
12847         varset="ffield",
12848         vartype="real",
12849         topics=['Berry_useful'],
12850         dimensions=[3],
12851         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=3, value=0),
12852         mnemonics="POLarization for CENtrosymmetric geometry",
12853         text="""
12854     When doing a finite electric displacement field calculation, if the structure
12855     is centrosymmetric but the polarization is non-zero (such as for AlAs), this
12856     non-zero polarization should be specified as [[polcen]] (in REDUCED
12857     coordinates, in atomic units) in the input file. See Eq.(24) in the Suppl. of
12858     [[cite:Stengel2009]]
12859     """,
12860     ),
12861     
12862     Variable(
12863         abivarname="posdoppler",
12864         varset="gstate",
12865         vartype="integer",
12866         topics=['positron_basic'],
12867         dimensions="scalar",
12868         defaultval=0,
12869         mnemonics="POSitron computation of DOPPLER broadening",
12870         text="""
12871     Relevant only when [[positron]]/=0.
12872     This input parameter activates the calculation of the Doppler broadening of
12873     the electron-positron annihilation radiation.
12874     An output file containing the momentum distributions of annihilating electron-positron pairs is created.
12875     Such a computation needs a core wave-function file (per atom type) to be
12876     provided. This core WF file should be named '**psp_file_name**.corewf' (where
12877     **pspfile_name** is the name of the pseudo-potential (or PAW) file) or
12878     'corewf.abinit**ityp**' (where **ityp** is the index of the atom type). Core WF
12879     files can be obtained with the atompaw tool by the use of **prtcorewf** keyword.
12880     """,
12881     ),
12882     
12883     Variable(
12884         abivarname="positron",
12885         varset="gstate",
12886         vartype="integer",
12887         topics=['positron_compulsory'],
12888         dimensions="scalar",
12889         defaultval=0,
12890         mnemonics="POSITRON calculation",
12891         text="""
12892     This input parameter can be positive or negative.
12893     Negative values for [[positron]] are only relevant for PAW calculations.
12894     Electron-positron correlation functional is defined by [[ixcpositron]].
12895     Other relevant input parameter: [[posocc]] (occupation number for the
12896     positron).
12897     
12898     Positive values for [[positron]]:\n
12899     For [[positron]] = 1 or 2, will perform the calculation of positron
12900     lifetime (and annihilation rate).
12901     
12902       * [[positron]] = 1:\n
12903     Starting from a previous electronic GS density (with [[positron]] = 0), a
12904     positronic ground-state calculation is performed, considering that the
12905     electrons are not perturbed by the presence of the positron.
12906     This is almost correct for a positron in a perfect bulk material. But this
12907     approximation fails when defects exist in the material (for instance: the
12908     positron might be trapped by a vacancy).
12909     The electronic density will be automatically read from a _DEN file (with or
12910     without [[irdden]] keyword).
12911     At the end of the SCF cycle, the positron lifetime and annihilation rate are
12912     printed out.
12913     
12914     Additional information for the use of pseudopotentials:
12915     
12916         PAW datasets: nothing to do; simply use usual electronic PAW datasets
12917         Norm-conserving pseudopotentials: One has to use specific pseudopotentials for the positron calculation. They must be of the FHI type (pspcod=6), and must contain at their end, the all-electrons core density generated with FHI98PP. They must have lmax=lloc=0 (check that this works for the electronic GS !! No ghost, etc...). Otherwise, their are similar to an usual FHI pseudopotential.
12918     
12919     
12920       * [[positron]] = 2:\n
12921     Starting from a previous positronic GS density (with [[positron]] = 1 ), an
12922     electronic ground-state calculation is performed, keeping the positronic
12923     density constant.
12924     The positronic density will be automatically read from a _DEN file (with or
12925     without [[getden]]/[[irdden]] keyword).
12926     At the end of the SCF cycle, the positron lifetime and annihilation rate are
12927     printed out.
12928     
12929     Additional information for the use of pseudopotentials:
12930     
12931         PAW datasets: nothing to do; simply use usual electronic PAW datasets
12932         Norm-conserving pseudopotentials: One has to use specific pseudopotentials for the electron calculation. They must be of the FHI type (pspcod=6), and must contain at their end, the all-electrons core density generated with FHI98PP.
12933     
12934     
12935       * **Typical use**:\n
12936     The calculation is done in several steps:
12937     The first one is a normal GS calculation for the electrons, with [[positron]] = 0.
12938     The only specific thing to do is to set [[prtden]] = 1 (this is the default
12939     for ABINIT v6.x+). This will create the associated _DEN file which will be
12940     used as input file for the positronic GS calculation.
12941     The second step is the GS calculation of the positron and subsequently its
12942     lifetime, with [[positron]] =1. One has to define also [[ixcpositron]].
12943     Then, it is possible to perform an additional step, computing the GS
12944     electronic density in presence of the positron, with [[positron]] = 2.
12945     and so on...
12946     This procedure can be automated (for PAW only) by the use of a negative value
12947     for [[positron]].
12948     At the end, a converged value of the positron lifetime (decomposed in several
12949     contributions) is printed.
12950     See also [[posdoppler]] keyword for the calculation of Doppler broadening.
12951     
12952     
12953     Negative values for [[positron]]:\n
12954     For [[positron]]<0, will perform an automatic calculation of electrons and
12955     positron densities in the two-component DFT context; then will compute
12956     positron lifetime (and annihilation rate).
12957     
12958       * [[positron]] = -1:\n
12959     Starting from scratch, will first perform a usual electronic ground-state
12960     calculation until convergence (controlled by the use of one of the _tolerance_
12961     keywords).
12962     Then will perform a positronic ground state calculation in presence of the
12963     electrons and ions; then an electronic ground state calculation in presence of
12964     the positron and the ions...
12965     and so on... until the total energy is converged.
12966     The convergence of the total energy of the ions+electrons+positron system is
12967     controlled by the use of the [[postoldfe]], [[postoldff]] and [[posnstep]]
12968     input keywords.
12969     With [[positron]] = -1, at the beginning of each new electronic/positronic
12970     step, the wave functions are unknown.
12971     
12972       * [[positron]] = -10:\n
12973     Same as [[positron]] = -1 except that the electronic/positronic wave functions
12974     are stored in memory.
12975     Consequently, the total number of iterations to reach the convergence
12976     ($\Delta$Etotal<[[postoldfe]] or $\Delta$Forces<[[postoldff]]) is smaller.
12977     But, this can increase the total amount of memory needed by the code.
12978     
12979       * [[positron]] = -2:\n
12980     Same as [[positron]] = -1 except that the two-component DFT cycle is forced to
12981     stop at the end of an electronic step.
12982     
12983       * [[positron]] = -20:\n
12984     Same as [[positron]] = -10 except that the two-component DFT cycle is forced to
12985     stop at the end of an electronic step.
12986     
12987     
12988     Advice for use:
12989     There are two typical cases which have to be differently treated:
12990     
12991       * **A positron in a perfect _bulk_ system**:\n
12992     In that case, the positron is delocalized in the whole crystal. Its density is
12993     almost zero.
12994     Thus, the "zero density positron limit" has to be used. [[ixcpositron]] has to
12995     be choosen accordingly.
12996     In order to have the zero density positron limit it is adviced to follow these
12997     points:
12998     
12999       * 1- Put a small positronic charge (by setting a [[posocc]] to a small value) **OR** use a big supercell.
13000       * 2- Use only k=$\Gamma$ wave vector for the positronic calculation.
13001       * 3- Use the manual procedure in 2 steps: first [[positron]] = 0 and then [[positron]] = 1; avoid the [[positron]] = 2 step and the automatic procedure ([[positron]]<0).
13002     
13003     In principle, the positron lifetime should converge with the value of
13004     [[posocc]] or the size of the supercell.
13005     
13006       * **A positron trapped in a _default_ (vacancy...)**:\n
13007     In that case, the positron is localized in the default. Its density can be
13008     localized in the simulation cell (provided that the cell is sufficiently
13009     large) and influences the electronic density.
13010     So, it is advised to use the automatic procedure ([[positron]]<0) or the
13011     manual procedure with several [[positron]] = 0,1,2,1,... steps.
13012     K-points can be used as in usual electronic calculations.
13013     Also note that it is possible to use forces and stresses to perform structural
13014     minimization.
13015     
13016     References: [[cite:Arponen1979a]], [[cite:Boronski1986]], [[cite:Sterne1991]], [[cite:Puska1995]], [[cite:Barbiellini1995]]
13017     """,
13018     ),
13019     
13020     Variable(
13021         abivarname="posnstep",
13022         varset="gstate",
13023         vartype="integer",
13024         topics=['positron_basic'],
13025         dimensions="scalar",
13026         defaultval=50,
13027         mnemonics="POSitron calculation: max. Number of STEPs for the two-component DFT",
13028         text="""
13029     Relevant only when [[positron]]<0.
13030     Sets the maximum number of electronic/positronic iterations that, when
13031     reached, will cause the two-component DFT SCF cycle to stop.
13032     The code will first compute the electronic ground-state, then the positronic
13033     ground state in the electronic density, then the electronic ground state in
13034     the positronic density until $\Delta$Etotal<[[postoldfe]] or $\Delta$Forces<[[postoldff]] or the number
13035     of electronic/positronic steps is [[posnstep]].
13036     """,
13037     ),
13038     
13039     Variable(
13040         abivarname="posocc",
13041         varset="gstate",
13042         vartype="real",
13043         topics=['positron_basic'],
13044         dimensions="scalar",
13045         defaultval=1,
13046         mnemonics="POSitron calculation: OCCupation number for the positron",
13047         text="""
13048     Relevant only when [[positron]]/=0.
13049     Sets the occupation number for the positron. Has to be <=1.
13050     Changing [[posocc]] is only useful for bulk calculation when one wants to
13051     perform lifetime computations using a small simulation cell (can avoid the use
13052     of a supercell). It simulates the dispersion of the positron in the whole
13053     crystal.
13054     """,
13055     ),
13056     
13057     Variable(
13058         abivarname="postoldfe",
13059         varset="gstate",
13060         vartype="real",
13061         topics=['positron_basic'],
13062         dimensions="scalar",
13063         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[postoldff]] = 0': 1e-06, 'defaultval': 0.0}),
13064         mnemonics="POSitron calculation: TOLerance on the DiFference of total Energy",
13065         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
13066         text="""
13067     Relevant only when [[positron]]<0.
13068     Sets a tolerance for absolute difference of total energy (of
13069     _ions+electrons+positron_ system) that, when reached, will cause the SCF cycle
13070     to stop before the number of steps is [[nstep]] or the number of
13071     electronic/positronic steps is [[posnstep]].
13072     
13073     Can be specified in Ha (the default), Ry, eV or Kelvin, since [[postoldfe]] has
13074     the [[ENERGY]] characteristics.
13075     One and only one of [[postoldfe]] or [[postoldff]] can be set.
13076     """,
13077     ),
13078     
13079     Variable(
13080         abivarname="postoldff",
13081         varset="gstate",
13082         vartype="real",
13083         topics=['positron_basic'],
13084         dimensions="scalar",
13085         defaultval=0,
13086         mnemonics="POSitron calculation: TOLerance on the DiFference of Forces",
13087         text="""
13088     Relevant only when [[positron]] < 0.
13089     Sets a tolerance for absolute difference of maximum force (in hartree/Bohr) acting on ions (due
13090     to _ions+electrons+positron_ system) that, when reached, will cause the SCF
13091     cycle to stop before the number of SCF steps is [[nstep]] or the number of
13092     electronic/positronic steps is [[posnstep]].
13093     One and only one of [[postoldfe]] or [[postoldff]] can be set.
13094     """,
13095     ),
13096     
13097     Variable(
13098         abivarname="ppmfrq",
13099         varset="gw",
13100         vartype="real",
13101         topics=['SelfEnergy_basic'],
13102         dimensions="scalar",
13103         defaultval=ValueWithUnit(units='Ha', value=0.0),
13104         mnemonics="Plasmon Pole Model FReQuency",
13105         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
13106         requires="[[optdriver]] in [3,4]",
13107         text="""
13108     **In plasmon-pole calculations**
13109     
13110     Usually only effective if GW corrections are evaluated using the plasmon-pole
13111     model of Godby-Needs ([[ppmodel]] == 1).
13112     
13113     In the present status of the GW code, the convolution in frequency space
13114     defining the self-energy operator can be evaluated using two different
13115     approaches: numerical integration and plasmon-pole models.
13116     Methods based on the numerical integration (contour deformation, analytic
13117     continuation) require the knowledge of the screened interaction for several
13118     frequencies. These approaches give the most accurate results but at the price
13119     of an increase in the CPU time required.
13120     Alternatively, it is possible to approximate the dynamical behaviour of the
13121     screened interaction through simple analytical expressions, the so-called
13122     plasmon-pole models. In the plasmon-pole model proposed by Godby-Needs
13123     ([[ppmodel]] = 1), the screening must be available at zero frequency, as well as
13124     at another imaginary frequency, of the order of the plasmon frequency (the
13125     peak in the EELS spectrum). This information is used to model the behaviour of
13126     the dielectric matrix for all frequencies. During the calculation of the
13127     screening, [[ppmfrq]] defines the imaginary frequency where the dielectric
13128     matrix is evaluated, in addition to the zero frequency. During the self-energy
13129     run, [[ppmfrq]] can be used to define the second frequency to be used to
13130     calculate the plasmon-pole parameters. This is particularly useful when the
13131     SCR file contains several frequencies along the imaginary axis. In this case
13132     the frequency whose value is the closest one to [[ppmfrq]] will be selected.
13133     Note that, if the plasmon-pole approximation is good, then, the choice of
13134     [[ppmfrq]] should have no influence on the final result. One should check
13135     whether this is the case. In general, the plasmon frequencies of bulk solids
13136     are of the order of 0.5 Hartree.
13137     
13138     **In Contour Deformation calculations**
13139     
13140     [[ppmfrq]] is here used to **override** the default value calculated from the
13141     average electronic density per unit cell. This can affect the distribution of
13142     gridpoints along the imaginary and real frequency axes. See
13143     [[cd_frqim_method]], [[gw_frqim_inzgrid]] and [[gw_frqre_inzgrid]] for more
13144     details.
13145     """,
13146     ),
13147     
13148     Variable(
13149         abivarname="ppmodel",
13150         varset="gw",
13151         vartype="integer",
13152         topics=['SelfEnergy_basic'],
13153         dimensions="scalar",
13154         defaultval=1,
13155         mnemonics="Plasmon Pole MODEL",
13156         requires="[[optdriver]] in [3,4]",
13157         text="""
13158       * [[ppmodel]] = 1: PP model of Godby and Needs [[cite:Godby1989]].
13159       * [[ppmodel]] = 2: PP model of Hybertsen and Louie [[cite:Hybertsen1986]].
13160       * [[ppmodel]] = 3: PP model of W. von der Linden and P. Horsh [[cite:vonderLinden1988]].
13161       * [[ppmodel]] = 4: PP model of Farid and Engel [[cite:Engel1993]].
13162       * [[ppmodel]] = 0: no PP model, numerical integration (contour deformation method [[cite:Lebegue2003]]).
13163     
13164     Please note the difference between [[ppmodel]] 1 and [[ppmodel]] 2,3,4. In the
13165     first case ([[ppmodel]] = 1), the plasmon-pole parameters are determined in
13166     order to reproduce the behaviour of the dielectric matrix at two calculated
13167     frequencies: the static limit ($\omega=0$) and the imaginary frequency defined by
13168     [[ppmfrq]]. In the last three cases, instead, the plasmon-pole parameters are
13169     found by using the dielectric matrix calculated only at $\omega=0$ and enforcing
13170     the so-called f-sum rule. See also [[nfreqre]].
13171     
13172     Please note also that in the case of [[ppmodel]] 4, the plasmon energies are
13173     not simple mathematical parameters, but rather have a physical meaning (at
13174     least the lowest ones). Thus the calculated plasmon band structure (plasmon
13175     energy vs q vector) is reported in the output file for the lowest 10 bands.
13176     """,
13177     ),
13178     
13179     Variable(
13180         abivarname="prepanl",
13181         varset="dfpt",
13182         vartype="integer",
13183         topics=['nonlinear_compulsory'],
13184         dimensions="scalar",
13185         defaultval=0,
13186         mnemonics="PREPAre Non-Linear response calculation",
13187         text="""
13188     The computation of third-order derivatives from the 2n+1 theorem requires the
13189     first-order wavefunctions and densities obtained from a linear response
13190     calculation. The standard approach in a linear response calculation is:
13191     
13192       * compute only the irreducible perturbations;
13193       * use symmetries to reduce the number of k-points for the k-point integration.
13194     
13195     This approach cannot be applied, presently (v4.1), if the first-order
13196     wavefunctions are to be used to compute third-order derivatives. First, for
13197     electric fields, the code needs the derivatives along the three directions.
13198     Still, in case of phonons, only the irreducible perturbations are required.
13199     Second, for both electric fields and phonons, the wavefunctions must be
13200     available in half the BZ (kptopt=2), or the full BZ (kptopt=3).
13201     During the linear response calculation, in order to prepare a non-linear
13202     calculation, one should put [[prepanl]] to 1 in order to force ABINIT to
13203     compute the electric field perturbation along the three directions explicitly,
13204     and to keep the full number of k-points.
13205     """,
13206     ),
13207     
13208     Variable(
13209         abivarname="prepgkk",
13210         varset="dfpt",
13211         vartype="integer",
13212         topics=['ElPhonInt_compulsory'],
13213         dimensions="scalar",
13214         defaultval=0,
13215         mnemonics="PREPAre GKK calculation",
13216         text="""
13217     The calculation of electron-phonon coupling quantities requires the presence
13218     of all the perturbations (all atoms in all directions) for the chosen set of
13219     (irreducible) q-points. To impose this and prevent ABINIT from using symmetry
13220     to reduce the number of perturbations, set [[prepgkk]] to 1. Use in
13221     conjunction with [[prtgkk]].
13222     """,
13223     ),
13224     
13225     Variable(
13226         abivarname="prepscphon",
13227         varset="dev",
13228         vartype="integer",
13229         topics=['printing_prngs'],
13230         dimensions="scalar",
13231         defaultval=0,
13232         mnemonics="PREPare Self-Consistent PHONon calculation",
13233         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
13234         text="""
13235     Print PCINFO, PHFREQ, and PHVEC files, for use with self-consistent phonon
13236     runs, after a perturbation calculation. Only prints out files for the present
13237     q-point, and there is presently no tool to symmetrize or merge these files, so
13238     use anaddb instead (with prtscphon input variable). The abinit input variable
13239     is destined to someday bypass the use of anaddb for scphon calculations.
13240     """,
13241     ),
13242     
13243     Variable(
13244         abivarname="prt1dm",
13245         varset="files",
13246         vartype="integer",
13247         topics=['printing_prgs'],
13248         dimensions="scalar",
13249         defaultval=0,
13250         mnemonics="PRinT 1-DiMensional potential and density",
13251         text="""
13252     If set >= 1, provide one-dimensional projection of potential and density, for
13253     each of the three axis. This corresponds to averaging the potential or the
13254     density on bi-dimensional slices of the FFT grid.
13255     """,
13256     ),
13257     
13258     Variable(
13259         abivarname="prtatlist",
13260         varset="rlx",
13261         vartype="integer",
13262         topics=['printing_prgeo', 'Output_useful'],
13263         dimensions=['[[natom]]'],
13264         defaultval=0,
13265         mnemonics="PRinT by ATom LIST of ATom",
13266         characteristics=['[[NO_MULTI]]'],
13267         text="""
13268     This is an array of the numbers associated to the index atoms that the user
13269     want to print in the output or log files, this is useful when you have a large
13270     number of atoms and you are only interested to follow specific atoms, the
13271     numbers associated should be consistent with the list in [[xcart]] or
13272     [[xred]]. This input variable does not affect the contents of the "OUT.nc" or
13273     "HIST.nc", those are NetCDF files containing the information about all the atoms.
13274     """,
13275     ),
13276     
13277     Variable(
13278         abivarname="prtbbb",
13279         varset="dfpt",
13280         vartype="integer",
13281         topics=['printing_prngs', 'Output_useful'],
13282         dimensions="scalar",
13283         defaultval=0,
13284         mnemonics="PRinT Band-By-Band decomposition",
13285         text="""
13286     If [[prtbbb]] is 1, print the band-by-band decomposition of Born effective
13287     charges and localization tensor, in case they are computed. See [[cite:Ghosez2000]].
13288     """,
13289     ),
13290     
13291     Variable(
13292         abivarname="prtbltztrp",
13293         varset="dev",
13294         vartype="integer",
13295         topics=['printing_prgs'],
13296         dimensions="scalar",
13297         defaultval=0,
13298         mnemonics="PRinT output for BoLTZTRaP code",
13299         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
13300         text="""
13301     Print out geometry _BLZTRP_GEOM and eigenenergy _BLZTRP_EIGEN files for
13302     the [BoltzTraP code](https://www.imc.tuwien.ac.at/forschungsbereich_theoretische_chemie/forschungsgruppen/prof_dr_gkh_madsen_theoretical_materials_chemistry/boltztrap/) by Georg Madsen.
13303     """,
13304     ),
13305     
13306     Variable(
13307         abivarname="prtcif",
13308         varset="dev",
13309         vartype="integer",
13310         topics=['printing_prgeo'],
13311         dimensions="scalar",
13312         defaultval=0,
13313         mnemonics="PRinT Crystallographic Information File",
13314         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
13315         text="""
13316     If set to 1, a CIF file is output with the crystallographic data for the
13317     present run (cell size shape and atomic positions).
13318     """,
13319     ),
13320     
13321     Variable(
13322         abivarname="prtden",
13323         varset="files",
13324         vartype="integer",
13325         topics=['printing_prden'],
13326         dimensions="scalar",
13327         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[nimage]] > 1': 0, 'defaultval': 1}),
13328         mnemonics="PRinT the DENsity",
13329         text="""
13330     If set to 1 or a larger value, provide output of electron density in real
13331     space rho(r), in units of electrons/Bohr^3.
13332     If [[ionmov]] == 0, the name of the density file will be the root output name,
13333     followed by _DEN.
13334     If [[ionmov]] == 1 or 2, density files will be output at each time step, with
13335     the name being made of
13336     
13337       * the root output name,
13338       * followed by _TIMx, where x is related to the time step (see later)
13339       * then followed by _DEN
13340     
13341     The file structure of this unformatted output file is described in [[help:abinit#denfile|this section]].
13342     If [[prtden]] is lower than 0, two files will be printed for restart every
13343     [[prtden]] step, with the names being made of
13344     
13345       * the root temporary name,
13346       * followed by _DEN_x, where x is 0000 or 0001 alternatively.
13347       * The most recent of the two files should be used for restart, and copied to root input name_DS2_DEN
13348       * To perform a restart, in a multidataset mode, use ndtset 2 and jdtset 2 3 (that is 2 datasets, numbered 2 and 3)
13349       * In the dataset 2, get the density you just copied (getden2 -1), perform a non self-consistent calculation and print the wave function (prtwf2 1)
13350       * In the dataset 3, get the previous wf(getwfk3 -1), and continue the calculation
13351       * This complicated procedure is due to the fact that reading the density is only allowed for a non sc calculation, and also for a dataset different of 0 or the previous one, the option we choose here.
13352     
13353     Please note that in the case of PAW ([[usepaw]] = 1) calculations, the _DEN
13354     density output is not the full physical electron density. If what is wanted is
13355     the full physical electron density, say for post-processing with [[help:aim|AIM]]
13356     or visualization, prtden > 1 will produce physical electron density or other interesting quantities (see below).
13357     Nevertheless, even in the PAW case, when chaining together calculations where
13358     the density from one calculation is to be used in a subsequent calculation, it
13359     is necessary to use the _DEN files and **not** one of the other files produced
13360     with prtden  > 1, i.e. _PAWDEN, ATMDEN_xxx or else. Note that the usual _DEN
13361     file is always generated as soon as prtden >= 1. Options 2 to 6 for prtden are
13362     relevant only for [[usepaw]] = 1 and control the output of the full electron
13363     density in the PAW case:
13364     
13365     
13366     **prtden=2** causes generation of a file _PAWDEN that contains the bulk
13367     **valence** charge density together with the PAW on-site contributions, and
13368     has the same format as the other density files.
13369     **prtden=3** causes generation of a file _PAWDEN that contains the bulk
13370     **full** charge density (valence+core)
13371     **prtden=4** causes generation of three files _ATMDEN_CORE, _ATMDEN_VAL and
13372     _ATMDEN_FULL which respectively contain the core, valence and full atomic
13373     protodensity (the density of the individual component atoms in vacuum
13374     superposed at the bulk atomic positions). This can be used to generate various
13375     visualizations of the bonding density.
13376     **prtden=5** options 2 and 4 taken together.
13377     **prtden=6** options 3 and 4 taken together.
13378     **prtden=7** causes the generation of all the individual contributions to the
13379     bulk **valence** charge density: n_tilde-n_hat (_N_TILDE), n_onsite (_N_ONE)
13380     and n_tilde_onsite (_NT_ONE). This is for diagnosis purposes only.
13381     
13382     Options 3 to 6 currently require the user to supply the atomic core and
13383     valence density in external files in the working directory. The files must be
13384     named properly; for example, the files for an atom of type 1 should be named:
13385     "core_density_atom_type1.dat" and "valence_density_atom_type1.dat". The file
13386     should be a text file, where the first line is assumed to be a comment, and
13387     the subsequent lines contain two values each, where the first one is a radial
13388     coordinate and the second the value of the density n(r). Please note that it
13389     is n(r) which should be supplied, **not** n(r)/r^2. The first coordinate point
13390     must be the origin, i.e. **_r = 0_ **. The atomic densities are spherically
13391     averaged, so assumed to be completely spherically symmetric, even for open
13392     shells.
13393     
13394     NOTE: in the PAW case, **DO NOT** use _PAWDEN or _ATMDEN_xxx files produced by
13395     prtden  > 1 to chain the density output from one calculation as the input to
13396     another, use the _DEN file for that.
13397     """,
13398     ),
13399     
13400     Variable(
13401         abivarname="prtdensph",
13402         varset="gstate",
13403         vartype="integer",
13404         topics=['printing_prden'],
13405         dimensions="scalar",
13406         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'defaultval': 1}),
13407         mnemonics="PRinT integral of DENsity inside atomic SPHeres",
13408         text="""
13409     When this flag is activated, values of integral(s) of total density inside
13410     sphere(s) around each atom are printed in output file (for each spin
13411     component). Spheres around atoms are defined by a radius given by [[ratsph]] keyword.
13412     Note: integral of density inside a sphere around an atom can be used to
13413     determine a rough approximation of the local magnetic moment; this is
13414     particularly useful for antiferromagnetic systems.
13415     The algorithm to compute this integral is particularly primitive: the points
13416     on the FFT grids, belonging to the interior of the sphere are determined, and
13417     the value of the functions on these points are summed, taking into account a
13418     fixed volume attributed to each point. In particular, the integral as a
13419     function of the radius will be a constant, except when a new point enters the
13420     sphere, in which case a sudden jump occurs. However, since the purpose of this
13421     output is to get a rough idea of the repartition of the density, this is not a
13422     real problem. If you are interested in a more accurate estimation of the
13423     density within a sphere, you should use the cut3d postprocessor ([[help:cut3d]]).
13424     """,
13425     ),
13426     
13427     Variable(
13428         abivarname="prtdipole",
13429         varset="dev",
13430         vartype="integer",
13431         topics=['printing_prgs'],
13432         dimensions="scalar",
13433         defaultval=0,
13434         mnemonics="PRinT DIPOLE",
13435         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
13436         text="""
13437     Print out dipole of unit cell, calculated in real space for the primitive cell
13438     only. Under development.
13439     """,
13440     ),
13441     
13442     Variable(
13443         abivarname="prtdos",
13444         varset="files",
13445         vartype="integer",
13446         topics=['printing_prdos', 'ElecDOS_basic'],
13447         dimensions="scalar",
13448         defaultval=0,
13449         mnemonics="PRinT the Density Of States",
13450         text="""
13451     Provide output of Density of States if set to 1, 2 or 3. Can either use a
13452     smearing technique ([[prtdos]] = 1), or the tetrahedron method ([[prtdos]] = 2).
13453     If [[prtdos]] = 3, provide output of Local Density of States inside a sphere
13454     centered on an atom, as well as the angular-momentum projected DOS, in the
13455     same sphere. The resolution of the linear grid of energies for which the DOS
13456     is computed can be tuned thanks to [[dosdeltae]].
13457     
13458     If [[prtdos]] = 1, the smeared density of states is obtained from the
13459     eigenvalues, properly weighted at each k point using [[wtk]], and smeared
13460     according to [[occopt]] and [[tsmear]]. All levels that are present in the
13461     calculation are taken into account (occupied and unoccupied). Note that
13462     [[occopt]] must be between 3 and 7. Also note that the sampling of the
13463     Brillouin Zone that is needed to get a converged DOS is usually much finer
13464     than the sampling needed to converge the total energy or the geometry of the
13465     system, unless [[tsmear]] is very large (hence the DOS is not obtained
13466     properly).. A separate convergence study is needed.
13467     In order to compute the DOS of an insulator with [[prtdos]] = 1, compute its
13468     density thanks to a self-consistent calculation (with a non-metallic
13469     [[occopt]] value, 0, 1 or 2), then use [[prtdos]] = 1, together with
13470     [[iscf]] = -3, and a metallic [[occopt]], between 3 and 7, providing the needed
13471     smearing. If [[prtdos]] = 1, the name of the DOS file is the root name for the
13472     output files, followed by "_DOS".
13473     
13474     If [[prtdos]] = 2, the DOS is computed using the tetrahedron method. As in the
13475     case of [[prtdos]] = 1, all levels that are present in the calculation are taken
13476     into account (occupied and unoccupied). In this case, the k-points must have
13477     been defined using the input variable [[ngkpt]] or the input variable
13478     [[kptrlatt]]. There must be at least two non-equivalent points in the
13479     Irreducible Brillouin Zone to use [[prtdos]] = 2. It is strongly advised to use
13480     a non-shifted k-point grid ([[shiftk]] 0 0 0): such grids contain naturally
13481     more extremal points (band minima and maxima at Gamma or at the zone-
13482     boundaries) than shifted grids, and lead to more non-equivalent points than
13483     shifted grids, for the same grid spacing. There is no need to take care of the
13484     [[occopt]] or [[tsmear]] input variables, and there is no subtlety to be taken
13485     into account for insulators. The computation can be done in the self-
13486     consistent case as well as in the non-self-consistent case, using [[iscf]] = -3.
13487     This allows one to refine the DOS at fixed starting density.
13488     In that case, if [[ionmov]] == 0, the name of the potential file will be the
13489     root output name, followed by _DOS (like in the [[prtdos]] = 1 case).
13490     However, if [[ionmov]] == 1 or 2, potential files will be output at each time
13491     step, with the name being made of
13492     
13493       * the root output name,
13494       * followed by _TIMx, where x is related to the time step (see later)
13495       * then followed by _DOS.
13496     
13497     If [[prtdos]] = 3, the same tetrahedron method as for [[prtdos]] = 2 is used, but
13498     the DOS inside a sphere centered on some atom is delivered, as well as the
13499     angular-momentum projected (l=0,1,2,3,4) DOS in the same sphere. The
13500     preparation of this case, the parameters under which the computation is to be
13501     done, and the file denomination is similar to the [[prtdos]] = 2 case. However,
13502     three additional input variables might be provided, describing the atoms that
13503     are the center of the sphere (input variables [[natsph]] and [[iatsph]]), as
13504     well as the radius of this sphere (input variable [[ratsph]]).
13505     In case of PAW, [[ratsph]] radius has to be greater or equal to largest PAW
13506     radius of the atom types considered (which is read from the PAW atomic data
13507     file; see rc_sph or r_paw). Additional printing and/or approximations in PAW
13508     mode can be controlled with [[pawprtdos]] keyword (in
13509     particular,[[pawprtdos]] = 2 can be used to compute quickly a very good
13510     approximation of the DOS).
13511     
13512     Note 1: when [[prtdos]] = 3, it is possible to output m-decomposed LDOS in _DOS
13513     file; simply use [[prtdosm]] keyword.
13514     Note 2: the integrated total DOS in spheres around atoms can be obtained when
13515     [[prtdensph]] flag is activated. It can be compared to the integrated DOS
13516     provided in _DOS file when [[prtdos]] = 3.
13517     
13518     [[prtdos]] = 4 delivers the sphere-projected DOS (like [[prtdos]] = 3), on the
13519     basis of a smearing approach (like [[prtdos]] = 1)
13520     
13521     [[prtdos]] = 5 delivers the spin-spin DOS in the [[nspinor]] == 2 case, using the
13522     tetrahedron method (as [[prtdos]] = 2).
13523     """,
13524     ),
13525     
13526     Variable(
13527         abivarname="prtdosm",
13528         varset="files",
13529         vartype="integer",
13530         topics=['printing_prdos', 'ElecDOS_basic'],
13531         dimensions="scalar",
13532         defaultval=0,
13533         mnemonics="PRinT the Density Of States with M decomposition",
13534         text="""
13535     Relevant only when [[prtdos]] = 3.
13536     If set to 1, the m-decomposed LDOS is delivered in DOS file.
13537     Note that [[prtdosm]] computes the M-resolved partial dos for complex
13538     spherical harmonics,giving e.g. DOS(L,M) == DOS(L,-M) (without spin-orbit). In
13539     the contrary, the LDA+U occupation matrix, see [[dmatpawu]] is in the real
13540     spherical harmonics basis.
13541     If set to 2, the m-decomposed LDOS is delivered in DOS file.
13542     In this case, [[prtdosm]] computes the M-resolved partial dos for real
13543     spherical harmonics in the same basis as the LDA+U occupation matrix.
13544     """,
13545     ),
13546     
13547     Variable(
13548         abivarname="prtebands",
13549         varset="gstate",
13550         vartype="integer",
13551         topics=['printing_prden'],
13552         dimensions="scalar",
13553         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[nimage]] > 1': 0, 'defaultval': 1}),
13554         mnemonics="PRinT Electron BANDS",
13555         text="""
13556     This option activates the output of the electron eigenvalues. Possible values:
13557     
13558       * 0- Disable the output of the band energies.
13559       * 1- Write eigenvalues in xmgrace format. A file with extension `EBANDS.agr` is produced at the end of the run.
13560         Use `xmgrace file_EBANDS.agr` to visualize the band energies
13561       * 2- Write eigenvalues in gnuplot format. The code produces a `EBANDS.dat` file with the eigenvalues
13562         and a `EBANDS.gnuplot` script. Use `gnuplot file_EBANDS.gnuplot` to visualize the band energies.
13563     """,
13564     ),
13565     
13566     Variable(
13567         abivarname="prtefg",
13568         varset="paw",
13569         vartype="integer",
13570         topics=['printing_prngs', 'EFG_basic'],
13571         dimensions="scalar",
13572         defaultval=0,
13573         mnemonics="PRint Electric Field Gradient",
13574         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1, [[quadmom]]",
13575         text="""
13576       * If nonzero, calculate the electric field gradient at each atomic site in the unit cell. Using this option requires [[quadmom]] to be set as well. Values will be written to main output file (search for Electric Field Gradient). If prtefg=1, only the quadrupole coupling in MHz and asymmetry are reported. If prtefg=2, the full electric field gradient tensors in atomic units are also given, showing separate contributions from the valence electrons, the ion cores, and the PAW reconstruction. If prtefg=3, then in addition to the prtefg=2 output, the EFGs are computed using an ionic point charge model. This is useful for comparing the accurate PAW-based results to those of simple ion-only models. Use of prtefg=3 requires that the variable [[ptcharge]] be set as well.
13577     The option prtefg is compatible with spin polarized calculations (see
13578     [[nspden]]) and also LDA+U (see [[usepawu]]).
13579     """,
13580     ),
13581     
13582     Variable(
13583         abivarname="prtefmas",
13584         varset="dfpt",
13585         vartype="integer",
13586         topics=['printing_prngs', 'EffectiveMass_useful'],
13587         dimensions="scalar",
13588         defaultval=0,
13589         mnemonics="PRint EFfective MASs data",
13590         requires="[[efmas]] == 1",
13591         text="""
13592       * If 1, at the end of an effective mass calculation ([[efmas]] = 1), create a file *_EFMAS, that contains the generalized second-order k-derivatives, see Eq.(66) in [[cite:Laflamme2016]], in view of further processing.
13593     """,
13594     ),
13595     
13596     Variable(
13597         abivarname="prteig",
13598         varset="files",
13599         vartype="integer",
13600         topics=['printing_prden'],
13601         dimensions="scalar",
13602         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[nimage]] > 1': 0, 'defaultval': 1}),
13603         mnemonics="PRinT EIGenenergies",
13604         text="""
13605     If set to 1, a file *_EIG, containing the k-points and one-electron eigenvalues is printed.
13606     """,
13607     ),
13608     
13609     Variable(
13610         abivarname="prtelf",
13611         varset="files",
13612         vartype="integer",
13613         topics=['printing_prgs'],
13614         dimensions="scalar",
13615         defaultval=0,
13616         mnemonics="PRinT Electron Localization Function (ELF)",
13617         text="""
13618     If set to 1 or a larger value, provide output of ELF in real space elf(r).
13619     This is a dimensionless quantity bounded between 0 and 1.
13620     The name of the ELF file will be the root output name, followed by _ELF.
13621     Like a _DEN file, it can be analyzed by cut3d. However unlike densities, in
13622     case of spin polarized calculations, the spin down component can not be
13623     obtained by subtracting the spin up component to the total ELF. Hence when
13624     spin polarized calculations are performed the code produces also output files
13625     with _ELF_UP and _ELF_DOWN extensions. (For technical reasons these files
13626     contain also two components but the second is zero. So to perform analysis of
13627     _ELF_UP and _ELF_DOWN files with cut3d you have to answer "ispden= 0 --> Total
13628     density" when cut3d ask you which ispden to choose. Also remember that spin
13629     down component can not be obtained by using cut3d on the _ELF file. Sorry for
13630     the inconvenience, this will be fixed in the next release.)
13631     ELF is not yet implemented in non collinear spin case.
13632     If prtelf is set to 2, in the case of spin polarized calculation, the total
13633     ELF is computed from an alternative approach which should better take into
13634     account the existence of spin dependent densities (see the documentation in
13635     /doc/theory/ELF of your ABINIT repository)
13636     
13637     Please note that ELF is **not** yet implemented in the case of PAW
13638     ([[usepaw]] = 1) calculations.
13639     """,
13640     ),
13641     
13642     Variable(
13643         abivarname="prtfc",
13644         varset="paw",
13645         vartype="integer",
13646         topics=['printing_prden', 'EFG_basic'],
13647         dimensions="scalar",
13648         defaultval=0,
13649         mnemonics="PRinT Fermi Contact term",
13650         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
13651         text="""
13652       * If set to 1, print the Fermi contact interaction at each nuclear site, that is, the electron density at each site. The result appears in the main output file (search for FC). Note that this calculation is different than what is done by cut3d, because it also computes the PAW on-site corrections in addition to the contribution from the valence pseudo-wavefunctions.
13653     """,
13654     ),
13655     
13656     Variable(
13657         abivarname="prtfull1wf",
13658         varset="dfpt",
13659         vartype="integer",
13660         topics=['DFPT_expert'],
13661         dimensions="scalar",
13662         defaultval=0,
13663         mnemonics="PRinT FULL 1st-order WaveFunction",
13664         text="""
13665     If set to 1, the output _1WF files will contain the full 1st-order wavefunctions, for both valence and conduction bands.
13666     Otherwise, the _1WF files are not really 1st-order perturbed wavefunctions, but merely a set of perturbed wavefunctions that yield the correct perturbed density.
13667     This is used when one expect to perform post-processing of the 1st-order wavefunctions.
13668     """,
13669     ),
13670     
13671     Variable(
13672         abivarname="prtfsurf",
13673         varset="files",
13674         vartype="integer",
13675         topics=['printing_prfermi'],
13676         dimensions="scalar",
13677         defaultval=0,
13678         mnemonics="PRinT Fermi SURFace file",
13679         text="""
13680     If set to 1, provide Fermi surface file in the BXSF format (Xcrysden) If
13681     [[prtfsurf]] = 1, a _BXSF file readable by [ XCrySDen ](http://www.xcrysden.org)
13682     will be produced at the end of the calculation. The file contains information
13683     on the band structure of the system and can be used to visualize the Fermi
13684     surface or any other energy isosurface. [[prtfsurf]] = 1 is compatible only with
13685     SCF calculations ([[iscf]] > 1) or NSCF runs in which the occupation factors
13686     and Fermi level are recalculated once convergence is achieved ([[iscf]] = -3).
13687     The two methods should produce the same Fermi surface provided that the
13688     k-meshes are sufficiently dense. The k-mesh used for the sampling of the Fermi
13689     surface can be specified using the standard variables [[ngkpt]], ([[shiftk]],
13690     and [[nshiftk]]. Note, however, that the mesh must be homogeneous and centered
13691     on gamma (multiple shifts are not supported by Xcrysden)
13692     """,
13693     ),
13694     
13695     Variable(
13696         abivarname="prtgden",
13697         varset="files",
13698         vartype="integer",
13699         topics=['printing_prden'],
13700         dimensions="scalar",
13701         defaultval=0,
13702         mnemonics="PRinT the Gradient of electron DENsity",
13703         text="""
13704     If set to 1 or a larger value, provide output of gradient of electron density
13705     in real space grho(r), in units of Bohr^-(5/2).
13706     The names of the gradient of electron density files will be the root output
13707     name, followed by _GDEN1, _GDEN2, GDEN3 for each principal direction (indeed
13708     it is a vector).
13709     Like a _DEN file, it can be analyzed by cut3d.
13710     The file structure of this unformatted output file is described in [[help:abinit#denfile|this section]].
13711     """,
13712     ),
13713     
13714     Variable(
13715         abivarname="prtgeo",
13716         varset="files",
13717         vartype="integer",
13718         topics=['printing_prgeo'],
13719         dimensions="scalar",
13720         defaultval=0,
13721         mnemonics="PRinT the GEOmetry analysis",
13722         text="""
13723     If set to 1 or a larger value, provide output of geometrical analysis (bond
13724     lengths and bond angles). The value of [[prtgeo]] is taken by the code to be
13725     the maximum coordination number of atoms in the system.
13726     It will deduce a maximum number of "nearest" and "next-nearest" neighbors
13727     accordingly, and compute corresponding bond lengths.
13728     It will compute bond angles for the "nearest" neighbours only.
13729     If [[ionmov]] == 0, the name of the file will be the root output name, followed by _GEO.
13730     If [[ionmov]] == 1 or 2, one file will be output at each time step, with the
13731     name being made of
13732     
13733       * the root output name,
13734       * followed by _TIMx, where x is related to the time step (see later)
13735       * then followed by _GEO
13736     
13737     The content of the file should be rather self-explanatory.
13738     No output is provided by [[prtgeo]] is lower than or equal to 0.
13739     If [[prtgeo]] > 0, the maximum number of atoms ([[natom]]) is 9999.
13740     """,
13741     ),
13742     
13743     Variable(
13744         abivarname="prtgkk",
13745         varset="files",
13746         vartype="integer",
13747         topics=['printing_prngs', 'ElPhonInt_compulsory'],
13748         dimensions="scalar",
13749         defaultval=0,
13750         mnemonics="PRinT the GKK matrix elements file",
13751         text="""
13752     If set to 1, provide output of electron-phonon "gkk" matrix elements, for
13753     further treatment by mrggkk utility or anaddb utility. Note that symmetry will
13754     be disabled for the calculation of the perturbation, forcing the inclusion of
13755     all k-points and all perturbation directions. Additional information on
13756     electron-phonon treatment in ABINIT is given in the tutorial [[tutorial:eph]].
13757     """,
13758     ),
13759     
13760     Variable(
13761         abivarname="prtgsr",
13762         varset="files",
13763         vartype="integer",
13764         topics=['printing_prgs'],
13765         dimensions="scalar",
13766         defaultval="prtgsr = 0",
13767         mnemonics="PRinT the GSR file",
13768         text="""
13769     If set to 1, ABINIT will produce a GSR file at the end of the GS calculation.
13770     The GSR file contains the most important GS results (band structure, forces,
13771     stresses, electronic density). The GSR file can be read by AbiPy and used for further post-processing.
13772     Note that, by default, the GSR file contains the electronic density unless [[prtden]] is set to 0.
13773     """,
13774     ),
13775     
13776     Variable(
13777         abivarname="prtkden",
13778         varset="files",
13779         vartype="integer",
13780         topics=['printing_prden'],
13781         dimensions="scalar",
13782         defaultval=0,
13783         mnemonics="PRinT the Kinetic energy DENsity",
13784         text="""
13785     If set to 1 or a larger value, provide output of kinetic energy density in
13786     real space tau(r), in units of Bohr^-5.
13787     The name of the kinetic energy density file will be the root output name, followed by _KDEN.
13788     Like a _DEN file, it can be analyzed by cut3d.
13789     The file structure of this unformatted output file is described in [[help:abinit#denfile|this section]].
13790     Note that the computation of the kinetic energy density must be activate,
13791     thanks to the input variable [[usekden]].
13792     Please note that kinetic energy density is **not** yet implemented in the case
13793     of PAW ([[usepaw]] = 1) calculations.
13794     """,
13795     ),
13796     
13797     Variable(
13798         abivarname="prtkpt",
13799         varset="files",
13800         vartype="integer",
13801         topics=['printing_prden', 'Output_useful', 'k-points_useful'],
13802         dimensions="scalar",
13803         defaultval=0,
13804         mnemonics="PRinT the K-PoinTs sets",
13805         text="""
13806     If set /= 0, proceeds to a detailed analysis of different k point grids.
13807     Works only if [[kptopt]] is positive, and neither [[kptrlatt]] nor [[ngkpt]]
13808     are defined. ABINIT will stop after this analysis.
13809     
13810     Different sets of k point grids are defined, with common values of [[shiftk]].
13811     In each set, ABINIT increases the length of vectors of the supercell (see
13812     [[kptrlatt]]) by integer steps. The different sets are labelled by "iset". For
13813     each k point grid, [[kptrlen]] and [[nkpt]] are computed (the latter always
13814     invoking [[kptopt]] = 1, that is, full use of symmetries). A series is finished
13815     when the computed [[kptrlen]] is twice larger than the input variable
13816     [[kptrlen]]. After the examination of the different sets, ABINIT summarizes,
13817     for each [[nkpt]], the best possible grid, that is, the one with the largest
13818     computed [[kptrlen]].
13819     
13820     Note that this analysis is also performed when [[prtkpt]] = 0, as soon as
13821     neither [[kptrlatt]] nor [[ngkpt]] are defined. But, in this case, no analysis
13822     report is given, and the code selects the grid with the smaller [[ngkpt]] for
13823     the desired [[kptrlen]]. However, this analysis takes some times (well
13824     sometimes, it is only a few seconds - it depends on the value of the input
13825     [[kptrlen]]), and it is better to examine the full analysis for a given cell
13826     and set of symmetries, [[shiftk]] for all the production runs.
13827     
13828     If set to -2, the code stops in invars1 after the computation of the
13829     irreducible set and a file named kpts.nc with the list of the k-points and the
13830     corresponding weights is produced
13831     """,
13832     ),
13833     
13834     Variable(
13835         abivarname="prtlden",
13836         varset="files",
13837         vartype="integer",
13838         topics=['printing_prden'],
13839         dimensions="scalar",
13840         defaultval=0,
13841         mnemonics="PRinT the Laplacian of electron DENsity",
13842         text="""
13843     If set to 1 or a larger value, provide output of Laplacian of electron density
13844     in real space grho(r), in units of Bohr^-(7/2).
13845     The name of the Laplacian of electron density file will be the root output name, followed by _LDEN.
13846     Like a _DEN file, it can be analyzed by cut3d.
13847     The file structure of this unformatted output file is described in [[help:abinit#denfile|this section]].
13848     """,
13849     ),
13850

13891     Possible values:
13892     
13893       * 0 Disable the output of the phonon frequencies.
13894       * 1 Write frequencies in |xmgrace| format. A file with extension `PHBANDS.agr` is produced.
13895         Use `xmgrace file_PHBANDS.agr` to visualize the data
13896       * 2 Write frequencies in |gnuplot| format. The code produces a `PHBANDS.dat` file
13897         with the eigenvalues and a `PHBANDS.gnuplot` script.
13898         Use `gnuplot file_PHBANDS.gnuplot` to visualize the phonon band structure.
