13950     Variable(
13951         abivarname="prtpot",
13952         varset="files",
13953         vartype="integer",
13954         topics=['printing_prpot'],
13955         dimensions="scalar",
13956         defaultval=0,
13957         mnemonics="PRinT total POTential",
13958         text="""
13959     If set >=1, provide output of the total (Kohn-Sham) potential (sum of local
13960     pseudo-potential, Hartree potential, and xc potential).
13961     
13962     If [[ionmov]] == 0, the name of the potential file will be the root output name,
13963     followed by _POT.
13964     If [[ionmov]] == 1 or 2, potential file will be output at each time step, with
13965     the name being made of
13966     
13967       * the root output name,
13968       * followed by _TIMx, where x is related to the time step (see later)
13969       * then followed by _POT.
13970     
13971     The file structure of this unformatted output file is described in [[help:abinit#localpotfile|this section]].
13972     No output is provided by a negative value of this variable.

13986     tables used by Abinit to apply the pseudopotential part of the KS Hamiltonian.
13987     The data can be visualized with AbiPy. if prtpsps is set to -1, the code will
13988     exit after the output of the PSPS.nc file.
13989     """,

13993         abivarname="prtspcur",
13994         varset="files",
13995         vartype="integer",
13996         topics=['printing_prgs'],
13997         dimensions="scalar",
13998         defaultval=0,
13999         mnemonics="PRinT the SPin CURrent density",
14000         text="""
14001     If set to 1 or a larger value, provide output of the current density of
14002     different direction spins (x,y,z) in the whole unit cell. Should require
14003     spinorial wave functions [[nspinor]] = 2. Experimental: this does not work yet.

14006     
14007     Variable(
14008         abivarname="prtstm",
14009         varset="files",
14010         vartype="integer",
14011         topics=['printing_prgs', 'STM_compulsory'],
14012         dimensions="scalar",
14013         defaultval=0,
14014         mnemonics="PRinT the STM density",
14015         text="""
14016     If set to 1 or a larger value, provide output of the electron density in real
14017     space rho(r), made only from the electrons close to the Fermi energy, in a
14018     range of energy (positive or negative), determined by the (positive or
14019     negative, but non-zero) value of the STM bias [[stmbias]].
14020     This is a very approximate way to obtain STM profiles: one can choose an
14021     equidensity surface, and consider that the STM tip will follow this surface.
14022     Such equidensity surface might be determined with the help of Cut3D, and
14023     further post-processing of it (to be implemented). The big approximations of
14024     this technique are: neglect of the finite size of the tip, and position-
14025     independent transfer matrix elements between the tip and the surface.
14026     The charge density is provided in units of electrons/Bohr^3. The name of the
14027     STM density file will be the root output name, followed by _STM. Like a _DEN
14028     file, it can be analyzed by cut3d.
14029     The file structure of this unformatted output file is described in [[help:abinit#denfile|this section]].
14030     For the STM charge density to be generated, one must give, as an input file,
14031     the converged wavefunctions obtained from a previous run, at exactly the same
14032     k-points and cut-off energy, self-consistently determined, using the
14033     occupation numbers from [[occopt]] = 7.
14034     In the run with positive [[prtstm]], one has to use:
14035     
14036       * positive [[iscf]]
14037       * [[occopt]] = 7, with specification of [[tsmear]]
14038       * [[nstep]] = 1
14039       * the [[tolwfr]] convergence criterion
14040       * [[ionmov]] = 0 (this is the default value)
14041       * [[optdriver]] = 0 (this is the default value)
14042     
14043     Note that you might have to adjust the value of [[nband]] as well, for the
14044     treatment of unoccupied states, because the automatic determination of
14045     [[nband]] will often not include enough unoccupied states.
14046     When [[prtstm]] is non-zero, the stress tensor is set to zero.
14047     No output of _STM file is provided by [[prtstm]] lower or equal to 0.
14048     No other printing variables for density or potentials should be activated
14049     (e.g. [[prtden]] has to be set to zero).
14050     """,
14051     ),
14052     
14053     Variable(
14054         abivarname="prtsuscep",
14055         varset="files",
14056         vartype="integer",
14057         topics=['printing_prngs'],
14058         dimensions="scalar",
14059         defaultval=0,
14060         mnemonics="PRinT the SUSCEPtibility file (the irreducible polarizability)",
14061         text="""
14062     If set to 0, no _SUSC file will be produced after the screening calculation,
14063     only the _SCR file will be output.
14064     """,
14065     ),
14066

14075         text="""
14076     If set >= 0 outputs a file with the Coulomb potential, defined as Hartree +
14077     local Pseudopotential.
14078     
14079     If **prtvclmb=1** and in case of PAW ([[usepaw]] > 0), the full core potential
14080     is added for the Hartree part, with the on-site corrections vh1 - vht1.
14081     
14082     If **prtvclmb=2**, only the smooth part of the Coulomb potential is output.
14083     """,
14084     ),

14110     
14111     If [[ionmov]] == 0, the name of the potential file will be the root output name,
14112     followed by _VHA.
14113     If [[ionmov]] == 1 or 2, potential files will be output at each time step, with
14114     the name being made of
14115     
14116       * the root output name,
14117       * followed by _TIMx, where x is related to the time step (see later)
14118       * then followed by _VHA.

14121     No output is provided by a negative value of this variable.

14125     Variable(
14126         abivarname="prtvhxc",
14127         varset="files",
14128         vartype="integer",
14129         topics=['printing_prpot'],
14130         dimensions="scalar",
14131         defaultval=0,
14132         mnemonics="PRinT V_HXC",
14133         text="""
14134     If set >=1, provide output of the sum of the Hartree potential and xc potential.
14135     
14136     If [[ionmov]] == 0, the name of the potential file will be the root output name,
14137     followed by _VHXC.
14138     If [[ionmov]] == 1 or 2, potential files will be output at each time step, with
14139     the name being made of
14140     
14141       * the root output name,
14142       * followed by _TIMx, where x is related to the time step (see later)
14143       * then followed by _VHXC.
14144

14146     No output is provided by a negative value of this variable.
14147     """,
14148     ),
14149     
14150     Variable(
14151         abivarname="prtvol",
14152         varset="files",
14153         vartype="integer",
14154         topics=['printing_prgs', 'Output_basic'],
14155         dimensions="scalar",
14156         defaultval=0,
14157         mnemonics="PRinT VOLume",
14158         text="""
14159     Control the volume of printed output. In particular, this concerns the
14160     explicit echo of eigenenergies and residuals for all bands and k points in the
14161     main output file. Also, the analysis of the value and location of the maximal
14162     density (and magnetization).
14163     Standard choice is 0. Positive values print more in the output and log files,
14164     while negative values are for debugging (or preprocessing only), and cause the
14165     code to stop at some point.
14166     
14167       * 0 --> The eigenenergies and residuals for all bands and k points are not echoed in the main output file. There are exceptions: the eigenvalues of the first k point are printed at the end of the SCF loop, and also, if [[iscf]] = -2 and [[kptopt]]<=0, the eigenvalues for all the k points are printed anyway, for a maximum of 50 k-points. Due to some subtlety, if for **some** dataset [[prtvol]] is non-zero, the limit for input and output echoes cannot be enforced, so it is like if [[prtvol]] = 1 for **all** the datasets for which [[prtvol]] was set to 0.
14168       * 1 --> the eigenvalues for the first 50 k-points are printed in all cases, at the end of the SCF loop.
14169       * 2 --> all the eigenvalues and the residuals are printed at the end of the SCF loop. Also, the analysis of the value and location of the maximal density (and magnetization) is printed.
14170       * 3 --> Print memory information for lobpcg
14171       * 4 --> Like 3 and prints information of lobpcg algorithm convergence
14172       * 10 --> the eigenvalues are printed for every SCF iteration, as well as other additions (to be specified in the future...)
14173     
14174     Debugging options:
14175     
14176       * = -1 --> stop in abinit (main program), before call driver. Useful to see the effect of the preprocessing of input variables (memory needed, effect of symmetries, k points...) without going further. Run very fast, on the order of the second.
14177       * =-2 --> same as -1, except that print only the first dataset. All the non default input variables associated to all datasets are printed in the output file, but only for the first dataset. Also all the input variables are written in the NetCDF file "OUT.nc", even if the value is the default.
14178       * = -3 --> stop in gstate, before call scfcv, move or brdmin. Useful to debug pseudopotentials
14179       * = -4 --> stop in move, after completion of all loops
14180       * = -5 --> stop in brdmin, after completion of all loops
14181       * = -6 --> stop in scfcv, after completion of all loops
14182       * = -7 --> stop in vtorho, after the first rho is obtained
14183       * = -8 --> stop in vtowfk, after the first k point is treated
14184       * = -9 --> stop in cgwf, after the first wf is optimized
14185       * = -10 --> stop in getghc, after the Hamiltonian is applied once
14186     
14187     This debugging feature is not yet activated in the RF routines. Note that
14188     [[fftalg]] offers another option for debugging.
14189     """,
14190     ),
14191     
14192     Variable(
14193         abivarname="prtvolimg",
14194         varset="files",
14195         vartype="integer",
14196         topics=['printing_prgs', 'Output_useful'],
14197         dimensions="scalar",
14198         defaultval=0,
14199         mnemonics="PRinT VOLume for IMaGes",
14200         text="""
14201     Control the volume of printed output when an algorithm using images of the
14202     cell is used ([[nimage]] > 1).
14203     When such an algorithm is activated, the printing volume (in output file) can
14204     be large and difficult to read.
14205     Using **prtvolimg=1**, the printing volume, for each image, is reduced to
14206     unit cell, atomic positions, total energy, forces, stresses, velocities and
14207     convergence residuals.
14208     Using **prtvolimg=2**, the printing volume, for each image, is reduced to
14209     total energy and convergence residuals only.
14210     """,
14211     ),
14212     
14213     Variable(
14214         abivarname="prtvpsp",
14215         varset="files",
14216         vartype="integer",

14223

14225     If [[ionmov]] == 1 or 2, potential files will be output at each time step, with the name being made of
14226     
14227       * the root output name,
14228       * followed by _TIMx, where x is related to the timestep (see later)
14229       * then followed by _VPSP.

14232     No output is provided by a negative value of this variable.

14236     Variable(
14237         abivarname="prtvxc",
14238         varset="files",
14239         vartype="integer",
14240         topics=['printing_prpot'],
14241         dimensions="scalar",
14242         defaultval=0,
14243         mnemonics="PRinT V_XC",

14250     the name being made of

14253       * followed by _TIMx, where x is related to the timestep (see later)
14254       * then followed by _VXC.

14257     No output is provided by a negative value of this variable.
14258     """,
14259     ),
14260     
14261     Variable(
14262         abivarname="prtwant",
14263         varset="files",
14264         vartype="integer",
14265         topics=['printing_prgs', 'Wannier_compulsory'],
14266         dimensions="scalar",
14267         defaultval=0,
14268         mnemonics="PRinT WANT file",
14269         text=r"""
14270     Flag used to indicate that either the Wannier90 or the WanT interfaces will be used.
14271     
14272       * [[prtwant]] = 1 --> Use the **ABINIT- WanT** interface.
14273     
14274     Provide an output file that can be used by the WanT postprocessing program
14275     (see [http://www.wannier-transport.org](http://www.wannier-transport.org)). The value of the prtwant indicates the
14276     version of the WanT code that can read it. Currently only the value
14277     [[prtwant]] = 1 is implemented, corresponding to WanT version 1.0.1, available
14278     since Oct. 22, 2004.
14279     
14280     Notes: Several requirements must be fulfilled by the wavefunction. Among
14281     them, two are mandatory:
14282     
14283         * 1. An uniform grid of k-points, including the GAMMA point must be used.
14284         * 2. The use of time reversal symmetry is not allowed (istwfk=1)
14285         * 3. The list of k-points must be ordered, such that the coordinates, namely
14286           three-components vectors has the third index varying the most rapidly, then the second index, then the first index
14287     
14288     If these requirement are not fulfilled, the program will stop and an error
14289     message is returned.
14290     
14291     As an example of k-point grid in case of systems that have some 3D character
14292     (1D systems are easy):
14293     
14294         nkpt 8
14295         kpt  0   0   0
14296         0   0   1/2
14297         0   1/2 0
14298         0   1/2 1/2
14299         1/2 0   0
14300         1/2 0   1/2
14301         1/2 1/2 0
14302         1/2 1/2 1/2
14303         istwfk 8*1
14304     
14305     Also, in order to use WanT as a post-processing program for ABINIT you might
14306     have to recompile it with the appropriate flags (see ABINIT makefile). Up to
14307     now only the -convert big-endian was found to be mandatory, for machines with
14308     little-endian default choice.
14309     
14310       * [[prtwant]] = 2 --> Use the **ABINIT- Wannier90** interface.
14311     
14312     ABINIT will produce the input files required by Wannier90 and it will run
14313     Wannier90 to produce the Maximally-locallized Wannier functions (see [
14314     http://www.wannier.org ](http://www.wannier.org) ).
14315     
14316     !!! Notes
14317     
14318         * The files that are created can also be used by Wannier90 in stand-alone mode.
14319         * In order to use Wannier90 as a post-processing program for ABINIT you might have to recompile it with the appropriate flags (see ABINIT makefile). You might use ./configure --enable-wannier90
14320         * There are some other variables related to the interface of Wannier90 and ABINIT. See [[varset:w90]].
14321     
14322       * [[prtwant]] = 3 --> Use the **ABINIT- Wannier90** interface after converting the input wavefunctions to **quasiparticle** wavefunctions.
14323     
14324     ABINIT will produce the input files required by Wannier90 and it will run
14325     Wannier90 to produce the Maximally-localized Wannier functions (see [
14326     http://www.wannier.org ](http://www.wannier.org) ).
14327     
14328     !!! Notes
14329     
14330         * An input file of LDA wave functions is required which is completely consistent with the _KSS file used in the self-consistent GW calculation. This means that [[kssform]] 3 must be used to create the _KSS file and the output _WFK file from the same run must be used as input here.
14331         * Wannier90 requires [[nshiftk]] = 1, and [[shiftk]] =  0 0 0 is recommended. The k-point set used for the GW calculation, typically the irreducible BZ set created using [[kptopt]] = 1, and that for the Abinit- Wannier90 interface must be consistent.
14332         * Full-BZ wavefunctions should be generated in the run calling the interface by setting [[kptopt]] = 3, [[iscf]] = -2, and [[nstep]] = 3. This will simply use symmetry to transform the input IBZ wavefunctions to the full BZ set, still consistent with the GW _KSS input.
14333         * The final _QPS file created by the self-consistent GW run is required as input.
14334         * Any value of [[gwcalctyp]] between between 20 and 29 should be suitable, so, for example, Hartree-Fock maximally-localized Wannier functions could be generated setting [[gwcalctyp]] = 25.
14335     """,
14336     ),
14337     
14338     Variable(
14339         abivarname="prtwf",
14340         varset="files",
14341         vartype="integer",
14342         topics=['printing_prden', 'vdw_useful'],
14343         dimensions="scalar",
14344         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[nimage]] > 1': 0, 'defaultval': 1}),
14345         mnemonics="PRinT the WaveFunction",
14346         text="""
14347     If [[prtwf]] = 1, provide output of wavefunction and eigenvalue file
14348     The file structure of this unformatted output file is described in [[help:abinit#wfkfile|this section]].
14349     For a standard ground-state calculation, the name of the wavefunction file
14350     will be the root output name, followed by _WFK. If [[nqpt]] = 1, the root name
14351     will be followed by _WFQ. For response-function calculations, the root name
14352     will be followed by _1WFx, where x is the number of the perturbation. The
14353     dataset information will be added as well, if relevant.
14354     No wavefunction output is provided by [[prtwf]] = 0.
14355     If [[prtwf]] = -1, the code writes the wavefunction file only if convergence is
14356     not achieved in the self-consistent cycle.
14357     
14358     
14359     If [[prtwf]] = 2, a file pwfn.data is produced, to be used as input for the
14360     CASINO QMC code. See more explanation at the end of this section.
14361     If [[prtwf]] = 3, the file that is created is nearly the same as with
14362     [[prtwf]] = 1, except that the records that should contain the wavefunction is
14363     empty (so, such records exist, but store nothing). This is useful to generate
14364     size-reduced DDK files, to perform an optic run. Indeed, in the latter case,
14365     only matrix elements are needed [so, no wavefunction], but possibly a large
14366     number of conduction bands, so that the DDK file might be huge if it contains
14367     the wavefunctions.
14368     
14369     Further explanation for the [[prtwf]] = 2 case. To produce a wave function
14370     suitable for use as a CASINO trial wave function, certain ABINIT parameters
14371     must be set correctly. Primarily, CASINO (and QMC methods generally) can only
14372     take advantage of time-reversal symmetry, and not the full set of symmetries
14373     of the crystal structure. Therefore, ABINIT must be instructed to generate
14374     k-points not just in the Irreducible Brillouin Zone, but in a full half of the
14375     Brillouin Zone (using time-reversal symmetry to generate the other half).
14376     Additionally, unless instructed otherwise, Abinit avoids the need for internal
14377     storage of many of the coefficients of its wave functions for k-points that
14378     have the property 2k=G_latt, where G_latt is a reciprocal lattice vector, by
14379     making use of the property that c_k(G)=c^*_k(-G-G_latt). Abinit must be
14380     instructed not to do this in order to output the full set of coefficients for
14381     use in CASINO. See the ABINIT theoretical background documents
14382     ABINIT/Infos/Theory/geometry.pdf and ABINIT/Infos/Theory/1WF.pdf for more
14383     information.
14384     The first of these requirements is met by setting the ABINIT input variable
14385     [[kptopt]] to 2 and the second by setting
14386     [[istwfk]] to 1 for all the k points. Since
14387     CASINO is typically run with relatively small numbers of k-points, this is
14388     easily done by defining an array of "1" in the input file.
14389     For example, for the 8 k-points generated with ngkpt 2 2 2, we add the
14390     following lines to the input file:
14391     
14392         # Turn off special storage mode for time-reversal k-points
14393         istwfk 1 1 1 1 1 1 1 1
14394         # Use only time reversal symmetry, not full set of symmetries.
14395         kptopt 2
14396     
14397     
14398     Other useful input variables of relevance to the plane waves ABINIT will
14399     produce include ecut, nshiftk, shiftk, nband, occopt, occ, spinat and nsppol
14400     (see relevant input variable documents in ABINIT/Infos/). If ABINIT is run in
14401     multiple dataset mode, the different wave functions for the various datasets
14402     are exported as pwfn1.data, pwfn2.data, ..., pwfnn.data where the numbers are
14403     the contents of the contents of the input array jdtset (defaults to
14404     1,2,...,ndtset).
14405     Once the routine is incorporated into the ABINIT package it is anticipated
14406     that there will be an input variable to control whether or not a CASINO
14407     pwfn.data file is written.
14408     
14409     Other issues related to [[prtwf]] = 2.
14410     The exporter does not currently work when ABINIT is used in parallel mode on
14411     multiple processors if k-point parallelism is chosen. ABINIT does not store
14412     the full wave function on each processor but rather splits the k-points
14413     between the processors, so no one processor could write out the whole file.
14414     Clearly this could be fixed but we have not done it yet. The sort of plane
14415     wave DFT calculations usually required to generate QMC trial wave functions
14416     execute very rapidly anyway and will generally not require a parallel
14417     machines. The outqmc routine currently bails out with an error if this
14418     combination of modes is selected - this will hopefully be fixed later.
14419     There has not been very extensive testing of less common situations such as
14420     different numbers of bands for different k-points, and more complicated spin
14421     polarized systems, so care should be taken when using the output in these circumstances.
14422     If there is any doubt about the output of this routine, the first place to
14423     look is the log file produced by ABINIT: if there are any warnings about
14424     incorrectly normalized orbitals or non-integer occupation numbers there is
14425     probably something set wrong in the input file.
14426     """,
14427     ),
14428     
14429     Variable(
14430         abivarname="prtwf_full",
14431         varset="files",
14432         vartype="integer",
14433         topics=['printing_prden'],
14434         dimensions="scalar",
14435         defaultval=0,
14436         mnemonics="PRinT Wavefunction file on the FULL mesh",
14437         requires="[[prtwf]] == 1",
14438         text="""
14439     If set to 1 in a ground-state calculation, the code will output another WFK
14440     file (with extension FULL_WFK) containing the wavefunctions in the full BZ as
14441     well as a text file with the tables used for the tetrahedron method. Note that
14442     prtwf_full requires [[prtwf]] == 1 and a ground-state calculation done on a
14443     homogeneous k-mesh (see [[ngkpt]] and [[shiftk]]). The tetrahedron table is
14444     produced only if the number of k-points in the irreducible zone ([[nkpt]]) is
14445     greater than 3.
14446     """,
14447     ),
14448     
14449     Variable(
14450         abivarname="prtxml",
14451         varset="files",
14452         vartype="integer",
14453         topics=['printing_prgs'],
14454         dimensions="scalar",
14455         defaultval=0,
14456         mnemonics="PRinT an XML output",
14457         text="""
14458     Create an XML output with common values. The corresponding DTD is distributed
14459     in sources as extras/post_processing/abinitRun.dtd. All the DTD is not yet
14460     implemented and this one is currently restricted to ground-state computations
14461     (and derivative such as geometry optimisation).
14462     """,
14463     ),
14464     
14465     Variable(
14466         abivarname="ptcharge",
14467         varset="paw",
14468         vartype="real",
14469         topics=['EFG_basic'],
14470         dimensions=['[[ntypat]]'],
14471         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=None, value=0),
14472         mnemonics="PoinT CHARGEs",
14473         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1 and [[prtefg]]>=3",
14474         text="""
14475       * Array of point charges, in atomic units, of the nuclei. In the normal computation of electric field gradients (see [[prtefg]]) the ionic contribution is calculated from the core charges of the atomic sites. Thus for example in a PAW data set for oxygen where the core is $1s^{2}$, the core charge is +6 (total nuclear charge minus core electron charge). In point charge models, which are much less accurate than PAW calculations, all atomic sites are treated as ions with charges determined by their valence states. In such a case oxygen almost always would have a point charge of -2. The present variable taken together with [[prtefg]] performs a full PAW computation of the electric field gradient and also a simple point charge computation. The user inputs whatever point charges he/she wishes for each atom type.
14476     """,
14477     ),
14478     
14479     Variable(
14480         abivarname="ptgroupma",
14481         varset="geo",
14482         vartype="integer",
14483         topics=['spinpolarisation_internal', 'SmartSymm_internal'],
14484         dimensions="scalar",
14485         defaultval=0,
14486         mnemonics="PoinT GROUP number for the MAgnetic space group",
14487         characteristics=['[[INTERNAL_ONLY]]'],
14488         text="""
14489     This internal variable characterizes a Shubnikov type III magnetic space group
14490     (anti-ferromagnetic space group). The user is advised to consult [[cite:Bradley1972]].
14491     A Shubnikov type III magnetic space group might be defined by its Fedorov
14492     space group (set of all spatial symmetries, irrespective of their magnetic
14493     action), and the halving space group (only the symmetries that do not change
14494     the magnetization).
14495     The specification of the halving space group might be done by specifying, for
14496     each point symmetry, the magnetic action. See Table 7.1 of the above-mentioned
14497     reference. Magnetic point groups are numbered from 1 to 58.
14498     
14499     Related input variables: [[spgroup]], [[spgroupma]], [[genafm]]
14500     """,
14501     ),
14502     
14503     Variable(
14504         abivarname="pvelmax",
14505         varset="gw",
14506         vartype="real",
14507         topics=['RandStopPow_basic'],
14508         dimensions=[3],
14509         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=3, value=1.0),
14510         mnemonics="Particle VELocity MAXimum",
14511         requires="[[optdriver]] == 3",
14512         text="""
14513     When [[npvel]] is larger than 0, it performs electronic stopping power
14514     calculations on a velocity grid along the direction determined by [[pvelmax]].
14515     The vector [[pvelmax]] defines both the direction and the maximum velocity.
14516     [[pvelmax]] is input in Cartesian coordinates.
14517     """,
14518     ),
14519     
14520     Variable(
14521         abivarname="pw_unbal_thresh",
14522         varset="paral",
14523         vartype="real",
14524         topics=['parallelism_expert'],
14525         dimensions="scalar",
14526         defaultval="40%",
14527         mnemonics="Plane Wave UNBALancing: THRESHold for balancing procedure",
14528         requires="[[paral_kgb]] == 1",
14529         text="""
14530     This parameter (in %) activates a load balancing procedure when the
14531     distribution of plane wave components over MPI processes is not optimal. The
14532     balancing procedure is activated when the ratio between the number of plane
14533     waves treated by a processor and the ideal one is higher than
14534     _pw_unbal_thresh_ %.
14535     """,
14536     ),
14537     
14538     Variable(
14539         abivarname="qmass",
14540         varset="rlx",
14541         vartype="real",
14542         topics=['PIMD_basic', 'MolecularDynamics_basic'],
14543         dimensions=['[[nnos]]'],
14544         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=None, value=10.0),
14545         mnemonics="Q thermostat MASS",
14546         text="""
14547     This are the masses of the chains of [[nnos]] thermostats to be used when
14548     [[ionmov]] = 13 (Molecular Dynamics) or [[imgmov]] = 13 (Path Integral Molecular
14549     Dynamics).
14550     
14551     If [[ionmov]] = 13 (Molecular Dynamics), this temperature control can be used
14552     with  [[optcell]] =0, 1 (homogeneous cell deformation) or 2 (full cell
14553     deformation).
14554     If [[imgmov]] = 13 (Path Integral Molecular Dynamics), this temperature control
14555     can be used with  [[optcell]] =0 (NVT ensemble) or 2 (fully flexible NPT
14556     ensemble). In that case, [[optcell]] = 2 iS NOT USABLE yet.
14557     """,
14558     ),
14559     
14560     Variable(
14561         abivarname="qprtrb",
14562         varset="ffield",
14563         vartype="integer",
14564         topics=['Artificial_useful'],
14565         dimensions=[3],
14566         defaultval=[0, 0, 0],
14567         mnemonics="Q-wavevector of the PERTurbation",
14568         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
14569         requires="[[vprtrb]]",
14570         text="""
14571     Gives the wavevector, in units of reciprocal lattice primitive translations,
14572     of a perturbing potential of strength [[vprtrb]]. See [[vprtrb]] for more
14573     explanation.
14574     """,
14575     ),
14576     
14577     Variable(
14578         abivarname="qpt",
14579         varset="gstate",
14580         vartype="real",
14581         topics=['q-points_useful'],
14582         dimensions=[3],
14583         defaultval=[0, 0, 0],
14584         mnemonics="Q PoinT",
14585         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
14586         text="""
14587     Only used if [[nqpt]] = 1.
14588     
14589     Combined with [[qptnrm]], define the q vector [[qptn]](1:3) in the case
14590     [[qptopt]] = 0.
14591     
14592     This input variable is not internal ([[qptn]](1:3) is used instead), but is
14593     used to echo the value of [[qptn]](1:3), with renormalisation factor one.
14594     """,
14595     ),
14596     
14597     Variable(
14598         abivarname="qptdm",
14599         varset="gw",
14600         vartype="real",
14601         topics=['Susceptibility_useful'],
14602         dimensions=[3, '[[nqptdm]]'],
14603         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=None, value=0.0),
14604         mnemonics="Q-PoinTs for the Dielectric Matrix",
14605         requires="[[optdriver]] == 3 and [[nqptdm]]!=0",
14606         text="""
14607     [[qptdm]] contains the set of q points used in the screening part of ABINIT,
14608     instead of the automatic generation of the q points when [[nqptdm]] = 0. These q
14609     points are given in terms of reciprocal space primitive translations (**not** in
14610     cartesian coordinates!). For further explanation, see the input variable
14611     [[nqptdm]].
14612     """,
14613     ),
14614     
14615     Variable(
14616         abivarname="qptn",
14617         varset="internal",
14618         vartype="real",
14619         topics=[' DFPT_internal'],
14620         dimensions=[3],
14621         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=3, value=0),
14622         mnemonics="Q-PoinT re-Normalized",
14623         characteristics=['[[INTERNAL_ONLY]]'],
14624         requires="[[nqpt]] == 1",
14625         text="""
14626     Only used if [[nqpt]] = 1.
14627     
14628     In ground-state calculation, the vector [[qptn]](1:3) is added to each
14629     renormalized k point (whatever the value of [[kptopt]] that was used) to
14630     generate the normalized, shifted, set of k-points [[kptns]](1:3,1: **nkpt** ).
14631     In response-function calculations, [[qptn]](1:3) is the wavevector of the
14632     phonon-type calculation.
14633     
14634     [[qptn]](1:3) can be produced on the basis of the different methods described
14635     in [[qptopt]], like using [[qpt]](1:3) with renormalisation provided by
14636     [[qptnrm]], or using the other possibilities defined by [[iqpt]], [[ngqpt]],
14637     [[nshiftq]], [[qptrlatt]], [[shiftq]].
14638     
14639     For insulators, there is no restriction on the q-points to be used for the
14640     perturbations. By contrast, for metals, for the time being, it is advised to
14641     take q points for which the k and k+q grids are the same (when the periodicity
14642     in reciprocal space is taken into account). Tests remain to be done to see
14643     whether other q points might be allowed (perhaps with some modification of the code).
14644     """,
14645     ),
14646     
14647     Variable(
14648         abivarname="qptnrm",
14649         varset="gstate",
14650         vartype="real",
14651         topics=['q-points_useful'],
14652         dimensions="scalar",
14653         defaultval=1.0,
14654         mnemonics="Q PoinTs NoRMalization",
14655         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
14656         text="""
14657     Only used if [[nqpt]] = 1 and [[qptopt]] = 0
14658     
14659     Provides re-normalization of [[qpt]]. Must be positive, non-zero. The actual q
14660     vector (renormalized) is [[qptn]](1:3)= [[qpt]](1:3)/[[qptnrm]].
14661     """,
14662     ),
14663     
14664     Variable(
14665         abivarname="qptopt",
14666         varset="gstate",
14667         vartype="integer",
14668         topics=['q-points_basic'],
14669         dimensions="scalar",
14670         defaultval=0,
14671         mnemonics="QPoinTs OPTion",
14672         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
14673         text="""
14674     Only used if [[nqpt]] = 1.
14675     
14676     Controls the set up to generate the Q point [[qptn]](1:3) to be used for the
14677     specific dataset, either as a shift of k-point grid in ground-state
14678     calculations, or as a stand-alone phonon wavevector.
14679     
14680     There are two basic techniques to generate the Q point: either by specifying
14681     it directly, possibly with a renormalisation factor ([[qptopt]] = 0), or
14682     extracting it from a grid a Q points ([[qptopt]] = 1 to 4), using the index
14683     [[iqpt]]. At variance with the similar generation of k points, only ONE q
14684     point can be used per dataset.
14685     
14686     With [[qptopt]] = 1 to 4, rely on [[ngqpt]] or [[qptrlatt]], as well as on
14687     [[nshiftq]] and [[shiftq]] to set up a q point grid, from which the q point
14688     with number [[iqpt]] will be selected. The values [[qptopt]] = 1 to 4 differ by
14689     the treatment of symmetries. Note that the symmetries are recomputed starting
14690     from the values of [[rprimd]], [[xred]] and [[spinat]]. So, the explicit value
14691     of [[symrel]] are not used. This is to allow doing calculations with
14692     [[nsym]] = 1, sometimes needed for T-dependent electronic structure, still
14693     decreasing the number of q points in the case [[qptopt]] = 1 or [[qptopt]] = 3.
14694     
14695       * 0 --> read directly [[qpt]], and its (eventual) renormalisation factor [[qptnrm]].
14696     
14697       * 1 --> Take fully into account the symmetry to generate the grid of q points in the Irreducible Brillouin Zone only.
14698         (This is the usual mode for RF calculations)
14699     
14700       * 2 --> Take into account only the time-reversal symmetry: q points will be generated in half the Brillouin zone.
14701     
14702       * 3 --> Do not take into account any symmetry: q points will be generated in the full Brillouin zone.
14703     
14704       * 4 --> Take into account all the symmetries EXCEPT the time-reversal symmetry to generate
14705         the k points in the Irreducible Brillouin Zone.
14706     
14707     In the case of a grid of q points, the auxiliary variables [[kptrlen]],
14708     [[ngkpt]] and [[prtkpt]] might help you to select the optimal grid, similarly
14709     to the case of the K point grid.
14710     """,
14711     ),
14712     
14713     Variable(
14714         abivarname="qptrlatt",
14715         varset="gstate",
14716         vartype="integer",
14717         topics=['q-points_useful'],
14718         dimensions=[3, 3],
14719         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=None, value=0),
14720         mnemonics="Q - PoinTs grid: Real space LATTice",
14721         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
14722         excludes="[[ngqpt]]",
14723         text="""
14724     This input variable is used only when [[qptopt]] is positive. It partially
14725     defines the q point grid. The other piece of information is contained in
14726     [[shiftq]]. [[qptrlatt]] cannot be used together with [[ngqpt]].
14727     
14728     The values [[qptrlatt]](1:3,1), [[qptrlatt]](1:3,2), [[qptrlatt]](1:3,3) are
14729     the coordinates of three vectors in real space, expressed in the [[rprimd]]
14730     coordinate system (reduced coordinates). They defines a super-lattice in real
14731     space. The k point lattice is the reciprocal of this super-lattice, possibly
14732     shifted (see [[shiftq]]).
14733     
14734     If neither [[ngqpt]] nor [[qptrlatt]] are defined, ABINIT will automatically
14735     generate a set of k point grids, and select the best combination of
14736     [[qptrlatt]] and [[shiftq]] that allows one to reach a sufficient value of
14737     [[kptrlen]]. See this latter variable for a complete description of this procedure.
14738     """,
14739     ),
14740     
14741     Variable(
14742         abivarname="quadmom",
14743         varset="paw",
14744         vartype="real",
14745         topics=['EFG_basic'],
14746         dimensions=['[[ntypat]]'],
14747         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=None, value=0),
14748         mnemonics="QUADrupole MOMents",
14749         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1 and [[prtefg]]>=1",
14750         text="""
14751       * Array of quadrupole moments, in barns, of the nuclei. These values are used in conjunction with the electric field gradients computed with [[prtefg]] to calculate the quadrupole couplings in MHz, as well as the asymmetries. Note that the electric field gradient at a nuclear site is independent of the nuclear quadrupole moment, thus the quadrupole moment of a nucleus can be input as 0, and the option [[prtefg]] = 2 used to determine the electric field gradient at the site.
14752     """,
14753     ),
14754     
14755     Variable(
14756         abivarname="random_atpos",
14757         varset="rlx",
14758         vartype="integer",
14759         topics=['crystal_expert', 'GeoOpt_expert'],
14760         dimensions="scalar",
14761         defaultval=0,
14762         mnemonics="RANDOM ATomic POSitions",
14763         text="""
14764     Control the inner coordinates, which can be generated randomly by using 4
14765     different methods depending ont its value
14766     (0) if zero, no random generation and xred are taken as they have been introduced by the user
14767     (1) if one, particles are generated completely random within the unit cell.
14768     (2) if two, particles are generated randomly but the inner particle distance
14769     is always larger than a factor of the sum of the covalent bonds between the
14770     atoms (note: this is incompatible with the definition of alchemical mixing,
14771     in which [[ntypat]] differs from [[npsp]])
14772     """,
14773     ),
14774     
14775     Variable(
14776         abivarname="ratsph",
14777         varset="gstate",
14778         vartype="real",
14779         topics=['printing_prdos', 'MagMom_useful', 'ElecBandStructure_useful', 'ElecDOS_useful'],
14780         dimensions=['[[ntypat]]'],
14781         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[usepaw]] == 1': '[[AUTO_FROM_PSP]]' , 'defaultval': 2.0}),
14782         mnemonics="Radii of the ATomic SPHere(s)",
14783         text="""
14784     Relevant only when [[prtdos]] = 3 or [[prtdensph]] = 1.
14785     
14786     When [[prtdos]] = 3:\n
14787     Provides the radius of the spheres around the [[natsph]] atoms of indices
14788     [[iatsph]], in which the local DOS and its angular-momentum projections will
14789     be analysed. The choice of this radius is quite arbitrary. In a plane-wave
14790     basis set, there is no natural definition of an atomic sphere. However, it
14791     might be wise to use the following well-defined and physically motivated procedure:
14792     from the Bader analysis, one can define the radius of the sphere that contains
14793     the same charge as the Bader volume. This "Equivalent Bader charge atomic
14794     radius" might then be used to perform the present analysis. See the
14795     [[help:aim]] for more explanations. Another physically motivated choice would
14796     be to rely on another charge partitioning, like the Hirshfeld one (see the
14797     cut3d utility [[help:cut3d]]). The advantage of using charge partitioning schemes comes from
14798     the fact that the sum of atomic DOS, for all angular momenta and atoms,
14799     integrated on the energy range of the occupied states, gives back the total
14800     charge. If this is not an issue, one could rely on the half of the nearest-
14801     neighbour distances, or any scheme that allows one to define an atomic radius.
14802     Note that the choice of this radius is however critical for the balance
14803     between the s, p and d components. Indeed, the integrated charge within a
14804     given radius, behave as a different power of the radius, for the different
14805     channels s, p, d. At the limit of very small radii, the s component dominates
14806     the charge contained in the sphere...
14807     
14808     When [[prtdensph]] = 1:\n
14809     Provides the radius of the spheres around (all) atoms in which the total
14810     charge density will be integrated.
14811     
14812     In case of PAW, [[ratsph]] radius has to be greater or equal to PAW radius of
14813     considered atom type (which is read from the PAW dataset file; see **rc_sph** or **r_paw**).
14814     """,
14815     ),
14816     
14817     Variable(
14818         abivarname="ratsph_extra",
14819         varset="gstate",
14820         vartype="real",
14821         topics=['printing_prdos'],
14822         dimensions="scalar",
14823         defaultval=ValueWithUnit(units='Bohr', value=2.0),
14824         mnemonics="Radii of the ATomic SPHere(s) in the EXTRA set",
14825         characteristics=['[[LENGTH]]'],
14826         text="""
14827     Radius for extra spheres the DOS is projected into. See [[natsph_extra]] and
14828     [[xredsph_extra]] for the number and positions of the spheres.
14829     """,
14830     ),
14831     
14832     Variable(
14833         abivarname="rcut",
14834         varset="gw",
14835         vartype="real",
14836         topics=['GWls_compulsory', 'Susceptibility_basic', 'SelfEnergy_basic'],
14837         dimensions="scalar",
14838         defaultval=0.0,
14839         mnemonics="Radius of the CUT-off for coulomb interaction",
14840         text="""
14841     Truncation of the Coulomb interaction in real space. The meaning of [[rcut]]
14842     is governed by the cutoff shape option [[icutcoul]].
14843     
14844     If [[rcut]] is negative, the cutoff is automatically calculated so to enclose
14845     the same volume inside the cutoff as the volume of the primitive cell.
14846     """,
14847     ),
14848     
14849     Variable(
14850         abivarname="recefermi",
14851         varset="dev",
14852         vartype="real",
14853         topics=['Recursion_useful'],
14854         dimensions="scalar",
14855         defaultval=0,
14856         mnemonics="RECursion - initial guess  of the FERMI Energy",
14857         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
14858         text="""
14859     Used in Recursion method ([[tfkinfunc]] = 2). In the first SCF calculation it
14860     fixes the initial guess for the Fermi energy.
14861     """,
14862     ),
14863     
14864     Variable(
14865         abivarname="recgratio",
14866         varset="dev",
14867         vartype="integer",
14868         topics=['Recursion_useful'],
14869         dimensions="scalar",
14870         defaultval=1,
14871         mnemonics="RECursion - Grid RATIO",
14872         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
14873         text="""
14874     Used in Recursion method ([[tfkinfunc]] = 2). It represents the ratio of the two
14875     grid step: [[recgratio]] = fine_step/coarse_step and it is bigger or equal than
14876     1. It introduces a double-grid system which permits to compute the electronic
14877     density on a coarse grid, using a fine grid (defined by [[ngfft]]) in the
14878     discretisation of the green kernel (see [[recptrott]]). Successively the
14879     density and the recursion coefficients are interpolated on the fine grid by
14880     FFT interpolation. Note that ngfft/recgratio=number of points of the coarse
14881     grid has to be compatible with the parallelization parameters.
14882     """,
14883     ),
14884     
14885     Variable(
14886         abivarname="recnpath",
14887         varset="dev",
14888         vartype="integer",
14889         topics=['Recursion_expert'],
14890         dimensions="scalar",
14891         defaultval=500,
14892         mnemonics="RECursion - Number of point for PATH integral calculations",
14893         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
14894         text="""
14895     Used in Recursion method ([[tfkinfunc]] = 2). Determine the number of
14896     discretisation points to compute some path integral in the recursion method;
14897     those path integrals are used to compute the entropy and the eigenvalues
14898     energy. during the latest SFC cycles.
14899     """,
14900     ),
14901     
14902     Variable(
14903         abivarname="recnrec",
14904         varset="dev",
14905         vartype="integer",
14906         topics=['Recursion_expert'],
14907         dimensions="scalar",
14908         defaultval=10,
14909         mnemonics="RECursion - Number of RECursions",
14910         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
14911         text="""
14912     Used in Recursion method ([[tfkinfunc]] = 2). Determine the maximum order of
14913     recursion, that is the dimension of the krylov space we use to compute
14914     density. If the precision set by [[rectolden]] is reached before that order,
14915     the recursion method automatically stops.
14916     """,
14917     ),
14918     
14919     Variable(
14920         abivarname="recptrott",
14921         varset="dev",
14922         vartype="integer",
14923         topics=['Recursion_expert'],
14924         dimensions="scalar",
14925         defaultval=0,
14926         mnemonics="RECursion - TROTTer parameter",
14927         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
14928         text=r"""
14929     Used in Recursion method ([[tfkinfunc]] = 2). Determine the trotter parameter
14930     used to compute the exponential of the hamiltonian in the recursion method:
14931     
14932     $$ e^{-\beta(-\Delta + V)} \approx
14933     \left(
14934         e^{-\frac{\beta}{4c} V}
14935         e^{-\frac{\beta}{4c} \Delta}
14936         e^{-\frac{\beta}{4c} V}
14937     \right)^{2c} $$
14938     
14939     where $c$=[[recptrott]].
14940     If set to 0, we use [[recptrott]] = $1/2$ in the above formula.
14941     Increasing [[recptrott]] improve the
14942     accuracy of the trotter formula, but increase the dicretisation error: it may
14943     be necessary to increase [[ngfft]]. The discretisation error is essentially
14944     the discretisation error of the green kernel $e^{\frac{c}{\beta|r|^2}}$ on
14945     the ngfft grid.
14946     """,
14947     ),
14948     
14949     Variable(
14950         abivarname="recrcut",
14951         varset="dev",
14952         vartype="integer",
14953         topics=['Recursion_useful'],
14954         dimensions="scalar",
14955         defaultval=0,
14956         mnemonics="RECursion - CUTing Radius",
14957         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
14958         text="""
14959     Used in Recursion method ([[tfkinfunc]] = 2). Used to improve the computational
14960     time in the case of the recursion method in a large cell: the density at a
14961     point will be computed with taking account only of a sphere of radius [[recrcut]].
14962     """,
14963     ),
14964

14980     Variable(
14981         abivarname="rectolden",
14982         varset="dev",
14983         vartype="real",
14984         topics=['Recursion_basic'],
14985         dimensions="scalar",
14986         defaultval=0.0,
14987         mnemonics="RECursion - TOLerance on the difference of electronic DENsity",

14989         commentdefault="Default value to be changed.",
14990         text="""
14991     Used in Recursion method ([[tfkinfunc]] = 2). Sets a tolerance for differences
14992     of electronic density that, reached TWICE successively, will cause one SCF
14993     cycle to stop. That electronic density difference is computed in the infinity
14994     norm (that is, it is computed point-by-point, and then the maximum difference
14995     is computed).
14996     """,
14997     ),

14999     Variable(

15009     In case [[berryopt]] = 16, a reduced finite electric displacement field
15010     calculation is performed. The value of this displacement field, and its
15011     direction is determined by [[red_dfield]]. It must be given in atomic units.
15012     
15013     [[red_dfield]] is defined via Eq.(26) in the Supplement of [[cite:Stengel2009]].
15014     """,

15039         topics=['Berry_useful'],

15047     by [[red_efieldbar]]. It must be given in atomic units.

15052     
15053     Variable(
15054         abivarname="restartxf",
15055         varset="rlx",
15056         vartype="integer",
15057         topics=['PIMD_useful', 'MolecularDynamics_useful', 'GeoOpt_useful'],
15058         dimensions="scalar",
15059         defaultval=0,
15060         mnemonics="RESTART from (X,F) history",
15061         text="""
15062     Control the restart of a molecular dynamics or structural optimization job.
15063     
15064     **restartxf >0 (Deprecated) **:The code reads from the input wf file, the
15065     previous history of atomic coordinates and corresponding forces, in order to
15066     continue the work done by the job that produced this wf file. If
15067     [[optcell]]/=0, the history of [[acell]] and [[rprim]] variables is also taken
15068     into account. The code will take into consideration the whole history (if
15069     [[restartxf]] = 1), or discard the few first (x,f) pairs, and begin only at the
15070     pair whose number corresponds to [[restartxf]].
15071     Works only for [[ionmov]] = 2 (Broyden) and when an input wavefunction file is
15072     specified, thanks to the appropriate values of [[irdwfk]] or [[getwfk]].
15073     
15074     NOTES:
15075     * The input wf file must have been produced by a run that exited cleanly. It cannot be one of the temporary wf files that exist when a job crashed.
15076     * One cannot restart a calculation with a non-zero [[optcell]] value from the (x,f) history of another run with a different non-zero [[optcell]] value. Starting a non-zero [[optcell]] run from a zero [[optcell]] run should work.
15077     * Deprecated, the use of the new options (-1 and -2) is preferred.
15078     
15079     **restartxf=0 (Default)**: No restart procedure is enable and will start a
15080     Molecular dynamics or structural optimization from scratch.
15081     
15082     **restartxf=-1 (New)**: Use the HIST file to reconstruct a partial
15083     calculation. It will reconstruct the different configurations using the forces
15084     and stress store in the HIST file, instead of calling the SCF procedure.
15085     Enable **restartxf=-1** from the beginning is harmless. The only condition is
15086     to keep the input file the same in such a way that the same predictor is used
15087     and it will predict the same structure recorded in the HIST file.
15088     This option will always compute extra [[ntime]] iterations independent of the
15089     number of iterations recovered previously.
15090     
15091     **restartxf=-2 (New)**:Read the HIST file and select the atomic positions and
15092     cell parameters with the lowest energy. Forget all the history and start the
15093     calculation using those values. The original atomic coordinates and cell
15094     parameters are irrelevant in that case.
15095     
15096     **restartxf=-3 (New)**:Read **ONLY** the last require the atomic positions and cell parameters in the HIST file to restart the Molecular dynamics or structural optimization.
15097     
15098     NOTES:
15099     * You can use **restartxf=-1, -2 or -3** for all predictiors that make no use of random numbers.
15100     * You can use **restartxf=-1, -2 or -3** to restart a calculation that was not completed. The HIST file is written on each iteration. So you always have something to recover from.
15101     * You can take advantage of the appropriate values of [[irdwfk]] or [[getwfk]] to get a good wave function to continue your job.
15102     """,
15103     ),
15104     
15105     Variable(
15106         abivarname="rf2_dkdk",
15107         varset="dfpt",
15108         vartype="integer",
15109         topics=['DFPT_expert'],
15110         dimensions="scalar",
15111         defaultval=0,
15112         mnemonics="Response Function: 2nd Derivative of wavefunctions with respect to K",
15113         text="""
15114     UNUSABLE (in development)
15115     
15116     Activates computation of second derivatives of wavefunctions with respect to
15117     wavevectors. This is not strictly a response function but is a needed
15118     auxiliary quantity in the calculations of 3rd-order derivatives of the energy
15119     (non-linear response). The directions for the derivatives are determined by
15120     [[rfdir]] (TO BE CORRECTED!).
15121     
15122       * 0 --> no derivative calculation
15123       * 1 --> calculation along diagonal directions ($\,d^2$/($\,d k_i \,d k_i$), natom+10 is activated)
15124       * 2 --> calculation along off-diagonal directions ($\,d^2$/($\,d k_i \,d k_j$), natom+11 is activated)
15125       * 3 --> calculation along all directions (both natom+10 and natom+11 are activated)
15126     """,
15127     ),
15128     
15129     Variable(
15130         abivarname="rfasr",
15131         varset="dfpt",
15132         vartype="integer",
15133         topics=['Phonons_basic'],
15134         dimensions="scalar",
15135         defaultval=0,
15136         mnemonics="Response Function: Acoustic Sum Rule",
15137         text="""
15138     Control the evaluation of the acoustic sum rule in effective charges and
15139     dynamical matrix at Gamma within a response function calculation (not active
15140     at the level of producing the DDB, but at the level of the phonon
15141     eigenfrequencies output).
15142     
15143       * 0 --> no acoustic sum rule imposed
15144       * 1 --> acoustic sum rule imposed for dynamical matrix at Gamma, and charge neutrality
15145         imposed with extra charge evenly distributed among atoms
15146       * 2 --> acoustic sum rule imposed for dynamical matrix at Gamma, and charge neutrality
15147         imposed with extra charge given proportionally to those atoms with the largest effective charge.
15148     
15149     The treatment of the acoustic sum rule and charge neutrality sum rule is finer
15150     at the level of the ANADDB utility, with the two independent input variables
15151     [[anaddb:asr]] and [[anaddb:chneut]].
15152     """,
15153     ),
15154     
15155     Variable(
15156         abivarname="rfatpol",
15157         varset="dfpt",
15158         vartype="integer",
15159         topics=['DFPT_basic', 'Elastic_compulsory', 'Phonons_compulsory'],
15160         dimensions=[2],
15161         defaultval=[1, 1],
15162         mnemonics="Response Function: ATomic POLarisation",
15163         text="""
15164     Control the range of atoms for which displacements will be considered in
15165     phonon calculations (atomic polarizations).
15166     These values are only relevant to phonon response function calculations.
15167     May take values from 1 to [[natom]], with [[rfatpol]](1)<=[[rfatpol]](2).
15168     The atoms to be moved will be defined by the
15169     do-loop variable iatpol:
15170     
15171       - do iatpol=[[rfatpol]](1),[[rfatpol]](2)
15172     
15173     For the calculation of a full dynamical matrix, use [[rfatpol]](1)=1 and
15174     [[rfatpol]](2)=[[natom]], together with [[rfdir]] 1 1 1. For selected
15175     elements of the dynamical matrix, use different values of [[rfatpol]] and/or
15176     [[rfdir]]. The name 'iatpol' is used for the part of the internal variable
15177     ipert when it runs from 1 to [[natom]]. The internal variable ipert can also
15178     assume values larger than [[natom]], denoting perturbations of electric field
15179     or stress type (see [the DFPT help file](../guide/respfn)).
15180     """,
15181     ),
15182     
15183     Variable(
15184         abivarname="rfddk",
15185         varset="dfpt",
15186         vartype="integer",
15187         topics=['DFPT_basic'],
15188         dimensions="scalar",
15189         defaultval=0,
15190         mnemonics="Response Function with respect to Derivative with respect to K",
15191         text="""
15192     Activates computation of derivatives of ground state wavefunctions with
15193     respect to wavevectors. This is not strictly a response function but is a
15194     needed auxiliary quantity in the electric field calculations (see [[rfelfd]]).
15195     The directions for the derivatives are determined by [[rfdir]].
15196     
15197       * 0 --> no derivative calculation
15198       * 1 --> calculation of first derivatives of wavefunctions with respect to k points ($\,d/ \,d k$ calculation).
15199         The exact same functionality is provided by [[rfelfd]] = 2.
15200     """,
15201     ),
15202     
15203     Variable(
15204         abivarname="rfdir",
15205         varset="dfpt",
15206         vartype="integer",
15207         topics=['DFPT_compulsory', 'Elastic_compulsory', 'Phonons_compulsory'],
15208         dimensions=[3],
15209         defaultval=[0, 0, 0],
15210         mnemonics="Response Function: DIRections",
15211         text="""
15212     Gives the directions to be considered for response function calculations (also
15213     for the Berry phase computation of the polarization, see the [[berryopt]]
15214     input variable).
15215     The three elements corresponds to the three primitive vectors, either in real
15216     space (phonon calculations), or in reciprocal space ($\,d/ \,d k$, homogeneous
15217     electric field, homogeneous magnetic field calculations). So, they generate a
15218     basis for the generation of the dynamical matrix or the macroscopic dielectric
15219     tensor or magnetic susceptibility and magnetic shielding, or the effective charge tensors.
15220     If equal to 1, response functions, as defined by [[rfddk]], [[rfelfd]],
15221     [[rfphon]], [[rfdir]] and [[rfatpol]], are to be computed for the
15222     corresponding direction. If 0, this direction should not be considered.
15223     """,
15224     ),
15225     
15226     Variable(
15227         abivarname="rfelfd",
15228         varset="dfpt",
15229         vartype="integer",
15230         topics=['EffectiveMass_compulsory', 'DFPT_basic'],
15231         dimensions="scalar",
15232         defaultval=0,
15233         mnemonics="Response Function with respect to the ELectric FielD",
15234         text="""
15235     Turns on electric field response function calculations. Actually, such
15236     calculations requires first the non-self-consistent calculation of derivatives
15237     with respect to k, independently of the electric field perturbation itself.
15238     
15239       * 0 --> no electric field perturbation
15240       * 1 --> full calculation, with first the derivative of ground-state wavefunction with respect to k ($\,d / \,d k$ calculation), by a non-self-consistent calculation, then the generation of the first-order response to an homogeneous electric field
15241       * 2 --> only the derivative of ground-state wavefunctions with respect to k
15242       * 3 --> only the generation of the first-order response to the electric field, assuming that the data on derivative of ground-state wavefunction with respect to k is available on disk.
15243     
15244     !!! note
15245         Because the tolerances to be used for derivatives or homogeneous
15246         electric field are different, one often does the calculation of derivatives in
15247         a separate dataset, followed by calculation of electric field response as well
15248         as phonon.
15249         The options 2 and 3 proves useful in that context; also, in case a scissor
15250         shift is to be used, it is usually not applied for the $\,d / \,d k$ response).
15251     """,
15252     ),
15253     
15254     Variable(
15255         abivarname="rfmagn",
15256         varset="dfpt",
15257         vartype="integer",
15258         topics=['DFPT_basic'],
15259         dimensions="scalar",
15260         defaultval=0,
15261         mnemonics="Response Function with respect to MAGNetic B-field perturbation",
15262         text="""
15263     [[rfmagn]] allows one to run response function calculations with respect to
15264     external magnetic field if set to 1. Currently, orbital magnetism is not taken into
15265     account and the perturbing potential has Zeeman form.
15266     """,
15267     ),
15268     
15269     Variable(
15270         abivarname="rfmeth",
15271         varset="dfpt",
15272         vartype="integer",
15273         topics=['DFPT_expert'],
15274         dimensions="scalar",
15275         defaultval=1,
15276         mnemonics="Response Function METHod",
15277         text="""
15278     Selects method used in response function calculations. Presently, only abs([[rfmeth]]) = 1 is
15279     allowed. This corresponds to storing matrix elements of the 2DTE computed using non-stationary expressions,
15280     instead of stationary ones.
15281     
15282     The difference between positive and negative values is rather technical. Very often, the symmetries can be used in such a way that
15283     some matrix elements can be proven to be zero even without doing any computation. Positive values of [[rfmeth]] activate
15284     this use of symmetries, while it is denied when [[rfmeth]] is negative. There is an indirect additional outcome of this,
15285     as a symmetrization of the whole 2DTE is sometimes rendered possible when the additional knowledge of the zero matrix elements
15286     is available. Thus, the results obtained for positive and negative values of [[rfmeth]] might slightly differ for non-zero elements of the 2DTE,
15287     if they are computed in both cases. 
15288     """,
15289     ),
15290     
15291     Variable(
15292         abivarname="rfphon",
15293         varset="dfpt",
15294         vartype="integer",
15295         topics=['DFPT_basic'],
15296         dimensions="scalar",
15297         defaultval=0,
15298         mnemonics="Response Function with respect to PHONons",
15299         text="""
15300     It must be equal to 1 to run phonon response function calculations.
15301     """,
15302     ),
15303     
15304     Variable(
15305         abivarname="rfstrs",
15306         varset="dfpt",
15307         vartype="integer",
15308         topics=['DFPT_basic', 'Elastic_compulsory'],
15309         dimensions="scalar",
15310         defaultval=0,
15311         mnemonics="Response Function with respect to STRainS",
15312         text="""
15313     Used to run strain response-function calculations (e.g. needed to get elastic
15314     constants). Define, with [[rfdir]], the set of perturbations.
15315     
15316       * 0 --> no strain perturbation
15317       * 1 --> only uniaxial strain(s) (ipert=natom+3 is activated)
15318       * 2 --> only shear strain(s) (ipert=natom+4 is activated)
15319       * 3 --> both uniaxial and shear strain(s) (both ipert=natom+3 and ipert=natom+4 are activated)
15320     
15321     See the possible restrictions on the use of strain perturbations, in the [[help:respfn]].
15322     """,
15323     ),
15324     
15325     Variable(
15326         abivarname="rfuser",
15327         varset="dfpt",
15328         vartype="integer",
15329         topics=['DFPT_expert'],
15330         dimensions="scalar",
15331         defaultval=0,
15332         mnemonics="Response Function, USER-defined",
15333         text="""
15334     Available to the developpers, to activate the use of ipert=natom+6 and
15335     ipert=natom+7, two sets of perturbations that the developpers can define.
15336     
15337       * 0 --> no computations for ipert=natom+6 or ipert=natom+7
15338       * 1 --> response with respect to perturbation natom+6 will be computed
15339       * 2 --> response with respect to perturbation natom+7 will be computed
15340       * 3 --> responses with respect to perturbations natom+6 and natom+7 will be computed
15341     
15342     !!! important
15343         In order to define and use correctly the new perturbations, the developper
15344         might have to include code lines or additional routines at the level of the
15345         following routines: dfpt_cgwf.F90, dfpt_dyout.F90, dfpt_symph.F90,
15346         dfpt_dyout.F90, dfpt_etot.F90, littlegroup_pert.F90, dfpt_looppert.F90,
15347         dfpt_mkcor.F90, dfpt_nstdy.F90, dfpt_nstwf.F90, respfn.F90, dfpt_scfcv.F90,
15348         irreducible_set_pert.F90, dfpt_vloca.F90, dfpt_vtorho.F90, dfpt_vtowfk.F90. In
15349         these routines, the developper should pay a particular attention to the rfpert
15350         array, defined in the routine respfn (in m_respfn_driver.F90), as well as to the ipert local
15351         variable.
15352     """,
15353     ),
15354     
15355     Variable(
15356         abivarname="rhoqpmix",
15357         varset="gw",
15358         vartype="real",
15359         topics=['GW_useful'],
15360         dimensions="scalar",
15361         defaultval=1.0,
15362         mnemonics="RHO QuasiParticle MIXing",
15363         text="""
15364     For self-consistent GW runs, [[rhoqpmix]] sets the mixing coefficient between
15365     the new and the previous electronic densities. This mixing damps the spurious
15366     oscillations in the Hartree potential when achieving self-consistency.
15367     [[rhoqpmix]] is meaningful only when doing self-consistency on the
15368     wavefunctions with [[gwcalctyp]] >= 20.
15369     """,
15370     ),
15371     
15372     Variable(
15373         abivarname="rprim",
15374         varset="basic",
15375         vartype="real",
15376         topics=['UnitCell_basic'],
15377         dimensions=[3, 3],
15378         defaultval=[[1, 0, 0], [0, 1, 0], [0, 0, 1]],
15379         mnemonics="Real space PRIMitive translations",
15380         characteristics=['[[EVOLVING]]'],
15381         commentdims="Internally, it is represented as rprim(3,3,[[nimage]])",
15382         text="""
15383     Give, in columnwise entry, the three dimensionless primitive translations in
15384     real space, to be rescaled by [[acell]] and [[scalecart]].
15385     It is [[EVOLVING]] only if [[ionmov]] == 2 and [[optcell]]/=0, otherwise it is
15386     fixed.
15387     If the Default is used, that is, [[rprim]] is the unity matrix, the three
15388     dimensionless primitive vectors are three unit vectors in cartesian
15389     coordinates. Each will be (possibly) multiplied by the corresponding [[acell]]
15390     value, then (possibly) stretched along the cartesian coordinates by the
15391     corresponding [[scalecart]] value, to give the dimensional primitive vectors,
15392     called [[rprimd]].
15393     In the general case, the dimensional cartesian coordinates of the crystal
15394     primitive translations R1p, R2p and R3p, see [[rprimd]], are
15395     
15396       * R1p(i)=[[scalecart]](i)[[rprim]](i,1)*[[acell]](1)
15397       * R2p(i)=[[scalecart]](i)[[rprim]](i,2)*[[acell]](2)
15398       * R3p(i)=[[scalecart]](i)[[rprim]](i,3)*[[acell]](3)
15399     
15400     where i=1,2,3 is the component of the primitive translation (i.e. x, y, and z).
15401     
15402     The [[rprim]] variable, scaled by [[scalecart]], is thus used to define
15403     directions of the primitive vectors, that will be multiplied (so keeping the
15404     direction unchanged) by the appropriate length scale [[acell]](1),
15405     [[acell]](2), or [[acell]](3), respectively to give the dimensional primitive
15406     translations in real space in cartesian coordinates.
15407     Presently, it is requested that the mixed product (R1xR2).R3 is positive. If
15408     this is not the case, simply exchange a pair of vectors.
15409     To be more specific, keeping the default value of [[scalecart]] = 1 to simplify
15410     the matter, [[rprim]] 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9 corresponds to input of the three
15411     primitive translations R1=(1,2,3) (to be multiplied by [[acell]](1)),
15412     R2=(4,5,6) (to be multiplied by [[acell]](2)), and R3=(7,8,9) (to be
15413     multiplied by [[acell](3)).
15414     Note carefully that the first three numbers input are the first column of
15415     [[rprim]], the next three are the second, and the final three are the third.
15416     This corresponds with the usual Fortran order for arrays. The matrix whose
15417     columns are the reciprocal space primitive translations is the inverse
15418     transpose of the matrix whose columns are the direct space primitive
15419     translations.
15420     
15421     Alternatively to [[rprim]], directions of dimensionless primitive vectors can
15422     be specified by using the input variable [[angdeg]]. This is especially useful
15423     for hexagonal lattices (with 120 or 60 degrees angles). Indeed, in order for
15424     symmetries to be recognized, rprim must be symmetric up to [[tolsym]] (10
15425     digits by default), inducing a specification such as
15426     
15427           rprim  0.86602540378  0.5  0.0
15428                 -0.86602540378  0.5  0.0
15429                  0.0            0.0  1.0
15430     
15431     that can be avoided thanks to [[angdeg]]:
15432     
15433           angdeg 90 90 120
15434     
15435     Although the use of [[scalecart]] or [[acell]] is rather equivalent when the
15436     primitive vectors are aligned with the cartesian directions, it is not the
15437     case for non-orthogonal primitive vectors. In particular, beginners often make
15438     the error of trying to use [[acell]] to define primitive vectors in face-
15439     centered tetragonal lattice, or body-centered tetragonal lattice, or similarly
15440     in face or body-centered orthorhombic lattices. Let us take the example of a
15441     body-centered tetragonal lattice, that might be defined using the following
15442     ("a" and "c" have to be replaced by the appropriate conventional cell vector length):
15443     
15444           rprim  "a"      0        0
15445                   0      "a"       0
15446                  "a/2"   "a/2"    "c/2"
15447         acell 3*1     scalecart 3*1    !  ( These are default values)
15448     
15449     
15450     The following is a valid, alternative way to define the same primitive vectors:
15451     
15452           rprim   1        0       0
15453                   0        1       0
15454                   1/2      1/2     1/2
15455         scalecart  "a"  "a"  "c"
15456         acell 3*1    !  ( These are default values)
15457     
15458     Indeed, the cell has been stretched along the cartesian coordinates, by "a",
15459     "a" and "c" factors.
15460     
15461     At variance, the following is WRONG:
15462     
15463           rprim   1       0       0
15464                   0       1       0
15465                   1/2     1/2     1/2
15466         acell  "a"  "a"  "c"    !   THIS IS WRONG
15467         scalecart 3*1    !  ( These are default values)
15468     
15469     Indeed, the latter would correspond to:
15470     
15471           rprim  "a"      0       0
15472                   0      "a"      0
15473                  "c/2"   "c/2"   "c/2"
15474         acell 3*1     scalecart 3*1    !  ( These are default values)
15475     
15476     Namely, the third vector has been rescaled by "c". It is not at all in the
15477     center of the tetragonal cell whose basis vectors are defined by the scaling factor "a".
15478     As another difference between [[scalecart]] or [[acell]], note that
15479     [[scalecart]] is [[INPUT_ONLY]]: its content will be immediately applied to
15480     rprim, at parsing time, and then scalecart will be set to the default values
15481     (3*1). So, in case [[scalecart]] is used, the echo of [[rprim]] in the output
15482     file is not the value contained in the input file, but the value rescaled by [[scalecart]].
15483     """,
15484     ),
15485     
15486     Variable(
15487         abivarname="rprimd",
15488         varset="basic",
15489         vartype="real",
15490         topics=['UnitCell_internal'],
15491         dimensions=[3, 3],
15492         mnemonics="Real space PRIMitive translations, Dimensional",
15493         characteristics=['[[INTERNAL_ONLY]]', '[[EVOLVING]]'],
15494         commentdims="Internally, it is represented as rprimd(3,3,[[nimage]]).",
15495         text="""
15496     This internal variable gives the dimensional real space primitive vectors,
15497     computed from [[acell]], [[scalecart]], and [[rprim]].
15498     
15499       * R1p(i)=[[rprimd]](i,1)=[[scalecart]](i)*[[rprim]](i,1)*[[acell]](1) for i=1,2,3 (x,y,and z)
15500       * R2p(i)=[[rprimd]](i,2)=[[scalecart]](i)*[[rprim]](i,2)*[[acell]](2) for i=1,2,3
15501       * R3p(i)=[[rprimd]](i,3)=[[scalecart]](i)*[[rprim]](i,3)*[[acell]](3) for i=1,2,3
15502     
15503     It is [[EVOLVING]] only if [[ionmov]] == 2 and [[optcell]]/=0, otherwise it is fixed.
15504     """,
15505     ),
15506     
15507     Variable(
15508         abivarname="scalecart",
15509         varset="basic",
15510         vartype="real",
15511         topics=['UnitCell_useful'],
15512         dimensions=[3],
15513         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=3, value=1),
15514         mnemonics="SCALE CARTesian coordinates",
15515         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
15516         text="""
15517     Gives the scaling factors of cartesian coordinates by which dimensionless
15518     primitive translations (in "[[rprim]]") are to be multiplied. [[rprim]] input
15519     variable, the [[acell]] input variable, and the associated internal [[rprimd]]
15520     internal variable.
15521     Especially useful for body-centered and face-centered tetragonal lattices, as
15522     well as body-centered and face-centered orthorhombic lattices, see [[rprimd]].
15523     Note that this input variable is [[INPUT_ONLY]]: its content will be
15524     immediately applied to rprim, at parsing time, and then scalecart will be set
15525     to the default values. So, it will not be echoed.
15526     """,
15527     ),
15528     
15529     Variable(
15530         abivarname="scphon_supercell",
15531         varset="gstate",
15532         vartype="integer",
15533         topics=['DFPT_expert'],
15534         dimensions=[3],
15535         defaultval=[1, 1, 1],
15536         mnemonics="Self Consistent PHONon SUPERCELL",
15537         text="""
15538     Give extent, in number of primitive unit cells, of the supercell being used
15539     for a self-consistent phonon calculation. Presumes the phonon frequencies and
15540     eigenvectors have been calculated in the original primitive unit cell, on a
15541     grid of q-points which corresponds to the supercell in the present calculation.
15542     Experimental.
15543     """,
15544     ),
15545     
15546     Variable(
15547         abivarname="scphon_temp",
15548         varset="gstate",
15549         vartype="real",
15550         topics=['DFPT_expert'],
15551         dimensions="scalar",
15552         defaultval=0.0,
15553         mnemonics="Self Consistent PHONon TEMPerature",
15554         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
15555         text="""
15556     Temperature which is imposed on phonon distribution, in the self-consistent
15557     scheme of [[cite:Souvatzis2008]]. Determines the extent of the
15558     finite displacements used, and consequent anharmonic effects. Experimental.
15559     """,
15560     ),
15561     
15562     Variable(
15563         abivarname="shiftk",
15564         varset="basic",
15565         vartype="real",
15566         topics=['k-points_useful'],
15567         dimensions=[3, '[[nshiftk]]'],
15568         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[nshiftk]]>1': None, 'defaultval': [0.5, 0.5, 0.5]}),
15569         mnemonics="SHIFT for K points",
15570         text="""
15571     It is used only when [[kptopt]] >= 0, and must be defined if [[nshiftk]] is
15572     larger than 1.
15573     [[shiftk]](1:3,1:[[nshiftk]]) defines [[nshiftk]] shifts of the homogeneous
15574     grid of k points based on [[ngkpt]] or [[kptrlatt]].
15575     The shifts induced by [[shiftk]] corresponds to the reduced coordinates in the
15576     coordinate system defining the k-point lattice. For example, if the k point
15577     lattice is defined using [[ngkpt]], the point whose reciprocal space reduced
15578     coordinates are ( [[shiftk]](1,ii)/[[ngkpt]](1) [[shiftk]](2,ii)/[[ngkpt]](2)
15579     [[shiftk]](3,ii)/[[ngkpt]](3) ) belongs to the shifted grid number ii.
15580     
15581     The user might rely on ABINIT to suggest suitable and efficient combinations
15582     of [[kptrlatt]] and [[shiftk]]. The procedure to be followed is described with
15583     the input variables [[kptrlen]]. In what follows, we suggest some interesting
15584     values of the shifts, to be used with even values of [[ngkpt]]. This list is
15585     much less exhaustive than the above-mentioned automatic procedure.
15586     
15587     1) When the primitive vectors of the lattice do NOT form a FCC or a BCC
15588     lattice, the default (shifted) Monkhorst-Pack grids are formed by using
15589     [[nshiftk]] = 1 and [[shiftk]] 0.5 0.5 0.5. This is often the preferred k point
15590     sampling, as the shift improves the sampling efficiency. However, it can also
15591     break symmetry, if the 111 direction is not an axis of rotation, e.g. in
15592     tetragonal or hexagonal systems. Abinit will complain about this breaking, and
15593     you should adapt [[shiftk]]. For a non-shifted Monkhorst-Pack grid, use
15594     [[nshiftk]] = 1 and [[shiftk]] 0.0 0.0 0.0, which will be compatible with all
15595     symmetries, and is necessary for some features such as k-point interpolation.
15596     
15597     2) When the primitive vectors of the lattice form a FCC lattice, with [[rprim]]
15598     
15599           0.0 0.5 0.5
15600           0.5 0.0 0.5
15601           0.5 0.5 0.0
15602     
15603     the (very efficient) usual Monkhorst-Pack sampling will be generated by using
15604     [[nshiftk]] =  4 and [[shiftk]]
15605     
15606           0.5 0.5 0.5
