17115     and has a significant memory overhead. In exchange, it provides improved
17116     performance when used on several bands at once (Chebyshev or LOBPCG algorithm
17117     with [[bandpp]]
17118     
17119     The memory overhead is proportional to the number of atoms, the number of
17120     plane waves, and the number of projectors per atom. It can be mitigated by
17121     distributing the array with [[npfft]]
17122     
17123     The performance depends crucially on having a good BLAS installed. Provided
17124     the BLAS supports OpenMP, this option also yields very good scaling for the
17125     nonlocal operator.
17126     """,
17127     ),
17128     
17129     Variable(
17130         abivarname="use_gpu_cuda",
17131         varset="paral",
17132         vartype="integer",
17133         topics=['parallelism_expert'],
17134         dimensions="scalar",
17135         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[optdriver]] == 0 and [[CUDA]]': 1, 'defaultval': 0}),
17136         mnemonics="activate USE of GPU accelerators with CUDA (nvidia)",
17137         text="""
17138     Only available if ABINIT executable has been compiled with cuda nvcc compiler.
17139     This parameter activates the use of NVidia graphic accelerators (GPU) if
17140     present.
17141     If [[use_gpu_cuda]] = 1, some parts of the computation are transmitted to the
17142     GPUs.
17143     If [[use_gpu_cuda]] = 0, no computation is done on GPUs, even if present.
17144     
17145     Note that, while running ABINIT on GPUs, it is recommended to use MAGMA
17146     external library (i.e. Lapack on GPUs). The latter is activated during
17147     compilation stage (see "configure" step of ABINIT compilation process). If
17148     MAGMA is not used, ABINIT performances on GPUs can be poor.
17149     """,
17150     ),
17151     
17152     Variable(
17153         abivarname="use_nonscf_gkk",
17154         varset="dev",
17155         vartype="integer",
17156         topics=['ElPhonInt_useful'],
17157         dimensions="scalar",
17158         defaultval=0,
17159         mnemonics="USE NON-SCF calculation of GKK matrix elements (electron phonon)",
17160         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
17161         commentdefault="Default is 0 for the moment. Do not use non-scf method.",
17162         text="""
17163     When this flag is activated during a phonon calculation with abinit, all of
17164     the perturbations are cycled through, but only the symmetry-irreducible ones
17165     are calculated self-consistently. For the others the perturbed density is
17166     rotated by the appropriate symop and the gkk matrix elements are calculated
17167     non-self-consistently. As they do not depend on the perturbed wave functions,
17168     they are correct from the first iteration, and nstep is set to 1 for those
17169     perturbations. Note that the resulting 1DEN files are simply the
17170     rotate/symmetric ones and that the resulting 1WF files are garbage (completely
17171     unconverged) except the matrix elements in the header (equivalent to GKK
17172     files, but please use the latter much smaller files for el-ph calculations).
17173     The new default behavior with [[use_nonscf_gkk]] = 1 should be transparent for
17174     the user, with the same output files but a much quicker execution.
17175     
17176     Caveat: Note that very tight convergence of ground state and phonon
17177     calculations is necessary to get good GKK matrix elements! [[tolwfr]] = 1.e-24
17178     or so is recommended everywhere. There may be problems using use_nonscf_gkk =
17179     1 with non-symmorphic symmetries - please check (at least) that lifetimes for
17180     phonons go to 0 for acoustic modes at Gamma.
17181     """,
17182     ),
17183     
17184     Variable(
17185         abivarname="use_slk",
17186         varset="paral",
17187         vartype="integer",
17188         topics=['parallelism_expert'],
17189         dimensions="scalar",
17190         defaultval=0,
17191         mnemonics="USE ScaLapacK",
17192         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
17193         text="""
17194     If set to 1, enable the use of ScaLapack within LOBPCG.
17195     """,
17196     ),
17197     
17198     Variable(
17199         abivarname="usedmatpu",
17200         varset="paw",
17201         vartype="integer",
17202         topics=['DFT+U_useful'],
17203         dimensions="scalar",
17204         defaultval=0,
17205         mnemonics="USE of an initial Density MATrix in Paw+U",
17206         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1 and [[usepawu]] == 1",
17207         text="""
17208     When [[usedmatpu]]/=0, an initial density matrix (given by [[dmatpawu]]
17209     keyword) is used and kept fixed during the first ABS([[usedmatpu]]) SCF steps.
17210     This starting value of the density matrix can be useful to find the correct
17211     ground state. Within LDA+U formalism, finding the minimal energy of the system
17212     is tricky; thus it is advised to test several values of the initial density
17213     matrix.
17214     Note also that the density matrix has to respect some symmetry rules
17215     determined by the space group. If the symmetry is not respected in the input,
17216     the matrix is however automatically symmetrised.
17217     
17218     The sign of [[usedmatpu]] has influence only when [[ionmov]] /= 0 (dynamics or relaxation):
17219     
17220     - When [[usedmatpu]]>0, the density matrix is kept constant only at first ionic step
17221     - When [[usedmatpu]]<0, the density matrix is kept constant at each ionic step
17222     """,
17223     ),
17224     
17225     Variable(
17226         abivarname="usedmft",
17227         varset="dev",
17228         vartype="integer",
17229         topics=['DMFT_compulsory'],
17230         dimensions="scalar",
17231         defaultval=0,
17232         mnemonics="USE Dynamical Mean Field Theory",
17233         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
17234         text="""
17235     If set to 1, enable the use of DFT+DMFT, see in particular the important
17236     variables [[dmft_solv]], [[dmftbandi]], [[dmftbandf]], [[dmft_nwli]],
17237     [[dmft_nwlo]], [[dmft_tollc]], [[dmft_tolfreq]], and [[dmft_iter]].
17238     
17239     The current implementation uses Wannier functions obtained from
17240     [[ cite:Amadon2008 | projected local orbitals ]] as
17241     correlated orbitals (see [[dmftbandi]] and [[dmftbandf]] input variables to
17242     define them).
17243     
17244     The Green functions are computed on a mesh of linear Matsubara frequencies.
17245     However, most of the code uses logarithmic Matsubara grid to lower the
17246     computational cost. Both [[dmft_nwli]] and [[dmft_nwlo]] are thus convergence
17247     parameters.
17248     
17249     DMFT is currently available for collinear ([[nspinor]] = 1) polarized or
17250     unpolarized calculations ([[nspden]] = [[nsppol]] = 2 or [[nspden]] = [[nsppol]] = 1)
17251     and for non collinear calculations ([[nspinor]] = 2,[[nspden]] = 4,[[nsppol]] = 1).
17252     However it is not yet available for collinear antiferromagnetic calculations
17253     ([[nspden]] = 2,[[nsppol]] = 1) and non collinear non magnetic calculations
17254     ([[nspden]] = 1, [[nsppol]] = 1,[[nspinor]] = 2). CTQMC calculations
17255     ([[dmft_solv]] = 5) are not yet possible if [[nspinor]] = 2.
17256     
17257     Only static calculations without relaxation or dynamics are possible (forces
17258     and stress are not computed in the scheme: so the computed values should NOT
17259     be trusted).
17260     
17261     When correlated density matrices are diagonal, all values of [[upawu]] and
17262     [[jpawu]] are possible. If the correlated density matrices are non diagonal,
17263     only [[jpawu]] = 0 is implemented.
17264     
17265     Relevant direct output quantities from converged DMFT calculations are total
17266     energy and occupation of correlated orbitals. For Hubbard I calculation
17267     ([[dmft_solv]] = 2), total and partial spectral functions can be obtained with
17268     prtdos=1 and can be found in files OUTSpFunc* (where OUT is the root for
17269     output files). For CTQMC calculations ([[dmft_solv]] = 5), imaginary time
17270     impurity Green function are output of the calculations and can be used to
17271     produce spectral function using an external Maximum Entropy Code.
17272     
17273     A typical DFT+DMFT calculation involves two runs. First, a DFT calculation is
17274     fully converged (even unoccupied wavefunctions have to be converged). Then,
17275     the DFT+DMFT calculation is started using DFT wavefunctions or density files.
17276     As DFT+DMFT calculations (with CTQMC) are computationally expensive, it is
17277     convenient to use prtden=-1, to write DEN file at each DFT iteration, in order
17278     to be able to restart the calculation easily.
17279     
17280     For details of the implementation with Wannier functions see [[cite:Amadon2008]],
17281     for self-consistency and Hubbard I
17282     implementation see [[cite:Amadon2012]]. If [[usedmft]] = 1 and [[nbandkss]]/=0, then, the DFT+DMFT
17283     calculation is not done and only projections are computed at the end of the
17284     calculation. They can be used by an external code or used to compute the
17285     screened interaction (see variable [[ucrpa]]).
17286     """,
17287     ),
17288     
17289     Variable(
17290         abivarname="useexexch",
17291         varset="paw",
17292         vartype="integer",
17293         topics=['xc_useful'],
17294         dimensions="scalar",
17295         defaultval=0,
17296         mnemonics="USE of EXact EXCHange",
17297         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
17298         text="""
17299     When [[useexexch]] = 1, the hybrid functional PBE0 is used in PAW, inside PAW
17300     spheres only, and only for correlated orbitals given by [[lexexch]]. To change
17301     the ratio of exact exchange, see also [[exchmix]].
17302     """,
17303     ),
17304     
17305     Variable(
17306         abivarname="usefock",
17307         varset="internal",
17308         vartype="integer",
17309         topics=['Hybrids_internal'],
17310         dimensions="scalar",
17311         defaultval=0,
17312         mnemonics="USE FOCK exact exchange",
17313         characteristics=['[[INTERNAL_ONLY]]'],
17314         text="""
17315     This internal variable is automatically set to 1 when the value of [[ixc]]
17316     refers to an Hartree-Fock calculation or hybrid functionals.
17317     
17318       * 0  -->  No use of exact exchange.
17319       * 1  -->  exact exchange is required for the calculation.
17320     """,
17321     ),
17322     
17323     Variable(
17324         abivarname="usekden",
17325         varset="gstate",
17326         vartype="integer",
17327         topics=['xc_expert'],
17328         dimensions="scalar",
17329         defaultval=0,
17330         mnemonics="USE Kinetic energy DENsity",
17331         text="""
17332     If [[usekden]] = 1 the kinetic energy density will be computed during
17333     the self-consistent loop, in a way similar to the computation of the density.
17334     This is needed if a meta-GGA is to be used as XC functional. By default
17335     ([[usekden]] = 0), the kinetic energy density is not computed during the self-
17336     consistent loop.
17337     """,
17338     ),
17339     
17340     Variable(
17341         abivarname="usepaw",
17342         varset="internal",
17343         vartype="integer",
17344         topics=['PAW_internal'],
17345         dimensions="scalar",
17346         defaultval="[[AUTO_FROM_PSP]]",
17347         mnemonics="USE Projector Augmented Waves method",
17348         characteristics=['[[INTERNAL_ONLY]]'],
17349         text="""
17350     This variable is determined by the pseudopotentials files. PAW calculations
17351     (see [[tutorial:paw1]]) can only be performed with PAW atomic data input files,
17352     while pseudopotential calculations are performed in ABINIT with norm-conserving
17353     pseudopotential input files. Most functionalities in ABINIT are
17354     available with either type of calculation.
17355     """,
17356     ),
17357     
17358     Variable(
17359         abivarname="usepawu",
17360         varset="paw",
17361         vartype="integer",
17362         topics=['DFT+U_compulsory', 'PAW_useful', 'GW_useful', 'SelfEnergy_useful'],
17363         dimensions="scalar",
17364         defaultval=0,
17365         mnemonics="USE PAW+U (spherical part)",
17366         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
17367         text=r"""
17368     Must be non-zero if a DFT+U calculation is done, or if a GW calculation
17369     following a DFT+U calculation is done (important!).
17370     
17371       * If set to 0, the LDA+U method is not used.
17372     
17373       * If set to 1, 2 or 4, the LDA+U method (cf [[cite:Anisimov1991a]]) is used. The full rotationally invariant formulation is used (see Eq. (3) of [[cite:Liechtenstein1995]]) for the interaction term of the energy. Two choices are allowed concerning the double counting term:
17374     
17375         * If [[usepawu]] = 1, the Full Localized Limit (FLL) (or Atomic limit) double counting is used (cf Eq. (4) of [[cite:Liechtenstein1995]] or Eq. (8) of [[cite:Czyzyk1994]]).
17376     
17377         * If [[usepawu]] = 2, the Around Mean Field (AMF) double counting is used (cf Eq. (7) of [[cite:Czyzyk1994]]). Not valid if nspinor=2.
17378     
17379         * If [[usepawu]] = 4, the FLL double counting is used. However, and in comparison to usepaw=1, the calculation is done without
17380         polarization in the exchange correlation functional (cf [[cite:Park2015]] and [[cite:Chen2016a]]). In this case, one must use [[iscf]]<10.
17381     
17382     If LDA+U is activated ([[usepawu]] = 1 or 2), the [[lpawu]], [[upawu]] and
17383     [[jpawu]] input variables are read.
17384     The implementation is done inside PAW augmentation regions only (cf [[cite:Bengone2000]]).
17385     The initial density matrix can be given in the input file (see [[usedmatpu]]).
17386     The expression of the density matrix is chosen thanks to [[dmatpuopt]].
17387     In the case of a GW calculation on top of a DFT+U, the absence of definition
17388     of a U value in the self-energy will LEAVE the underlying U from the DFT
17389     calculation. Thus, the code will actually do a GW+U @ DFT+U calculation. Note
17390     that the screening calculation will not be affected by the presence/absence of
17391     a U value.
17392     Actually, in order to perform a GW @ DFT+U calculation, one should define the
17393     same value of U in the self-energy calculation, than the one defined in the
17394     DFT calculation. The code will know that the interaction corresponding to that
17395     value has to be SUBTRACTED inside the self-energy. The easiest is actually to
17396     define the presence of U for the whole set of calculations (for the different
17397     datasets), including the screening, even if the U value does not play
17398     explicitly a role in the computation of the latter (well, the input
17399     wavefunctions will be different anyhow).
17400     It is possible to perform calculations of the type GW+$U^{'}$ @ DFT+U, so
17401     keeping a smaller U interaction in the GW calculation, by subtracting a
17402     smaller U than the one used in the DFT calculation. See the description of the
17403     [[upawu]] input variable.
17404     
17405     
17406     Suggested acknowledgment:[[cite:Amadon2008a]].
17407     
17408     """,
17409     ),
17410     
17411     Variable(
17412         abivarname="usepotzero",
17413         varset="dev",
17414         vartype="integer",
17415         topics=['Coulomb_useful'],
17416         dimensions="scalar",
17417         defaultval=0,
17418         mnemonics="USE POTential ZERO",
17419         text="""
17420     Fix the convention for the choice of the average value of the Hartree potential, as described in [[cite:Bruneval2014]].
17421       * [[usepotzero]] = 0, the usual convention: the smooth potential is set to zero average value.
17422       * [[usepotzero]] = 1, the new convention: the all-electron physical potential is set to zero average value.
17423       * [[usepotzero]] = 2, the PWscf convention: the potential of equivalent point charges is set to
17424       zero average value (convention also valid for NC pseudopotentials).
17425     """,
17426     ),
17427     
17428     Variable(
17429         abivarname="userec",
17430         varset="internal",
17431         vartype="integer",
17432         topics=['Recursion_internal'],
17433         dimensions="scalar",
17434         defaultval=0,
17435         mnemonics="USE RECursion",
17436         characteristics=['[[INTERNAL_ONLY]]'],
17437         text="""
17438     This internal variable is set to 1 when the recursion method is activated (see [[tfkinfunc]]).
17439     """,
17440     ),

17446         topics=['Dev_expert'],
17447         dimensions="scalar",
17448         defaultval=0,
17449         mnemonics="USER Integer variable A",
17450         text="""
17451     These are user-definable integers which the user may input and then utilize in
17452     subroutines of his/her own design. They are not used in the official versions
17453     of the ABINIT code, and should ease independent developments (hopefully
17454     integrated in the official version afterwards).
17455     Internally, they are available in the dtset structured datatype, e.g. `dtset%useria`.
17456     """,
17457     ),

17592     Variable(
17593         abivarname="usewvl",
17594         varset="basic",
17595         vartype="integer",
17596         topics=['Wavelets_compulsory'],
17597         dimensions="scalar",
17598         defaultval=0,
17599         mnemonics="Use WaVeLet basis set",
17600         commentdefault="use plane-wave basis set",
17601         text="""
17602     Used to define if the calculation is done on a wavelet basis set or not.
17603     The values of [[usewvl]] must be 0 or 1. Putting [[usewvl]] to 1, makes
17604     [[icoulomb]] mandatory to 1. The number of band ([[nband]]) must be set
17605     manually to the strict number need for an isolator system ( _i.e._ number of
17606     electron over two). The cut-off is not relevant in the wavelet case, use
17607     [[wvl_hgrid]] instead.
17608     In wavelet case, the system must be isolated systems (molecules or clusters).
17609     All geometry optimization are available (see [[ionmov]], especially the
17610     geometry optimisation and the molecular dynamics).
17611     The spin computation is not currently possible with wavelets and metallic
17612     systems may be slow to converge.
17613     """,
17614     ),
17615     
17616     Variable(
17617         abivarname="usexcnhat",
17618         varset="paw",
17619         vartype="integer",
17620         topics=['PAW_useful'],
17621         dimensions="scalar",
17622         defaultval=-1,
17623         mnemonics="USE eXchange-Correlation with NHAT (compensation charge density)",
17624         requires="[[usepaw]] == 1",
17625         text="""
17626     
17627     This flag determines how the exchange-correlation terms are computed for the
17628     pseudo-density.
17629     When [[usexcnhat]] = 0, exchange-correlation potential does not include the
17630     compensation charge density, i.e. $V_{xc}=V_{xc}(\\tilde{n}_{core} + \\tilde{n}_{valence})$.
17631     When [[usexcnhat]] = 1, exchange-correlation potential includes the compensation
17632     charge density, i.e. $V_{xc}=V_{xc}(\\tilde{n}_{core} + \\tilde{n}_{valence}+\\hat{n})$.
17633     When [[usexcnhat]] = -1,the value of [[usexcnhat]] is determined from the
17634     reading of the PAW dataset file (pseudopotential file). When PAW datasets with
17635     different treatment of $V_{xc}$ are used in the same run, the code stops.
17636     """,
17637     ),
17638     
17639     Variable(
17640         abivarname="useylm",
17641         varset="dev",
17642         vartype="integer",
17643         topics=['TuningSpeed_expert'],
17644         dimensions="scalar",
17645         defaultval=ValueWithConditions({'[[tfkinfunc]] == 1': 1, '[[usepaw]] == 1': 1, 'defaultval': 0}),
17646         mnemonics="USE YLM (the spherical harmonics)",
17647         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
17648         text="""
17649     When this flag is activated, the non-local operator is applied using an
17650     algorithm based on spherical harmonics. Non-local projectors are used with
17651     their usual form:
17652     
17653     $$P_{lmn}(r) = Y_{lm}(r) p_{ln}(r)$$
17654     
17655     When [[useylm]] = 0, the sum over $Y_{lm}$ can be reduced to a Legendre polynomial form.
17656     """,
17657     ),
17658     
17659     Variable(
17660         abivarname="vaclst",
17661         varset="geo",
17662         vartype="integer",
17663         topics=['AtomManipulator_useful'],
17664         dimensions=['[[vacnum]]'],
17665         mnemonics="VACancies LiST",
17666         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
17667         text="""
17668     Gives the identification number(s) of atoms to be subtracted from the set of
17669     atoms that are obtained after having rotated, translated and repeated the objects.
17670     Useful to created vacancies.
17671     """,
17672     ),
17673     
17674     Variable(
17675         abivarname="vacnum",
17676         varset="geo",
17677         vartype="integer",
17678         topics=['AtomManipulator_useful'],
17679         dimensions="scalar",
17680         defaultval=0,
17681         mnemonics="VACancies NUMber",
17682         text="""
17683     Gives the number of atoms to be subtracted from the list of atoms after the
17684     rotations, translations and repetitions have been done. The list of these
17685     atoms is contained in [[vaclst]].
17686     """,

17688     
17689     Variable(
17690         abivarname="vacuum",
17691         varset="gstate",
17692         vartype="integer",
17693         topics=['k-points_expert'],
17694         dimensions=[3],
17695         mnemonics="VACUUM identification",
17696         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
17697         text="""
17698     Establishes the presence (if [[vacuum]] = 1) or absence (if [[vacuum]] = 0) of a vacuum layer, along the
17699     three possible directions normal to the primitive axes.
17700     
17701     This information might be used to generate k-point grids, if [[kptopt]] = 0 and
17702     neither [[ngkpt]] nor [[kptrlatt]] are defined (see explanations with the
17703     input variable [[prtkpt]]).
17704     It will allow to select a zero-, one-, two- or three-dimensional grid of k
17705     points. The coordinate of the k points along vacuum directions is
17706     automatically set to zero.
17707     
17708     If [[vacuum]] is not defined, the input variable [[vacwidth]] will be used to
17709     determine automatically whether the distance between atoms is sufficient to
17710     have the presence or absence of vacuum.
17711     """,
17712     ),
17713     
17714     Variable(
17715         abivarname="vacwidth",
17716         varset="gstate",
17717         vartype="real",
17718         topics=['k-points_expert'],
17719         dimensions="scalar",
17720         defaultval=10.0,
17721         mnemonics="VACuum WIDTH",
17722         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]', '[[LENGTH]]'],
17723         text="""
17724     Give a minimum "projected" distance between atoms to be found in order to
17725     declare that there is some [[vacuum]] present for each of the three
17726     directions. By default, given in Bohr atomic units (1 Bohr=0.5291772108
17727     Angstroms), although Angstrom can be specified, if preferred, since
17728     [[vacwidth]] has the '[[LENGTH]]' characteristics.
17729     The precise requirement is that a slab of width [[vacwidth]], delimited by two
17730     planes of constant reduced coordinates in the investigated direction, must be empty of atoms.
17731     """,
17732     ),
17733     
17734     Variable(
17735         abivarname="vcutgeo",
17736         varset="gw",
17737         vartype="real",
17738         topics=['GWls_compulsory', 'Susceptibility_basic', 'SelfEnergy_basic'],
17739         dimensions=[3],
17740         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=3, value=0.0),
17741         mnemonics="V (potential) CUT-off GEOmetry",
17742         requires="[[icutcoul]] in [1,2]",
17743         text="""
17744     [[vcutgeo]] is used in conjunction with [[icutcoul]] to specify the geometry
17745     used to truncate the Coulomb interaction, as well as the particular approach
17746     to be used. It has a meaning only for the cylindrical symmetry
17747     ([[icutcoul]] = 1) or in the case of surfaces ([[icutcoul]] = 2). For each
17748     geometry, two different definitions of the cutoff region are available (see
17749     Phys. Rev. B 73, 233103 and Phys. Rev. B 73, 205119 for a complete description
17750     of the methods)
17751     
17752     In the method of Ismail-Beigi [[cite:Ismail-Beigi2006]], the cutoff region is given by the
17753     Wigner-Seitz cell centered on the axis of the cylinder. The cutoff region is
17754     thus automatically defined by the unit cell and there is no need to specify
17755     When [[rcut]].
17756     
17757     To define a cylinder along the z-axis use the following lines:
17758     ```
17759     icutcoul 1
17760     vcutgeo  0 0 1
17761     ```
17762     
17763     Please note that the method of Ismail-Beigi is implemented only in the case if an
17764     orthorhombic Bravais lattic. For hexagonal lattices, one has to use the method
17765     of Rozzi [[cite:Rozzi2006]]. In this case, the interaction is truncated
17766     in a finite cylinder. Contrarily to the first approach, here one has to
17767     specify both the radius of the cylinder with [[rcut]] as well as the length of
17768     the cylinder along the periodic dimension that should always be smaller than
17769     the extension of the Born von Karman box. The length of the cylinder is given
17770     in terms of the fraction of the primitive vector along the periodic direction.
17771     
17772     For example, in order to define a finite cylinder along z of radius 2.5 Bohr
17773     and length 3*R3,
17774     ```
17775     icutcoul 1
17776     vcutgeo  0 0 -3.0 # note the minus sign
17777     rcut     2.5
17778     ```
17779     
17780     For surface calculations ([[icutcoul]] = 2), [[vcutgeo]] is used to define the
17781     two periodic directions defining the surface. Also in this case two different
17782     techniques are available. In the method of Ismail-Beigi, the (positive) non-zero
17783     components of vcutgeo define the periodic directions of the infinite surface.
17784     The interaction is truncated within a slab of width L where L is the length of
17785     the primitive vector of the lattice along the non-periodic dimension. For
17786     example:
17787     ```
17788     icutcoul 2
17789     vcutgeo  1 1 0
17790     ```
17791     
17792     It is also possible to define a finite
17793     surface by employing negative values. For example:
17794     ```
17795     icutcoul 2
17796     vcutgeo -3 -2 0
17797     ```
17798     **Definition to be added**
17799     """,
17800     ),
17801     
17802     Variable(
17803         abivarname="vdw_df_acutmin",
17804         varset="vdw",
17805         vartype="real",
17806         topics=['vdw_expert'],
17807         dimensions="scalar",
17808         defaultval=10,
17809         mnemonics="vdW-DF MINimum Angular CUT-off",

17812         text="""

17814     """,
17815     ),

17934     Used when [[vdw_xc]]>0, to build the vdW-DF kernel.

17938     Variable(
17939         abivarname="vdw_df_ngpts",
17940         varset="vdw",
17941         vartype="integer",
17942         topics=['vdw_expert'],
17943         dimensions="scalar",
17944         defaultval=-1,
17945         mnemonics="vdW-DF Number of G-mesh PoinTS",
17946         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],

17953     Variable(
17954         abivarname="vdw_df_nqpts",
17955         varset="vdw",
17956         vartype="integer",
17957         topics=['vdw_expert'],
17958         dimensions="scalar",
17959         defaultval=30,
17960         mnemonics="vdW-DF Number of Q-mesh PoinTS",
17961         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
17962         requires="[[vdw_xc]]>0",
17963         text="""
17964     Used when [[vdw_xc]]>0, to build the vdW-DF kernel.
17965     """,
17966     ),
17967     
17968     Variable(
17969         abivarname="vdw_df_nrpts",

18081         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
18082         requires="[[vdw_xc]]>0",
18083         text="""
18084     Sets a threshold for the energy gradient that, when reached, will cause the
18085     vdW-DF interactions to be calculated.
18086     Adjust it to a big value (e.g. 1e12) to enable it all along the SCF
18087     calculation. Too small values, as well as negative values, will result in the
18088     vdW-DF energy contributions never being calculated.
18089     """,
18090     ),

18128     Variable(
18129         abivarname="vdw_df_zab",
18130         varset="vdw",
18131         vartype="real",
18132         topics=['vdw_expert'],
18133         dimensions="scalar",
18134         defaultval=-0.8491,

18142     
18143     Variable(
18144         abivarname="vdw_nfrag",
18145         varset="vdw",
18146         vartype="integer",
18147         topics=['vdw_basic'],
18148         dimensions="scalar",
18149         defaultval=1,
18150         mnemonics="Van Der Waals Number of interacting FRAGments",
18151         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
18152         requires="[[vdw_xc]] in [10,11]",
18153         text="""
18154     The absolute value of vdw_nfrag is the number of vdW interacting fragments in
18155     the unit cell. As wannierization takes place in reciprocal space, the MLWF
18156     center positions could be translated by some lattice vector from the cell
18157     where atoms are placed. If [[vdw_nfrag]] >= 1 then MLWFs are translated to the
18158     original unit cell, otherwise the program will keep the positions obtained by
18159     Wannier90. The later is usually correct if some atoms are located at the
18160     corners or at limiting faces of the unit cell.
18161     """,
18162     ),
18163     
18164     Variable(
18165         abivarname="vdw_supercell",
18166         varset="vdw",
18167         vartype="integer",
18168         topics=['vdw_basic'],
18169         dimensions=[3],
18170         defaultval=[0, 0, 0],
18171         mnemonics="Van Der Waals correction from Wannier functions in SUPERCELL",
18172         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
18173         requires="[[vdw_xc]] in [10,11]",
18174         text="""
18175     Set of dimensionless positive numbers which define the maximum multiples of
18176     the primitive translations ([[rprimd]]) in the supercell construction. Each
18177     component of vdw_supercell indicates the maximum number of cells along both
18178     positive or negative directions of the corresponding primitive vector i.e. the
18179     components of [[rprimd]]. In the case of layered systems for which vdW
18180     interactions occur between layers made of tightly bound atoms, the evaluation
18181     of vdW corrections coming from MLWFs in the same layer (fragment) must be
18182     avoided. Both a negative or null value for one component of [[vdw_supercell]]
18183     will indicate that the corresponding direction is normal to the layers.
18184     """,
18185     ),
18186     
18187     Variable(
18188         abivarname="vdw_tol",
18189         varset="vdw",
18190         vartype="real",
18191         topics=['vdw_compulsory'],
18192         dimensions="scalar",
18193         defaultval=1e-10,
18194         mnemonics="Van Der Waals TOLerance",
18195         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
18196         requires="[[vdw_xc]] == 5",
18197         text="""
18198     The DFT-D methods [[cite:Grimme2010]] dispersion potentials, [[vdw_xc]] == 5 or
18199     6 or 7, include a pair potential. The number of pairs of atoms contributing to
18200     the potential is necessarily limited. To be included in the potential a pair
18201     of atom must have contribution to the energy larger than [[vdw_tol]].
18202     """,
18203     ),
18204     
18205     Variable(
18206         abivarname="vdw_tol_3bt",
18207         varset="vdw",
18208         vartype="real",
18209         topics=['vdw_basic'],
18210         dimensions="scalar",
18211         defaultval=-1,
18212         mnemonics="Van Der Waals TOLerance for 3-Body Term",
18213         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
18214         commentdefault="Do include the 3-body term in the correction",
18215         requires="[[vdw_xc]] == 6",
18216         text="""
18217     Control the computation of the 3-body correction inside DFT-D3 dispersion
18218     correction (Grimme approach) to the total energy:
18219     
18220       * If **vdw_tol_3bt** <0, no 3-body correction.
18221       * If **vdw_tol_3bt** >0, the 3-body term is included with a tolerance = **vdw_tol_3bt**.
18222     
18223     DFT-D3 as proposed by S. Grimme adds two contributions to the total energy in
18224     order to take into account of the dispersion:
18225     
18226       * A pair-wise potential for which the tolerance is controlled by [[vdw_tol]]
18227     
18228       * A 3-body term which is obtained by summing over all triplets of atoms. Each individual contribution depends of the distances and angles between the three atoms. As it is impossible to sum over all the triplets in a periodic system, one has to define a stopping criterium which is here that an additional contribution to the energy must be higher than **vdw_tol_3bt**
18229     
18230     The last term has been predicted to have an important effect for large
18231     molecules [[cite:Grimme2010]]. It is however quite costly in computational
18232     time for periodic systems and seems to lead to an overestimation of lattice
18233     parameters for weakly bound systems [[cite:Grimme2011]]. Still, its
18234     contribution to energy, to forces and to stress is available (not planned for
18235     elastic constants, dynamical matrix and internal strains).
18236     """,
18237     ),
18238     
18239     Variable(
18240         abivarname="vdw_typfrag",
18241         varset="vdw",
18242         vartype="integer",
18243         topics=['vdw_basic'],
18244         dimensions=['[[natom]]'],
18245         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=1, value='[[natom]]'),
18246         mnemonics="Van Der Waals TYPe of FRAGment",
18247         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
18248         requires="[[vdw_xc]] in [10,11]",
18249         text="""
18250     This array defines the interacting fragments by assigning to each atom an
18251     integer index from 1 to **vdw_nfrag**. The ordering of [[vdw_typfrag]] is the
18252     same as [[typat]] or [[xcart]]. Internally each MLWF is assigned to a given
18253     fragment by computing the distance to the atoms. MLWFs belong to the same
18254     fragment as their nearest atom. The resulting set of MLWFs in each interacting
18255     fragment can be found in the output file in xyz format for easy visualization.
18256     """,
18257     ),
18258     
18259     Variable(
18260         abivarname="vdw_xc",
18261         varset="vdw",
18262         vartype="integer",
18263         topics=['vdw_compulsory'],
18264         dimensions="scalar",
18265         defaultval=0,
18266         mnemonics="Van Der Waals eXchange-Correlation functional",
18267         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
18268         text="""
18269     Selects a van-der-Waals density functional to apply the corresponding
18270     correction to the exchange-correlation energy. If set to zero, no correction
18271     will be applied.
18272     Possible values are:
18273     
18274       * 0: no correction.
18275       * 1: apply vdW-DF1 (DRSLL) from [[cite:Dion2004]].
18276       * 2: apply vdw-DF2 (LMKLL) from [[cite:Lee2010]].
18277       * 5: apply vdw-DFT-D2 as proposed by S. Grimme [[cite:Grimme2006]] (adding a semi-empirical dispersion potential). Available only for ground-state calculations and response functions; see [[vdw_tol]] variable to control convergence.
18278       * 6: apply vdw-DFT-D3 as proposed by S. Grimme [[cite:Grimme2010]] (refined version of DFT-D2). Available only for ground-state calculations and response functions; see [[vdw_tol]] variable to control convergence and [[vdw_tol_3bt]] variable to include 3-body corrections.
18279       * 7: apply vdw-DFT-D3(BJ) as proposed by Grimme (based on Becke-Jonhson method from [[cite:Becke2006]]). Available only for ground-state calculations and response functions; see [[vdw_tol]] variable to control convergence.
18280       * 10: evaluate the vdW correlation energy from maximally localized Wannier functions, as proposed by P. L. Silvestrelli, also known as vdW-WF1 method [[cite:Silvestrelli2008]]. For details on this implementation please check [[cite:Espejo2012]]. The improvements introduced by Andrinopoulos _et al._ [[cite:Andrinopoulos2011]], namely the amalgamation procedure, splitting of p-like MLWFs into two s-like Wannier functions and fractional occupation of MLWFs are performed automatically.
18281       * 11: evaluate the vdW correlation energy from maximally localized Wannier functions, as proposed by A. Ambrosetti and P. L. Silvestrelli, also known as vdW-WF2 method [[cite:Ambrosetti2012]].
18282       * 14: apply DFT/vdW-QHO-WF method as proposed by Silvestrelli, which combines the quantum harmonic oscillator-model with localized Wannier functions [[cite:Silvestrelli2013]]. For periodic systems a supercell approach has to be used since **vdw_supercell** is not enabled in this case.
18283     
18284     For [[vdw_xc]] = 1 and [[vdw_xc]] = 2, the implementation follows the strategy
18285     devised in the article of Roman-Perez and Soler [[cite:Romanperez2009]].
18286     """,
18287     ),
18288     
18289     Variable(
18290         abivarname="vel",
18291         varset="rlx",
18292         vartype="real",
18293         topics=['PIMD_useful', 'MolecularDynamics_basic'],
18294         dimensions=[3, '[[natom]]'],
18295         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=None, value=0),
18296         mnemonics="VELocity",
18297         characteristics=['[[EVOLVING]]'],
18298         commentdims="It is represented internally as [[vel]](3,[[natom]],[[nimage]])",
18299         requires="[[ionmov]] > 0",
18300         text="""
18301     Gives the starting velocities of atoms, in cartesian coordinates, in
18302     Bohr/atomic time units (atomic time units given where [[dtion]] is described).
18303     For [[ionmov]] = 8 (Nose thermostat), if [[vel]] is not initialized, a random
18304     initial velocity giving the right kinetic energy will be generated.
18305     If the atom manipulator is used, [[vel]] will be related to the preprocessed
18306     set of atoms, generated by the atom manipulator. The user must thus foresee
18307     the effect of this atom manipulator (see [[objarf]]).
18308     Velocities evolve is [[ionmov]] == 1.
18309     """,
18310     ),
18311     
18312     Variable(
18313         abivarname="vel_cell",
18314         varset="rlx",
18315         vartype="real",
18316         topics=['PIMD_expert'],
18317         dimensions=[3, 3],
18318         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=None, value=3),
18319         mnemonics="VELocity of the CELL parameters",
18320         characteristics=['[[EVOLVING]]'],
18321         commentdims="It is represented internally as [[vel_cell]](3,3,[[nimage]])",
18322         requires="""[[imgmov]] in [9,13] and [[optcell]] > 0
18323     (Path-Integral Molecular Dynamics with NPT algorithm)""",
18324         text="""
18325     Irrelevant unless [[imgmov]] = 9 or 13 and [[optcell]]>0 (Path-Integral
18326     Molecular Dynamics with NPT algorithm).
18327     Gives the starting velocities of the dimensional cell parameters in
18328     Bohr/atomic time units (atomic time units given where [[dtion]] is described).
18329     """,
18330     ),
18331     
18332     Variable(
18333         abivarname="vis",
18334         varset="rlx",
18335         vartype="real",
18336         topics=['PIMD_basic', 'MolecularDynamics_basic'],
18337         dimensions="scalar",
18338         defaultval=100,
18339         mnemonics="VIScosity",
18340         text=r"""
18341     The equation of motion is:
18342     
18343     M  I  d  2  R  I  /dt  2  = F  I  - [[vis]] dR  I  /dt
18344     
18345     The atomic unit of viscosity is hartree * (atomic time units)/Bohr 2. Units
18346     are not critical as this is a fictitious damping used to relax structures. A
18347     typical value for silicon is 400 with [[dtion]] of 350 and atomic mass 28
18348     [[amu]]. Critical damping is most desirable and is found only by optimizing
18349     [[vis]] for a given situation.
18350     
18351     In the case of Path-Integral Molecular Dynamics using the Langevin Thermostat
18352     ([[imgmov]] = 9), [[vis]] defines the friction coefficient, in atomic units.
18353     Typical value range is 0.00001-0.001.
18354     """,
18355     ),
18356     
18357     Variable(
18358         abivarname="vprtrb",
18359         varset="ffield",
18360         vartype="real",
18361         topics=['Artificial_useful'],
18362         dimensions=[2],
18363         defaultval=[0.0, 0.0],
18364         mnemonics="potential -V- for the PeRTuRBation",
18365         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]', '[[ENERGY]]'],
18366         requires="[[qprtrb]]",
18367         text="""
18368     Gives the real and imaginary parts of a scalar potential perturbation. Can be
18369     specified in Ha (the default), Ry, eV or Kelvin, since [[vprtrb]] has the
18370     '[[ENERGY]]' characteristics.
18371     This is made available for testing responses to such perturbations. The form
18372     of the perturbation, which is added to the local potential, is:
18373     
18374       * ([[vprtrb]](1)$+I$[[vprtrb]](2)$)/2$ at $G=$[[qprtrb]] and
18375       * ([[vprtrb]](1)$-I$[[vprtrb]](2)$)/2$ at $G=-$[[qprtrb]] (see [[qprtrb]] also).
18376     """,
18377     ),
18378     
18379     Variable(
18380         abivarname="w90iniprj",
18381         varset="w90",
18382         vartype="integer",
18383         topics=['Wannier_basic'],
18384         dimensions="scalar",
18385         defaultval=1,
18386         mnemonics="Wannier90- INItial PROJections",
18387         requires="[[prtwant]] == 2 or [[prtwant]] == 3",
18388         text="""
18389     In order to find the Maximally Localized Wannier Functions, the user has to
18390     provide an initial guess. A set of localized trial orbitals is chosen
18391     corresponding to some rough initial guess at the Wannier Functions, and these
18392     are projected onto the Bloch eigenstates. See [[cite:Souza2002a]].
18393     These initial projections are stored in a file **.amn** and the variable
18394     **w90iniprj** is used to construct them:
18395     
18396       * **w90iniprj** =1: Random projections.
18397     
18398       * **w90iniprj** =2: The initial projections will be a linear combination of hydrogenic atomic orbitals.
18399     The user has to define the projections in the secondary input file
18400     wannier90.win.
18401     Information about how to define them can be found in the manual of Wannier90.
18402     See [www.wannier.org](http://www.wannier.org)
18403     """,
18404     ),
18405     
18406     Variable(
18407         abivarname="w90prtunk",
18408         varset="w90",
18409         vartype="integer",
18410         topics=['Wannier_basic'],
18411         dimensions="scalar",
18412         defaultval=0,
18413         mnemonics="Wannier90- PRINT UNKp.s file",
18414         commentdefault="""The default is set to zero because UNKp.s files occupy a lot of memory.""",
18415         requires="[[prtwant]] == 2 or [[prtwant]] == 3",
18416         text="""
18417     Defines whether or not the UNKp.s file will be printed.
18418     
18419       * [[w90prtunk]] = 0: Do not print the UNKp.s files
18420     
18421       * [[w90prtunk]] = 1: Print the UNKp.s files on a fine grid
18422     
18423       * [[w90prtunk]]>1: Print the UNKp.s files on a coarse grid
18424     
18425     Instead of printing every record we will print every [[w90prtunk]] records. This
18426     is useful to reduce the size of the UNKp.s files, but, the quality is also reduced.
18427     
18428     These files contain the periodic part of the bloch states represented on a
18429     regular real space grid. They are indexed by k-point **p** (from 1 to nkpt)
18430     and spin **s** ('1' for 'up','2' for 'down').
18431     
18432     The name of the wavefunction file is assumed to have the form:
18433     
18434     write(wfnname,200) **p**, **spin**
18435     200 format ('UNK',i5.5,'.',i1)
18436     
18437     These file are unformatted. The first line of each file contains 5 integers:
18438     the number of grid points in each direction ( **n1**, **n2** and **n3** ),
18439     the k-point number **ikpt** and the total number of bands mband in the file.
18440     The following rows contain the wavefunctions in real space.
18441     
18442     These files are written in the following way for the coarse grid:
18443     
18444     ```fortran
18445          write(iun_plot) n1/w90prtunk,n2/w90prtunk,n3/w90prtunk,ikpt,nband
18446          write(iun_plot) (((fofr(1,jj1,jj2,jj3),fofr(2,jj1,jj2,jj3),&
18447         &      jj1=1,n1,w90prtunk),jj2=1,n2,w90prtunk),jj3=1,n3,w90prtunk)
18448     ```
18449     
18450     Where **fofr** is a double precision variable which contains the wavefunctions
18451     in real space. Note that in order to reduce the size of the UNK files we are
18452     just including records in the wavefunctions for 1/(w90prtunk$^3$) of the grid
18453     points. That is why we divide **n1**, **n2** and **n3** by [[w90prtunk]]. The output .xsf files
18454     for plotting with XCrysDen will also be on the coarse grid. When this does not
18455     produce an acceptable plot, [[w90prtunk]] can be set to 1 to output every grid point.
18456     (You should try spline interpolation in XCrysDen first.)
18457     """,
18458     ),
18459     
18460     Variable(
18461         abivarname="wfmix",
18462         varset="gstate",
18463         vartype="real",
18464         topics=['Hybrids_useful'],
18465         dimensions="scalar",
18466         defaultval=1.0,
18467         mnemonics="WaveFunctions MIXing factor",
18468         requires="[[usefock]] > 0 and [[nnsclohf]] >0 and [[fockoptmix]]/100 > 0",
18469         text="""
18470     When the wavefunctions are determined using a SCF double loop (hybrid
18471     functionals), [[wfmix]] provides the mixing factor to obtain the new input
18472     wavefunctions by the combination of the earlier input wavefunctions and
18473     corresponding (DFT-preconditioned) output wavefunctions at the level of the
18474     outer loop, according to the algorithm specified by [[fockoptmix]]/100. If
18475     [[wfmix]] is 1.0, the output wavefunctions only will determine the new input
18476     wavefunctions. This might possibly lead to instabilities. If [[wfmix]] is
18477     smaller than 1.0, the whole iteration procedure is damped, which might allow
18478     better stability, but might be slower. If it is larger than 1.0, perhaps less
18479     iterations will be needed (if there is no instability).
18480     """,
18481     ),
18482     
18483     Variable(
18484         abivarname="wfoptalg",
18485         varset="dev",
18486         vartype="integer",
18487         topics=['SCFAlgorithms_basic'],
18488         dimensions="scalar",
18489         defaultval="[[AUTO_FROM_PSP]]",
18490         mnemonics="WaveFunction OPTimisation ALGorithm",
18491         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
18492         commentdefault="0 when [[usepaw]] = 0 (norm-conserving pseudopotentials), 10 when [[usepaw]] = 1 (PAW); 114 if [[paral_kgb]] = 1.",
18493         text="""
18494     Allows one to choose the algorithm for the optimisation of the wavefunctions.
18495     The different possibilities are:
18496     
18497       * [[wfoptalg]] = 0: standard state-by-state conjugate gradient algorithm, with no possibility to parallelize over the states;
18498     
18499       * [[wfoptalg]] = 2: minimisation of the residual with respect to different shifts, in order to cover the whole set of occupied bands,
18500       with possibility to parallelize over blocks of states (or bands). The number of states in a block is defined in [[nbdblock]]. THIS IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT.
18501     
18502       * [[wfoptalg]] = 3: minimisation of the residual with respect to a shift. Available only in the non-self-consistent case [[iscf]] = -2,
18503       in order to find eigenvalues and wavefunctions close to a prescribed value.
18504     
18505       * [[wfoptalg]] = 4: (see also [[wfoptalg]] = 14), a parallel code based on the Locally Optimal Block Preconditioned Conjugate Gradient (LOBPCG)
18506       method of [[cite:Knyazev2001 ]].
18507       The implementation rests on the [matlab program by Knyazev](http://www.mathworks.com/matlabcentral/fileexchange/48-lobpcg-m) [[cite:Knyazev2007]].
18508       For more information see [[cite:Bottin2008]]
18509     
18510       * [[wfoptalg]] = 10: (for PAW) standard state-by-state conjugate gradient algorithm, with no possibility to parallelize over the states,
18511       but modified scheme described in [[cite:Kresse1996]] (modified kinetic energy, modified preconditionning, minimal orthogonalization, ...);
18512     
18513       * [[wfoptalg]] = 14: the recommended for parallel code, the same as [[wfoptalg]] = 4 except that the preconditioning of the block vectors does not
18514       depend on the kinetic energy of each band, and the orthogonalization after the LOBPCG algorithm is no longer performed. The first modification increases the convergence and the second one the efficiency.
18515     
18516       * [[wfoptalg]] = 114: A new version of [[wfoptalg]] = 14 which is more efficient for few blocks and can take advantage of OpenMP if abinit is compiled with a multithreaded linear algebra library.
18517       With more than 1 thread [[npfft]] shoud NOT be used for the time being.
18518     
18519       * [[wfoptalg]] = 1: new algorithm based on Chebyshev filtering, designed for very large number of processors, in the regime
18520       where LOBPCG does not scale anymore. It is not able to use preconditionning and therefore might converge slower than other algorithms.
18521       By design, it will **not** converge the last bands: it is recommended to use slightly more bands than necessary.
18522       For usage with [[tolwfr]], it is imperative to use [[nbdbuf]]. For more performance, try [[use_gemm_nonlop]].
18523       For more information, see the [ performance guide ](../../theory/howto_chebfi.pdf) and the [[cite:Levitt2015]]. Status: experimental but usable.
18524       Questions and bug reports should be sent to antoine (dot) levitt (at) gmail.com.
18525     """,
18526     ),
18527     
18528     Variable(
18529         abivarname="wtatcon",
18530         varset="rlx",
18531         vartype="real",
18532         topics=['GeoConstraints_useful'],
18533         dimensions=[3, '[[natcon]]', '[[nconeq]]'],
18534         defaultval=0,
18535         mnemonics="WeighTs for AToms in CONstraint equations",
18536         characteristics=['[[NO_MULTI]]'],
18537         text=r"""
18538     Gives the weights determining how the motion of atoms is constrained during
18539     structural optimization or molecular dynamics (see [[nconeq]], [[natcon]],
18540     and [[iatcon]]). For each of the [[nconeq]] independent constraint equations,
18541     wtatcon is a 3*[[natcon]] array giving weights, W  I, for the x, y, and z
18542     components of each of the atoms (labeled by I) in the list of indices
18543     [[iatcon]]. Prior to taking an atomic step, the calculated forces, F  I, are
18544     replaced by projected forces, F'  I, which satisfy the set of constraint equations
18545     
18546     Sum  mu=x,y,z; I=1,natcon: W  mu,I  * F'  mu,I  = 0 for each of the [[nconeq]] arrays W  I.
18547     
18548     Different types of motion constraints can be implemented this way. For example,
18549     
18550         nconeq 1 natcon 2 iatcon 1 2 wtatcon 0 0 +1 0 0 -1
18551     
18552     could be used to constrain the relative height difference of two adsorbate
18553     atoms on a surface (assuming their masses are equal), since F'  z,1  - F'
18554     z,2  = 0 implies z  1  - z  2  = constant.
18555     """,
18556     ),
18557     
18558     Variable(
18559         abivarname="wtk",
18560         varset="basic",
18561         vartype="real",
18562         topics=['k-points_useful'],
18563         dimensions=['[[nkpt]]'],
18564         defaultval=MultipleValue(number='[[nkpt]]', value=1.0),
18565         mnemonics="WeighTs for K points",
18566         commentdefault="Except when [[kptopt]]/=0",
18567         text="""
18568     Gives the k point weights.
18569     The k point weights will have their sum (re)normalized to 1 (unless
18570     [[occopt]] = 2 and [[kptopt]] = 0; see description of [[occopt]]) within the
18571     program and therefore may be input with any arbitrary normalization. This
18572     feature helps avoid the need for many digits in representing fractional weights such as 1/3.
18573     [[wtk]] is ignored if [[iscf]] is not positive, except if [[iscf]] = -3.
18574     """,
18575     ),
18576     
18577     Variable(
18578         abivarname="wtq",
18579         varset="gstate",
18580         vartype="real",
18581         topics=['q-points_useful'],
18582         dimensions="scalar",
18583         defaultval=1,
18584         mnemonics="WeighTs for the current Q-points",
18585         commentdefault="Except when [[qptopt]]/=0",
18586         text="""
18587     Gives the current q-point weight.
18588     """,
18589     ),

18592         abivarname="wvl_bigdft_comp",
18593         varset="gstate",
18594         vartype="integer",
18595         topics=['Wavelets_expert'],
18596         dimensions="scalar",
18597         defaultval=0,
18598         mnemonics="WaVeLet BIGDFT Comparison",
18599         text="""
18600     This variable is used for the wavelets capabilities of ABINIT (see [[usewvl]]).
18601     It is used to compare the results obtained with ABINIT with those obtained
18602     with BigDFT stand-alone. When it is set to 1, ABINIT will follow the workflow
18603     as in BigDFT stand-alone. Therefore, the results must be exactly the same with the two codes.
18604     """,
18605     ),
18606     
18607     Variable(
18608         abivarname="wvl_crmult",
18609         varset="gstate",
18610         vartype="real",
18611         topics=['Wavelets_basic'],
18612         dimensions="scalar",
18613         defaultval=6.0,
18614         mnemonics="WaVeLet Coarse grid Radius MULTiplier",
18615         text="""
18616     This factor is used to define the expansion of the coarse resolution grid in
18617     the case of wavelets (see [[usewvl]]). The grid is made of points inside
18618     spheres centered on atoms. The radius of these spheres are the product between
18619     this factor and the covalent radius of element (read from the pseudo-potential file).
18620     This factor is responsible for the amount of used memory (see also [[wvl_hgrid]]).
18621     """,
18622     ),
18623     
18624     Variable(
18625         abivarname="wvl_frmult",
18626         varset="gstate",
18627         vartype="real",
18628         topics=['Wavelets_basic'],
18629         dimensions="scalar",
18630         defaultval=10.0,
18631         mnemonics="WaVeLet Fine grid Radius MULTiplier",
18632         text="""
18633     This factor is used to define the expansion of the fine resolution grid in
18634     the case of wavelets (see [[usewvl]]). This fine resolution grid has the same
18635     grid step than the coarse one (see [[wvl_crmult]] ), but on each point, 8
18636     coefficients are stored instead of one, increasing the precision of the
18637     calculation in this area. The grid is made of points inside spheres centered
18638     on atoms. The radius of these spheres are the product between this factor and
18639     a value read from the pseudo-potential file.
18640     This factor is responsible for the amount of used memory (see also [[wvl_hgrid]]).
18641     """,
18642     ),
18643     
18644     Variable(
18645         abivarname="wvl_hgrid",

18650         defaultval=0.5,

18655     basis set. This value is highly responsible for the memory occupation in the
18656     wavelet computation. The value is a length in atomic units.
18657     """,

18666         defaultval=[1, 100],

18670     complex Gaussians. The fit is done for [[wvl_ngauss]](1), [[wvl_ngauss]](1)+1... up
18671     to [[wvl_ngauss]](2) Gaussians.
18672     """,
18673     ),

18675     Variable(
18676         abivarname="wvl_nprccg",
18677         varset="gstate",
18678         vartype="integer",
18679         topics=['Wavelets_expert'],
18680         dimensions="scalar",
18681         defaultval=5,
18682         mnemonics="WaVeLet maximum Number of PReConditionner Conjugate Gradient iterations",
18683         text="""
18684     In the wavelet computation case, the wavefunctions are directly minimised
18685     using a real-space preconditionner. This preconditionner has internally some
18686     conjugate gradient iterations. This value defines a boundary for the number of
18687     conjugate gradient iterations on each wavefunction convergence step.
18688     """,

18691     Variable(
18692         abivarname="xangst",
18693         varset="basic",
18694         vartype="real",
18695         topics=['crystal_compulsory'],
18696         dimensions=[3, 'min([[natom]],[[natrd]])'],
18697         mnemonics="vectors (X) of atom positions in cartesian coordinates -length in ANGSTrom-",
18698         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
18699         text="""
18700     Gives the cartesian coordinates of atoms within unit cell, in angstrom. This
18701     information is redundant with that supplied by array [[xred]] or [[xcart]].
18702     If [[xred]] and [[xangst]] are ABSENT from the input file and [[xcart]] is
18703     provided, then the values of [[xred]] will be computed from the provided
18704     [[xcart]] (i.e. the user may use xangst instead of [[xred]] or [[xcart]] to
18705     provide starting coordinates).
18706     One and only one of [[xred]], [[xcart]] and [[xangst]] must be provided.
18707     The conversion factor between Bohr and Angstrom is 1 Bohr=0.5291772108
18708     Angstrom, see the [NIST site](http://physics.nist.gov/cuu/Constants/index.html).
18709     Atomic positions evolve if [[ionmov]]/=0. In constrast with [[xred]] and
18710     [[xcart]], [[xangst]] is not internal.
18711     """,
18712     ),
18713     
18714     Variable(
18715         abivarname="xc_denpos",
18716         varset="dev",
18717         vartype="real",
18718         topics=['xc_expert'],
18719         dimensions="scalar",
18720         defaultval=1e-14,
18721         mnemonics="eXchange-Correlation - DENsity POSitivity value",
18722         characteristics=['[[DEVELOP]]'],
18723         text="""
18724     For the evaluation of the exchange-correlation functionals, the density cannot
18725     be negative, or even too small (e.g. the LDA exchange kernel behaves like the
18726     density at power -(2/3), and the density is used at the denominator of
18727     different factors in GGAs and metaGGAs. [[xc_denpos]] is the smallest value
18728     that the density can assume at the time of the evaluation of a XC functional,
18729     in ABINIT. When then computed density drops below [[xc_denpos]] before
18730     attacking the evaluation of the XC functional, then it will be (only for that
18731     purpose) replaced by [[xc_denpos]]. Note that the evaluation of the gradients
18732     or other quantities that are density-dependent is performed before this replacement.
18733     
18734     It has been observed that the SCF cycle of the Tran-Blaha mGGA can be quite
18735     hard to make converge, for systems for which there is some vacuum. In this
18736     case, setting [[xc_denpos]] to 1.0e-7 ... 1.0e-6 has been seen to allow good
18737     convergence. Of course, this will affect the numerical results somehow, and
18738     one should play a bit with this value to avoid incorrect calculations.
18739     """,
18740     ),
18741     
18742     Variable(
18743         abivarname="xc_tb09_c",
18744         varset="dev",
18745         vartype="real",
18746         topics=['xc_expert'],
18747         dimensions="scalar",
18748         defaultval=99.99,
18749         mnemonics="Value of the c parameter in the eXchange-Correlation TB09 functional",
18750         text=r"""
18751     The modified Becke-Johnson exchange-correlation functional by
18752     [[cite:Tran2009 | Tran and Blaha]] reads:
18753     
18754     $$ V_x(r) =
18755     c V_x^{BR}(r) +
18756     (3c - 2) \frac{1}{\pi} \sqrt{\frac{5}{12}}
18757     \sqrt{2 \frac{t(r)}{\rho(r)}} $$
18758     
18759     where $\rho(r)$ is the electron density,
18760     $t(r)$ is the kinetic-energy density, and
18761     $ V_x^{BR}(r)$ is the Becke-Roussel potential.
18762     
18763     In this equation the parameter $c$ can be evaluated at each SCF step according
18764     to the following equation:
18765     
18766     $$ c = \alpha + \beta
18767     \left( \frac{1}{V_{cell}}
18768     \int_{V_{cell}} \frac{|\nabla \rho(r)|}{\rho(r)}
18769     d^3r \right)^{1/2} $$
18770     
18771     The $c$ parameter is evaluated thanks to the previous equation when xc_tb09_c is
18772     equal to the "magic" default value 99.99. The $c$ parameter can also be fixed to
18773     some (property-optimized or material-optimized) value by using this variable.
18774     """,
18775     ),
18776     
18777     Variable(
18778         abivarname="xcart",
18779         varset="basic",
18780         vartype="real",
18781         topics=['crystal_compulsory'],
18782         dimensions=[3, 'min([[natom]],[[natrd]])'],
18783         mnemonics="vectors (X) of atom positions in CARTesian coordinates",
18784         characteristics=['[[EVOLVING]]', '[[LENGTH]]'],
18785         text="""
18786     Gives the cartesian coordinates of atoms within unit cell. This information is
18787     redundant with that supplied by array [[xred]] or [[xangst]]. By default,
18788     [[xcart]] is given in Bohr atomic units (1 Bohr=0.5291772108 Angstroms),
18789     although Angstrom can be specified, if preferred, since [[xcart]] has the
18790     '[[LENGTH]]' characteristics.
18791     If [[xred]] and [[xangst]] are ABSENT from the input file and [[xcart]] is
18792     provided, then the values of [[xred]] will be computed from the provided
18793     [[xcart]] (i.e. the user may use [[xcart]] instead of [[xred]] or [[xangst]]
18794     to provide starting coordinates).
18795     One and only one of [[xred]], [[xcart]] and **xangst** must be provided.
18796     Atomic positions evolve if [[ionmov]]/=0.
18797     """,
18798     ),

18800     Variable(
18801         abivarname="xclevel",
18802         varset="internal",
18803         vartype="integer",

18805         dimensions="scalar",

18811     
18812       * 0  -->  No XC contribution.

18819     Variable(
18820         abivarname="xred",
18821         varset="basic",
18822         vartype="real",
18823         topics=['crystal_compulsory'],
18824         dimensions=[3, 'min([[natom]],[[natrd]])'],
18825         defaultval=MultipleValue(number=None, value=0.0),
18826         mnemonics="vectors (X) of atom positions in REDuced coordinates",
18827         characteristics=['[[EVOLVING]]'],
18828         commentdims="represented internally as xred(3,[[natom]],[[nimage]])",
18829         text=r"""
18830     Gives the atomic locations within unit cell in coordinates relative to real
18831     space primitive translations (NOT in cartesian coordinates). Thus these are
18832     fractional numbers typically between 0 and 1 and are dimensionless. The
18833     cartesian coordinates of atoms (in Bohr) are given by:
18834     R_cartesian = xred1*rprimd1+xred2*rprimd2+xred3*rprimd3
18835     where (xred1,xred2,xred3) are the "reduced coordinates" given in columns of
18836     "[[xred]]", (rprimd1,rprimd2,rprimd3) are the columns of primitive vectors
18837     array "[[rprimd]]" in Bohr.
18838     
18839     If you prefer to work only with cartesian coordinates, you may work entirely
18840     with "[[xcart]]" or "[[xangst]]" and ignore [[xred]], in which case [[xred]]
18841     must be absent from the input file.
18842     One and only one of [[xred]], [[xcart]] and [[xangst]] must be provided.
18843     Atomic positions evolve if [[ionmov]]/=0.
18844     """,
18845     ),

18864         varset="geo",
18865         vartype="string",
18866         topics=['crystal_useful'],
18867         dimensions="scalar",
18868         mnemonics="XYZ FILE input for geometry",
18869         characteristics=['[[INPUT_ONLY]]'],
18870         text="""
18871     Gives the name of a xyz format file, to take [[natom]], [[ntypat]], [[typat]],
18872     [[znucl]], and [[xangst]] from. This input can not be mixed with normal atom
18873     specifications for other datasets.
18874     
18875     Notes: do not quote the file name in the abinit input file, simply leave a
18876     space after xyzfile. The xyz format is the number of atoms on the first line,
18877     a comment line, then one line per atom, with the element as a 2 letter symbol
18878     ("As" "O" or "Pu") and the three cartesian coordinates in Angstrom.
18879     """,

18881     
18882     Variable(
18883         abivarname="zcut",
18884         varset="gw",
18885         vartype="real",
18886         topics=['Susceptibility_expert', 'BSE_expert', 'SelfEnergy_expert'],
18887         dimensions="scalar",
18888         defaultval=0.0036749326,
18889         mnemonics="Z-CUT",
18890         characteristics=['[[ENERGY]]'],
18891         commentdefault="0.0036749326 Ha = 0.1 eV",
18892         requires="[[optdriver]] in [3,4,99]",
18893         text="""
18894     It is meant to avoid some divergences that might occur during the evaluation
18895     of the Adler-Wiser expression of the irreducible polarizability
18896     ([[optdriver]] = 3) or during the numerical treatment of the integrals defining
18897     the contribution to the self-energy matrix elements ([[optdriver]] = 4). If the
18898     denominator becomes smaller than [[zcut]], a small imaginary part (depending
18899     on [[zcut]]) is added, in order to avoid the divergence.
18900     
18901     When [[optdriver]] = 99, [[zcut]] defines the small complex shift used to avoid
18902     divergences in the expression for the macroscopic dielectric function. It
18903     simulates the experimental uncertainty and the finite lifetime of the
18904     quasiparticles (although the true lifetime should be k- and band-dependent).
18905     The value of [[zcut]] affects the number of iteration needed to achieve
18906     convergence in the Haydock iterative method. In this case, [[zcut]] should be
18907     larger than the typical distance between the eigenvalues of the exciton
18908     Hamiltonian.
18909     Ideally, one should make a convergence study decreasing the value of [[zcut]]
18910     for increasing number of k points.
18911     """,
18912     ),
18913     
18914     Variable(
18915         abivarname="zeemanfield",
18916         varset="ffield",
18917         vartype="real",
18918         topics=['MagField_basic'],
18919         dimensions=[3],
18920         defaultval=0,
18921         mnemonics="ZEEMAN FIELD",
18922         characteristics=['[[MAGNETIC_FIELD]]'],
18923         text="""
18924     Give the value of the Zeeman field, $H$, acting on the spinorial wavefunctions.
18925     Note that Tesla are admitted. This sets the magnitude of $\mu_0H$, in Tesla,
18926     with H in Amperes/metre.
18927     """,
18928     ),

18945     Variable(
18946         abivarname="znucl",
18947         varset="basic",
18948         vartype="real",
18949         topics=['AtomTypes_compulsory', 'PseudosPAW_compulsory'],
18950         dimensions=['[[npsp]]'],
18951         mnemonics="charge -Z- of the NUCLeus",
18952         characteristics=['[[NO_MULTI]]'],
18953         text="""
18954     Gives nuclear charge for each type of pseudopotential, in order.
18955     If [[znucl]] does not agree with nuclear charge, as given in pseudopotential
18956     files, the program writes an error message and stops.
18957     
18958     !!! note
18959         In the pseudopotential files, [[znucl]] is called "zatom".
18960     
18961     For a "dummy" atom, with [[znucl]] = 0, as used in the case of calculations
18962     with only a jellium surface, ABINIT sets arbitrarily the covalent radius to one.
18963     """,
18964     ),
18965     #{"abinit_version": "8.7.3"},
18966     Variable(
18967         abivarname="tmesh",
18968         varset="eph",
18969         topics=['ElPhonInt_basic'],
18970         vartype="real",
18971         defaultval=[5.0, 59.0, 6.0],
18972         dimensions=[3],
18973         mnemonics="Temperature MESH",
18974         text="""
18975     This variable defines the linear mesh of temperatures used in the EPH code ([[optdriver]] = 7).
18976     The first entry gives the initial temperature in Kelvin, the second entry the linear step in Kelvin,
18977     the third entry is the number of points in the mesh. The default value corresponds to 6 points between 5 K and 300 K.
18978     """,
18979     ),
18980     
18981     Variable(
18982         abivarname="prtkbff",
18983         varset="files",
18984         topics=['printing_prden'],
18985         vartype="integer",
18986         defaultval=0,
18987         dimensions="scalar",
18988         requires="[[iomode]] == 3",
18989         mnemonics="PRinT Kleynman-Bylander Form Factors",
18990         text="""
18991     This input variable activates the output of the Kleynman-Bylander form factors in the **netcdf** WFK file
18992     produced at the end of the ground-state calculation. Remember to set [[iomode]] to 3.
18993     
18994     The form factors are needed to compute the matrix elements of the commutator [Vnl, r]
18995     of the non-local part of the (NC) pseudopotentials.
18996     This WFK file can therefore be used to perform optical and/or many-body calculations with external codes such as DP/EXC and Yambo.
18997     The option is ignored if PAW.
18998     
18999     !!! important
19000     
19001         At the time of writing (|today|, [[istwfk]] must be set to 1 for all k-points in the IBZ
19002         since external codes do not support wavefunctions given on the reduced G-sphere.
19003         Moreover [[useylm]] must be 0 (default if NC pseudos).
19004     """,
19005     ),
19006     
19007     ]
19008     
19009
